Because the expected number of heads in an infinite sequence of fair flips is infinite, μ(F)=0.  Nonetheless, in Bayesian epistemology we often wish to reason about what to believe if one learns F.  Formally, that means producing a **regular conditional probability** μ(·|F).  Standard measure theory guarantees that such a conditional exists and is unique μ-almost everywhere, though it is not determined on F itself; any candidate is permissible so long as it agrees with μ on sets disjoint from F.  We shall see that one natural and well-motivated choice forces μ(ω₀=1|F)=0.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
2.  Expected heads given finitely many
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Let Xᵢ be the indicator of a head on coin i.  For every N let

F_N := {ω : the total number of heads in ω is at most N}.

The F_N form a decreasing sequence with intersection F, and μ(F_N)>0 (although μ(F_N)→0 as N→∞).  We may therefore compute **ordinary** conditional probabilities on F_N and then take a limit.

Claim.  For each fixed i,

lim_{N→∞} μ(Xᵢ=1 | F_N) = 0.

Proof.  Because the ωᵢ are exchangeable, μ(Xᵢ=1 | F_N) is the same for every i.  Write p_N for this common value.  The expected total number of heads conditioned on F_N is the sum of the marginal expectations, hence

E(Σ_j X_j | F_N) = Σ_j μ(X_j=1 | F_N) = Σ_j p_N.

But F_N entails that the total number of heads is ≤ N, so the conditional expectation is ≤ N as well.  Therefore

Σ_j p_N ≤ N.

If p_N were bounded away from 0—say p_N ≥ ε>0—then the left-hand side would diverge (ε·∞), contradicting the finitude of N.  Hence p_N must itself go to 0 as N→∞.  ∎

One thus arrives at the **canonical** regular conditional

μ(Xᵢ=1 | F) := 0  for every i.

By symmetry, your coin is no better positioned than any of the infinitely many others, and yet the conditional expectation of the total is finite.  The only way to reconcile those facts is to give each individual coin zero chance of being among the finitely many heads.

Another route to the same result appeals to tail-probability counting.  Given F, there is *some* K such that exactly K heads occurred.  Conditional on “exactly K heads,” the probability that coin 0 is heads is K/ℵ₀ = 0, because one chooses K distinguished positions out of countably many without a uniform distribution over ℵ₀.  Integrating over the possible values of K (each with whatever posterior weight you please) leaves the probability 0.

Either calculation breaks the allure of the naïve ½.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
3.  Why independence does not survive
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

A persistent objection is:  “My coin flip was physically independent of the others, and its fairness has not changed.  I learned something only about the joint outcome, not about my coin in particular.  So surely my credence should stay at ½.”

The rebuttal is that **physical independence does not entail epistemic independence once further information couples the variables.**  Even in the finite case the point is incontestable.

Finite analogue.  Suppose two fair coins are tossed independently.  You are told that *at most one* landed heads.  Conditional on that announcement, the sample space has three equiprobable members: HT, TH, and TT.  The first letter is your coin.  The conditional probability your coin is heads is 1/3, not ½.  Learning a global constraint correlates the outcomes.

Scale this up.  With n fair coins, told that at most k (fixed) are heads, the probability any particular coin is heads is k/n.  As n grows while k stays fixed, that probability tends to 0.  Our infinite room is simply the ω-limit of that sequence.

So long as there are *infinitely many* other, symmetry-equivalent coins, news that restricts the total number of heads to something finite almost surely drags your individual chance to 0.  Independence is not absolute; it is relative to the information you possess.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
4.  Conditioning on events of probability 0
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Yet another worry is technical: standard Bayesian conditionalization is undefined when the evidence has prior probability 0.  Why are we allowed to *pick* a conditional at all?

(a)  Regularity.  Bayesians commonly adopt the postulate that every logically possible state of affairs receives nonzero prior probability.  One could then rescue the present case by using a slightly perturbed prior that assigns probability ε > 0 to F (for instance by mixing into μ a distribution concentrated on F with weight ε).  After updating, send ε → 0.  The limit of the resulting posteriors is exactly the regular conditional constructed above.

(b)  Jeffrey’s radical conditionalization.  When new evidence is **logically stronger** than what one previously would have regarded as possible, one replaces the old measure by any coherent revision that makes the evidence certain and otherwise respects symmetry or other rationality constraints.  The conditional derived in §2 is singled out by the following symmetry principle: **permutation invariance.**  No finite permutation of coin labels should affect the revised credences.  That principle uniquely fixes μ(·|F) among all candidate extensions of μ to F, and yields μ(Xᵢ=1|F)=0.

Either way, there is a principled Bayesian pathway to the 0 answer; suspending belief at ½ is not.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
5.  Philosophical morals
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

5.1  Self-location versus contentful evidence  
One might try to insist that what you really learn is *indexical*: “I (this very person) am in a world where only finitely many heads occur.”  Could that be consistent with assigning ½ to *my* coin?  No.  Indexical information can indeed change how one distributes probability over observer-moments even when the non-centered world is fixed, but here the new information narrows the set of possible centered worlds to those in which you hold a coin that—the odds dictate—almost certainly is tails.  There is no residual room for a ½ credence without violating ordinary Bayesian conditioning at the centered level.

5.2  Fairness without uniformity  
The case is an instructive warning against equating *fair* with *uniform*.  Each coin is fair in the sense of *chance* ½; nevertheless, there is no uniform probability distribution over countably many coins that makes exactly K of them heads.  The global constraint creates an unavoidable bias at the local level.  Philosophers sometimes assume that symmetry forces a “principle of indifference’’ assigning 1/ℵ₀ to each coin’s being among the K heads, but there simply is no countably additive measure that realizes such indifference.  “Zero” is the only countably additive option.

5.3  Rationality under impossible evidence  
Learning an event of prior probability 0 is not exotic.  Any perfect continuous observation—exactly *that* real-valued datum at infinite precision—has probability 0 under most physical models.  Rational agents therefore need a policy for updating on the impossible.  The present example shows that such policies must, at a minimum, reckon with how the evidence disrupts prior independences.  A simple “stick to the marginal” rule is untenable.

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Conclusion
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Your coin began life with chance ½ of heads, but your epistemic situation has changed radically.  The announcement that only finitely many heads occurred injects powerful negative correlations among the infinitely many tosses.  When those correlations are taken seriously—via regular conditional probabilities, via finite approximations, or via symmetry principles—you are driven to the verdict

Credence(coin 0 = heads | only finitely many heads) = 0.

The intuitive pull of ½ rests on a mistaken view of independence and on discomfort with measure-zero conditioning.  Once those confusions are cleared, the posterior collapses determinately to 0.  You should place an infinitesimal bet—literally, no stake at all—on your coin having landed heads.

Heads‐Up in the Null Set: Why Learning that “Only Finitely Many Coins Landed Heads” Underdetermines Your Own Odds

1. The Set-Up and the Temptation  
Countably many agents—call them 0,1,2,…—each toss an independent fair coin. You are agent 0 and, like the others, have not yet inspected your outcome. A loudspeaker then announces:

(E)  “Remarkably, only finitely many of the coins came up heads.”

Should you revise the prior ½ that your own coin is heads?  
Two temptations pull in opposite directions.

Temptation A (Independence): My coin was flipped independently of the others, so their joint pattern—even if freakish—should not influence my personal odds. Keep the credence at ½.

Temptation B (Scarcity): Finitely many heads distributed over countably many people means that almost everyone must be tails. By symmetry, the chance that any particular person belongs to the privileged finitely many seems to be 0. Lower the credence to 0.

Both lines can be made crisp and seductive, yet they cannot both be right. I shall argue that neither is determinately right: Bayesian conditionalization supplies *no* unique posterior, because (E) has prior probability 0. Absent further information about **how** the remarkable fact was ascertained, rationality permits a wide range of posteriors—½ and 0 included. The case is a concrete instance of the more general “Borel–Kolmogorov paradox”: conditioning on a measure-zero event is path-dependent, and without specifying the path the problem is underdetermined.

The dialectic unfolds in five stages. (i)  I show that (E) indeed has probability 0 and so falls outside the scope of ordinary Bayes’ rule. (ii)  I exhibit two different regular conditional probabilities, each obtained by a natural approximation procedure, and prove that one yields posterior ½ while the other yields posterior 0. (iii)  I anatomize why the intuitive arguments for A and B track these distinct approximations. (iv)  I answer potential objections—most pressingly, why the symmetry appeal behind B is not decisive. (v)  I draw morals for epistemology: unconditional independence does not survive arbitrary zero-measure updates, and rationality may demand imprecise credences in such cases.

2. Why (E) Has Prior Probability 0  
Let Hₙ be the event “coin n is heads.” Because the coins are i.i.d. with P(Hₙ)=½, the expected number of heads is infinite. By the second Borel–Cantelli lemma,

P(Infinitely many Hₙ)=1, hence P(Only finitely many Hₙ)=0.

Intuitively, after any finite stage one still expects half of the remaining coins to be heads, so the odds that the heads eventually peter out are nil. Standard conditional probability is therefore undefined: P(H₀ | E)=P(H₀ ∧ E)/P(E) divides 0 by 0. To speak sensibly about “the posterior given E” we must choose a *regular* conditional probability—roughly, a way of extending Bayes to null events by specifying an appropriate limiting procedure. But different procedures can disagree, precisely the phenomenon the Borel–Kolmogorov paradox warns of.

3. Two Natural Limiting Procedures, Two Incompatible Posteriors  

Procedure I: Truncation with a Moving Ceiling (favors ½)  
For k=1,2,3,… let E_k be “among the first k people, only finitely many heads occurred.” Each E_k has positive probability. Compute

P(H₀ | E_k)=½,     because H₀ concerns only coin 0 and is independent of what happens to coins 1,…,k once we *condition only on their total count*.

Taking the limit k→∞ yields a regular conditional in which P(H₀ | E)=½. This formalizes Temptation A: keep slicing off bigger finite blocks, look at their head-counts, and independence seems preserved in the limit.

Procedure II: Exact-Count Conditioning (favors 0)  
Fix an integer m≥0 and let F_m be “exactly m heads occurred in total.” Whenever m is finite, F_m still has probability 0, but we can approximate F_m by the positive-probability events F_m^N: “exactly m heads among the first N people *and tails for everyone else*.” For each N≥m,

P(H₀ | F_m^N) = m/N.

Now let N→∞. The ratio m/N drops to 0, and the limit yields P(H₀ | F_m)=0. Next, form E as the union of the F_m over all m. A weighted mixture of the corresponding conditionals again assigns P(H₀ | E)=0. This formalizes Temptation B: finite heads spread over countably infinite people makes any given person’s chance of being a head vanish.

Both procedures satisfy the technical requirements for a regular conditional. Nothing in the Kolmogorov axioms privileges one over the other. The posterior is path-dependent; the prior alone does not decide.

4. Diagnosing the Intuitions

4.1 Why Independence Intuition A Misleads  
Independence guarantees P(H₀ | data about *other* coins)=½ only when the data concern a set of coins probabilistically independent of H₀. Yet the proposition “only finitely many heads in total’’ *is a global constraint that directly involves coin 0.* If coin 0 were heads, one fewer “head slot’’ would remain available to the infinitely many other coins. This subtle entanglement is invisible in finite contexts but looms large here. Procedure I smuggles in independence by conditioning on ever larger but still finite blocks—blocks that, by construction, exclude information about the tails beyond them. The limit inherits that bias.

4.2 Why Symmetry Intuition B Overreaches  
The symmetry argument observes that, if there are exactly m heads, every *finite* subset of size m is equiprobable. Since there are countably many people, the “probability’’ that yours is in such a subset seems m/ℵ₀=0. But the very idea of a uniform distribution over countably infinite sets is mathematically incoherent. When we rigorously implement the symmetry thought via Procedure II, we must decide *how* to approximate the uniform choice of m people, and that choice again embeds a path dependency. The limit carried out above yields 0, but one could construct a different sequence of approximations—say, always forcing person 0 into the sample whenever possible—that gives posterior 1. Symmetry by itself does not fix a unique regular conditional.

5. Answering Four Objections

Objection 1 (Pragmatist): Surely whichever procedure underwrites our *actual* evidence-acquisition is the right one; in real life we cannot ascertain E by magic.  
Reply: Agreed. The thought experiment abstracts from the discovery method precisely to reveal that, until the method is specified, the posterior is undetermined. If you imagine a device that scans coins in increasing numerical order until it detects the first m heads and then halts, you are implicitly enacting Procedure II. If instead a supervisor counts heads inside successively larger arenas without ever peeking at coin 0, you are enacting Procedure I. Rational choice of posterior depends on which scenario you deem the source of E.

Objection 2 (Dutch-Booker): Indeterminacy invites vulnerability to sure-loss bets.  
Reply: Dutch-book coherence forbids *incoherent* sets of prices; it does not forbid *interval-valued* credences that respect the probability calculus point-wise. Set-based credences can be coherent in the sense of Walley or Joyce. In the present case any singleton in [0,1] can be embedded consistently in such a set; hence no sure loss follows from the indeterminacy per se.

Objection 3 (Countability Skeptic): The paradox is an artifact of the infinite idealization; in any physically realistic scenario only finitely many coins exist.  
Reply: True but irrelevant. Thought experiments routinely exploit idealizations (eternal cosmology, continuous spacetime, perfect rational agents) to probe the extensional adequacy of our epistemic principles. If conditionalization cannot navigate a mathematically clear limit case, that shows a limitation of the principle even when the world is merely *close* to the limit.

Objection 4 (Meta-Bayesian): One could impose a higher-order prior over regular conditionals and then take an expectation, restoring uniqueness.  
Reply: You certainly *could,* at the cost of introducing an additional empirical hypothesis—how Nature happens to select a conditional. My point is precisely that nothing in the *original* evidential situation forces any such higher-order specification. Rational, minimally committal agents need not go beyond it.

6. Moral: When the Evidence Lies in a Null Set, the Prior Cannot Speak

The moral generalizes. Let Ω be a probability space and E a null event (P(E)=0). The posterior P(· | E) is defined only up to a family of σ-additive extensions parameterized by the choice of conditional density. Unless one supplements the prior with extra structure—either a protocol for generating E, or a hierarchy of hyperpriors—rationality requires no unique update. The puzzle illustrates three deeper lessons.

Lesson 1: Independence Is Fragile. A global constraint can correlate events that were independent unconditionally. Routine appeals to independence must be re‐examined in the presence of measure-zero updates.

Lesson 2: Symmetry Does Not Determine Uniformity on the Countable. When dealing with infinitely many possibilities, the Principle of Indifference may lack a coherent implementation, and different regularizations of “equal likelihood’’ diverge.

Lesson 3: Imprecise Credence Is Sometimes Rationally Mandatory. The proper reaction to underdetermination is not arbitrary point selection but the admission of irreducible credal intervals. In the present case it is epistemically permissible (and practically safe) to retain ½, to drop to 0, or to adopt any intermediate value, provided one remains open to revision upon learning *how* (E) was established.

7. Summary Answer to the Guiding Question  
Because the information that “only finitely many coins landed heads’’ has prior probability 0, standard Bayesian conditionalization is inapplicable. Distinct, equally legitimate regular conditional probabilities yield incompatible posteriors—most saliently, ½ and 0. Without further description of the mechanism by which you came to know (E), rationality does not single out a unique credence for your own coin. Any value in [0,1] can be defended; a cautious agent should admit indeterminacy and perhaps refrain from decisive wagers until the evidential pathway is clarified.

Only finitely many heads!  Although the sentence sounds innocuous, it radically up-ends the probabilistic landscape.  Under an ordinary product measure for countably many fair and independent coin-flips, the event

 F = “the total number of heads is finite”

has probability 0.  If you are told with certainty that F has in fact occurred, you are being given information that the original model regarded as practically impossible.  How should a Bayesian rational agent update on such information?  I shall argue that your rational credence that your own coin is heads should fall to 0, not stay at ½.  The argument has five steps:

1.  Make learning-from-probability-zero events coherent by approximation.  
2.  Exploit exchangeability: in a world with only finitely many heads, any *particular* coin is “almost certainly” tails.  
3.  Show formally—using finite truncations—that the conditional probability tends to 0.  
4.  Vindicate the result through the theory of regular conditional probabilities for tail events.  
5.  Answer the most pressing objections: the “but I’m a fixed person, not a random index” worry, the paradox of conditioning on measure-zero events, and the claim that ½ must remain by Lewis’s Principal Principle or the Reflection Principle.

The discussion is self-contained, but I shall note along the way how the case illuminates broader issues about learning from “impossible” evidence, the meaning of self-locating credences, and the role of symmetry in infinite contexts.

--------------------------------------------------
1.  Learning from probability-zero evidence
--------------------------------------------------

Kolmogorov’s axioms do not prohibit conditioning on a probability-zero event, but they do leave the value of such a conditional completely *undetermined*.  To make it determinate one must supply a *rule*.  The standard strategy is *approximation*: represent the zero-probability event as the limit of a nested sequence of positive-probability events and take the limiting conditional probabilities.  This procedure is justified both measure-theoretically (as a form of regular conditional probability) and decision-theoretically (because your preferences over lotteries that approximate F from within already determine how you should behave were you to learn F exactly).

For F, the obvious approximants are

 Fₖ = “at most k heads occurred”, k = 0,1,2,…

Each Fₖ has positive probability (indeed > 0 though rapidly vanishing).  If P is the original product measure, define

 Pₖ(H₁) = P(H₁ ∧ Fₖ)/P(Fₖ)

and then set

 P(H₁ | F) = limₖ→∞ Pₖ(H₁).

If the limit exists and is scheme-independent, we have a principled answer.

--------------------------------------------------
2.  The symmetry intuition
--------------------------------------------------

Before calculating, an informal symmetry consideration already points toward 0.

•  Exchangeability: Because the coins are independent and identically distributed, the joint measure is invariant under any finite permutation of indices.  Whatever conditional probability we produce must respect that symmetry.

•  Finite exceptionality:  Conditional on F, the *set* of heads is finite.  A finite subset of ℕ has natural density 0; informally, “almost every” index is tails.  If one insists that each concrete coin retains probability ½ of being heads, the expected total number of heads becomes infinite again—contradicting F.

Symmetry plus finite exceptionality forces the probability for any *fixed* coin to collapse to 0.  What breaks the tie between the finitely many “exceptional” coins and the infinitely many “ordinary” coins is simply cardinality.  Because there is no uniform probability distribution over ℕ, the conditional measure must put weight 0 on each individual index but still allocate total probability 1 to the *existence* of some heads.

The lesson: the fact that *someone* is special does not make *me* likely to be that someone.

--------------------------------------------------
3.  The finite truncation calculation
--------------------------------------------------

We now justify the intuition with the approximation scheme.

Let H₁ be the event “my coin is heads.”  Denote by N the total number of heads and by N\₋₁ the number of heads among the **other** coins.  Then N = 1 + N\₋₁ on H₁ and N = N\₋₁ otherwise.  Because the coins are independent, the distribution of N\₋₁ does not depend on H₁.

For each k ≥ 0:

P(H₁ ∧ Fₖ) = P(H₁) · P(N\₋₁ ≤ k – 1) = ½ · P(N ≤ k – 1).

Likewise,

P(Fₖ) = ½ · P(N ≤ k – 1) + ½ · P(N ≤ k).

Therefore

Pₖ(H₁) = [½ · P(N ≤ k – 1)] / [½ · P(N ≤ k – 1) + ½ · P(N ≤ k)]  
     = P(N ≤ k – 1) / [P(N ≤ k – 1) + P(N ≤ k)].

But P(N ≤ k) > 0 while P(N ≤ k – 1) / P(N ≤ k) → 0 as k grows (informally: getting *one fewer* head than “at most k” is exponentially more unlikely as k rises).  A more pedestrian argument replaces the infinite set of coins by the first n coins and lets n → ∞.  In that variant one easily shows

P(H₁ | Fₖ ∧ “only the first n coins were flipped”) ≤ k/n,

so the conditional probability shrinks like 1/n and tends to 0 as n → ∞ for each fixed k, and then a fortiori as k → ∞.  Either route yields

 limₖ→∞ Pₖ(H₁) = 0.

Hence, on the approximation doctrine, rational credence falls to 0.

--------------------------------------------------
4.  Regular conditional probabilities for tail events
--------------------------------------------------

The preceding limit agrees with a more abstract construction.  The event F belongs to the *tail σ-algebra*—the collection of events whose truth is unaffected by altering any finite initial segment of the sequence.  Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law tells us such events have probability 0 or 1, and indeed P(F)=0.

Jeffrey (1965) and later Kemeny & Oppenheim (1956) showed that for countably additive measures on product spaces, one can define a *regular conditional probability* P(· | τ) that is invariant under permutations and well-behaved with respect to tail events.  The unique such conditional that respects permutation symmetry assigns, for any fixed index i,

 P(Hᵢ | F) = 0.

So the finite approximation rule and the general measure-theoretic rule converge on the same verdict.  (Technical detail: although the conditional is defined only up to F-null sets, exchangeability lets us pin down its value on each coordinate cylinder.)  Thus the “0 answer” is not a quirk of a chosen scheme but the unique shift-invariant regular conditional.

--------------------------------------------------
5.  Addressing three major objections
--------------------------------------------------

5.1  “Conditioning on a probability-zero event is illegitimate; therefore credence must remain ½.”

Rebuttal:  Bayesianism *permits* learning from events to which one previously assigned probability 0.  Rational credence change is determined not merely by prior probabilities but also by what the *agent takes for granted* after the update.  Suppose a perfectly logical demon tells you a Diophantine sentence that you had believed had chance 0.  You would—on pain of inconsistency—adopt credence 1 in that sentence, notwithstanding its prior improbability.  The same holds here.  What matters is that you are now *certain* of F.  Given certainty, coherence constrains your joint credences; it does not care that F previously had probability 0.

5.2  “I am a definite person, not a random index among countably many; symmetry considerations are irrelevant.”

This protest conflates *indexical* uncertainty with ordinary aleatory uncertainty.  You are indeed a concrete physical individual occupying, let us say, seat #17.  But the coins and seating assignments are labeled only for the analyst, not for nature’s laws.  As long as you had no prior information correlating seat numbers with outcomes, your prior is exchangeable.  When you employ the approximation rule, the limit uses only facts about relative frequencies, not any assumption that “I might have been someone else.”  The de se / de re distinction therefore does no work here.

A helpful analogy: imagine you pick one real number uniformly at random from (0,1) (a fiction, but instructive).  The probability that the number is rational is 0.  Learning that the number is rational rationally leads you to assign probability 0 that it equals, say, 17/23.  Your specific choice (“my number”) is fixed, yet rationality demands probability 0 for any *particular* rational.  Our coin problem is the discrete analogue.

5.3  “The Principal Principle or the Reflection Principle tells me my credence should stay ½.”

The Principal Principle links credences to *objective chances* when you have no inadmissible information.  But learning F is paradigmatically inadmissible: it contains information about the outcomes themselves.  Likewise, Reflection governs how you should expect your *future* credences to evolve in the absence of new evidence.  Here, however, you have received evidence—albeit of probability-zero—so Reflection is silent.  A better motto is van Fraassen’s *Principle of Total Evidence*: conditionalize on everything you know, and do not withhold part of it simply because it was once deemed “impossible.”

--------------------------------------------------
6.  Philosophical morals
--------------------------------------------------

1.  Countable additivity and symmetry jointly force surprising conditional probabilities.  The situation is akin to Bertrand’s paradox: without a symmetry-respecting regularizer, conditional probabilities on measure-zero events are ill-defined, but once one imposes invariance, answers can become unique and counter-intuitive.

2.  Self-locating beliefs do not trump population statistics in infinite contexts.  You need not think of yourself as a “randomly selected” observer to have the probability calculus treat you as *statistically negligible* among an infinite crowd.

3.  The case underscores the *non-robustness of ½*: a rational agent can rationally swing from ½ to 0 or 1 on the basis of information that does not speak directly to her own coin—merely to the global pattern.  This illustrates why some epistemologists (e.g., Williamson) insist that objective chance alone cannot fix rational credence; evidential context matters irreducibly.

--------------------------------------------------
7.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------

When a probability-zero event becomes certain, Bayesian rationality does not grind to a halt; it asks us to step back, approximate, and take limits that respect the symmetries of the problem.  Doing so here yields an uncompromising result:

Given that only finitely many out of countably infinitely many fair and independent coins came up heads, the rational conditional credence that *my* coin is heads is 0.

Any residual intuition for ½ is a relic of forgetting to incorporate the radical import of F.  Once F is integrated, the overwhelming likelihood is that you are among the infinitely many whose coins landed tails.  Heads are *rare* in that world—so rare that the probability attached to any particular index vanishes.

That verdict is philosophically instructive.  It shows how learning the “global shape” of an infinite sequence can drain local events of their prior probability, and it exhibits the subtle dance between probability theory, symmetry, and the metaphysics of persons in infinite domains.  Far from being a pathology, the 0 answer is the natural, uniquely defensible extension of Bayesian reasoning into the transfinite.

Heads Once in a Blue Moon: Conditional Belief on a Probability-Zero Event  

1. The question and the puzzle  

You and countably many companions each toss a fair coin. Before anyone looks, you are told that “only finitely many coins landed heads.” Intuitively the information feels global, almost irrelevant to your own coin: why should learning something about the infinite tail of other tosses affect the fifty–fifty balance of yours? Yet a moment’s reflection suggests the opposite: if only finitely many heads occurred altogether, then once those few heads have been “used up,” every remaining coin must in fact be tails. Does that force your rational credence in ‘my coin landed heads’ to drop from ½ to 0? Or does independence license you to stand pat at ½?  

I shall argue for the radical answer: a rational agent who updates by conditionalisation and respects the obvious symmetries should assign credence 0 to her own coin’s landing heads once she learns that only finitely many heads were tossed. The reasoning reveals something philosophically important about conditionalisation on probability-zero events, about the dependence of marginal probabilities on global constraints in infinite settings, and about the way symmetry considerations can rescue uniqueness where bare mathematics allows multiple “regular conditional probabilities.” I close by rebutting the main objections and sketching how the lesson generalises.  

2. Why the event has probability zero and why that matters  

For independent fair coins, the Strong Law of Large Numbers tells us that the proportion of heads converges almost surely to ½. Equivalent formulations say that with probability 1 the sequence contains infinitely many heads. Hence the event  

F = {only finitely many heads}  

has prior probability 0. Standard Bayesian conditionalisation, Pnew(A)=P(A∧E)/P(E), therefore treats conditioning on F as undefined. In practice Bayesians extend their prior to a “regular conditional probability” that assigns coherent posteriors to measure-zero events by taking suitable limits. Unfortunately, for measure-zero events the extension is not unique; different limiting schemes can yield different posteriors, an ambiguity familiar from the Borel–Kolmogorov paradox. The philosophical question is therefore not merely “what is the number?” but “what principled constraints select one posterior rather than another?”  

Two constraints seem unavoidable here. (i) Symmetry: the problem is permutation-invariant—all coins are set up alike, and the event F mentions no particular index. Any acceptable conditional probability ought to preserve that symmetry. (ii) Regularity: the posterior should be obtainable as the limit of conditioning on events of positive probability that approximate F in an intuitively natural way. I show that under those two constraints the conditional probability of heads for any particular coin must be 0.  

3. An informal but revealing finite approximation  

Imagine first a finite version. A million coins are tossed. You are told that at most ten heads were obtained. By exchangeability, every coin has the same chance of being one of those ten successful heads. Since at most ten coins out of a million can be heads, the posterior probability that a randomly chosen coin (your coin) is heads is at most 10/1 000 000 = 0.00001—a dramatic fall from ½. As we increase the number of coins while keeping the “head budget” fixed, the posterior shrinks proportionally. This finite reasoning strongly hints at the limiting value 0 when the number of coins becomes countably infinite while the allowed number of heads remains finite.  

Of course the actual information we receive is not “at most ten” but “some finite number”—we are not even told which finite number. Yet that uncertainty about k cannot raise the posterior. For each fixed k, at most k heads can occur, so in the finite-million model the posterior is bounded above by k/1 000 000. Weighting over all k therefore keeps the overall upper bound tiny. Letting the number of coins go to ℵ₀ drives the bound to 0.  

4. A formal limit-of-limits argument  

We can now make the heuristic precise. Let  

Sk,n = {exactly k heads among the first n coins, and tails thereafter}.  

For any fixed k the events Sk,n are nested (Sk,n ⊃ Sk,n+1), their intersection as n→∞ is the event that there are at most k heads in total, and the union over k of those intersections is precisely F. Moreover P(Sk,n) > 0 for all finite k,n, so ordinary conditionalisation applies to them.  

Because the coins are exchangeable,  

P(X0 = 1 | Sk,n) = k/n.                      (1)  

(Exactly k of the first n coins are heads, chosen uniformly at random, so the chance the 0th coin is among them is k/n.)  

Now fix k and let n→∞. Equation (1) gives  

limn→∞ P(X0 = 1 | Sk,n) = 0.               (2)  

Next form the limit over k by conditioning on “at most k heads” and then letting k→∞; (2) survives because every term in the mixture is dominated by its k/n factor. Finally let k range over ℕ to arrive at conditioning on F itself. The double-limit thus delivers P(X0 = 1 | F) = 0.  

Note the crucial role of symmetry: we used the fact that the 0th coin is exchangeable with the others to assert (1). Without symmetry we could monkey with the approximating sequence to force any value we liked; with symmetry the limit is pinned down.  

5. The expectation argument  

A second route, shorter but equally decisive, uses only linearity of expectation and symmetry. Suppose, contrary to what we have just derived, that after learning F your credence that your own coin is heads is some p>0. By symmetry the same p must be assigned to each coin. The expected number of heads given F is therefore  

E(#heads | F) = Σi P(Xi = 1 | F) = Σi p = ∞,      (3)  

because there are countably many coins. But F entails that #heads is finite; hence its expectation must be finite. Equation (3) contradicts that. The only escape is p = 0. That airtight little calculation shows that *any* permutation-invariant regular conditional probability must assign 0 to each individual head.  

6. Objection: “independence”  

A common reaction is: “But the coins are independent! Learning facts about the others can’t affect the probability of mine.” That would be true in a finite setup if we learned an *independent* fact, for instance which side of *another* coin came up. But F is not independent of your coin; it is a global constraint that rigidly ties together all outcomes. Indeed, after conditioning on F the variables cease to be independent—knowing that many earlier coins are tails raises the chance that some later coin will consume one of the finitely many allowed heads. Independence is a property of the prior; conditioning can and often does destroy it.  

7. Objection: “conditionalisation on measure-zero events is arbitrary”  

It is certainly correct that Kolmogorov’s axioms alone do not determine a unique posterior here. One can concoct a regular conditional probability that assigns, say, P(Xi = 1 | F) = 2^−i, so that the expected number of heads is still 1. That violates symmetry, allocating higher chances to earlier-indexed coins. Are we entitled to rule such posteriors out?  

Yes, on pain of irrational index-sensitive betting behaviour. The indices are artefacts of description; they carry no physical or epistemic content. If the agent would, on learning F, buy a $1 ticket that pays $100 if coin #0 is heads for a penny but demand a dollar for the same ticket on coin #1, she would be licensing a sure-loss Dutch book by a simple renaming of the agents. Epistemic rationality therefore requires that credences be invariant under the symmetries one knows the world to have. Once that requirement is imposed, the previous sections show that the 0-posterior is forced.  

8. Objection: “credence 0 is too extreme”  

Assigning probability 0 to an epistemically possible event may seem dogmatic. But probability 0 after conditionalisation is perfectly coherent when the conditioning information is powerful enough. In a finite world learning “all tosses came up tails” would force the credence in a particular toss’s being heads to 0, though the event is still metaphysically possible. The infinite version is just a more abstract instance. Nor does the infamous “zero-makes-revision-impossible” worry bite here: the only way to become certain that your coin in fact landed heads is to *look* at it; that requires updating on further evidence outside the current probabilistic model, and Jeffrey-style updating or other non-standard tools can handle that revision. So dogmatism is a mirage.  

9. Objection: “but the prior probability of receiving this information was itself 0”  

Correct: you assigned probability 0 to ever learning F. Does conditionalising on an event you deemed impossible violate the Reflection Principle or Dutch-book coherence? It does not. Reflection says that when you are certain you will later have credence q in proposition A, you should already have credence q in A. Here you were certain you would *not* later learn F, so the antecedent of the principle fails. As van Fraassen noted, conditioning on previously-impossible events is coherent provided the post-update probability measure itself is coherent; our derivation ensures it is. In counterfactual terms: if you had known that you were going to hear “only finitely many heads,” rationality would already have had you at 0. That is precisely what we have established.  

10. Philosophical significance  

The case dramatizes three morals.  

First, the Infinite amplifies the Global. In a finite ensemble, learning a sharp global constraint (e.g. “no more than ten heads”) has tractable, intuitive impacts on local probabilities. In the limit the impact can be qualitative—forcing a marginal to collapse to 0—even though no *finite* evidence could ever do so.  

Second, symmetry can rescue uniqueness for conditionalisation on measure-zero events. Without a principled symmetry demand the posterior is indeed under-determined; with it, the posterior can be unique even when the event conditioned on is probability-zero. That fact undermines the fatalistic reading of the Borel–Kolmogorov paradox and supports a more nuanced stance: zero-probability conditioning is perilous but navigable when we bring additional structural knowledge to bear.  

Third, the example shows that “objective” independence is fragile under epistemic conditioning. Agents who insist that independence facts survive learning must move to causal or graphical representations, where conditioning on non-descendant variables preserves independence, or else accept that purely probabilistic independence is an artefact of the prior not a metaphysical floor.  

11. Extensions and variants  

(a) Uncountably many coins. If the set of coins had the cardinality of the continuum, the symmetry argument breaks: there is no countably additive uniform measure on that set, so marginal probabilities are forced to 0 even *before* any information. More carefully, the only permutation-invariant σ-finite measure on an uncountable index set is the zero measure. The intuition that independence gives you ½ already fails. The countable case is therefore the delicate, revealing one.  

(b) Allowing “at most finitely many tails” instead. By parity the result flips: your posterior for heads skyrockets to 1. Symmetry again forces every coin to be tail with probability 0.  

(c) Higher-level uncertainty about the bias. If each coin’s bias is itself drawn from a Beta distribution, then before conditioning you have an exchangeable mixture (de Finetti). The posterior after learning F still forces individual probabilities to 0 by the same expectation argument; the only difference is that the posterior over the underlying parameter concentrates on 0.  

12. Conclusion  

Your initial ½ credence embodied only the local physics of one fair coin. Learning that the entire infinite sequence contains merely finitely many heads injects a sweeping global constraint that, when filtered through symmetry and the mathematics of infinite sums, obliterates the chance that this particular coin is one of the privileged few. The correct Bayesian posterior is therefore 0, not ½. Far from being an embarrassment, the result deepens our appreciation of how probability-zero information, infinite populations, and structural symmetries interact. Philosophy of probability often treats the Infinite as a technical afterthought; this case shows instead that infinity changes everything, sometimes pulling credence from ½ to 0 in a single, “remarkable” announcement.

Heads or Tails After an Impossible Announcement?  
A 2 000-Word Inquiry into Zero-Probability Updates, Symmetry, and Countable Additivity
─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. The Set-Up and the Puzzling Report  
We inhabit a room with countably many agents ⟨A₀, A₁, A₂, …⟩. Each flips an independently fair coin. Before anyone inspects the outcome we are told:

  (R)  Only finitely many of the coins have landed Heads.

Because a fair coin lands Heads with probability ½, classical probability theory assigns P(R)=0: with probability 1 the sequence contains infinitely many Heads. That is why the announcement feels “miraculous.” The question is what credence A₀ (you) should now assign to

  (H₀)  “My own coin landed Heads.”

Should it remain ½, or shift—perhaps to 0, something near 0, or perhaps become undefined?  

The case forces a clash among three individually appealing principles:

P1  Bayesian Conditionalisation: After learning E you should adopt P(·|E).  
P2  Countable Additivity: Probabilities of countable disjoint unions sum normally.  
P3  Symmetry/Indifference: Each individual flip is fair; in the absence of coin-specific information credence in Heads for any particular coin is ½.

Because P(R)=0, straightforward conditionalisation (P1) is silent; the ratio P(H₀∧R)/P(R) is 0/0. The puzzle is therefore not a routine Bayes problem but one about *how we ought to extend Bayesian updating to zero-measure information while respecting—or deciding which to abandon among—P1–P3.*

I shall argue that the rational credence remains ½. Doing so is not trivial: one must (i) explain why seemingly powerful arguments for collapsing the probability to 0 fail, (ii) show how a principled extension of conditionalisation is possible, and (iii) make explicit which background axioms are being kept. Along the way we will see that the case illustrates a deep fault-line in probability theory: no update rule can simultaneously satisfy P1–P3 *and* retain the classical requirement of countable additivity. Choosing ½ amounts to keeping symmetry and a suitable extension of conditionalisation while relaxing countable additivity on the updated belief state. I close by outlining why that trade-off is, all things considered, the best way to honour the information actually received.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. Two Tempting—but Misleading—Lines of Reasoning  

2.1  “Expectation Says the Probability Must Be Zero.”  
Suppose, on the updated belief state, every coin individually has probability p of coming up Heads. Because the expected number of Heads equals Σₙ p and that sum must be finite (it is even supposed to be *almost surely* finite), the only way to avoid an infinite expectation is p=0. Hence, the argument continues, your credence in H₀ should plummet from ½ to 0.

What is wrong? The argument tacitly presumes countable additivity: it identifies the expectation with the countable sum of individual probabilities. Yet finite additivity suffices for subjective probability; de Finetti was happy to deny countable additivity exactly because reasoning of this kind produces contradictions in infinite lotteries. If we allow merely finite additivity, the inference from “Σₙ p must be finite” to “p=0” is blocked; an infinite sum of identical positive numbers can fail to be defined at all. In short, the argument leverages an axiom (countable additivity) that turns out to be inconsistent with simultaneous respect for P1 and P3 in this scenario. It begs the very question at issue.

2.2  “Approximate by Positive-Probability Events.”  
Another common gambit defines R^{(m)} = “at most m Heads occur in the *first* m coins” (P(R^{(m)})>0). One then computes

P(H₀ | R^{(m)})  
 = P(H₀ ∧ R^{(m)}) / P(R^{(m)})  
 = (½)·P(at most m−1 additional Heads among first m−1 coins) / P(R^{(m)}).

Elementary calculation shows that as m→∞ this ratio tends to 0; so, the advocate says, the limiting conditional probability is 0.

The problem is subtle but fatal. Different approximating sequences of positive-probability events can produce *different* limits—a version of the Borel paradox. If, instead of conditioning first on the initial segment, one conditions on “only finitely many Heads among coins *with prime indices*,” the limit is ½. Because no canonical approximation exists, a limit-of-ratios procedure fails to pick a uniquely determined posterior. Constructing an approximation is tantamount to smuggling in a *choice of conditional probability* rather than discovering one.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. Independence, Tail Events, and Why They Don’t Settle the Issue  

One might hope to deploy the Kolmogorov 0-1 law: “tail events” are independent of any finite initial segment, and R is a tail event, so H₀ ought to remain independent of R, yielding probability ½. The hitch is that the 0-1 law tells us only that P(R)=0 or 1 (in fact 0). It does *not* provide a well-defined conditional probability when the tail event has measure 0. So again we confront the need for an extension of conditionalisation.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. Extending Conditional Probability Beyond Measure-Zero  

There are three broad strategies on offer:

S-A  Abandon Conditionalisation. Instead employ “ratification” principles (van Fraassen) or a causal learning rule (Skyrms).  
S-B  Keep Conditionalisation and Countable Additivity, but accept that no unique posterior exists; credence becomes interval-valued or otherwise indeterminate.  
S-C  Keep Conditionalisation (understood via *regular* or *Popper* conditional probabilities) and Symmetry, but relax countable additivity after the update.

Strategy S-C is the road I recommend. Let me spell it out.

4.1  Popper Functions and Regular Conditionals  
Popper functions supply conditional probabilities P(·|·) as primitive, defined for all pairs (A, B) with P(B)≥0 even when B is measure-zero on the prior. They must satisfy:

(i)  For fixed B, A ↦ P(A|B) is a finitely additive probability.  
(ii) For A⊆B, P(A|B)=1.  
(iii) Generalised Bayes: P(A∧B | C) = P(A|B∧C)·P(B|C).

Given an ordinary Kolmogorov prior one can extend it to a Popper function, but the extension is *not* unique. Hence further principles must guide the choice.

4.2  The Permutation Invariance Requirement  
The announcement R makes no mention of *which* finitely many coins came up Heads. Any epistemically permissible posterior should therefore be permutation-invariant: for any bijection π:ℕ→ℕ, P(H₀ | R) = P(H_{π(0)} | R). Combined with finite additivity, permutation invariance fixes the unique *exchangeable* Popper extension discovered by Rényi (1956). Under that extension:

 P(H₀ | R) = ½.

Roughly, one first restricts attention to sentences involving only *finitely* many coins (a countable Boolean algebra) on which the prior is σ-additive; independence of disjoint finite blocks then forces the posterior on this algebra to remain unchanged. A finitely additive—but no longer countably additive—extension to the *full* σ-algebra exists and is unique under permutation invariance. Technical details aside, the moral is clear: symmetry plus a natural generalisation of Bayes yields ½.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. Objections and Replies  

Obj 1: “But then the posterior assigns *each* coin probability ½ of being Heads, so the expected total number of Heads is infinite, contradicting R!”

Reply: In a finitely additive setting the expected value of an *infinite* sum need not equal the sum of expectations. The contradiction relies again on countable additivity. What we preserve is the expectation of *every finite* partial sum, which *is* bounded by the information in R and so remains consistent. Intuitive worry dissipates once we notice that “expected total number of Heads” is not well-defined after the update unless one chooses a summation method (e.g. a Banach limit). The finitely additive posterior compatible with symmetry assigns no determinate value to that grand total, thereby avoiding inconsistency.

Obj 2: “Finitely additive probabilities are exotic and epistemically unmotivated.”

Reply: They are exotic only because most expositions of probability theory aim at measure‐theoretic convenience. From the normative Bayesian perspective what matters is Dutch-book coherence, and de Finetti’s theorem shows finite additivity suffices for avoiding sure loss. Indeed, whenever ordinary conditionalisation on an event of prior measure 0 is required, one must go beyond the Kolmogorov axioms or abandon single-valued credences altogether. Finitely additive Popper functions provide a principled, minimal departure.

Obj 3: “Why not accept indeterminate credences instead?”

Reply: Interval or set-valued beliefs undoubtedly form one legitimate response (Strategy S-B). Yet symmetry considerations still delimit the interval considerably; the upper and lower probabilities of H₀ both come out to ½ under the permutation-invariant Popper extension, collapsing the interval. Hence indeterminacy offers no genuine enlargement of rationally permissible credence in this particular case.

Obj 4: “The strong intuition that *few* coins are Heads pushes probability toward 0 for each coin.”

Reply: Careful reflection reveals two competing intuitions: (i) “There are only finitely many Heads” versus (ii) “Nothing distinguishes any one coin.” The first tugs probability toward 0; the second fixes it at ½. The puzzle is precisely that they cannot be jointly satisfied within the classical axioms. The permutation-invariant Popper solution honours (ii) and the literal content of R while letting go of a dispensable technical principle (countable additivity). If one instead forces probabilities toward 0, one dumps symmetry and hence implicitly ascribes *extra* information—the announcement would have to have singled out a particular probabilistic structure among the coins, which it did not.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6. A Philosophical Moral: Three-Way Incompatibility  

The case is an instance of a general impossibility: no update rule can simultaneously satisfy

•  Standard Bayesian Conditionalisation for *all* learned events,  
•  Countable Additivity, and  
•  Permutation Symmetry among countably many exchangeable trials.

If we insist on the first two, we must relinquish the third (probability per coin collapses to 0, breaking fairness). If we insist on the first and third, we must drop countable additivity (my proposal). If we insist on the last two, we must abandon conditionalisation and seek some other learning rule. In ordinary finite contexts these tensions never surface; the present thought-experiment is valuable precisely because it lays them bare.

─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
7. Conclusion  

What should your credence be that your own coin landed Heads once you are (miraculously) assured that only finitely many Heads occurred?  The best answer is that it *remains ½.* Achieving this outcome forces us to confront the inadequacy of the classical Kolmogorov package for certain kinds of epistemic updates. By extending conditional probability via permutation-invariant Popper functions we secure:

•  Coherence (no Dutch book),  
•  Respect for the information actually received (the posterior treats R as certain), and  
•  Fairness symmetry across all individuals.

The price is a modest one: relaxing countable additivity in the posterior belief state. The alternative prices—either discarding symmetry or discarding conditionalisation—are, I submit, costlier in rational currency. The case thus offers both a verdict (credence ½) and a lesson: when reasoning about infinite collections, philosophical judgments about which axioms encode genuine rationality and which encode merely technical convenience must come to the fore.

THESIS 

When you discover that out of a countably infinite collection of fair and independent coin-flips only finitely many came up heads, you should—on pain of inconsistency—set your credence that your own coin landed heads to 0 (or, if you prefer a non-classical but still regular probability measure, to an infinitesimal).  The initial ½-credence is wiped out, not because the coin has ceased to be fair, but because the information that “only finitely many heads occurred” is probabilistically explosive: it forces any positive probability of heads for each particular coin to entail an infinite expected number of heads, contradicting what you have just learned.  So independence cannot survive the update, and symmetry alone does not rescue the ½ figure.  In short, conditional on the zero-probability event that only finitely many heads were tossed, the rational credence for a head on your own coin is zero.

The argument proceeds as follows:

1.  Explain why the “finite heads” event (call it F) has unconditional probability 0 and why ordinary Bayes conditioning therefore breaks down.  
2.  Show that a regular conditional probability can nevertheless be defined for F.  The easiest way is via symmetry: the conditional probability that any given coin is heads must be the same for every coin; call that common value q.  If q were positive, the expected number of heads given F would be infinite (because E[#Heads│F] = Σ_i q = ∞), contradicting F.  Hence q = 0.  
3.  Address the two most tempting objections: (a) “But the coins are still independent and fair, so surely the probability remains ½,” and (b) “Conditioning on a probability-zero event is illegitimate, so no rational credence is defined.”  We show why (a) is mistaken—independence is destroyed by the new evidence—and why (b) misfires—well-developed frameworks (Popper functions, nonstandard probabilities, or limits of positive-probability events) deliver a perfectly coherent conditional credence of zero.  
4.  Draw out broader lessons: the case illustrates the fragility of independence under global constraints, the way measure-zero information can dominate local symmetries, and the need for extended Bayesian machinery when reasoning about infinite structures.  

I.  THE PROBLEM OF ZERO-PROBABILITY EVIDENCE  

The event F—“only finitely many heads” in a countable sequence of fair coins—has probability 0.  A standard Kolmogorov measure puts unit mass on the complement (almost surely infinitely many heads).  So naïve Bayes’ rule,

        P(H_i │ F) = P(H_i ∧ F) / P(F),

delivers a 0/0 indeterminacy.  

Bayesians face two options.  

•  The ascetic option: refuse to condition on events that had zero prior probability.  That is coherent but psychologically implausible.  You have been told F; presumably you must incorporate that information somehow.  

•  The permissive option: extend conditionalisation to a wider domain.  Philosophy of probability since Borel, Popper and Rényi has developed tools exactly for this predicament.  We will exploit those tools, but the key point can be captured with nothing more exotic than symmetry and linearity of expectation.  

II.  DEFINING A REGULAR CONDITIONAL FOR F  

Call the coins C₁, C₂, … .  Because the prior distribution is permutation-invariant, the posterior distribution given F should also treat each coin symmetrically.  Let q be the sought conditional probability P(C_i = H │ F).  Linearity of expectation then gives

        E[#Heads │ F] = Σ_{i=1}^{∞} q.

If q > 0, the right-hand side diverges to ∞.  But F tells us that the left-hand side must be a finite number.  Contradiction.  Therefore q = 0.

Nothing in that reasoning assumed anything special about C₁ in particular.  You merely occupy the position of one index among countably many; your expected contribution to the finite set of heads must be 0.  The independence that held ex ante evaporates, because learning F imposes a global constraint that tightly correlates the coins.  (Indeed, the conditional distribution now lives on an extremely thin σ-algebra; for example, the conditional probability that exactly k heads occured is well-defined and positive for each finite k, with ∑_k P_k = 1, and conditional on “exactly k heads” the positions of those heads form a uniformly random k-element subset of ω.  Within that distribution any designated coin has head-probability 0.)

III.  OBJECTION 1: “THE COINS ARE STILL FAIR”  

“But my coin was fair and independent of all the others; learning about the others should not influence its outcome.”  This reply conflates physical fairness with epistemic independence.  Conditioning on F destroys epistemic independence because you have learned something about the joint state of the world that correlates the coins.  In finite cases we see the same phenomenon: suppose two fair coins are independently tossed but you are told ‘at most one of them landed heads.’  Each coin is still physically fair, yet conditional on the evidence each has only 1/3 probability of heads.  The infinite case is an extreme limit of the same logic.

A helpful toy model is the following finite proxy.  Imagine N fair coins, with N enormous.  Conditional on “at most n heads” (where n ≪ N) the probability that any fixed coin is heads is n / N, which tends to 0 as N → ∞ with n fixed.  The countably infinite limit simply freezes n but lets N diverge without bound; the limiting conditional probability is therefore 0.

IV.  OBJECTION 2: “CONDITIONING ON P=0 EVENTS IS ILLEGITIMATE”  

A)  Borel paradox worries.  There are indeed pathologies when one conditions on a measure-zero set that is not determined by a limiting process independent of the parameter of interest.  The classic example: in a uniform distribution over the unit sphere, conditioning on “latitude = 0” is ambiguous because different limiting sequences (e.g. narrowing bands vs narrowing longitudes) yield different conditional distributions.  

Our event F is not like that.  It is shift-invariant and tail-measurable; every approximation by cylinder sets converges to the same result.  One rigorous way is to define F_n: “at most n heads” and condition on F_n; for every fixed coin C_i we have

        P(C_i = H │ F_n) = P(one of ≤ n heads is at position i)
                         = (n / (n + 1))·0 + (1 / (n + 1))·1
                         = n/(n+1)·0 + 1/(n+1) ——> 0 as N→∞,

which tends to 0 as we let N—the number of coins we consider—go to ∞ first and then let n go to ∞.  More sophisticated methods—Popper functions, Rényi’s conditional probabilities, or nonstandard infinitesimal probabilities—deliver the same verdict.  So the conditioning is well-posed.

B)  Proper vs improper priors.  In Bayesian statistics one sometimes rejects updating on probability-zero events out of worry for Dutch book vulnerabilities.  But the proposed credence of 0 for heads is actually Dutch-book immune; an agent who sells a ‘heads ticket’ at any positive price while knowing F would be guaranteed to lose utility in expectation, because she believes it is almost certain that her own coin is tails.

V.  WHAT IF WE INSIST ON A NON-ZERO BUT INFINITESIMAL PROBABILITY?  

Some philosophers are uneasy about assigning point-probability 0 to any logically possible outcome.  Non-standard probability frameworks—e.g. hyperreals, surreal probabilities, or regular and proper priors—can model the updated credence as an infinitesimal ε rather than 0.  Then E[#Heads │ F] = Σε = ω·ε, which can be made finite if ε is itself infinitesimal of order 1/ω² or smaller.  But from the point of view of betting behaviour, the difference between 0 and an infinitesimal is nil: you would still sell a $1 ticket that pays if your coin is heads for any standard positive price.  So the practical conclusion stands.

VI.  COMPARISON WITH RELATED PARADOXES  

1.  The Doomsday argument.  There too the crucial move is conditioning on a piece of information that correlates you with a huge population (your temporal rank among humans), thereby lowering the probability you are very early.  The present coin case is a purified, non-anthropic version.  

2.  Bertrand’s sphere and the Borel paradox.  The moral is that we must specify the σ-algebra on which conditioning occurs.  Here it is clear: the σ-algebra generated by the tail event F and the cylinder σ-field of coin outcomes.  

3.  Countable additivity vs finite additivity.  Violating countable additivity—e.g. in de Finetti’s finitely additive but not countably additive probabilities—one can cook up a measure in which P(F) = c > 0; then conditioning would return ½.  But that measure gives probability c of getting only finitely many heads in a countably infinite sequence of fair coins, violating the law of large numbers.  So rescuing ½ requires a heavy price: abandoning Kolmogorov and the strong LLN.

VII.  WHY SYMMETRY ALONE DOES NOT SAVE ½  

One might appeal to the Principle of Indifference: “Nothing distinguishes my coin from any other, so being told only finitely many heads occurred gives me no reason to privilege tails over heads on my coin.”  But that assumes a global symmetry that is now broken.  The new information picks out an exceptional set of coins—the finitely many heads—without identifying which ones they are.  For any particular coin, being one of those exceptional heads is like winning an infinite lottery with infinitesimal ticket probability.  Symmetry applies only among the exceptional ones, not between exceptional and generic coins.

VIII.  LESSONS FOR THE PHILOSOPHY OF PROBABILITY  

1.  Independence is defeasible.  It is a fragile, not an unconditional, epistemic relation.  Information about a global constraint almost always tears it apart.  

2.  Probability-zero events can matter.  Rational agents sometimes have to update on surprises that had zero prior probability.  A complete Bayesian theory needs conditional probabilities for null events; regular conditional probabilities or Popper functions supply them.  

3.  Infinite populations exhibit counter-intuitive behaviour.  Finite intuition fails because expectations can diverge; the “mass per individual” can collapse to zero.  

4.  Conditional expectations are better behaved than pointwise probabilities in the infinite setting.  Grasping why your credence drops to zero is easier by first thinking about the expected total number of heads.

IX.  CODA: A QUICK FORMAL CONSTRUCTION  

Let Ω = {0,1}^ℵ₀ with the product σ-algebra.  Write ω(i) for the i-th coordinate.  Define F := {ω ∈ Ω : ∑_i ω(i) < ∞}.  The prior measure μ is the standard product measure (each ω(i) = 1 with prob ½).  For k ∈ ℕ let F_k := {ω : ∑_i ω(i) ≤ k}.  Each F_k is measurable and μ(F_k) = 0.  Set

        ν_k(A) = μ(A ∩ F_k) / μ(F_k ∪ B_k),

where B_k = {ω : ∑_{i=1}^{k+1} ω(i) ≥ 1} ensures the denominator is non-zero.  Then for any fixed i,

        ν_k(ω(i)=1) ≤ k/(k+1).

Taking k → ∞, the limit measure ν (a finitely additive but σ-finite restriction) satisfies ν(ω(i)=1) = 0.  That ν is a regular conditional of μ given F.  Hence your credence is 0.

X.  CONCLUSION  

Your coin is still objectively fair; but given the extraordinary global fact you have learned, rational credence is governed not by local fairness but by the hard arithmetic of infinities.  Conditional on only finitely many heads, the chance that any particular coin—including yours—is one of those rare heads collapses to zero.  Any residual empathy for the ½ figure reflects a conflation of physical propensity with epistemic probability or an uncritical faith in independence.  A fully articulated Bayesian (or Popperian, or nonstandard) calculus vindicates the stark update: P(Heads│Only-finitely-many-heads) = 0.

Heads I win, tails you win?  
Updating on a probability-zero event

1. The set-up and the puzzle  

A countable infinity of people—𝑃₀, 𝑃₁, 𝑃₂, …—each tosses an independent, fair coin. Before anyone looks, we are told something that, from the point of view of ordinary probability theory, is virtually impossible: only finitely many of the infinitely many coins have landed heads. Call that information FIN. What credence should 𝑃₀ (you) now assign to the proposition H₀ that your own coin came up heads?  

At first glance two considerations pull in opposite directions.  

(i) Symmetry: The mechanism that produced your toss is still exactly the one you believed in five seconds ago—a fair, independent flip. Symmetry screams “½!”  

(ii) Rarity: Given FIN, the set of heads is a mere speck in an ocean of tails. Intuitively, the odds of being among that speck seem negligible. Rarity whispers “almost 0.”  

Which voice should a rational Bayesian heed? I shall argue that a fully worked-out Bayesian analysis forces the credence all the way down to 0. The symmetry-based temptation to stay at ½ rests on a misuse of independence that collapses once we take the infinite structure of the evidence seriously. I then explain why the episode teaches a broader moral about learning from probability-zero information.

2. Why ordinary conditionalization breaks down

For finite probability spaces Bayesian updating is straightforward: P(E│F) = P(E∧F)/P(F). With FIN, however, P(FIN)=0. Bayes’ fraction is undefined; the textbook rule leaves us speechless.

Two routes suggest themselves.

(a) Forget FIN is measure-zero, pretend it isn’t, and apply the usual fraction. That is incoherent because the numerator is also 0: independence gives P(H₀∧FIN)=P(H₀)P(FIN)=0. We get 0/0, i.e. anything we like. The probability theory by itself places no constraint.

(b) Use a more sophisticated notion of conditional probability—regular conditional probabilities (RCPs). An RCP is a family of distributions P_F(·) defined for almost every outcome that behaves “as if” we had conditioned on the σ-algebra generated by F. RCPs exist for product spaces like ours, but they are *not unique on events of prior measure zero*. One can build an RCP that makes P(H₀│FIN)=½, another that makes it 0, a third that makes it .314159…, all while preserving the original (Kolmogorov) probability calculus on events of positive measure. If that is all we care about, nothing forces a choice.

So mere mathematics underdetermines the rational update. We need philosophical principles.

3. The independence illusion—and how it dissolves

The argument for sticking at ½ is very quick: before hearing FIN, H₀ was independent of all “tail events”—events whose truth is determined by coin tosses beyond some finite index. FIN *looks* like a tail event, so surely H₀ remains independent of it; therefore P(H₀│FIN)=P(H₀)=½.

The flaw is subtle but fatal.

(i) FIN is *indeed* a tail event. By Kolmogorov’s 0-1 law every tail event has prior probability 0 or 1; FIN’s is 0.  

(ii) Statements of independence are *formulated and proved in the prior measure*. They say nothing about how to apportion credence once we have made ourselves certain of a probability-zero tail event. Put differently: “H₀ and FIN are independent” entails

 P(H₀ ∧ FIN) = P(H₀)·P(FIN) = 0,

but when we replace the prior with a new probability that assigns FIN measure 1, the equality is vacuous. We have simply left the universe in which the independence fact held.

Independence, then, does **not** survive conditionalization on FIN, because the very act of learning FIN yanks us out of the probability space in which independence was defined.

4. An argument that forces P(H₀│FIN)=0

Consider the random variable T that counts the total number of heads. FIN is the event “T is finite.” Let μ(·│FIN) be any posterior probability that (i) assigns FIN probability 1 and (ii) preserves exchangeability of the coins (a symmetry requirement every reasonable Bayesian should still accept—the labelling of people carries no evidential weight). Suppose, for reductio, that μ(H₀│FIN)=ε>0. By exchangeability, μ(H_n│FIN)=ε for every n. Then

 E_μ[T│FIN] = Σ_{n=0}^{∞} μ(H_n│FIN)  
      = Σ_{n=0}^{∞} ε  
      = ∞,  because ε>0.

But FIN assures us T is finite with μ-probability 1, so E_μ[T│FIN] must itself be finite. Contradiction. Therefore ε=0. By the very same symmetry E_μ(H_n│FIN)=0 for every n. In plain English: *given that only finitely many heads occurred, the chance that any specific coin was one of them must be zero.*

This argument is perfectly rigorous; it uses only countable additivity of expectation and the idea that posteriors respecting the evidence must make the expectation of a bounded random variable finite. No question-begging about independence remains.

5. Can the symmetry assumption be rejected?

One might attempt to salvage a non-zero credence by abandoning exchangeability in the posterior: perhaps FIN correlates early indexes with heads, later indexes with tails. But that is ad hoc in two ways.

First, nothing in the evidence singles out early people. Second, even without explicit exchangeability, we can run a *coarser* version of the above argument. Let N be the largest index of a head (finite by FIN). Conditional on “N ≥ k”, the probability you are heads is at most 1/(k+1) (there are k+1 coins to choose from, of which at most k+1 are heads). Since “N ≥ k” holds for every k (we have no upper bound), the limit forces your credence to 0. Making the posterior non-exchangeable therefore does not help.

6. Maximum-entropy confirmation

A different, more constructive route to the same verdict uses the Principle of Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt): pick the posterior distribution that (i) satisfies the new constraint (FIN) and (ii) minimises relative entropy (Kullback–Leibler divergence) from the prior. For an i.i.d. prior, the unique MaxEnt posterior sets every coin deterministically to tails except for *some* finite set of indexes about which it remains agnostic. In that posterior each particular coin is almost surely tails, hence credence 0 in heads. MaxEnt thus coincides with the expectation argument.

7. Why “almost surely tails” is not paradoxical

Some find the answer counter-intuitive: “If each specific coin has probability 0 of being heads, how can any heads occur at all?” The resolution is familiar from standard measure theory. Probability-0 events are not impossible; they are merely negligible *with respect to the measure*. The posterior we have built allows (with probability 1) that the set of heads is finite, yet for every fixed n it is *possible* (though measure-0) that coin n lands heads. Finite additivity ensures consistency: a countable union of measure-0 sets can have positive measure (in fact, 1). There is no contradiction, only the unavoidable subtleties of infinity.

8. Objections and replies

Objection A: “But conditionalising on probability-zero events is arbitrary; why privilege the 0 answer over ½ or 1/π?”  
Reply: The expectation argument shows that any posterior with a positive conditional chance for H₀ contradicts a *logical implication* of the evidence—namely, that the expected number of heads is finite. Posteriors giving value ½ are therefore incoherent with FIN.

Objection B: “The argument presupposes countable additivity. A finitist Bayesian might drop that axiom.”  
Reply: True but unmotivated. Countable additivity underwrites the very probability theory in which we formulated FIN. If one wants to explain the everyday successes of classical probability, jettisoning the axiom is too high a price.

Objection C: “Your result makes learning too powerful. How can a single bit of testimony override the direct physical information that the coin was fair?”  
Reply: Learning FIN is not *one bit* in any informational sense. It encodes an infinite pattern among infinitely many tosses. Conditioning on it is informationally gargantuan; it is unsurprising that such wholesale information swamps the small-scale physical propensity of a particular toss.

9. Philosophical upshot: the brittleness of independence and the geometry of zero

We have encountered a vivid instance of two general morals.

(1) Independence is *fragile under learning*. Tails of sequences, propensity facts, and local causal stories do not by themselves guarantee future independence once we condition on global constraints. Philosophers sometimes treat causal independence as inviolable. The present case shows that independence is hostage to one’s total information state.

(2) Conditioning on measure-zero events is not automatically well-defined; extra principles are needed. Those principles can come from symmetry, maximum entropy, or (as here) coherence with logical implications of the evidence. Once they are supplied, probability-zero “miracles” can and often do force credence changes all the way to 0 or 1.

10. Conclusion

Rational credence in H₀, after learning FIN, should be 0. The route to that conclusion is indirect because the standard Bayesian recipe (divide by P(FIN)) breaks down. But demanding coherence with the truth that *only finitely many heads exist* places a strict upper bound on the probability any particular coin is one of them, and that bound is zero. Symmetry-based arguments for sticking with ½ overlook how independence evaporates when we condition on events of prior measure zero. The puzzle is a dramatic illustration of how infinite combinatorics and the geometry of null sets reshape epistemic landscapes—a salutary reminder that in the probabilistic labyrinth, the walls themselves move when we shine new light.

A Miracle in an Infinite Coin-Room:  What Ought You Now Believe?

1.  Framing the puzzle

Imagine an ω-long row of fair coins, one for each person in an infinite room.  All coins are flipped simultaneously but concealed.  A loud-speaker then announces the seemingly impossible:  “Only finitely many of the flips came up heads.”  Your epistemic question is local—what to believe about your own coin—yet it is posed against a global background in which something of probability 0 has just been learned.  Standard Bayesian conditionalisation, P(A│E)=P(A∧E)/P(E), gives no guidance when P(E)=0, so any answer must draw on deeper principles—symmetry, regular conditional probabilities, indexical information, and the logic of “learning from a miracle.”  

I shall defend the following thesis.

Thesis:  Given only the information that (i) the coins were originally fair and independent and (ii) in fact only finitely many landed heads, a rational agent should set her posterior credence that her own coin is a head to 0.  In effect, learning the global fact shatters the original independence; after the update, each particular coin is almost-surely a tail.  The rival view, that the credence should remain at ½, rests on a misapplication of independence in a setting where the evidence itself breaks it.

The argument proceeds in five stages.  (1)  I formalise the sample space and highlight why the ordinary conditional probability is undefined.  (2)  I construct a **regular conditional distribution** on the zero-measure event and prove that it forces the probability of heads for every fixed coin to be 0.  (3)  I answer the intuitive worry that “there are *some* heads, so why not me?”.  (4)  I examine two alternative update rules—“ignore the miracle” and “typicality reasoning”—and show why they either violate basic symmetry or collapse back into the 0-credence verdict.  (5)  I tease out the philosophical moral:  whenever evidence reduces an infinite family of exchangeable events to a *finite* subfamily, each particular event inherits probability 0, even though, collectively, some occur.

2.  Formal preliminaries and the zero-measure obstacle

Let Ω = {0,1}^ℵ₀ be the space of infinite binary sequences, indexed by ℕ.  
For ω ∈ Ω, write H(ω) = {n : ωₙ = 1}.  
The fair product measure μ on (Ω,𝔹) makes the coordinate projections Xₙ(ω) = ωₙ independent and μ(Xₙ=1)=½.

Define the “miracle” event
 F  = {ω :  |H(ω)|  <  ω}.   (There are only finitely many heads.)

By the Strong Law and Kolmogorov’s 0–1 law F is a tail event with μ(F)=0.  
Hence P(X₀=1│F) is undefined inside ordinary Kolmogorov theory.  The question is therefore which, if any, *regular* conditional probabilities we should adopt.

3.  A symmetry-based regular conditional distribution

A **regular conditional probability** (rcp) for X₀ given F is a function r  with:

(i)  r(ω) ∈ [0,1] for all ω∈F;
(ii)  For every measurable A⊆Ω, the map ω↦r_A(ω):=r(ω)(A) is measurable on F;
(iii)  μ(A ∩ F) = ∫_F  r_A(ω)  dμ(ω).

Because μ(F)=0, condition (iii) imposes almost no uniqueness constraints; additional principles must therefore select the “right” rcp.  Two natural demands suffice:

S1—Shift invariance.  Exchanging the labels of people ought not matter.  Formally, let σ_k be the k-step left-shift on Ω.  The posterior measure conditioned on F should satisfy r(σ_kω)=r(ω) for μ-a.e. ω∈F.

S2—Countable additivity, hence finite‐support events retain probability 0 unless forced otherwise.

Proposition 1.  Under S1 and S2 there is exactly one rcp on F, namely the measure ν that puts probability 1 on the all-tails sequence.  Consequently, for every fixed n,
 ν(Xₙ=1) = 0.

Sketch of proof.  Suppose toward contradiction that ν(X₀=1)=ε>0.  By shift invariance ν(X_k=1)=ε for every k.  Because there are countably many coins, the expected number of heads under ν is ∑ₖ ε = ∞, contradicting the definition of F which restricts support to sequences with *finitely* many heads.  Hence ε=0.  No other choice satisfies both S1 and finite-heads support. □
