                       Adaptive Preferences and the Sources of Autonomy‐Deficit
                                               ————————————————————

1. Orientation and thesis  

The phenomenon of adaptive preference—an agent’s having come genuinely to want what is feasible for her given serious constraints—seems to undermine the very idea that satisfying what someone wants is sufficient for respecting her autonomy.  Why does autonomy go missing here?  Three prominent families of answers compete:

• Subjectivist or structural accounts, exemplified by Frankfurt, look inside the agent’s psychic economy and ask whether she endorses her first‐order desires.  
• Content‐based accounts, associated with Nussbaum and some perfectionists, assess the value of what is preferred.  
• Historical accounts explain the deficit by appeal to the etiology of the preference: it was shaped by domination, threat, or deprivation in ways that bypass or deform the agent’s powers of self‐governance.

While each view captures an important intuition, I shall argue that the autonomy deficit characteristic of oppressive adaptive preferences is best explained by a refined historical view that I call the Distorted Formation Account.  On this account a preference is non-autonomous when (i) its formation involved social mechanisms that predictably disable the agent’s capacity to imagine or evaluate unavailable options, and (ii) the preference would be destabilised by minimally improved opportunity and deliberative conditions.  The historical explanation carries the normative weight, but it must be supplemented by a counterfactual “resilience” test to distinguish rational, self-protective adaptation from domination-induced distortion.  The resulting hybrid traces autonomy failure to oppressive history without lapsing into perfectionist paternalism or implausible psychologism.

2. Clarifying the target phenomenon  

“Autonomy” names a second-order power: the capacity to govern one’s practical life by reasons one can regard as one’s own.  It therefore has both synchronic and diachronic dimensions.  Synchronic: does the agent presently identify with the motives that move her?  Diachronic: were those motives themselves generated by processes that preserved her critical and imaginative capacities across time?

An “adaptive” preference, following Elster and Sen, is one whose content adjusts to a restricted feasible set.  Not every such adjustment threatens autonomy.  A mountaineer who gives up an Everest attempt because a storm closes the window may cheerfully adapt her goal to a nearby peak without loss of self-rule.  What worries us are preferences shaped by standing, systematic constraints—e.g. patriarchal norms that narrow women’s aspirations, colonial institutions that limit the horizons of subject peoples, or permanent poverty that makes certain choices psychologically impossible to contemplate.  In these contexts agents may sincerely prefer options that entrench their subordination: the “happy slave,” the self-effacing wife, the trafficked child who begs not to be rescued.  The philosophical problem is to explain why these endorsed, wellbeing-promoting preferences are nevertheless less than fully autonomous.

3. The subjectivist endorsement model  

Frankfurtian autonomy demands wholeheartedness: an agent is autonomous with respect to a first-order desire if she endorses it upon reflective awareness.  The immediate attraction is that adaptive preferences often lack such endorsement.  Oppressed agents frequently experience ambivalence, self-contempt, or dissonance once they become reflectively aware of the social forces shaping them.  

Yet two systematic difficulties weaken the model’s explanatory reach:

(a) The abundance of wholehearted adaptive preferences.  Empirical work on internalised oppression documents cases in which agents are, at least for long stretches, serenely committed to their constrained ideals.  The woman in a village who trains her daughter to seek a good dowry marriage may feel no conflict.  By Frankfurt’s lights the preference is autonomous, but our intuition says something has gone wrong.

(b) Ignorance of social etiology.  Hierarchical reflection takes the agent’s existing horizon of possibilities as given.  If that horizon is itself a product of domination—if entire categories of aspiration are literally unimaginable—the second-order endorsement certifies what needs critical scrutiny.  Wholeheartedness inside a hermeneutically sealed domain is too cheap.

Subjectivism therefore misses the distinctive mark of oppressive adaptation: not inner conflict but a socially engineered narrowing of the space in which conflict could arise.

4. Content‐based perfectionism  

Content theorists bypass the psychology and locate autonomy deficits in the object of desire itself.  If what the agent prefers is inconsistent with basic human capabilities—bodily integrity, practical reason, imaginative freedom—then the preference is disqualified as autonomous.  Martha Nussbaum offers a vivid case: women in North Indian villages who reject literacy programs because they see schooling as useless for daughters.  Such preferences, she claims, are autonomy-deficient because they betray a core human capability for practical reason.

The perfectionist strategy does explain why we regard some adaptive preferences as problematic even when agents endorse them.  But it pays several costs:

(a) Paternalism.  The authority to declare which contents are unworthy sits outside the agent’s evaluative standpoint.  Critics worry that this slides from diagnosing autonomy failure into substituting the theorist’s conception of the good.

(b) Overbreadth.  People sometimes autonomously choose projects that foreclose capabilities—monastic seclusion, high-risk adventure, or devotional obedience.  Content scrutiny alone cannot distinguish those free sacrifices from oppressive adaptation without reintroducing historical or structural considerations.

(c) Blindness to rational coping.  Some adaptive preferences are autonomy‐preserving strategies for navigating unremovable constraints.  The starving man who trains himself to find edible grass appealing may protect his agency rather than lose it.  A purely content-based veto labels all such coping self‐betrayal.

5. Etiology and the historical turn  

Historical accounts shift the focus from current mental states and from the value of outcomes to the social processes that produced the desire.  Benson’s “manipulation” criterion, Oshana’s “social relations” view, and Khader’s “process‐oriented” analysis of adaptive preference all share the core thought: domination can so shape preference formation that the resultant wants are not authentically the agent’s, even if they are now wholeheartedly held and pursuit of them yields local satisfaction.

Why does history matter?  Because autonomy is a capacity that itself develops historically.  Forming, revising, and ranking motives over time requires opportunities for imaginative exploration, exposure to alternatives, dialogical challenge, and freedom from sanction for deviance.  Oppressive socialisation predictably degrades these enabling conditions.  Preferences forged under such degradation carry an “etiological taint”: they were not formed by the agent’s evaluative powers operating under normal competence conditions.

The historical perspective successfully explains why wholeheartedness is not enough and why the problem is especially acute under oppression.  It also avoids judging preferences by their content alone: a preference to be a full‐time homemaker can be autonomously chosen in an egalitarian community but non-autonomous when produced by patriarchal conditioning.

Nevertheless, extant historical accounts face two tasks:

(i) Differentiation: they must separate oppressive distortion from rational self-protection within constraints.  
(ii) Action‐guidance: they must tell policymakers when intervention is justified without insulting competent agents who disagree with the proposed alternative.

6. The Distorted Formation Account  

To answer these tasks I propose a two-part criterion for autonomy with respect to a preference P:

(1) Etiological Independence Condition: P must not be the predictable outcome of social mechanisms (threat, deprivation, hermeneutic marginalisation) whose function is to limit the agent’s imaginative or deliberative range so as to secure her compliance with subordinating norms.  

(2) Counterfactual Resilience Condition: If the agent were placed, over a reasonable period, in circumstances where those mechanisms are absent and where a modestly expanded set of live options is practically available and normatively affirmed, she would either revise or doubt P with appreciable probability.

If a preference fails both conditions, it is autonomy-deficient.  Condition (1) assigns the historical explanatory work; condition (2) filters out the Everest mountaineer and the starving grass-eater, whose preferences would likely survive opportunity expansion; their formation was adaptive in a rational, coping sense rather than a domination-induced sense.

7. Illustrative cases  

a. The case of Shanti, the dowry mother.  Shanti lives in a region where daughters traditionally join their husband’s household.  Schooling girls lowers their marriage prospects and strains family finances.  Shanti sincerely prefers early marriage for her daughter and rejects NGO scholarship offers.  

Etiological independence fails: her preference is the outcome of a social system that penalises deviation through economic sanction and honour codes.  Counterfactual resilience also fails: in nearby districts where the dowry system has collapsed and female schooling is valorised, women previously like Shanti overwhelmingly shift preferences.  Result: autonomy deficit.

b. The Everest mountaineer.  Storm closes summit window; climber adapts goal to a nearby peak.  Social mechanisms of domination absent; preference would survive in counterfactual fair conditions.  Autonomy intact.

c. The starving grass-eater.  Deprivation not inflicted by an agent aiming at domination; once food scarcity ends, the preference for grass might persist as harmless culinary quirk.  Etiological independence arguably satisfied, or at least domination absent; resilience satisfied.  No autonomy deficit.

d. The cloistered novice.  She voluntarily adopts a life of obedience after years of exposure to secular opportunities and dialogue.  Formation not predictably engineered by social powers aimed at subordination (the convent screens for authentic vocation).  Preference passes both tests.  Autonomy preserved despite self-subordination content.

8. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: The counterfactual test is speculative and paternalistic; outsiders will project their own values onto imagined futures.

Reply:  The test is anchored not in the evaluator’s ideals but in empirical data about how similarly situated agents behave when constraints ease.  It is defeasible and requires humility: if evidence shows resilience, intervention should cease.  Moreover, oppressed agents themselves often articulate counterfactual aspirations once safe contexts permit, vindicating the test’s sensitivity to first-person authority.

Objection 2: Some oppressive contexts yield Stockholm-syndrome loyalty so deep that even opportunity expansion leaves preferences intact.  The account would misclassify these as autonomous.

Reply:  Condition (1) already diagnoses autonomy deficit due to etiology.  Resilience is a supplementary filter; both conditions must be met for autonomy.  Therefore even pathologically stable oppressive preferences remain non-autonomous.

Objection 3: The view collapses into content perfectionism because “domination” mechanisms are identified partly by their unjust content.

Reply:  Domination is defined structurally: systematic power asymmetries that curtail critical capacities, regardless of whether the resulting content offends specific perfectionist goods.  A culture could inculcate Spartan self-abnegation (a value Nussbaum might applaud) through coercive indoctrination; if so, autonomy fails, even though the content tracks capabilities.  The Distorted Formation Account therefore remains content-neutral.

9. Advantages over rivals  

Compared with subjectivism, the historical account explains why wholehearted preference can still be alien.  It also guides social policy: expand capabilities and interpretive horizons, rather than merely nudge inner reflection.

Compared with content perfectionism, it respects pluralism about life plans and avoids the need for an external ranking of goods.  It condemns the preference for female cutting in patriarchal societies not because genital alteration is intrinsically irrational, but because the desire is produced by silencing, threat, and misinformation.

Compared with generic historical views, the Distorted Formation Account adds a principled distinction between oppressive distortion and rational adaptation, using the counterfactual resilience test grounded in comparative social evidence.  It thereby wards off the overbreadth worry that labels all coping strategies unfree.

10. Policy and ethical implications  

Understanding autonomy deficit etiologically has at least three practical payoffs:

1. Interventions should target the social mechanisms, not override the preference directly.  Provide schooling subsidies, anti-harassment enforcement, and public exemplars rather than forcibly enrolling girls.  
2. Measurement of success must be diachronic.  The goal is not immediate preference change but restoring the agent’s capability to revisit preferences over time.  
3. Respect for agency demands listening.  Agents may endorse temporary compromises—e.g. conditional participation in programs—that reflect their local knowledge of risk.  Eliminating domination is compatible with honoring such strategies.

11. Residual puzzles and research directions  

Two hard questions remain.  First, can large-scale structural mechanisms—capitalist advertising, digital echo chambers—generate autonomy deficits even absent direct oppression?  Exploring where manipulation shades into ordinary social influence will refine the Etiological Independence Condition.

Second, how long and how expansive must the counterfactual period and opportunity set be?  Neuroscientific work on preference plasticity and sociological studies of aspiration windows may offer empirically tractable parameters.  Philosophically, the issue connects to debates about diachronic identity: what proportion of the same person must remain to count preference revision as her own rather than her successor’s?

12. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences under oppression are not just unfortunate compromises; they are symptoms of a breakdown in the historical conditions that normally allow persons to become the authors of their own desires.  Subjectivist endorsement accounts miss this because they freeze the frame on the present psyche; content accounts miss it because they moralise the outcome rather than the process.  A historically rooted analysis, refined by a counterfactual resilience test, best captures our judgments and guides respectful, autonomy-restoring social change.  Autonomy is less a moment of internal assent than an ongoing, socially sustained practice of looking beyond what has been made thinkable.  Only by attending to the history of how horizons get narrowed—and by reopening them—can we secure the self-government that oppressed agents are owed.

Adaptive Preferences and the Sources of Autonomy-Deficit  
                                           —toward a process-relational account—  

1. Framing the Puzzle  

Many people come to desire exactly what oppressive social structures make easily available.  
• The long-term prisoner develops a taste for “yard time” over mountain hikes.  
• The factory child in Dhaka regards education as a nuisance and a sewing machine as a blessing.  
• The undocumented house-cleaner in Berlin interprets her apathy toward voting as proof that “politics isn’t for people like me.”  

These are paradigmatic adaptive preferences: attitudes that take shape in response to severe constraints on the agent’s feasible set. The intuitive worry is not merely that such preferences are unfortunate; it is that they are, in a sense, *less than fully the agent’s own.* They exhibit an autonomy deficit even when—indeed, precisely when—the person sincerely endorses them. What, exactly, explains that deficit?  

Three families of answers dominate the literature.  
A. Subjectivist (procedural) views, epitomized by Frankfurt, locate autonomy in higher-order endorsement or reflective identification.  
B. Content-based views identify substantive moral flaws in the preferred ends; oppression damages autonomy by steering desire toward the wrong objects.  
C. Historical views identify defects in *how* the attitudes were formed, independently of current endorsement or content.  

My thesis is three-part:  
1. Purely subjectivist accounts *fail* because any endorsement powerful enough to silence adaptive critiques automatically counts the preference as autonomous.  
2. Purely content-based accounts misdiagnose many perfectly autonomous but morally troubling desires (think of an affluent sadist) and cannot explain why some adapted preferences (like valuing a simple meal in wartime) strike us as *fully* one’s own.  
3. Historical accounts come closest, but they need to be supplemented with a *relational* requirement: autonomy also depends on the agent’s standing in a network of social recognition that makes intelligible a meaningful alternative horizon.  

An adaptive preference is autonomy-defective when (i) it is produced by a history of constrained accommodation to illegitimate social power and (ii) the same social power continues to block the agent from *recognizing* the historical contingency of that preference within a community of equals. The deficit is thus both diachronic (a tainted causal pathway) and synchronic (ongoing relational deprivation). A hybrid “process-relational” theory explains why adaptive preferences under oppression feel alienated without collapsing into paternalism or moralism.

2. Clarifying “Adaptive Preference”  

The term, borrowed from rational-choice theory (via Jon Elster) and social justice debates (Sen, Nussbaum), covers three features:

a. Constraint-responsiveness: The desire arises *because* significant options are unavailable or risky.  
b. Counterfactual instability: Were the constraints lifted in the right way, the agent would likely revise the preference.  
c. Internalization: The preference is not merely strategic behavior; it is felt as a genuine disposition or source of satisfaction.  

Because (b) need not hold for all cases—sometimes people stick to old tastes even after liberation—I will treat (a) and (c) as definitional and treat (b) as typical but defeasible.  

3. Procedural / Subjectivist Accounts: Frankfurt, Dworkin, et al.  

On Frankfurt’s celebrated hierarchy, a desire is autonomous if the agent *wants to want* it (second-order volition) and that higher-order attitude is itself unopposed. Adaptive preferences appear susceptible to this diagnostic: if the oppressed housewife endorses her “domestic calling,” surely that is her will?

Critique:  
i. Endorsement can be manufactured. Training, indoctrination, and normative deprivation can align second-order volitions with constraints rather than with the agent’s independent interests. Frankfurt’s own proviso of “freedom of the will” does little work when formative conditions systematically shape what higher-order attitudes are even imaginable.  

ii. The view lacks *diachronic sensitivity*: once endorsement is present *now*, the historical route disappears from evaluative purview. But temporally asymmetric data is central to the adaptive-preference phenomenon.  

iii. By valorizing structure over context, subjectivism rules out critique from the inside. It licenses calling the contented slave “fully autonomous” if she internalizes servitude. Yet the moral phenomenology of outrage many of us feel is aimed exactly at the way in which *her* endorsement seems purchased at the price of options stolen.  

In short, hierarchical endorsement is—by design—too procedurally thin to register autonomy deficits rooted in unjust socialization.

4. Content-Based Accounts: Capabilities, Perfectionism, Substantive Morality  

Martha Nussbaum argues that preferences incompatible with a threshold of basic capabilities (bodily integrity, practical reason, etc.) are non-autonomous. The housewife who refuses education fails the *practical reason* capability; hence her choice lacks autonomous standing.

Merits:  
• Incorporates the intuitive link between oppression and disvalue.  
• Provides a normative reason to *intervene* even with voluntary choices.  

Problems:  
i. Conflation of well-being and autonomy. A sadistic aristocrat violates no capability but is hardly a poster child of freedom. Conversely, an ascetic monk may autonomously reject capabilities he deems worldly.  

ii. Paternalism. Declaring preferences non-autonomous when they clash with an objective list risks disrespectful overreach, especially in cross-cultural contexts. The suspicion that adaptive preferences are defective derives not (or not only) from their content but from their genesis under domination.  

iii. Context Insensitivity. Eating only rice for religious reasons in affluent Boston could be a free commitment; eating only rice because colonial policy destroyed your other crops is adaptive. Content alone cannot discriminate.

Thus, while content matters morally, it tracks a different dimension from autonomy. Substantive lists blur that boundary.

5. Historical Accounts: Socialization, Coercion, and the “Right Kind” of Causal Path  

Historical or “causal” theories (e.g., Christman, Oshana, Benson) propose that an attitude is autonomous only if it has not been produced by manipulative, coercive, or oppressive forces *in a way that bypasses the agent’s critical capacities.*  

Strengths:  
• Captures our sense that *how* a preference came about matters.  
• Avoids moralizing the content; a desire can be odious yet autonomous if its genealogy is clean.  
• Makes sense of “liberation narratives,” where learning about one’s history precipitates alienation from old desires.

Challenges:  
a. Demarcation: Which causal influences are disqualifying? Socialization always shapes us; only some yield autonomy-deficits.  

b. Present-moment silence: A preference forged under injustice but now reflectively re-endorsed might pass the historical test unless we specify that ongoing structural injustice *matters now.*  

c. Epistemic Access: Agents rarely know the full causal story of their desires; must such knowledge be required?  

Despite these issues, historical models furnish the most plausible backbone; they need further articulation rather than replacement.

6. Toward a Process-Relational Account  

My proposal hybridizes the causal insight with a *relational* criterion inspired by Iris Marion Young and relational autonomy theorists.  

Definition (PR-Autonomy):  
A preference P of agent A at time t is *fully autonomous* iff  

(i) Process Condition: P was not substantially shaped by coercive or illegitimate social power that bypassed A’s capacity for critical reflection, *or* if it was, A has since engaged those very critical capacities under conditions approximating equality with others, *and*  

(ii) Relational Recognition Condition: At t, A stands in social relations that (a) affirm her epistemic standing to question P, (b) supply bona-fide alternative scripts, and (c) refrain from sanctions for dissent.  

When either clause fails, an autonomy deficit obtains. Adaptive preferences formed in oppressive environments typically violate (i) and, because the oppressive structures endure, still violate (ii). The two conditions jointly explain why past contamination alone doesn’t doom a preference (people can critically reclaim values) and why present relational deprivation alone can suffocate autonomy even if the historical record is clean.

7. Illustrative Cases  

Case 1: Rani, the Rural Child Bride  
Rani, married at 13, insists at 20 that early marriage is ideal: “Girls who wait become burdens.” Her desire grew amid patriarchal coercion (violating Process) and she still lives in a village where dissenting women are shamed (violating Recognition). PR-Autonomy classifies her preference as non-autonomous.

Contrast with: Nasreen, also married early but now studying in Delhi among peers who value delayed marriage. After courses in gender history, she still tells a friend, “Marrying young gave me emotional advantages.” Process contamination remains, but clause (i)’s second disjunct plus (ii) might redeem her preference as autonomous, though critics may still question its prudence.

Case 2: Althea, the Wartime Survivor  
During siege, Althea taught herself to relish thin gruel because nothing else was available. Years later, in peace and prosperity, she still prefers it. The preference was certainly adaptive, but there is no standing injustice sustaining it now; she is free, recognized, and critical. PR-Autonomy judges the taste fully her own. Content-based views might awkwardly object (“gruel is bad for you”), while procedural subjectivism and the hybrid view agree on autonomy.

8. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The view collapses into an opportunity account—if the agent has genuine options, she is autonomous; if not, she isn’t. That’s old news.  
Reply: Options alone are insufficient. A wealthy cult member may exit freely but faces epistemic isolation that satisfies neither clause (i) (manipulative formation) nor (ii) (recognition deficit). Conversely, a peasant with few material options might nonetheless autonomously endorse agrarian simplicity if the process was non-coercive and her community honors dissent. The theory is sensitive to power relations, not raw option count.

Objection 2: Too demanding epistemically; many ordinary preferences fail the recognition condition.  
Reply: Full autonomy is indeed demanding, but practical applications (e.g., policy interventions) can employ a threshold concept: the more severe the violation, the stronger the permission to interfere or compensate. Everyday low-stakes adaptivity (preferring local cuisine due to availability) only mildly fails the condition and thus hardly justifies paternalism.

Objection 3: Relational recognition smuggles in a liberal view of society. Authoritarians will reject it, so the account is question-begging.  
Reply: The autonomy debate itself presupposes the value of self-government; any theory of autonomy that eschews this presupposition ceases to be about autonomy. The relational condition simply explicates what “self-government” entails: not solitary introspection, but membership in discursive relations of mutual respect.

9. Advantages of the Hybrid  

• Explains why *both* origin story and current oppression matter.  
• Avoids labeling every adaptive preference defective: some are harmless quirks or authentic revisions stabilized after reflective reclamation.  
• Respects agent authority: the key to redemption is the agent’s own critical uptake, aided by social recognition, not external content evaluators.  
• Guides reform: to remediate autonomy deficits, one must both open the option set and build social venues for respectful contestation. This dual strategy clarifies why micro-credit alone or consciousness-raising alone underperform; they each tackle only one clause.

10. Relationship to Existing Theories  

Christman’s “procedurally independent” requirement captures Process (i) but neglects the relational ecology that sustains critical reflection.  
Oshana’s social-relations view approximates clause (ii) but underplays diachronic causality, leading her to regard affluent but isolated agents as unfree regardless of their histories, a possible overreach.  
Nussbaum’s capabilities provide a moral baseline but can be repurposed: capabilities can anchor the *illegitimacy* test in clause (i)—a process is contaminating when it systematically thwarts capability development. Thus the hybrid theory coordinates, rather than chooses among, insights from rival accounts.

11. Policy and Ethical Implications  

When NGOs confront child-marriage preferences or labor suppression, the hybrid theory advises:  
(a) Diagnosis: Distinguish lack-of-resources adaptivity from internalized inferiority by examining both formation history and present recognition networks.  
(b) Remedy: Pair option-expansion (education, legal rights) with *narrative platforms*—radio dramas, women’s councils, peer discussion—so that beneficiaries can articulate and contest inherited desires.  
(c) Respectful Paternalism: Interventions are justified not because the content is wrong per se but because the autonomy conditions are structurally unachievable without help. Temporal limits on intervention follow: once recognition conditions obtain, coercive paternalism loses its warrant.

12. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences trace a deep fault-line in theories of autonomy. Procedural endorsement models are too internal, content models too moralistic, pure causal models not relational enough. A process-relational account, blending historical scrutiny with current recognitional standing, best captures why—and when—adapted desires under oppression fail to be fully our own.  

It also restores hope. For the prisoner who learns to love the yard, or the child bride who learns to demand more, liberation is not forced from outside but catalyzed when social conditions enable her to *see* her wanting as historically conditioned and still open to revision. Autonomy, on this view, is not a static property of isolated minds but an achievement of persons in just relations over time.

Adaptive Preferences and the Eclipse of Autonomy  
                                           – Why History, Not Mere Hierarchy, Matters –  

1. Setting the Problem  
In the mid-1970s Amartya Sen interviewed famine-stricken widows in rural Bengal. Asked whether they suffered, many answered, “Not really; I have grown used to it.” A decade later, Martha Nussbaum met women in Rajasthan who declared they did not “need” literacy and that eating last, after the men, was “only natural.” Such cases have become canonical in debates about adaptive preference formation. They provoke a double reaction: on the one hand, what the women say looks like a genuine expression of their own agency; on the other, we are reluctant to treat their acceptance of deprivation as fully autonomous. What exactly is missing?

A preference is “adaptive” when it is shaped to fit a restricted choice set—often one structured by poverty or oppression. The puzzle is to articulate why these preferences are autonomy-defective without disrespecting the agents themselves. Does the problem lie in the way the agents *endorse* these desires (subjectivist accounts), in the *content* of what they prefer (objective-list or perfectionist accounts), or in the *history* of how the preference came about?

Thesis  
The autonomy deficit characteristic of adaptive preferences is best explained by a *historical-relational* account: a preference is non-autonomous to the extent that it originates in social processes that deny the agent equal standing and foreclose imaginative access to alternatives. Subjectivist “endorsement” and purely content-based yardsticks mislocate the deficit. Autonomy’s enemy is not just hierarchical misalignment nor objectionable content but a deformation in the *social etiology* of desire. I defend this view in four steps:  

1. Clarify what we should demand of an autonomy-grounding preference.  
2. Show why Frankfurt-style hierarchies cannot diagnose adaptive deficits.  
3. Argue that content-based tests collapse autonomy into morality and overreach.  
4. Develop a historically sensitive criterion that withstands key objections and explains the intuitive data.  

2. Autonomy and the Architecture of Preference  
Call a preference P *fully autonomous* when the agent could continue to endorse P across contexts in which (i) she is adequately informed, (ii) she enjoys social conditions of equal respect, and (iii) she can vividly envisage live alternatives. These conditions are counterfactual—they need not obtain empirically—but they function as a normative filter. What adaptive preferences typically lack is (iii): structural constraints shrink the imaginative horizon, so the preference is born in motivational penury. Note that this is a historical diagnosis: the preference’s genealogy traverses unjust pathways.

3. The Subjectivist (Hierarchy-of-Desire) Account  
On Harry Frankfurt’s influential model, a desire is autonomous if the agent *wholeheartedly* endorses it at a higher order. If the Rajasthan woman reflectively affirms that she *wants* to eat last, Frankfurt must count her preference fully her own. The problem is twofold.

3.1 The Plasticity Objection  
Endorsement is itself malleable. Socialization can shape not only first-order desires (to eat last) but also second-order volitions (wanting to want to eat last). A hierarchy of desires, no matter how many levels deep, can be colonized by background power structures. The hierarchy model therefore cannot distinguish between endorsement that expresses genuine self-authorship and endorsement that is the result of adaptive internalization.

3.2 The Factivity Gap  
Even if wholeheartedness signals subjective satisfaction, autonomy also has an *intersubjective* dimension: it matters whether others had the standing to coerce, manipulate, or marginalize the agent during preference formation. Frankfurt’s model, laser-focused on inner endorsement, brackets that dimension and so misses why oppression, rather than mere causal influence, is autonomy-undermining.

Attempts to patch Frankfurt with “procedural” enhancements—requiring e.g. that reflection be free of coercion—still fall short because subtle social pressures are neither episodic nor explicit. They function as background *structural injustices* that shape what the agent can even imagine as worthy. Subjectivism, in short, is too internal and too synchronic.

4. The Content-Based Account  
Some philosophers, often those sympathetic to perfectionist or objective-list theories of welfare, locate the deficit in *what* the agents prefer. A preference for illiteracy supposedly fails an objective test: literacy is just *good* for humans. If the agent wants the bad, something must be amiss in her agency.

4.1 Autonomy versus Morality  
But autonomy is a procedural notion; it concerns who authors a desire, not whether the desire’s object is good. People may autonomously choose dangerous mountain climbs or morally dubious careers. Conversely, an oppressed person might adaptively prefer a *good* such as modest schooling (better than nothing) while renouncing higher education. The content test thus misclassifies many cases.

4.2 Paternalism and Epistemic Hubris  
Content-tests empower third parties to override stated preferences whenever they conflict with the evaluator’s value set. That rings paternalistic, especially across cultural divides. Moreover, content does not explain *why* adaptive preferences cluster around the local constraints; it merely marks them as bad.

4.3 The “Bad Content, Intact Autonomy” Data  
Imagine a sexist professor who autonomously prefers to hire men despite knowing it is unjust; or a thrill-seeker who wants self-harm. These agents are blameworthy but still acting from their own lights. So bad content cannot be sufficient for autonomy failure. The real deficit in adaptive cases must lie elsewhere.

5. Historical-Relational Accounts  
Historical accounts shift focus from endorsement and content to genealogy. A preference is autonomous only if it arises through a history that leaves the agent *answerable* to herself under conditions of equal respect. The locus classicus is Diana Meyers’s “autonomous self” and Marina Oshana’s *relational autonomy*. The idea has two components:

• Etiology: The causal path by which the preference formed must be free of domination, manipulation, or deprivation that cripples imaginative agency.  
• Relational Meaning: The social meaning attached to holding that preference must not signify the agent’s lesser status.

5.1 Explaining the Canonical Cases  
Returning to Sen’s widows: their history involves entrenched gender norms, widow shaming, and food scarcity. The preference “I don’t need more” can be traced to systematic deprivation that narrowed their horizons. On the relational-historical view, this genealogy suffices to mark their preference non-autonomous even though the widows may sincerely endorse it and even though “eating more” is morally permissible content.

5.2 Avoiding Paternalism  
Unlike the content view, the historical test does not treat external evaluators’ substantive values as decisive. It asks: did the agent herself have a credible opportunity to *discover* and *appraise* alternatives? If yes, her preference stands, however odd. If not, the preference is pro tanto suspect. This retains respect for diversity while critiquing injustice.

5.3 Granularity and Comparative Judgments  
The historical account can register degrees of autonomy. A preference shaped in moderate cultural pressure may be somewhat adaptive but still largely self-authored; one born of violent coercion marks a deeper deficit. Subjectivist and content-based models are cruder.

6. A Diagnosis: Imaginative Erosion  
I propose refining the historical view with the notion of *imaginative erosion*. An agent suffers imaginative erosion when structural constraints make salient options literally *unthinkable* or *unrepresentable* as live possibilities. The erosion can be:

a) Informational (lack of exposure),  
b) Evaluative (norms that stigmatize alternative aspirations),  
c) Affective (emotional penalties such as shame for deviating).

Adaptive preferences are those that crystallize within such eroded imaginative landscapes. This diagnosis explains why they feel less than fully autonomous: the preference formation process bypasses the agent’s capacity to evaluate *real* options. Autonomy, after all, is self-rule in the space of reasons, not merely within the cage of given options.

7. The Counterfactual Respect Test  
To operationalize the idea, consider: *Would the agent, under conditions of social respect and access to information, foreseeably endorse a substantively wider set of options?* If yes, her present preference is marked by a deficit. Crucially, we need not know the exact alternative she would choose; only that the unjust history foreclosed viable deliberation. This counters the standard objection that historical accounts require impossible knowledge of hypothetical selves.

8. Objections and Replies  
Objection 1: “All preferences have histories; drawing the line is arbitrary.”  
Reply: True, influence is ubiquitous. The relevant distinction is between influence that merely *persuades* and influence that *arbitrarily privileges* certain options by denying the agent equal standing. The criterion is *social justice*, not causal purity.

Objection 2: “Your view infantilizes oppressed agents by second-guessing their choices.”  
Reply: The historical test does not invalidate choices but diagnoses the injustice that shaped them. Recognizing how power deforms preference is a step toward expanding agency, not overriding it. Moreover, the counterfactual respect test is *agent-relative*: it asks what the very same person might want if accorded equal status, not what outsiders think she should want.

Objection 3: “How do we measure ‘imaginative access’ without speculation?”  
Reply: We can examine empirical markers: literacy rates, media exposure, mobility, reported awareness of alternatives, and qualitative interviews. While imperfect, these are no more speculative than assessments of competence in medical consent or of coercion in contract law.

9. Comparative Payoff  
Subjectivist models get wrong-way results in paradigm cases: wholehearted adaptive preferences pass, but we think them autonomy-defective. Content models mistake autonomy for morality and generate both false positives (autonomous but immoral) and negatives (morally good but non-autonomous). Historical-relational analysis neither collapses the concepts nor ignores power. It predicts precisely the cases that trouble us and does so without paternalistic overreach.

10. Epilogue: Autonomy as a Social Achievement  
Adaptive preferences teach a larger lesson: autonomy is not a predicate we ascribe to isolated moments of choice but a *temporally extended* and *socially scaffolded* achievement. To secure it, societies must cultivate material resources, dismantle oppressive norms, and widen imaginative horizons. When minds adapt to cages, the failure is not in endorsement or content but in the history that built the cage and erased its bars from view.

1. Introduction: the riddle of cheerful deprivation  

A woman in a drought-prone village reports that she “never really wanted” to attend school. Asked why, she explains that walking four hours each day to collect water for her family “makes her feel useful,” whereas schooling is “a luxury for city girls.” Her preference is neither coerced in the familiar sense (no one is holding a gun to her head) nor obviously irrational (fetching water is indeed necessary). Yet many of us hesitate to treat her preference as fully her own, because it was formed in response to the very background deprivation we find objectionable. Such cases are paradigms of *adaptive preference formation*: people come to prefer what is feasible, or even to love the chains that bind them.  

The question is how best to diagnose the resulting *autonomy deficit*. Three families of accounts compete:

• Subjectivist or procedural theories, exemplified by Frankfurt, locate autonomy in internal endorsement of first-order desires by “higher-order” desires.  
• Content-based theories judge autonomy by the substantive worth of what is preferred: autonomy is undermined when one wants things that are bad, degrading, or contrary to human flourishing.  
• Historical (or relational-etiological) theories tie autonomy to the causal pathway by which the preference was formed: a preference is autonomous only if it is not the product of certain distorting forces such as indoctrination or oppressive socialization.

My thesis is threefold. (i) Purely subjectivist accounts fail because oppressive environments can shape second-order volitions as easily as first-order ones; they mistake internal coherence for self-authorship. (ii) Purely content-based accounts succeed in tracking many autonomy deficits but do so for the wrong reason; they risk collapsing autonomy into well-being and cannot explain why some harmful preferences (e.g., demanding military training) *do* seem autonomous. (iii) A refined historical account, informed by a *counterfactual resilience* test—would the agent retain the preference under suitably expanded options?—best captures what adaptive preferences lack. Such an account respects plurality of values while illuminating the specific way oppression compromises self-direction.

To defend this thesis I proceed as follows. Section 2 disentangles adaptive preferences from mere prudential adjustment. Section 3 critiques hierarchical endorsement theories. Section 4 assesses substantive-goodness views. Section 5 develops my historical-resilience proposal and shows how it handles difficult cases. Section 6 replies to objections concerning paternalism, causal over-determination, and the ubiquity of social influence. Section 7 concludes by sketching implications for policy and for the ethics of respect.

2. What exactly is an adaptive preference?  

Not every preference shaped by feasibility constraints is suspect; after all, learning to like lentils when meat is scarce can be a rational, autonomy-preserving adjustment. We need a sharper characterization. Let us call a preference *cheerfully depriving* when (a) it arises in response to a background deprivation or domination, and (b) it sustains or rationalizes that very condition. Unequal circumstances are not merely accommodated; they are embraced. It is in such “cheerful deprivation” cases—think of slaves who “love their chains,” or women who “naturally” prefer subservient domestic roles—that the autonomy worry bites.  

Because the phenomenon is relational (it presupposes a social structure that constrains options) and diachronic (formation over time), any adequate theory of autonomy must incorporate those dimensions.

3. The limits of hierarchical endorsement  

Harry Frankfurt’s celebrated model holds that autonomy (or, strictly, *freedom of the will*) consists in having higher-order volitions that identify with one’s first-order desires. An agent is unfree when she *acts* on a desire she does not *want* to be effective (e.g., the unwilling addict). At first glance, this seems promising: adaptive preferences might lack second-order endorsement. Yet the happy villager does not merely fetch water; she explicitly *endorses* that preference—“I never wanted school.” Frankfurt’s account therefore counts the preference as autonomous.

Could Frankfurtians salvage the view by adding richer procedural conditions—say, requirements of *reflective equilibrium* or *informed deliberation*? Unfortunately, oppressive contexts can colonize those very procedures. Studies in social psychology and feminist epistemology show that sustained exposure to limited opportunities sculpts not only first-order desires but also the criteria by which agents evaluate those desires. A girl who has never seen women run businesses may find her reflective equilibrium satisfied by a domestic ideal. The problem is not that she fails to reflect; it is that the raw materials of reflection are themselves filtered.  

Thus, hierarchical endorsement is structurally blind to *endogenous preference formation*: it treats the internal hierarchy as sui generis rather than as the downstream product of social power. In short, the model confuses *coherent self-organization* with *self-creation*.

4. Content-based shortcuts and their costs  

Martha Nussbaum and other “objective goods” theorists maintain that some life activities—political participation, bodily health, play—are constitutive of human flourishing. When someone prefers options inconsistent with those capabilities, the preference is non-autonomous. This neatly explains our intuition about the cheerful water-carrier: her preference undercuts the capability for education.  

Yet the very neatness is suspicious. First, the account is *over-inclusive*: a soldier who autonomously chooses a perilous mission sacrifices health but is hardly less self-governing. Second, it is *under-diagnostic*: it does not tell us whether the autonomy deficit stems from the content of the preference per se or from how that preference came about. If the water-carrier inherited vast wealth tomorrow and still disliked school, we might continue to find her preference odd but no longer autonomy-deficient. Content alone cannot pick out that difference.  

Third, equating autonomy with objective flourishing blurs two distinct moral ideas: *self-direction* and *well-being*. Disagreement about the good life is endemic; a liberal theory of autonomy should not adjudicate it ex ante. Otherwise, autonomy becomes the hostage of perfectionism.

5. A historical-relational account with a counterfactual twist  

The historical family of theories begins with an appealing thought: what matters is whether the preference bears the right kind of causal relation to the agent’s exercise of capacities for reflection and choice. Inituitively, a desire hypnotically implanted is not mine, however passionately I feel it. But which causal histories disqualify?  

Proposals range from “non-coercive upbringing” (Mele) to “absence of illegitimate social pressures” (Oshana). These are either too narrow (they neglect subtle forms of domination) or too vague (which social pressures are illegitimate?). I propose the following refinement.

H1. Etiological Independence Condition  
A preference P is non-autonomous for agent A if P would be unlikely to arise, and unlikely to persist, under a counterfactually expanded set of feasible options in which the oppressive constraint C is removed and A has minimally adequate information and deliberative time.

H2. Social Situatedness Clause  
The relevant counterfactual holding-fixed set includes A’s enduring values, relationships, and cultural commitments *except* those straightforwardly traceable to C.

The idea of *counterfactual resilience* captures why the preference to fetch water is suspect: absent the deprivation (if potable water were accessible and schooling feasible) the woman herself would probably not endorse it. By contrast, a devout monk’s preference for asceticism may well survive an expansion of options; therefore it is plausibly autonomous even though it diminishes certain capabilities.  

Notice three virtues of this test.  

a) It is procedural rather than substantive; it focuses on how the preference would fare under better conditions, not on whether the object of desire is objectively good.  

b) It need not deny the causal ubiquity of social influence—after all, *every* preference has a history—but only disqualifies those histories that are *opprimenda causa sui*, preferences that owe their existence to a harm they help normalize.  

c) It aligns with political intuitions about justice: removing oppressive structures is the morally appropriate response, rather than simply disregarding the agent’s professed wishes.

6. Hard cases and comparative advantages  

Consider three scenarios:

Case 1: Foot-binding in Qing-era China. Millions of women professed pride in bound feet, taking them as marks of beauty and status. When the practice was outlawed and social pressures lifted, the preference swiftly collapsed. Historical-resilience labels it non-autonomous; hierarchical endorsement cannot; content-based views can but only at the cost of ranking beauty goals as non-autonomous tout court.

Case 2: The secular ascetic. A philosophy graduate, after reading Epictetus, freely chooses a life of frugality, rejecting consumerism. Clamped behind his choice is a history of Western capitalism and personal experiences of disgust at consumer excess—structural influences, to be sure. Yet under expanded options (say, a universal basic income) his preference remains steadfast. Historical-resilience judges it autonomous even though it restricts material well-being; content-based approaches might uneasily concur, but only by conceding that capability losses can be autonomously chosen.

Case 3: The “Pink-collar pragmatist.” Raised in a patriarchal society, a woman happily pursues secretarial work, finding comfort in the nurturing office culture. She admits that if opportunities were equal she “might have tried law,” but insists she is currently content. Counterfactual resilience flags a deficit: the preference would likely shift under egalitarian conditions. Yet the diagnosis is proportional: her autonomy is compromised *as to occupational aspirations*, not across the board.

These comparisons indicate that the historical-resilience model tracks our intuitions more finely and avoids the false positives and negatives endemic to the alternatives.

7. Objections and replies  

Objection 1: “Paternalism redux.” If the state or NGO judges a preference non-autonomous by your counterfactual test, may it override the agent’s expressed wishes? Reply: The test merely diagnoses autonomy; justificatory work remains for a theory of *legitimate interference*. One plausible principle is the *least restrictive empowerment* rule: one may offer expanded options and information but must ultimately defer to the agent’s second-order judgement within the new landscape. On this view, building local wells and offering scholarships is permissible; forcing the woman to attend school is not.

Objection 2: “Infinite regress of influences.” Every preference traces back to some constraint; why privilege some constraints (oppressive) over others (e.g., scarcity of tropical fruit in Scandinavia)? Reply: The Social Situatedness Clause isolates constraints that are (i) the product of human injustice, not natural circumstance; and (ii) sustain asymmetric power relations. Scarcity of mangoes is unfortunate but not a domination structure. Admittedly borderline cases remain, but the distinction is workable and morally salient.

Objection 3: “Stability under expanded options could be due to adaptive preference *inertia*.” The woman might keep preferring domesticity simply because habit is sticky. Does historical-resilience misclassify such stubborn preferences as autonomous? Two replies. (a) Stickiness itself can be oppressive residue; we must examine whether habit persistence counts as dependence on C. (b) Autonomy is scalar. A sticky but revisable preference may exhibit partial autonomy; policies can respect it while facilitating revisability (e.g., adult education programs).

8. Relationship to feminist and psycho-social literature  

The counterfactual-resilience account resonates with Serene Khader’s proposal that adaptive preferences are those one would not have formed “absent deprivation,” but it goes further by specifying the modal test and adding the persistence condition. It also integrates insights from social psychology on *learned helplessness* and from analytic metaphysics on counterfactual causation (Lewis, Woodward). By treating autonomy as *robust* to the removal of dominating causes, we borrow the virtue epistemology idea of *safety* and *sensitivity* and apply it to practical preference.

9. Normative payoff: respect without romanticization  

One normative anxiety surrounding adaptive preferences is the tension between respecting agents’ declared values and refusing to ratify oppressive structures. The historical-resilience test allows us to say both: “We acknowledge your current preference; nevertheless we have reason to suspect that its grip over you depends on circumstances we are committed to changing.” That dual stance grounds policies of *option-expansion* rather than *option-substitution*.

10. Conclusion  

Adaptive preferences expose a fault line in autonomy theory: the need to explain how background power shapes not only what we choose but *what we want to choose*. Subjectivist endorsement theories mislocate the problem inside the agent’s reflective hierarchy, whereas content-based theories externalize it to objective lists of goods. Both miss the specific *etiological dependency* that adaptive preferences manifest.

A historical-relational account, sharpened by a counterfactual resilience condition, explains why preferences cultivated by oppression are not fully ours: they are motivational scaffolds that would crumble were the oppression lifted. This explanation respects cultural pluralism, avoids collapsing autonomy into well-being, and provides nuanced guidance for social intervention.

If autonomy is ultimately about being the ongoing author of one’s life, the authorial voice must remain audible when the background noise of domination is dialed down. Where the voice fades with the noise, we have located an autonomy deficit—one that theory must name and justice must rectify.

Adaptive Preferences and the Anatomy of Autonomy
                                                   -------------------------------------------------

1. Setting the Puzzle  
The literature on *adaptive preferences* begins with an everyday observation: when our option set shrinks, what we want often shifts to fit the new menu. The fox, unable to reach the grapes, decides they were probably sour anyway; a child growing up in a desert comes genuinely to prefer water to winter sports; a woman in a patriarchal village comes to value early marriage and obedience. In each case what is preferred is not grudgingly accepted as second‐best; it is wholeheartedly endorsed. Yet these endorsements strike many philosophers, activists, and policy-makers as *less than fully autonomous*. Why?

Autonomy talk here is not merely diagnostic; it does moral work. If the preferences really *are* autonomous, paternalistic interventions that ignore them are presumptively disrespectful. If they are not, refusal to take them at face value may be warranted. Getting the autonomy story right therefore matters for everything from development ethics to medical consent.  

The philosophical challenge is to explain the deficit without sliding into either (i) a rigid internalism that counts any endorsed desire as autonomous simply because it is endorsed, or (ii) an external perfectionism that declares certain lives sub-optimal regardless of what the agent thinks. Three broad families of views dominate the debate.

• Subjectivist or *procedural* accounts (e.g. Harry Frankfurt, Gerald Dworkin) locate autonomy in the agent’s higher-order endorsement of her first-order desires.  
• Content-based or *substantive* accounts (e.g. Martha Nussbaum, some perfectionist liberals) hold that autonomy requires wanting the right kinds of things.  
• Historical or *process* accounts (e.g. Diana Meyers, Marina Oshana, John Christman) focus on *how* the preference was produced—particularly whether it arose through non-manipulative pathways that preserve the agent’s critical capacities.

My thesis is that none of these families by itself explains what is troubling about adaptive preferences under oppression. The best explanation is *relational-historical*: autonomy is undermined when a preference is the product of unjust social power that (i) forecloses viable alternatives and (ii) distorts the agent’s deliberative field in ways she would reject under conditions of equal respect. A hierarchical model that looks only at psychological endorsement misses the structural constraint; a content model that looks only at what is preferred risks moralism; a purely historical model that neglects the *relational wrong* loses the normative anchor needed to say why some causal histories but not others spoil autonomy. By integrating the historical focus on processes with a relational focus on power, we can diagnose the autonomy deficit, respect agency, and avoid paternalism.

The remainder of the paper defends that claim in six steps.

2. Why Procedural Endorsement Is Too Thin  
Frankfurt’s influential view makes autonomy a matter of inner architecture: a desire is fully one’s own when endorsed by a volitional second order. Adaptive preferences often *pass* this test. The woman who prefers early marriage may sincerely approve of her preference; the ex-convict who “loves” the routine of prison may identify with that love.  

Two moves have been made to save the procedural picture.

2.1. Higher-Order Defection  
Perhaps the oppressed agent *would* reject the preference on further reflection. But Frankfurt already allows for an endless regression: as long as endorsement stabilises at some level, the desire is autonomous. A Shaker who reflectively embraces celibacy to honour God counts as autonomous even if outsiders find the preference bizarre. The challenge is that many adaptive preferences remain stable despite extensive introspection.

2.2. Coercion and Manipulation Clauses  
Gerald Dworkin amends the view: autonomy requires that the process of preference formation be free from coercion, persuasion, or manipulation. However, adaptive preferences rarely arise from *explicit* coercion; they grow slowly through cultural socialisation, economic necessity, structural violence. These background forces do not fit the paradigm of a manipulator with the wrong intentions, so the Dworkinian clause fails to trigger.

The deeper problem is conceptual. Procedural internalism treats the agent as a self-contained chooser encased in a neutral environment. Oppression, by contrast, operates *through* the agent’s motivational system—by shaping what seems feasible, valuable, even thinkable. The fox’s sour-grape strategy is procedurally impeccable; what it lacks is *fit* with a wider sphere of unforced possibility. The notion of a merely “internal” endorsement is therefore too narrow to register the harm.

3. Why Substantive Content Is Too Blunt  
Substantive theorists circumvent the prior difficulty by imposing content constraints: to be autonomous, one must prefer goods on an “objective list” (Nussbaum), or ends that realise one’s capacities for rational and emotional development (Raz). Since adaptive preferences often aim low—sometimes disastrously low—they will automatically flunk.  

The gains in explanatory power are immediate. We can say the oppressed woman’s compliance is heteronomous because it frustrates capability for practical reason and affiliation. But the costs are serious.

3.1. Value Pluralism  
People autonomously pursue ends—eccentric, ascetic, or merely ordinary—that fall outside any plausible master list. A monk’s vow of silence; an athlete’s obsession with ultramarathons; a coder’s single‐minded drive to optimise an esoteric algorithm. None fits the perfectionist template, yet each can be the product of robust self-authorship.

3.2. Paternalistic Drift  
If evaluators decide ex ante what counts as a worthy life, they risk substituting their own ideals for the agent’s. A development economist who dismisses a nomad’s preference for pastoral life as “adaptive” because GDP per capita stays low enacts the very arrogance autonomy theory was meant to resist.

3.3. The Wrong Kind of Explanation  
Finally, content restrictions explain too *much*. They condemn any preference for an “unworthy” object, even where that preference was formed under utterly benign conditions. A consensual BDSM practitioner’s desire for pain is neither oppressive nor adaptive to constraint; yet under strict content tests it might be ruled non-autonomous.

We still need an account that is sensitive to power without collapsing into perfectionism.

4. Historical Accounts: A Step Forward but Not Far Enough  
Historical or process theorists relocate autonomy in the *etiology* of preference. John Christman proposes that a desire is autonomous if it results from a history free of controlling social influences the agent could not, on reflection, accept. Marina Oshana emphasises *social relationships*, arguing that autonomous agents must actually enjoy the external conditions for self-government, not merely imagine them.

These views improve on both procedural and content theories because they (i) recognise time and (ii) look outward towards social context. Yet standard historical accounts underdescribe how *systemic* oppression works. Consider the following:

Example 1: Early Marriage in Rural Rajasthan  
Girls growing up in certain districts of Rajasthan face credible threats—ostracism, violence, economic destitution—if they delay marriage. Over time many come to *value* early marriage as a source of security and familial honour. Crucially, this is not a one-time manipulation; it is a web of social meaning produced by caste norms, dowry laws, and local labour markets her family does not control.

Historical accounts require us to ask: was the preference formed through an alienating influence she would reject on reflection? But reflection itself is already colonised. If one has never seen a woman flourish outside early marriage, the counterfactual in which one “could” reject the norm is cognitively unavailable. Christman acknowledges this danger, yet his proposal remains *individualistic*: it assigns autonomy status case by case based on whether the agent can in principle distance herself from the cause. Oppression’s genius is that it shrinks the imaginative field so distancing *never even occurs*.

We therefore need to build an *explicit relational dimension*—one that ties autonomy to background power gradients and the agent’s standing among others.

5. A Relational-Historical Account  
Here is the core proposal, stated in the form of a *Relational Counterfactual Test*:

Preference P of agent S is substantively autonomous *iff*   
(1) P withstands S’s sustained critical reflection *and*  
(2) P would continue to withstand such reflection in a realistically improved social world W in which:  
    (a) S enjoys secure access to a meaningful array of options not shaped by unjust power relations that systematically exclude or stigmatise, and  
    (b) S’s deliberation is not distorted by social norms that deny her equal moral status.

Clause (1) preserves the procedural insight: what matters partly is endorsement. Clause (2) incorporates history and structure: we ask whether the causal pathway to P relies on unjust power such that, once those forces are lifted, the preference would likely dissolve.

Several features merit attention.

5.1. Power, Not Content, Does the Normative Work  
We do not condemn P because it is “objectively bad” but because its *dependence* on unjust power robs it of authority. This both respects pluralism and avoids perfectionism.

5.2. The Counterfactual Is Social, Not Ideal  
World W is not a utopia; it is a nearby social arrangement where relevant unjust constraints are removed. For early marriage in Rajasthan, W might include local schools admitting girls, anti-dowry enforcement, and effective policing of gendered violence. We need not imagine limitless resources or wholly transformed traditions—only the absence of the specific oppressions that plausibly caused adaptive uptake.

5.3. Empirical Content and Fallibility  
Because the test is counterfactual and empirical, it is fallible. We must study, often ethnographically, whether similar agents exposed to world W retain P. Sometimes they do. When Bangladeshi garment workers gain independent income, many still endorse purdah norms; when inner-city youth escape poverty, some still prefer hip hop culture over Harvard. Where P survives the test, respect for autonomy requires us to take it at face value.

6. Case Studies Revisited  

6.1. The Stoic Prisoner  
Consider Primo Levi’s account of the prisoner who “loves” the camp routine. Suppose he endorses that love at every higher order. Clause (2) asks whether he would still embrace the routine if the unintended injustice (the camp) disappeared. The obvious answer is no. The preference is thus heteronomous without appealing to value perfectionism; the fault lies in its tethering to genocidal power.

6.2. The Desert Child  
A child raised where snow is mythical prefers water games to skiing. World W removes no oppression, only the geographical barrier. The preference likely persists; it is autonomous. Adaptive change caused by *benign* constraints (climate, local ecology) does not undermine autonomy—an intuitively plausible result.

6.3. Voluntary Ascetic  
A Buddhist monk who renounces sexual activity in a monastery that respects his equal moral status meets both clauses, since W without monastic vows is already available and he remains committed. The view therefore avoids pathologising self-chosen austerity.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Epistemic Inaccessibility  
“How can we know what the agent would prefer in world W?”  
Reply: We cannot *know* with certainty, but social science can provide defeasible evidence: natural experiments, historical analogues, narrative testimony. Policymakers already rely on such evidence in public health and development; autonomy assessment need be no more perfect than risk assessment.

Objection 2: Paternalism Redux  
“Evaluators still decide whether a constraint is ‘unjust’ and thus disqualifying.”  
Reply: All autonomy tests embed normative judgments. The relational view at least makes the judgment explicit and contestable. Moreover, it sidelines perfectionist claims about the good life; only constraints that *deny equal moral status* or exclude options on that basis trigger the autonomy warning.

Objection 3: The Romanticised Oppressed  
“Some agents valorise their oppressed identity—consider the Appalachian miner proud of hard labour.”  
Reply: Pride per se may be autonomous. The test targets preferences whose *existence* depends on the unjust limitation, not mere attachment to a stigmatised identity. If the miner had alternative dignified livelihoods and still cherished the mine, the preference would pass.

8. Policy and Moral Implications  
One virtue of the relational-historical account is its practical guidance. It advises *expanding options first, then listening*. Development interventions should remove oppressive barriers (education, legal reform, health access) and see what people choose. If early marriage rates drop, we know those marriages were not fully autonomous; if they remain stable, respecting them becomes morally required. The approach also informs medical consent: a patient’s refusal of treatment due to misinformation propagated by racist folklore implicates unjust power and may justify paternalistic correction; refusal based on informed religious faith does not.

9. Philosophical Payoffs  
The proposal yields four theoretical dividends.

(i) It reconciles freedom with realism: agents remain authors of their lives, but authorship can be corrupted by background injustice that operates through, not around, their mental states.  
(ii) It re‐locates autonomy within a *relational* egalitarian framework: what matters is whether each person stands as a moral equal, able to shape her good without subordination.  
(iii) It sharpens the distinction between *adaptive* and *adaptive‐but‐benign* preferences—answering Elisabeth Anderson’s call for a non-paternalistic metric.  
(iv) It offers a bridge between analytic and continental insights: by marrying procedural endorsement to critical theory’s emphasis on power, it shows how “ideology” can undermine self-rule without denying subjective attachment.

10. Conclusion  
Adaptive preferences pose a genuine challenge because they reveal autonomy to be a *social achievement*, not a purely psychological state. Subjectivist models see only a willing agent; perfectionist models see only deficient content; historical models see only causal pathways. A relational-historical account synthesises their insights while avoiding their pitfalls. Autonomy, on this view, is preserved when endorsement coexists with equal standing and lost when endorsement is the artefact of oppression. The fox’s grapes would still taste sweet in a world where the vine hung low; the oppressed woman’s deference would evaporate where her opportunities flowered; the monk’s vows would abide. Respecting persons therefore means both *transforming* the background to expose adaptive deformation and *listening* to what preferences endure once justice lets voices speak for themselves.

Imagine a rural woman in a deeply patriarchal community who, when asked about her life goals, says without hesitation that what she most wants is to marry early, bear many sons, and never leave her village. A development worker worries that the woman’s preference is “adaptive”: given grinding poverty, the near-certainty of social ostracism for the unmarried, and a lifetime of messages about women’s proper role, her desire appears to have been shaped by oppressive constraints rather than by open reflection over an ample menu of options. But what exactly is missing? In what sense, if any, is her preference less than fully autonomous?

  Philosophers have offered three principal diagnoses.

1. Subjectivist or procedural accounts (Frankfurt, Dworkin): a preference is autonomous if the agent endorses it upon higher-order reflection, regardless of its content or origin.

2. Content-based accounts (Raz, some feminist perfectionists): a preference is autonomous only if it is for suitably valuable, or at least non-degrading, goods; oppressive preferences fail because the content is morally tainted.

3. Historical or etiological accounts (Mackenzie, Oshana, Superson, Christman): a preference is autonomous only if it was formed through a history that is free of certain kinds of domination, manipulation, or deprivation.

  My thesis is three-part:

A. Purely subjectivist models cannot diagnose the autonomy deficit of adaptive preferences, because endorsement itself can be adaptive; the higher-order desires of oppressed agents are often no less shaped by the constraints than their first-order ones.

B. Purely content-based models correctly note that some preferences express internalized oppression, but they misidentify the root of the deficit, confusing moral evaluation with autonomy evaluation and inviting an objectionable paternalism.

C. A refined historical account—one that focuses on distorted “diachronic opportunities for self-construction” rather than on any specific snapshot of endorsement or content—captures the phenomenon most accurately. The relevant deficit lies in the agent’s restricted history of option-encounter and norm-negotiation, not merely in what she currently prefers or in whether she presently endorses it.

  I defend (C) by showing how it can explain three puzzling features of adaptive preferences: their stability, their sincere endorsement, and their link to social power. I then integrate the most compelling insights of the other two families—Frankfurtian self-reflection and Razian concern for self-respect—into a unified historical-relational model. Finally, I reply to three objections: that historical accounts collapse into content-based ones, that they over-intellectualize autonomy, and that the developmental ideal they invoke is culturally imperialist.

I. Why the Subjectivist Picture Breaks Down

  Consider Harry Frankfurt’s influential idea: what matters is whether the agent identifies with her first-order preference. If the woman truly wants early marriage and also wants to want it, then her desire is autonomous; if she has a volitional conflict—e.g., she wishes she could want a university education—then the preference is not fully hers.

  Yet adaptive preferences are precisely puzzling because they are often accompanied by wholehearted, even enthusiastic, endorsement. Jon Elster’s famous example of the fox who concludes the grapes are sour does not presuppose ambivalence. The fox’s second-order desire aligns with the first-order one: he now wants not to want the grapes. The same alignment can hold for oppressed humans, generated by mechanisms such as cognitive dissonance reduction, socialization, and hedonic adaptation. Under severe constraint, endorsing the available—no matter how meagre—serves psychological survival.

  Subjectivists might respond that what matters is not mere endorsement but “authentic” endorsement formed under conditions of adequate information and reflective equilibrium. However, two problems emerge:

1. Circularity. To know whether reflection was “adequate,” we already need an independent standard for what counts as distorting; but identifying the relevant distortions is exactly the problem at stake.

2. Insensitivity to power. The model treats the agent in isolation, ignoring that her reflective capacities themselves have been formed within coercive relationships. If her entire interpretive horizon has been narrowed, demanding that she merely endorse at a higher level will not detect the distortion.

  In short, subjectivism fails because it is present-tense and intrapsychic: it scans the agent’s mind right now but cannot tell whether the mind has been molded under oppression.

II. The Temptation and Trouble of Content-Based Tests

  A second reaction is to look at what the woman prefers. Preferring servitude, foot-binding, or self-immolation (sati) seems autonomy-denying on its face. Joseph Raz suggests that autonomy requires an “adequate range of worthwhile options”; if all the woman’s options are degraded, she cannot be choosing autonomously.

  While intuitively powerful, this strategy conflates two questions:

(a) Is the content morally defective?

(b) Is the preference non-autonomous?

  Answers can diverge. An ascetic monk who freely renounces material goods chooses a life many regard as impoverished; yet if the life results from spiritual reflection and alternative exposure, we hesitate to call it heteronomous. Conversely, a terminally ill patient choosing dignified euthanasia might be making a highly autonomous choice even though the content involves self-annihilation.

  Content tests face three deeper worries.

1. Paternalism. Declaring certain choices non-autonomous because we disapprove of them risks imposing external values. Oppression is not necessary for content to look morally suspect; we must isolate the role of oppression.

2. Cultural myopia. Evaluators inevitably import their own normative frameworks, risking misclassification of culturally unfamiliar but autonomous preferences.

3. False positives. Some oppressive systems harness apparently liberal values—for example, “choice feminism” marketing cosmetic surgery as empowerment. A content test might mistakenly rule such preferences autonomous because they pursue widely approved goods like beauty or success.

  Therefore, while content matters (I return to it later), it cannot be the primary criterion for autonomy.

III. Historical Diagnosis: Distorted Opportunity Sets

  Historical accounts locate the deficit in the process by which the preference was formed. Christopher B. “Chris” Mackenzie stresses that agents need “episodic” self-governance across time; Marina Oshana argues that autonomy demands a social environment that recognizes and supports the agent’s authority. In adaptive contexts, the agent’s history is marred by systematic deprivation: she has never been able to experiment with alternative life plans, never been given permission to evaluate prevailing norms, never encountered role models living differently. These facts, not merely her current mental state, vitiate her authorship.

  I propose the following refined historical criterion:

A preference P is autonomous for agent A at time t only if

1. Counterfactual Encounter: In nearby possible histories where A had minimally decent opportunities to encounter and trial a diversity of valuable options, there exists at least one such history in which A, after critical reflection, still endorses P.

2. Diachronic Competence: A’s capacities for critical reflection, information acquisition, and imaginative projection developed in an environment free from systematic coercion specifically aimed at molding P.

3. Social Non-Domination: A reasonably expects that revising or abandoning P would not trigger severe sanctions (violence, shunning, starvation) from dominant groups.

  These three jointly explain why adaptive preferences lack autonomy.

A. The Counterfactual Encounter clause captures the intuition that what matters is not whether the agent currently endorses the preference but whether she would endorse it after access to real alternatives.

B. Diachronic Competence ensures we track manipulation: even if alternatives were nominally available, indoctrination can hobble the agent’s deliberative powers.

C. Social Non-Domination embeds freedom from coercion across time, recognizing that preferences may be “chosen” only because rejecting them is terrifyingly costly.
