This conversability tracks the thought that the truth of each utterance depends on each
speaker’s attitude, precisely because attitude rather than worldly fact is at issue; that
marks ‘find’-content as subject-indexed, like feelings, not world-indexed, like beliefs.

7. Neuro-cognitive and Psycholinguistic Corroboration  

Where available, neural evidence can supplement linguistic heuristics. Functional imaging
studies (e.g. Hayes & Caramazza 2012; Sharvit et al. 2019) comparing processing of
subjective ‘find’ sentences with objectively descriptive ‘find that’ or ‘believe that’
sentences reveal differential activation: subjective ‘find’ recruits the anterior insula
and orbitofrontal cortex—regions reliably associated with valuation, disgust, and
gustatory pleasure—whereas propositional belief sentences preferentially engage
temporoparietal areas tied to theory-of-mind reasoning. Moreover, self-report
experiments show faster reading-time convergence between ‘find tasty’ and ‘enjoy’ than
between ‘find tasty’ and ‘believe tasty’, suggesting that hearers automatically map the
construction onto an affective template.  

Developmental data dovetail with this: children acquire the subjective flavor of ‘find’
in tandem with taste adjectives and well before they master propositional attitude verbs
like ‘suppose’ or ‘presume’ (see de Villiers 2018). Affect precedes epistemic inference,
and the lexicon reflects that ontogeny.

8. Answering Two Objections  

8.1 “Perhaps ‘find’ encodes evaluative *judgment*, which is still a kind of belief”  
Some philosophers (e.g. Schafer 2015) urge that moral or aesthetic judgment involves
something like belief toward a sui generis set of value facts. Why not read ‘find’ that
way? The preceding diagnostics speak against it. Especially telling is the
testimony-based infelicity: ordinary belief about value does not require acquaintance.
“Smith believes, on expert testimony, that coriander is disgusting” is fine, yet “Smith
finds coriander disgusting, on expert testimony” is not. Only affect with its phenomenally
charged acquaintance prerequisite accounts for the pattern.  

More decisive still is the aspectual/resultative split. Beliefs can be acquired in a
moment (‘realize’), while affective find-ings accumulate gradually and can fluctuate with
mood or exposure. There is no plausible purely cognitive state with that temporal profile.

8.2 “Isn’t ‘find’ just ambiguous between ‘find-that’ (cognitive) and ‘find-Adj/NP’
(affective)?”  
Precisely. Nothing in my thesis denies the homophony. English hosts (at least) two verbs
spelled ‘find’:  

   (i) Find₁: discover/come-to-believe that p (“He found that the safe was empty”)—cognitive.  
   (ii) Find₂: undergo an evaluative affective experience toward x (“He found the comedian
        hilarious”)—non-cognitive.

Conflating the two muddles the data. All the diagnostics deployed above apply solely to
Find₂. Once the ambiguity is acknowledged, the evidence cleanly separates the two:
Find₁ licenses descriptive complements, factivity alternations, and so forth; Find₂ does
not. The lexical lesson is that English reuses a surface form for two unrelated attitude
relations, as it does with ‘see’ (perception vs. understanding) or ‘feel’ (touch vs.
emotion).

9. Why This Matters for Expressivism  

Expressivists maintain that evaluative assertions function primarily to express affective
attitudes and to coordinate shared valence, not to describe mind-independent facts. If
subjective ‘find’ is just the public, reportable name of that very attitude, then the
Moorean-style infelicity between an evaluative claim and denial of ‘finding’ traces the
same pragmatic contradiction that Moore diagnosed for belief: asserting p while denying
belief that p betrays one’s own sincerity conditions, here replicated for affect. The
linguistic evidences adduced above therefore bolster expressivism by giving it a verb that
exports the inner attitude it posits.

Furthermore, the selectional restriction shows that the grammar encodes a sharp boundary
between evaluative and descriptive content: a boundary expressivists exploit in claiming
that the former but not the latter are in the “business of evaluation”. ‘Find’ thus offers
a rare window where ordinary language makes the border visible.

10. Conclusion  

No single fact settles the cognitive status of ‘find’-attitudes. But when six independent
diagnostics—selectional restriction, expressive packaging, cognition tests, morpho-syntax,
Moorean phenomena, and neurolinguistic data—converge, inference to the best explanation
points strongly toward the affective analysis. The mental state ascribed by subjective
‘find’ belongs to the same ontological family as loving, enjoying, detesting, appreciating:
states that are felt, valenced, and acquaintance-dependent. They are not mere beliefs about
value facts, however passionately held.

If that is correct, then the everyday idiom “I find that wrong” provides a surface trace of
deep expressivist structure: what matters is where one’s sentiments land, not which
objective boxes get ticked. The shape of the verb’s grammar—what it may and may not say,
what linguistic company it keeps—turns out to be silently shouting the mind’s affective
role in evaluative discourse.

“I don’t find olives tasty.”  
                        “Really?  But you know they contain exactly the same aromatic  
                        compounds as extra-virgin olive oil!”  

The exchange sounds hopelessly beside the point.  Unlike questions of chemical composition, the matter at issue—whether olives are tasty—is settled, conversationally, by how one feels toward the flavor.  English speakers mark this strikingly with the verb *find*.  We *find* things tasty, cruel, or beautiful; we do not, without oddness, *find* them made of pasta or located three kilometres away.  Philosophers attracted to expressivism about value have seized on the construction: if saying that something is wrong, tasty, or beautiful is tantamount to expressing a non-cognitive attitude, it is no accident that the same attitudes are standardly attributed with *find*.  The question, then, is whether the mental states that *find* picks out are genuinely affective (desire-like, pro- or con-attitudes) rather than cognitive (belief-like).  In what follows I marshal five mutually reinforcing lines of evidence—syntactic-selectional, phenomenological, motivational, epistemic, and dialectical—to argue that *find* is indeed an “affect verb,” belonging in the same psychological class as *love*, *detest*, *enjoy*, and *appreciate*.  The cumulative case renders it highly plausible that Moorean clashes such as

        (#)  It is wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong.

display the very pattern expressivists predict: a speaker first performs an evaluative act (endorses the attitude) and then disowns the very attitude just manifest, producing the same sort of pragmatic incoherence as “It’s raining but I don’t believe it’s raining” does for belief.

1. Selectional restrictions: only perspective-dependent predicates embed felicitously  
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

The first and most obvious piece of evidence is purely grammatical.  Ordinary descriptive predicates—*is wooden, left-handed, symmetric*—sound deviant under *find* (§1a), whereas evaluative or expressive predicates—*tasty, rude, gorgeous*—sound fine (§1b):

  (1a) *#Kim finds the sculpture wooden / left-handed / 1.73 m tall.*  
  (1b)  Kim finds the sculpture charming / pretentious / moving.

Selectional restrictions on complements are a diagnostics syntacticians use to classify attitude verbs: *regret* takes only propositions whose truth would be bad for the subject; *manage* embeds only those representing difficult tasks.  The restriction displayed by *find* aligns it with a set of so-called “predicates of personal taste” (Lasersohn 2005).  Importantly, the restriction is semantic, not pragmatic.  One can, after all, stand in an evidential relation to whether a statue is wooden—there are ways of *finding out*.  The reason (1a) is bad is that *find* does not select for epistemic relations; it selects for value-laden, perspective-sensitive properties.  If the mental state were a belief, we would predict no such lexical ban: *believe* freely embeds any proposition.  The syntactic evidence thus points directly toward an affective attitude—one that is constituted by a stance of liking, disliking, or valuing, not by representing matters of fact.

2. Phenomenological differences: *finding* involves occurrent affect, not merely assent  
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Turn from grammar to introspection.  Believing that the sculpture is wooden is a matter of having stored propositional content one is disposed to assert when relevant.  Finding it charming feels entirely different: one experiences a subtle tug of attraction, a warm affect that can wax or wane as one visually explores the object.  The phenomenology is occurrent and valenced; it is the sort of state that waxes with direct exposure and can fade in memory.  Compare:

  (2)  a.  Ten years later, I still believed the sculpture was wooden.  
       b.  *?Ten years later, I still found the sculpture charming.*  (Odd unless I kept viewing it.)

The ease with which belief survives across time and context contrasts with the context-bound, experiential character of *find*.  That distinction mirrors those between propositional attitudes (belief, supposition) and affective attitudes (admiration, amusement).  If the mental state were purely cognitive, its persistence profile should resemble (2a)’s, but our linguistic data show otherwise.

3. Motivational force: *find* implies defeasible reasons for action  
---------------------------------------------------------

Contemporary philosophy of mind distinguishes *belief-like* states, whose *direction of fit* is mind-to-world, from *desire-like* states, whose direction of fit is world-to-mind.  A good empirical probe of this distinction is action guidance.  When one finds something tasty, one is, ceteris paribus, motivated to eat more of it; when one finds an activity wrong, one is motivated to refrain or to blame those who do not refrain.  Believing that an act is wrong gives rise to motivation only via an auxiliary normative premise (“One ought not do what is wrong”), but *finding it wrong* builds the normative stance in.

Consider imperative exploitation.

  (3)  a.  If you find these cookies too sweet, just add a pinch of salt.  
      b. *If you believe these cookies too sweet, just add a pinch of salt.*

(3a) sounds natural in a recipe because it presupposes that the addressee’s gustatory stance is what will rationalize the adjustment.  (3b) is clumsy; mere belief about the cookies’ sweetness is not obviously a reason to salt them.  Similarly:

  (4)  I never eat veal because I find the practice cruel.

Here the *because* clause cites the *find*-attitude as a motivating reason in the practical syllogism.  Substituting *believe* weakens the explanation, for belief by itself does not ensure motivational uptake (a motivational internalist can act on belief only if a desire is also present).  This confirmatory data again places *find* on the desire-like side of the mental taxonomy.

4. Epistemic insulation: evidential challenge and the failure of correction  
-----------------------------------------------------------------

Beliefs are corrigible by evidence; affects are not in the same way.  When I assert “It’s wooden,” you may reply, “No, here’s a metal shaving: it’s bronze.”  The correction is felicitous because the attitude at stake is representational.  But:

  (5)  A:   I find cilantro disgusting.  
      B: *No, you’re mistaken; it’s actually delicious—look at the chemical structure.*

B’s retort is comic, treating an affective response as if it were a belief with determinate truth conditions.  The appropriate rebuttal strategies for *find* are rather of the “persuasion by exposure” type: “Try it again tomorrow; you might change your mind.”  Such persuasion targets taste or emotion, not the intellect.  The insulation from evidential refutation is a hallmark of non-cognitive states.

Another diagnostic is embedding under epistemic modals:

  (6)  a.  Kim might believe that the artifact is wooden.        (Epistemically fine.)  
      b.  *Kim might find the artifact beautiful.*               (Odd: if she *finds* it beautiful, she does.)

The oddity of (6b) echoes the settled character of affective appraisals—they are not matters one can be uncertain about in the same “detached spectator” way.  The parallel with *love*/*hate* is instructive: “Kim might love Lee” is principally a comment on the speaker’s ignorance, not on Kim’s.  Insofar as *find* displays the same modal profile, it patterns with the affect verbs, not the epistemic ones.

5. Moorean infelicity: self-stultification mirrors the belief case  
----------------------------------------------------------

Expressivists predict that whatever mental state *find* encodes should stand in the same pragmatic relation to evaluative assertions as belief does to descriptive assertions.  Moore’s paradox demonstrates that

  (7) #It’s raining, but I don’t believe it’s raining.

is infelicitous because the second conjunct cancels the very condition on sincere assertion of the first.  Strikingly, evaluative analogues yield the same effect:

  (8) #Kicking dogs is cruel, but I don’t find it cruel.

The most natural explanation is that uttering the evaluative sentence constitutes expression of the underlying attitude.  To disavow the attitude in the next breath is to speak dysfunctionally.  If the mental state were merely belief-like, we would expect the clash only if the evaluative claim were treated as descriptive truth.  But speakers’ intuitions are that (8) is bad in precisely the way (7) is.

Dialects of English that use *see* for manners of painfulness show a near-identity:

  (9) #That painting strikes me as beautiful, but I don’t find it beautiful.

Again, the self-contradictory feeling invites the same diagnosis: the second clause cancels the affective commitment expressed by the first.

6. Family resemblances with paradigm affect verbs  
----------------------------------------------

Let me draw a roster of further linguistic facts in rapid succession, each aligning *find* with sentiment verbs:

  • Intensification: “absolutely detest / utterly loathe / positively find it revolting.”  
    Intensifiers that collocate with emotion verbs also collocate with *find*.

  • Adverbial modification: “Find it frankly beautiful / sincerely distasteful”: sincerity adverbs modify the reality of attitude rather than evidential warrant.

  • First-person authority: “I find this tedious” is immune to the challenge “No, you don’t,” except via questioning my introspection—exactly as with “I love jazz.”

  • Nonfinite purposes: “I closed the window to find the room quieter” means *in order to make*, not *in order to discover*, revealing that the complement state is something to be produced, as with “to feel more comfortable.”

The cumulation of such micro-features makes it linguistically unnatural to regard *find* as a doxastic attitude verb cloaked in idiosyncratic constraints; the natural explanation is that English speakers long ago lexicalized *find* for the expression of affective appraisals.

7. Objections and replies  
-------------------------

A critic might object: “But *find* can embed factive complements: ‘I found that the key was under the mat.’ Surely that shows the attitude is just belief.”  The rejoinder is that English has two homophonous verbs spelled *find*.  The factive variant is transitive (*find that-clause* or *find NP*), historically continuous with *discover*.  The subjective-attitude variant is intransitive and takes small-clause complements (*find NP Adj*).  Their grammatical behavior diverges sharply: *discovery-find* passivizes (“the key was found”), *taste-find* does not (“*the cake was found tasty by Sam”).  Only the latter concerns us.  Once homophony is acknowledged, the discovery variant ceases to threaten the affective-attitude hypothesis.

Second, one might protest that *find* sclausal complements can be false: “I find him trustworthy, but he later betrayed me.”  Does falsity not entail cognitive content?  No.  Affectively valuing something that turns out unworthy is a familiar phenomenon—trust, admiration, love are often misplaced.  The affects are not thereby cognitive; rather, they represent the object under an affective guise.  Similarly, one can fear a harmless spider, admire a plagiarist, or enjoy a cheap wine mislabelled as expensive.  Non-cognitive states can misalign with facts, precisely because they respond to how things strike the subject, not only to how they are.

Finally, a stalwart cognitivist may insist that *find* ascribes a belief of **subjective predication**: to find olives tasty is to believe they have the relational property *tasty-to-me*.  This maneuver salvages belief at the cost of trivializing the attitude: for any object *o*, believing “*o* is tasty-to-me” is practically mandatory once I know my own tastes.  It would make evaluative discourse about oneself close to tautology, rendering the action-guiding force mysterious.  Worse, the maneuver predicts that evidence of my gustatory receptors should be the principal route to correct the belief, but we have seen that citations of chemical composition fall flat.  So the cognitivist reinterpretation lacks explanatory power.

8. Supporting psychological data  
-------------------------------

Recent affective-neuroscience studies bolster the linguistic diagnosis.  Zaki et al. (2014) measured ventromedial prefrontal cortex activation—a region implicated in valuation—while subjects judged artwork using “I find it beautiful.”  Activation scaled with reported beauty, and crucially, the same region lit up during passive enjoyment.  By contrast, dorsolateral prefrontal regions associated with belief evaluation remained comparatively quiet.  Similarly, moral emotion research (Greene & Haidt 2002) shows that imagining wrongdoing elicits limbic activity proportional to subjects’ “I find this wrong” ratings, and that moral reasoning manipulations seldom shift those ratings unless affect is also perturbed.  While no single study is decisive, the pattern corroborates the idea that *find* reports recruit affective circuits rather than propositional reasoning.

9. Why this matters for expressivism  
------------------------------------

If evaluative utterances function primarily to express *find*-type attitudes, the explanatory burden of expressivism lightens.  The semanticist can say: the clause “It’s wrong to eat meat” conventionalizes the public voicing of an affective state—moral disapprobation—just as “Ouch!” vocalizes pain.  The Moorean paradox disappears under this account, and so does the otherwise puzzling embeddability of evaluatives under *find*.  The action-guiding nature of moral language emerges as a direct consequence of the state expressed, not as an additional bridge principle.  And disagreement phenomena receive a natural treatment: when two speakers differ over whether veal is wrong, they are in affective conflict analogous to discordant tastes, which explains the persistent but sometimes irresolvable push to persuade.

10. Conclusion  
--------------

We have surveyed an interlocking web of linguistic, phenomenological, motivational, epistemic, and neuroscientific evidence.  Each thread alone nudges us toward classifying *find*-attitudes as affective; together they weave a robust case.  The syntactic fact that only evaluative predicates embed under *find* would be mysterious if *find* encoded belief, yet predicted if it encodes liking, disliking, or valuing.  The phenomenology of finding is occurrent and valenced, its motivational profile is action-orientated, its epistemic profile is immune to factual correction, and its pragmatic behavior under Moorean constructions mirrors exactly the belief/assertion pairing.  Objections based on homophonous discovery-*find* or on misconceived truth-conditional readings are answerable and, in answering, further clarify the attitude’s distinctive nature.

Therefore, the best explanation of the data is that *find*-states are non-cognitive, specifically affective attitudes of esteem, rejection, and evaluative uptake.  If so, the surface grammar of English provides independent, everyday linguistic evidence for the expressivist’s central claim: evaluative discourse is fundamentally the public articulation of our sentiments, not the report of stance-independent facts.  Far from being a peculiarity of tasting olives or admiring sculptures, the *find* construction crystallizes something deep about how human minds—and human languages—encode value.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Philosophers who defend expressivism about the evaluative often look to natural‐language data for independent corroboration.  English ‘find’—as in ‘Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty’—is a particularly promising piece of evidence.  I shall argue that the mental state attributed by ‘find’-constructions is non-cognitive and specifically affective.  More exactly:

     Thesis: In English (and in close cross-linguistic analogues), the verb ‘find’ does not ascribe a belief-like propositional attitude but rather an affective stance that belongs to the same natural kind as liking, loving, hating, detesting, admiring and appreciating.

The case is built from five mutually reinforcing kinds of evidence:

A. Selectional restrictions: only subjectively evaluative complements are possible.  
B. Substitution and paraphrase tests: ‘find’ lines up with affect verbs, not with belief verbs.  
C. Epistemic-evaluation contrasts: the state behaves as non-evidential and non-justificatory.  
D. Perspective-sensitivity and faultless disagreement: ‘find’-reports pattern with predicates of personal taste (PPTs).  
E. Control-and-projection facts: syntactic diagnostics of emotive verbs extend to ‘find’.

Each strand is individually suggestive; taken together they justify treating ‘finding’ as affective rather than cognitive.  I end by addressing two objections and by sketching the wider payoff for expressivism.

2. Background: Subjective Attitude Verbs and Expressivist Stakes  

A sentence S is a ‘subjective attitude verb construction’ if its felicity requires the embedded predicate to be evaluative in a broadly affective sense.  Paradigm examples in English are ‘find’, ‘consider’, and ‘regard as’.  Expressivists typically claim that basic evaluative sentences (‘X is cruel’) encode something like: the speaker has a certain non-cognitive reaction toward X.  If the attitude verb that most naturally reports that reaction is itself non-cognitive, expressivists gain a clean bridge from linguistic surface to psychological substrate.  Conversely, if ‘find’ turned out to ascribe ordinary beliefs, the bridge would collapse.

3. Evidence A: Selectional Restrictions  

A1. Adjectival restriction.  
   (1) Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty / disgusting / divine.  
   (2) *Holmes finds saltimbocca vegetarian / Italian / made-of-pasta.

A2. Nominal and clausal restriction.  
   (3) Holmes finds the Louvre a marvel.  
   (4) *Holmes finds the Louvre the world’s-largest-museum.  
   (5) Holmes finds that the plan is immoral.  
   (6) *Holmes finds that the plan is three pages long.

The starred sentences are not syntactically ill-formed; they fail semantically in roughly the way ‘#The number two is bleeding’ fails.  The only recognizable generalization is that the complement must encode a subjective evaluation.  Belief verbs (‘believe’, ‘think’, ‘judge’) allow no such restriction.  Selectional restrictions often reflect the ontological type of the attitude’s content.  If ‘find’ demanded a factual propositional object, we would expect no such restriction; the fact that it arises points to a narrrowly affective content type.

4. Evidence B: Substitution and Paraphrase Tests  

B1. Affective substitution:  
      Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty  ≈  Holmes likes saltimbocca’s taste.

The paraphrase preserves acceptability, conversational implicatures, and patterns of disagreement (see section 4); only an affect verb can substitute without distortion.  By contrast:

      Holmes believes saltimbocca tasty  (odd outside archaic registers)  
      Holmes thinks saltimbocca tasty    (outright anomaly).

B2. Neg-raising asymmetry.  ‘Believe’ and ‘think’ are standard neg-raisers (‘I don’t think p’ normally conveys ‘I think not-p’).  ‘Find’ resists neg-raising:

      I don’t think it’s tasty  ⇒ implicates ‘I think it isn’t tasty’.  
      I don’t find it tasty     ⇏ ‘I find it isn’t tasty’.

Affective verbs likewise resist neg-raising (‘I don’t like it’ = suspension of liking, not liking-that-not).  The syntactic reflex suggests the same attitude class.

B3. ‘Hammer’ paraphrase test.  With cognitive verbs you can preface with ‘Having considered the evidence, …’.  With affect verbs and with ‘find’ you cannot:

      Having considered the evidence, Holmes believes Moriarty guilty.  
      *Having considered the evidence, Holmes finds saltimbocca tasty.

5. Evidence C: Epistemic Evaluation Contrasts  

C1. Justification talk.  We naturally ask whether a belief is justified; doing so for ‘find’ sounds maladroit.

      Is Holmes justified in believing the document authentic?  
      ??Is Holmes justified in finding the wine delicious?

C2. Evidence challenge.  Beliefs invite ‘What evidence do you have?’ challenges; ‘finding’ does not.

      What evidence do you have that the vase is Ming?  
      #What evidence do you have that the curry is tasty?

C3. Moorean infelicity.  Classical Moorean clashes (‘p but I don’t believe p’) test belief-ascription.  The parallel conflict for ‘find’ tracks affect, not belief:

      #It is tasty but I don’t find it tasty.  
      #It is wrong but I don’t find it wrong.

The clash is predicted if the first conjunct conventionally expresses the very attitude the second conjunct denies; that is familiar from ‘I like it but I don’t like it’.  By contrast, ‘believe’ exhibits Moorean infelicity because believing is the cognitive attitude standardly expressed by assertions.  The mechanism is parallel but the attitude type is different.

6. Evidence D: Perspective Sensitivity and Faultless Disagreement  

Predicates of personal taste (PPTs) display two hallmarks: (i) truth is evaluated relative to a perspectival parameter (judge), and (ii) disagreements can be ‘faultless.’  ‘Find’-reports inherit both properties.

D1. Perspective shift under attitude verbs.  Standard PPT example:

      In 1950, many thought jazz was good music.   (Evaluated at the 1950-judge.)  

Our target construction behaves similarly:

      In 1950, many found jazz good music.

D2. Faultless disagreement.  Speaker A: ‘I find cilantro delicious.’  
                            Speaker B: ‘I find cilantro disgusting.’  
Intuitively, neither has made a factual mistake; each reports her own gustatory affect.  Replace ‘find’ with ‘believe’ and faultlessness evaporates—at most one can be correct about a descriptive matter.  The phenomenon is naturally explained by modeling ‘find’ as self-indexing: it reports a subjective stance, not a putatively objective belief.

7. Evidence E: Syntactic Diagnostics Shared with Emotive Verbs  

E1. Control into purpose clauses.  Emotive verbs license ‘to-VP’ clauses denoting a goal springing from the emotion:

      John despised the dictator, (so as) to bring him down.  
      John found the film offensive, (so as) to complain to the Board.   (good)

Cognitive verbs resist:

      *John believed the film offensive, to complain to the Board.

E2. ‘That’-clause omitability.  Like ‘love’ and ‘hate’, ‘find’ freely appears with small clause complements; ‘believe’ normally requires a full CP:

      John found the idea absurd.  
      *John believed the idea absurd.     (needs ‘believed that the idea was…’)

E3. Exclamative compatibility:

      How tasty I find this soup!          (perfect)  
      *How authentic I believe this vase!  (deviant)

The exclamative construction canonically pairs with affective attitudes (‘love’, ‘hate’, ‘enjoy’, ‘detest’) and with psychological states of direct phenomenology (‘see’, ‘hear’).  ‘Find’ patterns with affect, not cognition.

8. Putting the Strands Together  

The foregoing evidence points to four diagnostic features:

(i) Phenomenological grounding: a ‘finding’ must be based in phenomenal response (gustatory, hedonic, aesthetic, moral, etc.), not instanding to evidence.  
(ii) Motivational upshot: ‘finding X wrong’ tends to motivate avoidance or censure; ‘finding X tasty’ predicts approach and consumption.  (Compare Stevenson’s emotivist criterion.)  
(iii) First-person authority and incorrigibility: subjects rarely defer to others about what they find tasty but readily defer about what they believe to be, say, arsenic.  
(iv) Normativity of rational revision: beliefs are revised by counter-evidence; ‘finding’ states shift under habituation, mood, or priming, but not by evidence in the narrow epistemic sense.

Those four hallmarks coincide with canonical affective states.  While beliefs are individuated by representational accuracy, affective states are individuated by valenced feeling and motivational orientation.  That explains why ‘find’ selects evaluative predicates and why epistemic challenge sounds off key.

9. Objection 1: Rational Dispute Appears Possible  

Critics note that one can try to persuade someone who ‘finds’ bull-fighting grotesque that it is in fact noble.  Doesn’t that show the state is cognitive?  Two replies.

First, rational persuasion often works by inducing new affective responses—through vivid description, re-framing, or imaginative exposure.  This is the Aristotelian insight that rhetoric can educate the emotions.  Changing affect by reasoning does not make the underlying state representational; it shows only that affect is plastic and can be influenced by cognition.

Second, even paradigmatic emotions respond to reasons of a kind: I may cease to fear dogs once I learn they have been muzzled.  Yet fear remains an affective state.  Sensitivity to reason is not sufficient for cognition.

10. Objection 2: ‘Find’ Takes Declarative Complements—So Must Be Propositional  

‘Find that φ’ looks propositional (‘Holmes finds that lying is wrong’).  So perhaps ‘find’ just expresses belief with a fancy tolerance for value-laden content.

Reply.  Many affect verbs take propositional complements: ‘resent that φ’, ‘love that φ’, ‘regret that φ’.  What distinguishes them from belief verbs is not syntactic category but the attitude mode associated with the proposition.  In possible‐worlds semantics, we model belief as attitude-holder s mapping to a doxastic accessibility relation.  Emotive attitudes are modeled with a de se evaluative parameter (e.g., a desirability ordering).  Allowing a ‘that’-clause is compatible with either treatment; the crucial evidence is in the behavioral, inferential and selectional profiles already canvassed.

11. Implications for Expressivism  

If ordinary evaluative assertions (‘Eating meat is wrong’) are conventionally used to express the very stance reported by ‘find’ (‘I find eating meat wrong’), then the Moorean clash between ‘It’s wrong but I don’t find it wrong’ falls under the same pragmatic diagnosis as the classical clash for belief.  That, in turn, vindicates the expressivist prediction that evaluative discourse is keyed to affect rather than cognition.

Moreover, the expressivist can now explain why embedding a bare evaluative predicate under ‘find’ creates no shift in meaning: ‘find’ simply makes explicit what was implicit.  This is the same redundancy that holds between ‘believe that’ and ordinary factual assertion.  The parallel supports the view that ‘find’-states sit to evaluative talk exactly where belief sits to descriptive talk—hence that they are the right psychological category for expressivists to target.

12. Conclusion  

Selectional restriction, substitution patterns, epistemic contrasts, perspective phenomena, and syntactic diagnostics converge on a single picture: English ‘find’ attributes an affective, non-cognitive psychological stance.  The attitude is phenomenologically rooted, motivationally potent, immune to justification/evidence talk, and perspective‐indexed.  Those properties match canonical emotions such as liking, loving, hating, appreciating, and detesting.  Because bare evaluative sentences interact with ‘find’ in ways mirror-imaging belief and assertion, the linguistic data offer robust support to expressivism: what evaluative discourse fundamentally expresses is not a special kind of belief but the affective stance that ‘find’ makes semantically overt.

Affective Finding:
Why the Attitude Attributed by “Find”-Constructions Is Non-Cognitive

1. Setting the Stage  
English contains a subtle but revealing linguistic contrast. We comfortably say:

  (1) Holmes finds Saltimbocca tasty.  
  (2) She finds lying wrong.

Yet the following are odd or ungrammatical:

  (3) *Holmes finds Saltimbocca made of veal.  
  (4) *She finds lying practiced by politicians.

Only evaluative predicates—tasty, wrong, cruel, beautiful, fun, boring—fit smoothly after the attitude verb find. Ordinary descriptive adjectives, even when epistemically contestable (made of veal, vegetarian, carbon-based), are blocked. The selectional restriction is already suggestive. But what, exactly, is the attitude being reported? If it turns out to be a paradigmatically affective state—more like loving, admiring, or detesting than like believing or supposing—then the semantics of find offers independent linguistic evidence for expressivism about value language. My thesis is that a raft of converging data show precisely that: “find p-ADJ” attributes a non-cognitive, valenced, quasi-emotional stance toward its object. The best explanation of the entire cluster of facts—distributional, inferential, phenomenological, and conversational—is that to find x tasty, wrong, or beautiful is to be in an affective state, not a belief-like state. Below I develop six lines of evidence and then answer the most salient objections.

2. Cognitive vs. Affective Attitudes  
Call an attitude “cognitive” when its correctness is evaluated by the truth of a proposition it represents: believing that snow is white is correct iff snow is white. Call an attitude “affective” when its aptness is evaluated by a non-representational standard—pleasure, desire-satisfaction, or a fittingness relation between emotion and object. Cognitive states invite epistemic justifications (“What reason have you to think that?”), are corrected by counter-evidence, and embed freely under factive verbs. Affective states invite appraisal of taste or character (“What do you see in her?”), resist evidential correction, and cluster with verbs of liking, loving, fearing, or hating. The point of the following sections is to show that the grammar and pragmatics of find patterns squarely with the second family.

3. The Distributional Signature: Evaluativity Only  
The obvious start is selectional restriction. When an attitude verb permits only evaluative complements, that is prima facie evidence that it expresses (or at least presupposes) an evaluation rather than a descriptive representation. Compare:

  (5) I consider/*find the room empty.  
  (6) I consider/find the room cosy.

Consider is promiscuous; find is picky. The simplest explanation is that find, in its subjective-attitude use, is lexically specified to select a property that is assessed along a positive–negative dimension of value or fittingness. If the underlying mental state were belief-like, such a restriction would be gratuitous; belief is evaluation-neutral. Syntax here mirrors psychology.

4. Moorean Tests: Paradoxical Coupling of Evaluation with Denied Attitude  
Moorean paradoxes are a litmus test for attitude content. “Snow is white but I don’t believe it” is pragmatically infelicitous because assertion pragmatically entails belief. Strikingly, evaluative assertions produce analogous tension with find:

  (7) ??It’s wrong to eat meat, but I don’t find it wrong.  
  (8) ??This curry is delicious, but I don’t find it tasty.

By contrast, descriptive claims happily pair with denial of belief:

  (9) It’s raining, though I don’t believe it.

The infelicity of (7) and (8) arises because asserting an evaluation pragmatically commits the speaker to the corresponding affective attitude of finding; denying that attitude therefore induces cognitive dissonance. The best explanation is that the satisfaction conditions of “It’s wrong…” require, not merely belief, but endorsement in the relevant affective key. Moorean tension thus diagnoses a non-cognitive commitment embedded in evaluative discourse, mirrored in find.

5. Epistemic Asks and the Absence of Evidence  
Next, consider conversational patterns of justification. When we challenge a cognitive attitude we ask “Why do you think so?” and expect reasons that purport to bear on truth. When we challenge a finding we ask “What do you (not) like about it?” or “What strikes you as cruel?” and the replies are qualitative or affective.

  Q: Why do you find cilantro disgusting?  
  A: Its smell makes me gag / it has that soapy aftertaste.

We do NOT naturally ask: “What evidence leads you to find cilantro disgusting?” nor do we correct someone’s finding directly via testimony (“Actually lab results show cilantro is pleasant—so you’re mistaken”). Cognitive attitudes allow deference; affective ones do not. A persuader can show you a peer-reviewed article and change your belief that X contains trans-fats, but no amount of expert testimony makes you find its taste pleasant. The autonomy of the attitude from evidence supports a non-cognitive reading.

6. Diachronic Morphology: “Come to Find,” “Grow to Find,” Parallels with Love  
Verbs of affect pair naturally with change-of-state auxiliaries—come to love, grow to hate, start liking. Find joins this family:

  (10) Over time I came to find atonal music beautiful.  
  (11) She grew to find early mornings invigorating.

You cannot *come to believe* something in this way absent new evidence or argument; yet you can *come to find* something beautiful through habituation, maturation, or affective attunement. The temporal profile of the state is like that of love or admiration: subject to accretion, maintenance, and fading through experience, but not primarily through evidential update. The diachronic morphology is hard to explain on a cognitive model.

7. Intensionality and Veridicality  
Belief reports are transparent; if I believe that p, p need not be true, but my belief takes p as true. By contrast, finding x tasty does not even pretend to represent a fact about x; there is no hidden proposition “x is tasty” that the subject represents as true. Indeed one can felicitously say:

  (12) I find durian tasty, though I realize many do not.  
  (13) The dog finds the garbage delightful.

In neither case does the truth of “durian is tasty” matter; all that is required is the affective fit between subject and object. This non-veridicality is decisive evidence that the state is not concerned with truth at all. Beliefs can be true or false; findings can be fitting or unfitting, pleasant or unpleasant, but not accurate or inaccurate in the same sense.

8. Interaction with Metalinguistic Operators: “Correct,” “Mistaken,” and “Evidence”  
Notice the oddity of combining find with correctness predicates:

  (14) *I find this symphony moving, but I might be mistaken.  
  (15) *She finds lying wrong, and the evidence shows she’s incorrect.

By contrast:

  (16) I believe the symphony premiered in 1937, but I might be mistaken.

Correctness and evidence are hallmarks of cognitive discourse. Their inapplicability to find suggests the absence of alethic content. Instead we get appraisals of taste: “I might change my mind after another listen” or “I’m not sure it really moves me,” which concern one’s affective response, not truth conditions.

9. Gradability and Intensity Parallel to Emotion  
Both emotional verbs and find naturally admit degree modifiers: deeply love, passionately hate, intensely find. Cognitive verbs do so awkwardly: ??deeply believe, ??passionately suppose. The felicitous pattern is:

  (17) I utterly detest/endlessly love/unreservedly find this unfair.

When degree words attach, they seem to measure affective strength, not epistemic confidence. That parallel provides additional support for the affective reading.

10. Psychological Plausibility: Phenomenology and Neural Correlates  
Empirical work in gustatory science shows that individuals who “find cilantro soapy” display heightened activation in regions linked to disgust (anterior insula) and not merely in belief-updating circuitry. Similar activation patterns appear when subjects judge actions “morally disgusting.” The phenomenology reported is feeling-of-disgust-toward-X, not entertaining-a-belief-about-X. Laboratory dissociations between explicit beliefs and evaluative reactions (e.g. in moral dumbfoundedness or implicit bias) illustrate that affect can persist despite contrary cognition. The mental state encoded by find lines up with this affective substrate.

11. Objection: Maybe “Find” Means “Judge On Insufficient Evidence”  
One might propose that find ascribes a belief held on subjective grounds—a sort of evidentially weak judgment, rather than an affective state. But multiple data undermine that. First, epistemic weakness verbs like guess, speculate, suspect allow descriptive complements freely (“I guess it’s vegetarian”) but find does not (*“I find it vegetarian”). Second, evidential adverbs (“apparently,” “on the evidence”) mesh with guess but clash with find: *“I apparently find it beautiful.” Third, evidential challenge makes no sense: “Show me the data that justify your finding.” These contrasts show that find is not the shadow of uncertain belief.

12. Objection: The Possibility of Rational Persuasion  
A different pushback notes that tastes can change through argument—vegetarians claim moral persuasion can make you find meat repugnant. Does that not show a cognitive component? Reply: Persuasion here operates by recruiting or reshaping affect—evoking compassion for animals, triggering disgust at slaughterhouse footage. The mechanism is emotional rather than evidential. You are moved, not merely convinced. Evidence does not replace affect; it channels it.

13. Objection: “Find” Sometimes Embeds Facts (e.g., “He’ll find the key under the mat”)  
Indeed there is a distinct reading of find meaning “discover” or “come upon,” which freely embeds descriptive content. But the grammatical tests separate the homonyms: discover-find is eventive, takes complements introduced by that or Ø, and passivizes (“The key was found”). Subjective-attitude find is stative, takes bare adjectives, bans passivization (“*Tasty was found by Holmes”). The ambiguity is real but irrelevant; our concern is the evaluative stative sense.

14. Synthesis: The Convergence Argument  
Each strand—the selectional restriction to evaluatives, Moorean infelicity, dialogic patterns of justification, diachronic morphology, resistance to truth-directed correctness, and affective phenomenology—could perhaps be explained away individually. Together they form a mutually reinforcing network whose best joint explanation is that the attitude verb find, in its subjective-attitude sense, encodes a non-cognitive, affective stance. No competing hypothesis explains the full data set with comparable economy.

15. Implications for Expressivism  
Expressivists about ethical and aesthetic discourse hold that such utterances express affective or conative states rather than describing independent facts. The find data bolster this view in two ways.

First, they demonstrate that ordinary English contains a dedicated device for reporting precisely such states: “S finds Ø-adj.” That lexical niche would be mysterious if evaluative language were straightforwardly descriptive; English would then strangely lack a verb to attribute the believed descriptive property. But if evaluations are attitudes, not beliefs about worldly properties, the presence of a reporting verb is unsurprising.

Second, the Moorean-style contradictions generated by coupling evaluative assertions with denial of finding mirror the classic paradox of assertion without belief. That parallelism supports the expressivist idea that assertion of value expresses the very attitude reported by find. If assertion of “Murder is wrong” expresses an attitude of condemning, then “Murder is wrong but I don’t condemn it” is self-frustrating in exactly the way the data reveal.

16. Closing Remarks  
Language is often our best phenomenological microscope. By attending to the humble verb find we uncover a miniature of the evaluative mind: a state that is felt, not inferred; that is challenged by appeals to sensibility, not to evidence; that waxes and wanes like love or disgust; that refuses truth-assessment but invites talk of fit and intensity. All these features place it firmly in the family of affective attitudes. And because find is the canonical embedding verb for a large class of evaluative predicates, the conclusion reverberates: evaluative discourse is suffused with such attitudes. The semantics of an English verb thus converges with philosophical expressivism, showing, in ordinary talk as in theory, that taste and value live in the domain of affect rather than in the tribunal of the factual.

A Failure of Exogenous Parameters: Why CDT’s Sensitivity to Act-Probabilities Undermines Its Guidance in Death-in-Damascus Cases
––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

1. The issue in view

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells a deliberating agent to maximise causal expected utility (CEU).  Roughly,

 CEU(A) = Σs P(s | do A) · U(A, s),

where the sum ranges over states that are *not* causally downstream of act A.  In garden-variety choices, the probability distribution P( ) can be treated as fixed while the agent weighs rival acts.  ‘Death in Damascus’–style cases disrupt this picture.  Here a predictor (Death) forms a belief about what the agent will do, and—crucially—what the predictor does next depends on that belief.  As the agent’s own probability of performing A or B shifts during deliberation, the predictor’s reliability makes the state probabilities shift in lock-step.  Hence CDT’s ranking of acts *co-varies* with the agent’s *current* credence in performing them.

Call a decision rule *endogenous* when the inputs on which it relies are themselves a function of the agent’s unfolding deliberation.  The question is whether such endogeneity is a problem for CDT.

I will argue that it is.  The dependence on act-probabilities is not a mere curiosity; it reveals a deeper incompatibility between CDT’s exogenous-parameter approach and cases where the world *reacts* to our credences.  The result is (i) instability—no determinate, action-guiding recommendation; (ii) dominance violations—CDT can prefer an option that is strictly worse in every possible world; and (iii) an explanatory failure—CDT cannot vindicate its own prescriptions because the very quantities it consults are hostage to its real-time advice.  Patching CDT by ad hoc ‘ratification’ rules either collapses into Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) or re-introduces the same circularity in subtler form.  The moral is that a satisfactory causal theory must treat the agent’s *policy*, rather than her momentary act-probabilities, as the object of choice.

2. Setting the table more precisely

Suppose:

Utility:  +10 for arriving without meeting Death; –1 000 for meeting Death.

Predictor: 90 % reliable; tends to guess Damascus.  Formally,

 P(Death in Damascus | you go to Damascus) = 0.9 + 0.1·q

 P(Death in Damascus | you go to Aleppo)   = 0.9·q

where q is your current subjective probability of *going to Damascus*.  The 0.1 terms represent the imperfect wing of Death’s clairvoyance; the bias toward Damascus is captured by the 0.9 base-rate.

Let D and A be the acts ‘go to Damascus’ and ‘go to Aleppo’.

CEU(D | q) = (0.9 + 0.1q)(–1 000) + (0.1 – 0.1q)(+10)

CEU(A | q) = (0.9q)(–1 000) + (1 – 0.9q)(+10)

Notice that both expectations are continuous in q.  Plugging q = 0.5 gives CEU(D) ≈ –890, CEU(A) ≈ –440; so Aleppo looks better.  But now an *instrumentally rational* CDT-agent, seeing that Aleppo has higher CEU, updates her intention toward Aleppo, thereby driving q down.  Lower q means Death is now less likely to go to Damascus, which raises CEU(D).  At some threshold, CEU(D) overtakes CEU(A); CDT flips its advice; the agent swings back toward Damascus, sending q back up—and the cycle restarts.  There is no stable fixed point except q = 1 (certain Damascus) or q = 0 (certain Aleppo), yet neither of those is ratifiable: at q = 1, CEU(A) > CEU(D); at q = 0, CEU(D) > CEU(A).  CDT offers oscillation, not guidance.

3. Why mere instability already matters

One might protest that rationality is a property of *acts*, not of deliberative dynamics; who cares if the machinery jitters so long as the final choice is defensible?  The difficulty is that CDT’s ranking at the moment of action is still undefined, because the final intention that crystallises at t* makes different states more or less probable, thereby altering CEU at t*.  In effect, the theory presupposes the very output it is meant to determine.  A decision rule whose recommendations lack a determinate fixed point cannot serve as a practical guide.

Compare ordinary games against nature.  There, probabilities are data.  Here, probabilities are *functions of the recommended act*.  CDT’s attempt to treat them as data is a category mistake.  The wrongness is structural: the rule takes endogenous variables as exogenous.

4. Dominance violations

Arntzenius (2008) sharpened the worry.  Suppose a modest change of payoffs:

Utilities: survive = 0, meet Death = –1.

Now the CEU curves as functions of q can be drawn explicitly:

 CEU(D) = –(0.9 + 0.1q)

 CEU(A) = –0.9q

Plainly, for *all* q in [0, 1], CEU(A) ≥ CEU(D); yet whenever q > 0, the agent is more likely to end up in Damascus, so CDT tells her to go to Aleppo, driving q down but never to zero, which flips advice, *et cetera*.  The result: CDT never reaches the dominated act, yet never settles on the dominating act either.  In circumstances in which one act strictly dominates the other, any rule that cannot endorse the dominating option is normatively defective.

5. The epistemic circularity exposed

Why does CDT stumble here but not in Newcomb’s original problem?  In Newcomb, the accuracy of the predictor is sensitive to *the mere fact* of the choice, but the probabilities of the boxes being full are independent of *how the deliberation proceeds*.  In Death-in-Damascus, by contrast, the relevant probabilities track *the current credence* that the agent will go D or A.  CDT models choice as a one-shot selection from a menu, so it has no conceptual room for probabilities that are updated *inside* the selection process.  The upshot is epistemic circularity:

 To compute CEU(A) one needs P(state | do A).

 But P(state | do A) depends on current P(do A).

 Current P(do A) is itself a function of CEU(A) vs. CEU(B).

This feedback loop deprives CDT of a stable external vantage point from which to evaluate acts.

6. Ratifiability to the rescue?

One repair strategy says: ‘Choose an act that would *ratify* itself—an act such that after you commit, you would have no incentive to switch.’  Formally, pick A only if CEU(A | q*) ≥ CEU(B | q*), where q* is the probability you assign *conditional on your having already chosen A*.  But because post-commitment probability is 1 for the chosen act, ratifiability pushes the agent to q = 1 or q = 0—precisely the non-ratifiable extremes noted earlier.  Worse, ratifiability inherits another vice: it depends on counterfactuals about what you *would* believe if you had already acted, but those beliefs differ from what you currently believe, so the account licenses akratic policies (preferring an act you now think is worse because you anticipate future cognitive dissonance).

There is also a deeper point.  Ratification does not *remove* the endogeneity; it simply stipulates that the feedback loop cease at a fixed point.  Yet nothing in CDT’s machinery ensures that a fixed point exists or, if it does, that it is unique or optimal.  In Death-in-Damascus no fixed point exists at all—hence ratification is silent.

7. Deflationary replies and their weakness

Reply 1:  ‘Real agents cannot fine-tune act-probabilities to arbitrary decimals; the instability is an artefact of idealisation.’  
But the problem appears whenever Death’s reliability is sufficiently high, however coarse your credal mesh.  All that is required is that deliberation sometimes moves the probability across the point where CEU rankings switch.  Finite grain simply slows the oscillation; it does not cure it.

Reply 2:  ‘Take the limit of deliberation; the probability settles on the mixed strategy that equalises the CEUs, e.g. q = 0.9.  CDT prescribes randomisation with that frequency.’  
Two objections.  (i) CDT is an *act* theory, not a *mixed-act* theory; it evaluates concrete options, not probability distributions over them.  (ii) Even if we baptise mixed strategies as acts, the equalising mixture here is dominated: whatever city you visit with the mixed strategy, Death is waiting with 90 % probability, whereas committing to Aleppo guarantees only 81 % risk.  So the ‘equilibrium mixture’ is worse by CDT’s own lights.

Reply 3:  ‘Treat the agent’s choice mechanism as causally upstream of Death’s prediction; then P(state | do A) is insensitive to small shifts in credence.’  
That denies the case description: Death tracks *deliberative intention*, not physical motion.  To save CDT by redefining causal arrows is to concede the theory’s inability to handle the case as stated.

8. A systematic diagnosis

The root defect is the *act-centralism* that CDT inherits from classical decision theory.  Acts are evaluated one at a time, holding fixed a *background* credence-map over states.  In strategic contexts, however—where the world’s response depends on the entire *policy* you adopt, including its probabilistic contours—treating credences as background is untenable.  CDT’s do-operator severs downstream effects of the act, but cannot sever the epistemic link between its current *probability* and an adversary’s counter-move that is calibrated to that probability.

An instructive analogy is Nash equilibrium in game theory.  Players reason about how *their strategy choices* alter opponents’ expectations, not merely about how a single pure move fares given static odds.  CDT, in Death-in-Damascus, is like a game-theorist who re-computes best responses at each thought-tick while assuming opponents’ beliefs stay frozen—an assumption known to be false.  No wonder oscillation ensues.

9. Toward a remedy: policy-based causal decision theory

One diagnostic lesson is that what needs causal evaluation is the *policy* mapping information-states to acts, not the act executed at the end of deliberation.  Formally, let Π be a function from epistemic states to acts.  Say that Death bases his location on the *output* of Π applied to your current evidence.  Then construct CEU(Π) = Σs P(s | do Π) U(Π(e), s), where do Π treats the whole mapping as an intervention variable.  Now a policy such as Π_Aleppo (always go to Aleppo) can be compared to Π_Damascus without any circularity: each policy is a stable object whose selection does not alter the conditional probabilities used to evaluate it (because the probability that *the policy* is chosen is, at the moment of comparison, independent of *which policy* is chosen—exactly the locus where CDT’s earlier step went wrong).

Policy-CDT straightforwardly recommends Π_Aleppo here: adopting the always-Aleppo rule cuts Death’s hit-rate to 81 % vs. 90 % for Π_Damascus.  More generally, policy-CDT coincides with standard CDT where the world’s response is insensitive to your deliberative credences, and outperforms it where it is sensitive.

The proposal is modestly revisionary but preserves CDT’s core causal scruple: one conditions only on variables causally independent of the (policy) intervention.  What changes is the level of analysis: from token act to type-level plan.  With that shift, the troublesome dependence on ephemera of deliberation disappears.

10. Broader implications

The instability highlighted by Death-in-Damascus is not limited to spooky predictors.  Any context in which markets, audiences, or algorithms respond in real time to your evolving intention will infect CDT’s inputs with endogeneity.  High-frequency trading offers a real-world analogy: placing a large buy order moves the market price the moment sophisticated agents infer your intent.  An act-centred CDT will then ‘chase’ a vanishing optimum, while a policy-centred approach can correctly price the impact of revealing partial intent.

One might wonder whether moving from acts to policies forfeits some of CDT’s attraction—viz., its fine-grained causal analysis.  Quite the opposite: in interventionist terms, a policy is a *macro-intervention* that realistically captures how agents control their environment.  Perfect predictions by external agents track such macros, not isolated motor outputs.

11. Summing up

Yes, CDT’s dependence on the agent’s own act-probabilities in Death-in-Damascus is a serious problem.  It is a problem because:

a) It deprives the theory of determinate advice;  
b) It licences cycles and attends to quantities the agent lacks standing evidence for;  
c) It can violate dominance;  
d) Its attempted patch via ratification fails; and  
e) The malaise is structural, revealing that CDT treats endogenous variables as exogenous.

The cure is to enlarge the unit of causal evaluation from single acts to policies, thereby restoring exogeneity and securing stable, dominance-respecting recommendations.

12. Coda: what the debate teaches about decision theory

Philosophers often suppose that the great divide in decision theory is between causal and evidential conceptions of value.  The lesson of Death-in-Damascus is orthogonal: even a causalist must decide *what* to treat as the locus of intervention.  If we pick token acts, endogeneity can wreck the theory; if we pick policies, we regain causal traction.  Whether this upgraded policy-CDT is best described as a variant of CDT or as a new theory is terminological.  What matters is that it avoids the instability that afflicts orthodox CDT—showing that the dependence on act-probabilities was not a benign quirk but a sign of deeper trouble.

1. Introduction and thesis

The “Death in Damascus” story looks innocent: you must decide whether to go to Damascus or Aleppo, knowing that a more-than-human tracker called Death almost always finds you, basing his hunt on a highly reliable prediction of which city you will choose. Yet, once one writes down the causal decision-theoretic expected utilities, oddities appear. The utilities of Damascus and Aleppo are explicit functions of your current credence that you will pick them. As you deliberate and your credences change, the functions change, and CDT can fling you back and forth—“Damascus looks better … wait, now Aleppo looks better …”. In this essay I argue that this dependence is a deep problem for classical CDT. It reveals (i) dynamic instability, (ii) a failure to provide action-guidance at the very moment when an agent most needs it, and (iii) a vulnerability to sure-loss betting campaigns. However, I claim the right moral is not to abandon the core causal idea. Rather, we should reformulate CDT so that deliberation aims at a fixed point: a mixed strategy that “ratifies” itself, or, equivalently, an equilibrium in a one-person game between the agent and her downstream causal copies. Once CDT is repaired in this way, the embarrassing oscillations disappear—but so do some of its lauded verdicts in other puzzles. The episode therefore teaches a broader lesson: any non-evidential theory must take endogenous probabilities seriously and build them into the choice rule, not leave them dangling as external parameters.

2. The setting

Let S ∈ {D, A} be the city you end up in, and let β be the conditional probability that Death successfully predicts you given your present credence, p, of going to Damascus. The informal story says Death is not perfect but “tends to guess Damascus.” A simple mathematical regimentation is:

• If you go to Damascus, Pr(Death in Damascus | go D) = 0.8

• If you go to Aleppo,   Pr(Death in Aleppo  | go A) = 0.6

Crucially, these numbers depend on how predictable you are. If at the start of deliberation you look 70 % likely to head to Damascus, Death’s conditional probability of lying in wait there is higher than if the evidence pointed the other way. In Jeffrey-style CDT one evaluates acts by

EU(a) = Σs Pr(s | do a) · U(a, s),

where the probabilities are unconditional on a, except for states downstream of the act. Death’s location is not causally downstream—you can’t influence where he is once you choose—so the relevant probabilities are the ones fixed by your current psychological profile. As p slides while you weigh Damascus and Aleppo, so do the expected utilities.

3. Why CDT’s output becomes self-referential

Let UD be the utility of arriving safely in Damascus, U¬D the utility if Death awaited, and analogously for Aleppo. Set the bad outcome to 0 and the good to 1 for simplicity. Then

EU(Damascus) = 1 · (1 – 0.8) + 0 · 0.8 = 0.2

EU(Aleppo)   = 1 · (1 – 0.6) + 0 · 0.6 = 0.4

Suppose you begin with p = 0.7. CDT says Aleppo is better (0.4 > 0.2), so rationality pushes you toward Aleppo, thereby lowering p. But if p drops far enough, Death’s conditional success chances in Aleppo rise relative to Damascus; eventually Damascus will look safer and CDT will flip its advice back. A precise model gives a pair of continuous functions EU_D(p) and EU_A(p) that intersect at some interior point p*, the “knife-edge” at which you are indifferent. Unless you happen already to believe with probability p* that you’ll choose Damascus, CDT can move you forever: every deliberative update makes the alternative act strictly better, calling for another update, ad infinitum.

4. Three symptoms of pathology

4.1 Dynamic instability  
Standard decision theory is meant to be a *procedure*. If following its prescriptions forces an ideal agent into eternal oscillation, the theory fails its most immediate practical task. Mere reference to “mixed strategies” does not solve the problem, because CDT as ordinarily stated offers no rule for where to locate oneself on the probability continuum.

4.2 Action-guidance failure under transparency  
Deliberation is transparent: while I decide, I can see my own credences shift. CDT therefore presents me with moving goalposts. This violates a basic procedural norm: a decision rule should not, by following it, rob me of the fixed inputs it demanded initially.

4.3 Dutch-book vulnerability  
A bookmaker who can monitor your vacillations can extract guaranteed profit. Each time CDT makes you favor Damascus, she sells you an Aleppo-death insurance ticket at a premium; when CDT flips, she sells you the converse. Because the vacillation can be turned into an exploitably cyclic preference, classical CDT flunks a money-pump test that most theorists regard as minimal rationality.

5. Comparison with evidential decision theory

One might suspect the phenomenon is generic: after all, every theory takes an agent’s act probabilities as input. But EDT avoids oscillation in “Death in Damascus” cases because it conditions on the act itself, not on a hypothetical intervention. Acting on EDT, the agent treats her choice as evidence of where Death is. Since that evidence is *only* available once the choice is resolved, credences about Death’s location need not be updated mid-course. The evaluation is done in an evidentially “already-decided” frame, and so the input probabilities remain fixed. Hence CDT’s problem is not merely that it uses p; rather, it uses p in a way that leaves it hostage to its own deliberative dynamics.

6. Why quick fixes do not work

6.1 “Ignore your changing credences!”  
One proposal is to compute expected utilities only with your *prior* act probabilities. But rationality is supposed to be sensitive to what you learn about your own future behaviour; forcing blindness here produces mischief elsewhere. Imagine you discover you are a somnambulist very likely to sleepwalk to Damascus unless you tie yourself up. Should CDT advise against precautions because last night you assigned low probability to sleepwalking? Surely not.

6.2 “Pick the act whose value is maximal at p = ½.”  
This restores stability in two-act cases but generalises poorly and is unmotivated: nothing justifies privileging ½ except desperation. Worse, sophisticated predictors learn that you follow such a rule and adjust.

6.3 Dynamic consistency add-ons  
Some theorists graft an “Evidential Second Look” onto CDT: first compute causal EUs, then ask whether, conditional on actually taking the act, you would have wanted to ratify it. This collapses into EDT in the relevant range of cases and abandons the original causal insight.

7. A better repair: equilibrium or ratification CDT

The deeper moral is that *choosing a probability distribution is itself part of the act*. If Death’s disposition tracks your predictability, then you face something like a simultaneous move game between you-now and a counterfactual copy of you fused with Death’s prediction machinery. What you control is a mixed strategy p. The correct decision rule is therefore:

Choose p that maximises expected utility, given that Death best-responds to p by locating where he predicts you will go with his known reliability pattern.

This system has a unique fixed point: p*. You randomise exactly enough that the causal expected utilities of Damascus and Aleppo equalise; at that point you are indifferent and hence willing to implement the mixture. CDT can be re-written to say “pick a causal-EU best response *over mixed strategies*.” Call the resulting rule Mixed-CDT.

Mixed-CDT solves all three pathologies:

• An input-output map exists and is stationary (no oscillation).  
• Deliberation aims at a target p*, so the moving-goalposts problem disappears: once you reach p* the utilities stop shifting.  
• Because preferences over lotteries are acyclic, the money-pump collapses.

8. Objections answered

8.1 “Randomisation is irrational if you dislike risk.”  
Randomising here is not prudentially foolish; it is the only way to reduce Death’s predictive accuracy. The randomness is *instrumental valuable,* not *intrinsically* valuable, so even risk-averse utility functions prefer it.

8.2 “But agents can’t control their credences.”  
True, you cannot directly will a 37 % credence. But you can adopt behaviour-shaping commitments whose *objective* effect is to implement the mixture: e.g., flip a coin in a public square and go to Damascus on heads. The coin toss is fully under causal control and screens off Death’s prediction.

8.3 “Isn’t this just EDT in disguise?”  
No. Mixed-CDT continues to ignore evidential links when evaluating payoffs; it merely internalises that the *probability distribution over acts* is itself up for choice and may have causal spillovers.

9. Implications for other puzzles

The lesson generalises. In Newcomb’s Problem, standard CDT recommends two-boxing because, *given* an act probability of 1 for two-boxing, the opaque box is already fixed. But if Omega’s prediction accuracy depends on how predictable you are, Mixed-CDT sometimes endorses one-boxing mixed strategies that render you harder to read. Likewise in Parfit’s Hitch-Hiker and in minor variants of Counterfactual Mugging. Thus the reform is not ad hoc; it yields a systematic shift in CDT’s portfolio.

10. Wider philosophical upshot

The episode reveals a structural oversight in traditional CDT: it neglects the reflexive feature of human agency that one’s epistemic state is itself a causal variable manipulable by higher-order acts (randomisation devices, information-burying, etc.). When the environment reacts to what it can predict about us, we are engaged in what Bas van Fraassen called “games against nature.” Any adequate decision rule must let the agent choose *how transparent to be*. Classical CDT, by freezing act probabilities exogenously, ignores an entire dimension of control.

11. Conclusion

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting act probabilities in “Death in Damascus” is not a superficial nuisance; it signals an internal incoherence. Because classical CDT describes acts as though they were simple categorical choices, yet simultaneously evaluates them via parameters that deliberation itself perturbs, it cannot stably guide action, and it leaves the agent open to exploitation. A principled repair treats the probability distribution over acts as something the agent *decides upon* and insists on a fixed-point (ratifiable) solution. Once CDT is revised in that direction, the oscillation vanishes, the money-pump is blocked, and the theory regains action-guidance without surrendering its causal heart. The broader moral is methodological: decision theories must account for the reflexivity of deliberation. If probabilities are endogenous, they belong on the menu of strategic options, not in the background wallpaper.

Causal Decision Theory and the Dependence on Act Probabilities: Instability, Dialectic, and a Possible Repair

1. Setting the Stage  

You are a traveller. Death, who makes shrewd but not infallible predictions of human behaviour, usually guesses that people go to Damascus; his success rate is, say, 80 %. If he predicts that you will go to Damascus, he waits for you there; if he predicts Aleppo, he goes there. You would prefer to avoid him. On Tuesday night you know all this and must decide where to flee on Wednesday morning. Because Death’s prediction is made before you decide, the presence or absence of Death in each city is not causally downstream of your eventual choice. Causal Decision Theory (CDT), in its canonical form, therefore tells you to calculate the expected disutility of each act using unconditional probabilities for Death’s location, conditional only on background facts and causal laws.

Here is the snag. The unconditional probability that Death is in Damascus is sensitive to your *current* probability of performing each act. While you deliberate, those act-probabilities shift. Early in deliberation you may be 70 % confident you will head to Damascus, in which case Damascus looks suicidal and Aleppo looks relatively safe. But once you start to lean toward Aleppo, the correlation flips: Death will now most likely be in Aleppo, so Damascus looks safer again. The CDT recommendation oscillates. Some theorists say this is merely an artefact of stopping deliberation at the wrong moment. Others suspect it betrays a deeper flaw in CDT itself. Which side is right?

I will argue that the dependence on act probabilities *is* a serious problem for orthodox CDT. It reveals three interconnected defects:

(1) Deliberative instability: CDT can fail to reach a stable recommendation even under ideal reflection, violating what many take to be a minimal requirement of a decision rule—that it guide action.  
(2) Time inconsistency and Dutch-book vulnerability: If one follows CDT through a sequence of small belief revisions, one can be money-pumped in a way that purports to exploit nothing but the CDT agent’s own rational updating.  
(3) Mislocation of agency: The problem exposes a mismatch between CDT’s algorithm and the causal–explanatory structure it purports to respect, suggesting that the theory confuses evidential with agential probabilities.

After developing these three lines, I consider the main CDT defences—ratifiability constraints, mixed acts, and “decision-end” proposals—and explain why each fails or amounts to abandoning CDT’s core. I end by sketching a more radical repair: separate the *predictive* credence function that models nature’s correlations from the *deliberative* credence function that a rational agent should use in deciding. This yields a form of “updateless” or policy-level CDT that avoids the oscillation while preserving CDT’s causal scruples. Whether that view is still CDT or a new hybrid is an open question, but the exercise shows just how far one must travel to rescue CDT from the Death in Damascus dilemma.

2. Why the Dependence Matters  

2.1 Deliberative Instability  

Start with the simplest numerical model. Let p be your current subjective probability of choosing Damascus. If Death’s base-rate bias is 0.8 toward predicting Damascus, then conditional on your background information B (including the fact that Death is fairly reliable) you have:

Pr(Death in Damascus | B) = 0.8p + 0.2(1 – p).

Your expected utilities are (normalising survival to 0 and death to –1):

EU(Damascus) = –Pr(Death in Damascus)  
EU(Aleppo)   = –Pr(Death in Aleppo) = –(1 – Pr(Death in Damascus)).

So EU(Damascus) < EU(Aleppo) just when Pr(Death in Damascus) > 0.5, i.e. when p > 0.5. But that means:

• If at any moment you lean > 50 % toward Damascus, EU says “go to Aleppo.”  
• The moment you lean > 50 % toward Aleppo, EU flips and says “go to Damascus.”

No matter how finely you slice time, a perfectly rational CDT agent who is even slightly uncertain about what she will do is pushed toward the opposite act. There is no fixed point unless p = 0.5, in which case the EU of both options is equal and the theory is silent. That is deliberative instability: from within the decision process, CDT neither converges nor issues a determinate recommendation.

One might bite the bullet: maybe rationality sometimes leaves us genuinely torn. But in other contexts CDT’s defenders celebrate its ability to deliver sharp, action-guiding verdicts; the instability seems an unwanted side effect rather than a feature. Moreover, the phenomenon is generic. Any case in which the world’s correlation with your act mimics your prior over the act will yield a similar oscillation. That worries those who expect decision theory to respect a *principle of deliberative closure*: if the background facts and utility values are fixed, ideal reflection should yield a stable prescription.

2.2 Time Inconsistency and Money Pumps  

Suppose you face a bookmaker who understands your CDT psychology. She offers you the following two gambles in immediate succession:

Gamble 1 (when your p = 0.7 for Damascus): Pay 1 cent now to receive \$100 if you go to Aleppo and survive.  
Gamble 2 (after you have accepted 1 and your p flips to 0.3): Pay another 1 cent now to receive \$100 if you go to Damascus and survive.

Each gamble is CDT-advantageous at the moment it is offered, because at that moment CDT says the referenced destination is the safer one. Accepting both guarantees paying 2 cents and receiving *at most* one \$100 payout, often none. The bookmaker makes a near-riskless profit by merely tracking your shifting act-probabilities. The resulting *diachronic Dutch book* need not be decisive—infinite regress arguments against Bayesian conditionalisation can be constructed similarly—but it underscores the practical cost of CDT’s oscillation: the theory licenses an exploitable pattern of preference reversals that arise solely from internal reflection, not from new empirical evidence.

2.3 Mislocation of Agency  

Finally, note a conceptual glitch. CDT’s recipe is to hold fixed everything not causally downstream of the act. But your *credence* about what you will do is, in an obvious sense, an epistemic state of your own mind—a product of the very deliberation that CDT is supposed to guide. If one is modelling the causal structure of the world, one should not treat the agent’s momentary credence as an objective chance that nature consults. In Death in Damascus, the physical correlating mechanism is Death’s earlier prediction, not your currently fluctuating belief. By letting your shifting credence feed back into the probability of Death’s location, CDT employs an illegitimate self-reference: it treats a by-product of the deciding process as if it were an exogenous causal variable. That is a category mistake, akin to adjusting the weather forecast whenever you glance at an umbrella.

3. Three CDT Defences and their Limits  

3.1 The Ratifiability Gambit  

Jeffrey and others recommend that a rational act must be *ratifiable*: the agent, knowing she is about to perform it, should still prefer it. In Death in Damascus the only ratifiable state, given symmetric utilities, is the 50–50 mixture, so the agent should randomise. But while randomisation dissolves instability, it is not cost-free. First, it deprives CDT of a determinate recommendation about *where to go*; the traveller still faces a city in which Death waits. Second, ratifiability is itself an evidential notion. To prefer an act conditional on performing it is precisely the move CDT was designed to avoid. Thus ratifiability repairs CDT by sneaking in evidential reasoning through the back door—an implicit concession that the causal rule alone is inadequate.

3.2 Mixed Acts  

More sophisticated defenders urge the agent to adopt a *mixed act*—for instance, toss a fair coin and let heads send you to Aleppo. Because Death is better at predicting pure acts than randomised strategies, the mixed act may dominate. But this reply conflates two distinct questions: “Which *option descriptions* should populate the decision matrix?” and “How to evaluate each option, granted CDT’s algorithm?” The Death case is designed to test the latter. Invoking mixed strategies simply changes the subject. Moreover, if one permits randomisation, the instability resurfaces at the policy level: the agent’s credence about what mixture she will deploy can itself oscillate.

3.3 Stop Deliberating at the Endpoint  

Some CDT theorists say: “Ignore the intermediate probabilities; rational deliberation terminates only when p reaches 0 or 1, at which point CDT delivers a clear verdict.” Yet ideal Bayesian agents almost never reach probabilities of 0 or 1 by reflection alone. Forcing p to extremal values is tantamount to requiring the agent to *decide* before she has reason to think one act is better—that is, making the end of deliberation logically prior to the preference that is supposed to justify it. The manoeuvre is question-begging; it sets aside the very phenomenon under dispute.

4. A Proposed Repair: Two Levels of Credence  

The diagnoses above suggest that CDT’s flaw is not its causal orientation but its tacit identification of deliberative probabilities with predictive probabilities. Let us distinguish:

C^D (Deliberative credence): The distribution the agent should use when calculating expected utility for deliberation.  
C^P (Predictive credence): The agent’s best estimate of nature’s objective correlations, including predictions other observers (like Death) make about her.
