In orthodox CDT, C^D = C^P by fiat. But we can question that identity. Suppose you adopt the following *Policy-Fixing Principle*:

(PFP) When evaluating a policy π from a deliberative standpoint, condition on the supposition that you *will* implement π, but do not update on the merely evidential fact that you are more or less likely to implement π.

Concretely, imagine choosing between two *policies*: “Go to Damascus” (π_D) and “Go to Aleppo” (π_A). To assess π_D, you ask: *Given that I go to Damascus, what is the probability, according to the causal laws and prior frequencies, that Death will be there?* Crucially, you do *not* let your current wavering confidence in π_D alter that probability. The relevant probability is fixed by a model in which policy choice is an exogenous node; your present subjective uncertainty about which node you will choose is irrelevant. Formally, one evaluates:

EU(π) = ∑_s C^P(s | do(π)) × U(π,s),

but where C^P(s | do(π)) is computed from the graphical causal model with an intervention on the policy node, exactly in Pearl’s sense. Because interventions break incoming arrows, your uncertainty about choosing π has no bearing on s.

Applying PFP to Death in Damascus yields a stable recommendation: choose the city with the lower *objective-chance* of Death conditional on the hypothetical *intervention* of choosing that city. If Death is 80 % reliable and biased toward Damascus, then C^P(Death in Damascus | do(Damascus)) = 0.8 while C^P(Death in Damascus | do(Aleppo)) = 0.2, so you go to Aleppo. The instability vanishes because EU no longer tracks your shifting self-prediction.

Is this still CDT? It keeps the causal spirit—probabilities are conditioned only on hypothetical interventions, not on evidential correlations—but it rejects a silent epistemic identification. Some may baptise the view “Updateless CDT”; others may see it as converging on Functional Decision Theory in recent AI works. Either way, the lesson is clear: to salvage causal decision-making in predictors’ paradoxes, one must insulate the deliberative standpoint from ondulations in self-prediction.

5. Implications and Open Questions  

The repair raises three intriguing issues.

(1) Reflection principle. Separating C^D and C^P means a fully rational agent can foresee that her predictive credence assigns a different probability distribution to outcomes than the one she will use in choosing. Does this violate Dutch-book rationality? Not if the agent refuses bets premised on predictive odds during deliberation. She operates with two accounting ledgers, each coherent in its own domain.

(2) Learning from internal evidence. Sometimes introspection—realising that one has become stubborn, say—really *is* evidence about the external world. Denying deliberative relevance to that evidence may leave expected-utility money on the table. The boundary between illegitimate self-reference and legitimate self-locating evidence needs further analysis, perhaps along Lewisian lines about de se beliefs.

(3) Multi-agent extensions. In bargaining or game-theoretic contexts, do all players need aligned C^D/C^P separations to avoid instability? If not, predictors could exploit mismatches among agents, suggesting a new research programme on *team-level* causal decision theories.

6. Conclusion  

The dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities in Death-in-Damascus cases is not a benign quirk. It undermines the theory’s ability to guide action, exposes it to diachronic money pumps, and rests on a category mistake about the causal status of deliberative credences. Standard patch-ups—ratifiability, mixed acts, endpoint fixation—either trade on evidential reasoning or sweep the instability under the rug. A more principled fix requires acknowledging two layers of probability and constraining deliberation to counterfactual interventions, not to fluctuating self-predictions. Whether that view remains CDT or amounts to a new decision theory, the moral is sobering: any viable causalist theory must explicitly separate *how the world would respond if I did X* from *how likely it is that I will do X*. Conflating the two is a recipe for chasing Death in circles—and, more generally, for decision rules that cannot decide.

Death waits in Damascus. You know that tomorrow he will be in whichever city—Damascus or Aleppo—he predicts you will visit. His predictions are highly but not perfectly reliable, and he has a slight bias toward guessing “Damascus.” Tonight you must decide where to go. According to orthodox causal decision theory (CDT), you evaluate each available act by its causal expected utility: sum, over possible world-states not downstream of your act, of the utility of that act in the state weighted by the unconditional probability of the state. Surprisingly, the value that CDT assigns to “Go to Damascus” turns out to depend on how probable you presently take that act to be. During deliberation you may swing from being 60% confident you will flee to Aleppo to being 40% confident; as that credence slides, CDT’s rankings of the two cities change with it. The result can be an unsettling “deliberative instability”: at various moments CDT tells you to do whatever you now think you are unlikely to do.

Is this dependence on your current act-probabilities an embarrassment—perhaps even a fatal flaw—for CDT? My answer is “Yes, but not for the reason that it involves probabilities of one’s own acts as such.” The real problem is that CDT, as ordinarily stated, treats your credence distribution as an exogenous input even when features of the world you must estimate—including Death’s whereabouts—depend sensitively on the very algorithm you are running to choose. In Death-in-Damascus-style feedback loops, CDT’s insistence on “unconditional” probabilities yields a moving target that undermines its claim to supply rational action guidance. I shall argue:

1. Why act-probability dependence generates genuine decision-making pathologies for CDT in predictor cases.  
2. Why the standard CDT cures (ratifiability fixes, mixed-strategy fixes, equilibrium fixes) fail to restore adequate guidance.  
3. How re-formulating CDT at the policy or algorithmic level—what I will call Upstream CDT—avoids the pathology and reveals the deeper moral: rational choice must treat the internal mechanics of deliberation as causally relevant when the world is an accurate mirror of those mechanics.

Although the conclusion is critical of textbook CDT, it identifies a way of preserving the causal spirit while avoiding oscillation. The target, then, is not causal decision theory per se, but a particular way of couching it that brackets off the very causal channels that matter when facing reliable predictors.

I. The Formal Source of the Instability

Let the utilities be simple:

• Survive: 0  
• Die: –1000

Let πD be your present probability of going to Damascus, and let δ be the predictor’s “bias”: other things equal, he guesses Damascus with probability 0.6 and Aleppo with 0.4. Let ρ = 0.9 be the predictor’s reliability.

Because Death is in whichever city he guesses, the probability Death is in Damascus conditional on your going to Damascus is:

P(Death in D | go-D) = ρ P(predict D | go-D) + (1–ρ) P(predict A | go-D).          (1)

But the predictor’s guess is formed by simulating you. If he thinks you go to Damascus with probability πD, simple Bayes plus his bias implies

P(predict D) = 0.6·πD + 0.4·(1–πD).                                              (2)

Plugging (2) into (1), elementary algebra yields

EU(go-D) = –1000 × [0.9(0.6πD + 0.4(1–πD)) + 0.1(1–0.6πD – 0.4(1–πD))].        (3)

The key point is qualitative: EU(go-D) is an increasing function of πD. When you presently regard Damascus as likely, the chance that Death will be there is also high, so the act looks bad; when you waver and start leaning toward Aleppo, equation (3) drives Death’s chance in Damascus down, making Damascus look safer again. The symmetric calculation for Aleppo shows the same mirror image dependence on πA = 1 – πD.

Result: As your credence shifts, CDT’s recommendation can flip—indeed, by transitivity it must flip whenever πD crosses the unique fixed point where EU(D) = EU(A). Introspective agents who foresee this pendulum can find themselves trapped in an endless loop: at each instant, “follow CDT!” pushes them toward the act that currently seems safer, only to have that very move raise Death’s likelihood of meeting them there.

II. Why This Is More Than Mild Cognitive Dissonance

A defender might urge that dependence on act-probabilities is not strange. In two-player mixed-strategy games your expected payoff for playing Rock indeed depends on the probability that you will play Rock: if you are committed to 1/3 Rock the payoff is fixed, if you deviate it changes. Yet no one thinks game theory defective for that reason. So why worry here?

The answer is threefold.

1. Lack of a Stable Recommendation. In ordinary mixed-strategy contexts, a rational agent selects the probability distribution that is a best response to itself (a Nash equilibrium). CDT, by contrast, provides no inbuilt mechanism for locating such a fixed point; worse, no guarantee exists that one will coincide with the act it recommends. The theory hands you a recipe that, when followed naively, never settles.

2. Guidance Failure at the Personal Level. Decision theory is an instrument of practical deliberation. If faithfully executing CDT in real time issues in perpetual vacillation, then it fails its instrumental purpose. A principle that, when consulted, predictably pushes you into cycles cannot be the final word on rational action. (Contrast: expected-utility maximization under ordinary uncertainty does not do that.)

3. Dutch Book Vulnerability. Consider a bookie who, at every oscillation, offers you small bets favouring your then-preferred city. Because you flip an unbounded number of times before dawn, the bookie can lock in a sure loss no matter which city you land in. So CDT, executed naively, exposes your credences to domination.

For these reasons, the mere fact that payoffs depend on mixed strategies is not a knock-down defence. CDT’s implementation gap is more severe because, unlike classical game theory, it refuses to treat one’s own deliberative state as a player in the game.

III. Standard Repairs and Why They Fall Short

(i) Ratificationism. Jeffrey and Harper suggested that a rational act should “ratify” itself: choose A only if, conditional on choosing A, A still looks best. In Death in Damascus, though, both acts ratify—if I treat πD as fixed at 1, then EU(D) < EU(A), so choosing Aleppo ratifies; but analogously Aleppo ratifies itself when πD = 0. An extension that searches for globally stable πD runs into indeterminacy or recommends the 50/50 mixed strategy. Yet the 50/50 mix does strictly worse in expectation than certain alternative dispositions (e.g., a hard-wired “Always Aleppo” can outperform it given Death’s Damascus bias).

(ii) Mixed-Act CDT. Some propose that the object of evaluation should be a probability distribution over acts, not the individual act taken. On that view the agent chooses the πD that maximizes expected utility, finds the best mixed strategy, and then randomizes accordingly. Unfortunately, to implement the very πD picked one must ensure the predictor learns precisely that distribution; any deviation, even due to quantum noise in the randomizer, re-opens the instability. Worse, ordinary humans are bad at sampling true randomness, so the prescription is practically self-defeating.

(iii) Equilibrium Fix. Gibbard and Harper’s “equilibrium” CDT stipulates that your credences and act must jointly be a fixed point. Technically elegant, this move purchases stability by definition, not explanation. Why should rationality require you to hold the specific credence at which CDT ceases to oscillate rather than some other equally coherent credence function? The theory provides no further argument beyond brute self-consistency, so the alleged cure merely re-describes the symptom.

(iv) Stick-to-Your-Guns Pragmatism. Stalnaker once remarked that you invoke CDT only “at the end of deliberation,” after your credences have settled. The recipe then outputs a single act and you proceed. But nothing in the orthodox axioms explains which credences count as “settled” or why the settling should happen at the unique fixed point rather than wherever introspection finds itself. Absent an account of the causal process, the advice is effectively: “Stop oscillating—when you are done oscillating.”

IV. Diagnosing the Deeper Malaise

What ties these failed repairs together is a common oversight. They preserve the letter of CDT’s prohibition on using evidential correlations as reasons to act, yet they try to patch the evident leak by tinkering with the output stage. The real trouble lies upstream: the “unconditional probabilities” that CDT instructs us to feed into the causal expected-utility formula are not, in predictor cases, independent of the algorithm that picks the act. We are, in effect, asked to estimate P(Death in Damascus) while pretending our estimation procedure and Death’s prediction algorithm are causally divorced, even though we know both spring from the same source code. The feedback loop thereby introduced is not solved by fiddling with ratification criteria; it calls for reconceiving which nodes count as “causally downstream.”

Here is a suggestive analogy. In Newcomb’s Problem, CDT’s causal model declares the opaque box’s content fixed, hence (it claims) my choice cannot causally influence that content. Yet one may convincingly protest that the predictor’s simulation of my very deliberation constitutes a causal pathway—not through future-to-past spooky action, but through information about my algorithm picked up earlier. Something parallel operates in Death in Damascus: my probability distribution over acts is part of the causal nexus whereby Death positions himself. If CDT’s decision graph omits that arrow, no wonder the expected utilities bob up and down whenever my credence does.

V. Upstream CDT: Incorporating the Deliberation Algorithm

Suppose we enrich the causal model to include a node A, representing the abstract algorithm (or policy) I am committed to implement, and a node P, representing the predictor’s output. P is causally downstream of A because the predictor simulates that very algorithm; my concrete act a tomorrow is, in turn, downstream of both A and a particular seed of random noise n (if the algorithm is stochastic). Death’s location D is a deterministic function of P. Finally, my utility U depends on a and D.

Once the act-selecting algorithm A appears explicitly in the graph, the instruction “evaluate expected utility using unconditional probabilities for nodes not downstream of the act” yields a very different result. The states upstream of a include P and hence D. Their probabilities depend on A but not on the particular branch of randomization that realizes a. Consequently:

1. The expected utility of adopting algorithm A is well-defined and does not vary as I introspect about which output branch I will take, because those branches lie downstream of the predictor’s guess.  
2. Oscillation disappears. The algorithm either deterministically points to Damascus, deterministically to Aleppo, or randomizes with a certain π. Each policy has a fixed expected utility independent of second-by-second vacillation.  
3. In the canonical parameter setting (predictor 90% reliable and biased toward Damascus), the highest-utility algorithm is “Always Aleppo.” The agent who embodies it calmly heads north while Death, more often than not, gets it wrong. CDT at the policy level thereby recovers the intuitive winner.

By shifting one rung “upstream” in the causal chain, we preserve CDT’s core doctrine—choose actions (or now, policies) by causally expected utility—while avoiding dependence on unstable subjective probabilities. The agent’s credence that *she will in fact go to Aleppo* may still flicker during contemplation, but those flickers no longer feed into the evaluation of the policy because the relevant upstream probabilities were set the moment she adopted the policy. In this reconception, only changes to the policy/node A, not moment-by-moment változások in self-prediction, are decision-relevant.

VI. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: “Policy” selection is spuriously grand. Rational agents are rarely able to bind themselves to a unique algorithm; real deliberation happens one choice at a time.  
Reply: Binding is not required. What matters is which causal factors the agent takes herself to control. If the world copies your algorithm, you control which algorithm that is, even if you cannot control its specific stochastic outcome. CDT already assumes agents can choose between acts; extending the choice to the algorithm that *generates* the acts is merely recognising an earlier node in the same causal chain.

Objection 2: Upstream CDT smuggles in evidential reasoning through the back door. Isn’t the agent now taking advantage of the correlation between A and P?  
Reply: The correlation is acknowledged because it is *causal*: the predictor’s access to the agent’s source code is a physical channel. CDT forbids treating mere evidential correlations as decision-relevant; it does not forbid exploiting genuine causal pathways previously overlooked because of an impoverished model. Adding the arrow from A to P respects the causal scruples.

Objection 3: The cure generalises too far. In simple choice problems with no predictor, policy evaluation collapses to ordinary act evaluation; but in ordinary games against nature, nobody needs this machinery.  
Reply: Correct. Upstream CDT is strictly conservative: in worlds where no upstream copy of the algorithm exists, the additional node is causally inert and the recommendations coincide with standard CDT. The new model matters precisely in opaque-box or predictor situations. A good decision theory should be extensionally equivalent to CDT in ordinary cases and diverge only where CDT’s guidance misfires. Upstream CDT does just that.

VII. Broader Lessons

The Death-in-Damascus puzzle exposes a fault line between two conceptions of rational choice:

A. The Snapshot View: At the instant of action, I treat my contemplated choices as the only causal levers and hold fixed my entire epistemic state.  
B. The Algorithmic View: Rational control reaches one layer deeper, to the policy that will determine (perhaps stochastically) my behaviour in all superficially similar situations.

Snapshot CDT implements A; Upstream CDT represents B. Predictor cases show the snapshot to be causally incomplete. Once we enlarge the grain of analysis, act-probability dependence ceases to be alarming because my fluctuating second-order beliefs are not the right input for the causal expectation calculus.

In other words, the pathology is not that utilities depend on πD; any sophisticated agent in a game-theoretic environment should expect that. The pathology is that orthodox CDT asks us to plug into its formula a quantity (the unconditional probability of Death’s location) that is in fact conditional on our still-in-flux deliberative state. Upstream CDT repairs that by regressing the causal cut one step and thereby stabilises the deliberative loop.

VIII. Conclusion

Does the dependence of CDT’s recommendations on one’s current act-probabilities constitute a problem for the theory? Yes—but the problem is not bare dependence. It is that orthodox CDT, by ignoring the causal influence of one’s own decision algorithm on predictor-informed states of the world, allows that dependence to swing uncontrolled during deliberation, depriving the agent of coherent guidance. Standard patches—ratification, mixed strategies, fixed-point stipulations—either fail to stop the oscillation in practice or buy stability at the cost of unargued stipulation. A more principled fix is to relocate the locus of choice upstream to the policy. When we do, CDT’s core causal insight is preserved, its deliverances stabilise, and the Death-in-Damascus conundrum dissolves: rational agents confidently adopt whatever algorithm maximises expected survival given how their algorithms are read by the world. In the familiar parameter settings that means taking the road to Aleppo and leaving Death puzzled in Damascus.

In sum, Death’s shadow reveals not that causal decision theory is wrong to care about causes rather than mere evidential correlations, but that its canonical articulation underestimates how far causal influence can reach when the world contains faithful mirrors of our deliberations. Recognising that reach restores CDT’s power and shows that the true measure of rational agency is control of one’s algorithm, not nervous monitoring of one’s immediate urges.

The Death in Damascus story has become a laboratory parable for probing weaknesses in Causal Decision Theory (CDT).  The case is simple enough to recount in a paragraph, yet rich enough to expose a structural feature of CDT that has received surprisingly little sustained analysis: CDT’s expected‐utility calculation for an act A explicitly includes the agent’s own present credence that she will perform A.  In ordinary cases that dependence is harmless (indeed, invisible), because the world state relevant to payoffs is normally independent of the agent’s idle probabilities about what she will do.  In Death-in-Damascus cases, however, an imperfect but highly reliable predictor uses exactly those probabilities—and nothing else—to decide where to wait.  As the agent deliberates, her probabilities shift, and the prediction shifts with them.  CDT’s recommendation therefore “chases” a moving target.  The result is an advice loop that never settles into a fixed point.  Is that merely an exotic curiosity, or does it reveal a genuine flaw in CDT?

I shall argue for the stronger verdict: the dependence on act probabilities is a deep problem for orthodox CDT.  It turns CDT from a normative principle into a mirage whenever (i) an outcome-relevant state of the world tracks the agent’s evolving uncertainty about her own act and (ii) the agent knows this fact and therefore rationally updates those probabilities in the very course of deliberation.  The instability is not just frustrating; it undermines CDT’s claim to be action-guiding, violates the Reflection Principle, and leaves the theory vulnerable to Dutch-book and money-pump arguments.  After clarifying the mechanics of the instability (§1), I turn to an attempted rescue that treats one’s act probabilities as exogenous “background” beliefs (§2).  I then explain why that proposal fails and why the most promising escape routes require abandoning a core commitment of traditional CDT (§3).  I close by sketching two alternative frameworks—ratificationist CDT and so-called Functional Decision Theory—that dissolve the instability by assigning probabilities to policies rather than to momentary acts (§4).

1.  How the dependence generates instability

Start with a precise toy model.  You value survival at 100 utiles and death at 0.  You may travel tonight to Aleppo (A) or Damascus (D).  Death has a crystal ball whose accuracy is 90 %: he predicts the city you will choose and goes there.  You also know that, for some inscrutable psychological reason, the predictor has a bias toward Damascus: when his crystal ball is cloudy, he says “Damascus.”  Formally,

P(Death’s prediction = your act) = 0.9  
P(Death forecasts D | crystal ball cloudy) = 1.

Let p be your current subjective probability that you will choose Aleppo.  Because Death’s presence in a city equals his prediction, and that prediction covaries with p, the causal decision theorist representing you calculates the expected utility of going to Aleppo as

EU(A) = 100 · P(survive | A) = 100 · [1 – P(Death in Aleppo | A)]  
EU(D) = 100 · [1 – P(Death in Damascus | D)].

By the independence rule at the heart of CDT, you evaluate only unconditional probabilities for states not downstream of your act.  Whether Death is in Aleppo or Damascus is not caused by your act (you are deciding after the prediction has been made), so CDT instructs you to treat P(Death in Aleppo) and P(Death in Damascus) as they stand now—probabilities that depend on p.

The algebra is transparent.  Death is in Aleppo iff he predicts Aleppo.  So

P(Death in Aleppo) = P(predicts A) = 0.9p + 0.1·0  = 0.9p  
P(Death in Damascus) = 1 – 0.9p.

Thus

EU(A) = 100(1 – 0.9p)  
EU(D) = 100·0.9p.

CDT says “Choose the act with higher EU.”  If p < ½, EU(A) > EU(D) and you should go to Aleppo; if p > ½, you should go to Damascus.  But notice: the boundary point ½ is identical to the rule’s recommendation.  If you start with p = 0.6—i.e., you find yourself leaning a bit toward Aleppo—the recipe tells you to go to Damascus, which would instantly drive p to (essentially) 0.  That flip restores the condition p < ½, which in turn recommends Aleppo.  The system ping-pongs.

There is no fixed point except the knife-edge p = ½, where the agent feels exactly indifferent between the two cities.  But such indifference is fragile: a flicker of self-doubt re-initiates the oscillation.  A rule that yields well-defined advice only under a perfectly balanced prior credence—and whose advice destabilizes that balance whenever it is heeded—is not a rule that can give usable guidance to finite, introspectively aware deliberators.

Why is that a philosophical problem rather than merely a psychological annoyance?  Three interlocking deficiencies follow.

a)  Action-guidance.  A decision rule earns its keep by telling an agent what to do, not merely what she would wish to do if she could freeze her own credences while deliberating.  CDT’s prescription in Death cases fails that minimal pragmatist test.

b)  Violating Reflection.  Van Fraassen’s Reflection Principle holds that if at time t you expect that your future credence in a proposition will be q, and you trust your future self, you should already assign credence q now.  CDT impels you to adopt a plan you believe will immediately force you to alter your credence—and thereby the plan itself.  The theory repeatedly counsels you to become someone you do not presently endorse.  That is a diachronic incoherence.

c)  Exploitability.  The classic symptom of incoherent probabilities is Dutch-book vulnerability.  In an expanded Death scenario one can construct betting schemes that siphon sure loss from the CDT agent as her credences rock back and forth.  More intuitively: a savvy predictor can sell “insurance” priced each time she flips, reaping arbitrage from the fact that her probability assignments cannot stably track her own behaviour.

2.  Treating act probabilities as exogenous: a failed repair

A natural response is to declare that the p entering the expected-utility calculus is fixed at the start of deliberation: “Take your current mixed strategy as given; then act as the argmax against that backdrop.”  On that construal the dependence on p is static, and CDT issues a determinate recommendation.  If you start with p = 0.6, EU(A) < EU(D); so you determinately go to Damascus after all.  Case closed.

Not so fast.  Two objections:

First, the rule misidentifies the time at which the decision problem is faced.  At the moment you commit to an act—perhaps five minutes after the first glimmer of deliberation—you know that p ≈ 1 for that act.  The exogenous-p rule therefore collapses into recommending Damascus (because Death’s bias already made p_Damascus > ½) for anyone who ends up there, and Aleppo for anyone who ends up in Aleppo.  The recommendation is ex post tautological.

Second, and more fundamentally, freezing p contradicts the informational dynamics of rational deliberation.  Discovering that EU(A) < EU(D) is evidence about what you will in fact do; ignoring that evidence violates Bayesian conditioning.  A theory that requires you to compartmentalize relevant information in order to follow its advice is self-undermining.  (Notice how unlike the ordinary “deliberation crowds out prediction” point this is: here it is precisely the predictive link that matters.)

3.  Why orthodox CDT cannot escape

The dependence problem is rooted in CDT’s insistence that (i) the value of an act be computed conditional on the act, but (ii) all probabilities for states not caused by that act remain unconditional.  In Death cases, the combination is explosive because the predictor has made the world state highly sensitive to the agent’s credence.  The only way to stop the explosion is to relax at least one of those two commitments.

Could we retain (ii) but weaken (i), evaluating whole policies instead of momentary acts?  That is Jeffrey’s ratificationism: choose an act only if you will still prefer having chosen it upon learning that very fact.  The ratification test looks for a fixed point by embedding the act within a self-referential loop of preference and prediction.  In the Death case there is still no ratifiable pure act; but one can show that a 50/50 mixed strategy is ratifiable.  That is progress—yet it comes at the price of abandoning CDT’s clean causal modularity.  Ratification glues together decision and prediction; the “causal” in CDT has faded.

Alternatively, keep (i) and reject (ii).  That is the route taken by “policy-based CDT” (Gibbard-Harper) and by Functional Decision Theory (FDT, Yudkowsky/Soares).  The idea is that, although your instantaneous choice cannot causally influence where Death is, the algorithm you instantiate is logically correlated with Death’s earlier prediction.  Therefore you should compute expected utility conditional on the output of that algorithm.  Formally, replace the unconditional probability P(Death in Aleppo) with P(Death in Aleppo | output = ‘Aleppo’).  Because the algorithm’s output is the same random variable that the predictor consulted, the conditional collapses the uncertainty: P(Death in Aleppo | output = ‘Aleppo’) ≈ 0.9.  But crucially—and here is the payoff—the figure no longer depends on your subjective credence during deliberation.  The fixed-point instability disappears.  FDT thus recovers action-guidance: it tells you to go to Aleppo irrespective of your wavering p, because that is the act correlated with survival.

What should we conclude?  You can keep CDT’s formalism only by inserting an epicycle (exogenous p) that conflicts with Bayesian updating, or by re-engineering CDT into a policy-conditioned theory that is CDT in name only.  Either way, the original dependence on act probabilities is revealed as untenable.

4.  Two stable replacements

Because space is limited I sketch rather than defend in detail two approaches that avoid the pathology.

4.1  Ratificationist CDT

Gibbard and Harper proposed that an act is rational iff, having discovered that you will do it, you would still prefer that act.  Formally, A is ratifiable if EU(A | will A) ≥ EU(B | will A) for every alternative B.  In the Death case, neither pure act is ratifiable, but the mixed 50/50 strategy is.  Critics complain that ratifiability can recommend randomization even when stakes are symmetrical, but defenders reply that the central desideratum—stability under self‐prediction—is achieved.

4.2  Functional Decision Theory

FDT conditions on the output of the agent’s decision function, not on the physical act.  In Death cases the function’s output is the variable Death predicts, so conditioning wipes out the dependence on degrees of belief.  FDT cleanly prescribes Aleppo, the city with only a 10 % chance of harboring Death given the agent’s algorithm.  The theory thereby treats logical correlation on par with causal influence, a move foreign to classical CDT but arguably in line with the instrumental core of expected‐utility reasoning.

Conclusion

The dependence of CDT’s verdict on the agent’s shifting act probabilities is not an innocuous quirk; it cripples CDT’s ability to guide action in any scenario where outcome‐relevant states track those probabilities.  Attempts to cordon off the problem by fixing the probabilities in advance are ad hoc and conflict with Bayesian learning.  To regain stability one must abandon at least one of CDT’s defining tenets, either by ratifying whole policies or by broadening the conditioning base to include logical correlations.  In short, the Death in Damascus reveals that orthodox CDT is hostage to a self‐referential feedback loop of its own making.  A decision theory fit for agents who know they are predictable must break that loop, even at the cost of radical revision.

I. Introduction and Thesis  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells us to maximize expected utility calculated with probabilities that treat the act itself as causally downstream of nothing and therefore held fixed.  In ordinary cases the resulting recommendation is insensitive to how confident you are that you will carry it out, because the utilities of the non-act states do not vary with that confidence.  In “Death in Damascus’’ (DiD)–style problems, however, the very utilities you assign to “go to Aleppo’’ and “go to Damascus’’ depend on your present subjective probabilities of performing those acts.  As you deliberate and those probabilities shift, CDT’s verdict shifts with them.  My thesis is that this sensitivity is a serious defect in standard CDT.  It shows that CDT, so formulated, lacks (i) deliberative stability, (ii) action-guidance, and (iii) diachronic rationality.  The defect is not merely cosmetic; it stems from CDT’s way of carving up the decision problem and can be repaired only by reconceiving the unit of agency (for example, by moving to policy-selection or updateless decision rules).  

I develop the argument in five stages.

1.  Reconstructing the DiD game and the feedback loop.  
2.  Explaining how CDT’s expected-utility calculations inherit that loop.  
3.  Showing three ways the loop violates core decision-theoretic desiderata.  
4.  Assessing two attempted repairs internal to CDT (ratifiability and mixed strategies) and showing why they fail.  
5.  Sketching an external repair that diagnoses the deeper problem, thereby illuminating the limitations of CDT’s causal-conditioning schema.

Throughout, the guiding idea is that a decision theory must not merely pick an option at an instant; it must license a self-reflective agent to settle on an option in full view of its own deliberation.  CDT, in the DiD setting, cannot do that.

II. Reconstructing Death in Damascus  

The original vignette (due to Gibbard & Harper) admits many parameter choices.  Let:  

•  U(survive the day) = 1, U(die) = 0.  
•  Death’s prediction reliability r = 0.9.  
•  Death has a mild bias toward Damascus: before predicting he flips a fair coin; on heads he predicts “Damascus’’ no matter what, on tails he tries (with reliability r) to predict your eventual destination.  

Let P(A) and P(D)=1–P(A) be your current subjective probabilities of ultimately going to Aleppo or Damascus.  Standard CDT directs you to compute:

EU(Aleppo) = P(Death predicted Damascus | go to A)·1 + P(Death predicted Aleppo | go to A)·0  
EU(Damascus) = P(Death predicted Aleppo | go to D)·1 + P(Death predicted Damascus | go to D)·0.

Because death’s prediction partially tracks your action, those conditional probabilities depend on P(A).  Elementary algebra yields

EU(A) = (½) + (½)(1–r)·P(A)  
EU(D) = (½)(1–r) + (½)·P(A).

Substituting r = .9 gives

EU(A) = .5 + .05·P(A)  
EU(D) = .05 + .5·P(A).

Hence:

•  If P(A) > .5, then EU(D) > EU(A); you ought to head for Damascus.  
•  If P(A) < .5, then EU(A) > EU(D); you ought to head for Aleppo.  
•  If P(A)=.5, they tie.

So whichever city you presently regard as likelier to visit, CDT tells you to switch to the other.  Once you switch, of course, your act-probabilities flip, reversing the recommendation.  CDT therefore issues no stable verdict.  We have a feedback loop:

believe-A ⇒ choose-D ⇒ believe-D ⇒ choose-A ⇒ … ad infinitum.

III. Why the Feedback is Trouble  

(1) Guidance Failure  

A decision theory should be action-guiding: a deliberating agent should be able to consult the theory and emerge with a conclusion.  CDT’s shifting verdict in DiD makes that impossible.  The agent who is perfectly self-reflective will anticipate that any concluded intention will immediately become more probable, overturning the very calculation that grounded it.  The only fixed points are mixed strategies that the theory never instructs the agent to adopt, because at no stage in the cycling does CDT rank a mix higher than a pure move.

Contrast: Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) gives the stable advice “stay in Damascus’’; Functional Decision Theory (FDT) says “go to Aleppo.’’  Whatever one thinks of those answers, they do not degenerate into oscillation.  CDT fails the basic criterion of delivering an answer in the first place.

(2) Diachronic Incoherence  

Suppose you are equipped with a causal decision-theoretic planning module updated continuously during deliberation.  Because CDT’s advice oscillates, you are guaranteed to change intentions an unbounded number of times in any interval with no new evidence.  This violates a weak form of dynamic consistency: you can foresee right now that tomorrow you will regard today’s intention as ex ante sub-optimal even though the informational state will be unchanged.  Standard Dutch Book theorems show that such predictable shifts allow a bookmaker to extract guaranteed losses from you via time-indexed bets conditional on your future behavior.  So the instability is not merely psychological but money-pumpable.

(3) Ratifiability Constraint  

Jeffrey (1983) suggested that rational acts should be “ratifiable’’: once you take into account the fact that you have decided on them, they should still maximize expected utility.  CDT’s recommendations in DiD are unratifiable by design, because the fact that you decide for Aleppo raises P(A) and thereby lowers EU(A).  A theory that routinely recommends unratiﬁable actions is, at best, incomplete.  Ratification might not be a categorical requirement, but CDT gives no story why unratiﬁability is benign here.

IV. Two Internal Repairs Considered  

A. Ratifiability Restriction  

One might bolt a ratifiability filter onto CDT: from among the CDT-approved acts, retain only those that would still be optimal conditional on performing them.  In DiD that leaves none unless P(A)=.5.  The filter therefore issues “stay undecided’’—an impossible command.  Worse, other familiar cases (e.g., toxicology problems) force the filter to select dominated options.  Hence adding ratifiability inside CDT collapses into paralysis or irrationality.

B. Mixed Strategies  

A second idea is to allow the agent to randomize with probability p so as to hit the fixed point p=.5, since at that mixture EU(A)=EU(D).  That breaks the oscillation.  But CDT has no resources for ranking mixed acts except by the same expectation formula that created the problem.  At p=.5, any ε-shift again makes one pure act strictly better, so the mixture is knife-edge unstable.  In game-theoretic terms, p=.5 is not a trembling-hand perfect equilibrium because arbitrarily small uncertainty restores the oscillation.  Moreover, CDT as ordinarily stated treats probabilities of acts as epistemic, not as intentional mixtures under the agent’s control; adding deliberate randomization is therefore an ad hoc expander of the action space and requires a further principle (maximin? maximum entropy?) to select the correct p in general.

Hence neither internal patch yields a satisfying decision rule.

V. The Deeper Diagnosis  

Why does CDT stumble here while EDT and updateless variants do not?  Because CDT insistently conditions on the *act token* as a causal intervention, holding fixed the very variable whose probability is endogenous to deliberation.  In problems where others predict you by simulating your decision process, the causal arrow from act to outcome is mediated by *the decision function*, not by the time-slice act itself.  CDT’s template—sum over probability of world-state given act—mislocates the cut between agent and environment.  The decision function you implement is part of the causal network that Death observes; yet CDT treats it as exogenous and thereby fails to reckon with the fact that changing your probabilities changes the world.

Functional Decision Theory and policy-selection variants of CDT avoid that error.  They treat the unit of choice as the function mapping informational states to actions.  You then maximize expected utility with respect to the distribution over worlds conditional on your *being such a function*.  In DiD, the function “always go to Aleppo’’ causally screens off Death’s tendency to predict Damascus, giving high survival probability; “always go to Damascus’’ yields low survival; the mixed function with p=.5 does no better.  The oscillation never gets started because probabilities of city-visits are outputs, not inputs, to the evaluation.

VI. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: “Real agents do not know their act-probabilities; so the oscillation is a philosopher’s artifact.’’  
Reply: The phenomenon appears as soon as the agent is even vaguely aware of a correlation between act and predictor.  Minor shifts in credence suffice.  Moreover, rationality criteria should not depend on limitations of introspection; a theory that breaks down if the agent does become self-aware is defective.

Objection 2: “CDT can stipulate that probabilities of acts are held fixed during deliberation—treat them as ‘screened-off’ variables.’’  
Reply: That begs the question.  If the agent believes her own act is contingent, she cannot *coherently* regard its probability as fixed while simultaneously trying to decide.  Telling her to pretend otherwise evacuates CDT of usefulness precisely when reflective intelligence matters.

Objection 3: “The instability is akin to the familiar fact that game-theory sometimes lacks pure-strategy equilibria; decision theory should live with that.’’  
Reply: In game situations we indeed expect mixed-strategy equilibria, but a single-agent decision problem should not replicate the strategic indeterminacy that arises when multiple independent utility maximizers interact.  When it does, that is evidence we have mis-modeled the causal structure and imported a ghost opponent (here, a simulation of ourselves) into the environment.

VII. Conclusion and Moral  

The dependence of CDT’s verdict on the agent’s shifting act-probabilities in Death in Damascus is not a quirky corner case but a symptom of a conceptual limitation.  It robs CDT of deliberative stability, violates ratifiability, and enables predictable diachronic preference reversals that a savvy bookmaker can exploit.  Internal repairs either paralyze the agent or smuggle in new decision principles.  The right lesson is that when predictors or copies of ourselves interact with us, the unit of agency expands from momentary acts to whole decision functions.  CDT, tied to act-conditioning, misplaces the cut and so generates a self-undermining feedback loop.  To recover a workable decision theory we must adopt a framework—functional, updateless, or policy-based—that evaluates options in a way insensitive to the real-time flux of one’s own act-probabilities.  The problem is thus real and reveals something deep: causal decision theory, in its standard form, is an incomplete blueprint for rational choice in a world that can see inside our heads.

1. Setting the Stage  

Imagine that at dawn you learn three things.  
(a) Death is waiting for you today in one of two cities, Aleppo or Damascus.  
(b) He has already tried to predict which of the two you will visit. If he guessed right, he will be there when you arrive and you die; if he guessed wrong, you live.  
(c) Death’s crystal ball is good but not perfect: with 90 % reliability it foresees your eventual choice, and when it errs it does so by guessing Damascus rather than Aleppo four times out of five.  
You can now choose: stay in Damascus or flee to Aleppo.  

This is a variant of “Death in Damascus.” The detail that Death is biased toward guessing Damascus simply makes explicit what the informal story suggests: he is slightly lazy and, all else equal, prefers to stay where he is.  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) instructs you to evaluate each act—going to Aleppo, staying in Damascus—by its expected utility computed with “causal” probabilities: for any factor not downstream of your act you use your present unconditional credence in it, not your credence conditional on performing the act. When Death’s prediction is outside your causal influence, the probability that Death is in a given city depends on how likely you currently deem it that you will head there. That dependence makes the expected utility of each act a function of your current self-anticipation, Pr(Aleppo) and Pr(Damascus). As those probabilities shift during deliberation, CDT’s recommendation can flip back and forth. Is that a real defect in the theory or merely a curiosity? I shall argue that it is a serious problem, because (i) it induces dynamic instability that undermines effective deliberation, (ii) it violates a plausible independence constraint on rational choice, and (iii) it points to a deeper structural flaw about how CDT models the causal relevance of an agent’s own decision process. I close by examining classical replies—mixed strategies, ratifiability, and “probabilities before deliberation”—and showing why they do not fully rescue standard CDT, though they gesture toward more radical reforms such as updateless or functional decision theories.

2. How the Dependence Arises  

Let p be your present credence that you will end up in Aleppo when deliberation is over. Because Death’s crystal ball has 90 % reliability and a Damascus-favoring bias, the unconditional probability that Death is currently in Aleppo is

Pr(Death in A) = 0.9 p + 0.1 (1–p) × 0.2 = 0.9 p + 0.02 (1–p).  
(The first term is the chance he predicts correctly; the second is the chance he predicts wrongly, multiplied by the 20 % probability that a wrong guess points to Aleppo.)

The chance he is in Damascus is 1 – that. If dying carries utility –100 and surviving 0, the causal expected utilities of the two acts are

EU(Aleppo) = –100 × Pr(Death in A)  
EU(Damascus) = –100 × Pr(Death in D).

Because the prefactor –100 is the same, we can focus on the probabilities themselves:

EU(A) > EU(D)  ⇔  Pr(Death in A) < Pr(Death in D).

Algebra shows that inequality holds just in case p < 0.2. If at the moment you regard the chance you will go to Aleppo as lower than 20 %, CDT tells you to go to Aleppo. But as soon as you begin to move your credence in that direction—“Perhaps I really should flee”—p rises. Cross the 0.2 threshold and the recommendation reverses: now you should stay in Damascus. Recognizing that, you lower p again, and the pendulum swings back. In effect, CDT supplies no action-stable guidance; any infinitesimal adjustment of self-belief can invert the prescription.

3. Why Instability Matters  

A decision theory is meant to be a practical guide for situated agents. Guidance that is not stable under competent reflective deliberation fails its purpose. The worry here is not simply that CDT’s output is sensitive to second-order facts (my beliefs about what I will do). Many perfectly sound deliberations are sensitive in that way. The complaint is sharper: CDT generates a feedback loop in which the very act of responding rationally to the recommendation predictably destroys its validity. No convergence point exists unless the relevant parameters happen to line up exactly with a knife-edge fixed point (p = 0.2 in our toy numbers). But knife-edge equilibria are measure-zero events; they cannot be relied on.

Dynamic instability undermines two desiderata of practical rationality:

Guidance: The theory should leave a conscientious agent with something she can stably do.  

Trust in Deliberation: Rational reflection should not systematically make things worse by eroding the basis of one’s own reasoning.

CDT in Death-type cases violates both. That alone is strong prima facie evidence of a defect.

4. Independence from Self-Referential Credences  

A second way to see the trouble is to notice that considerations about how probable I currently take an action to be seem normatively irrelevant. Suppose just before I open the door I learn that an alien mathematician has assigned an arbitrary real number between 0 and 1 to “the probability the human will go to Aleppo.” Does that make the mortal stakes of Aleppo any higher or lower? Surely not. Yet CDT effectively allows such “probabilities”—even when they arise endogenously from my own shifting sentiments—to do decisive causal work. That smells of an independence violation: rational choice should not turn on evidentially inert, introspectively labile second-order beliefs.

The comparison with the widely accepted independence of irrelevant alternatives is apt. Here the irrelevant item is not an alternative act but a doxastic state: what I happen to think about my propensity to act. By letting that intrude, CDT contravenes the spirit (if not the letter) of the independence norm.

5. A Structural Diagnosis  

Why does CDT stumble? The root lies in the way it combines two commitments:

Causal Sufficiency: Only factors causally downstream of the act are “screened off.”  

Synchronic Evaluation: Probabilities are assessed at the very moment of choice, using the agent’s current unconditional credence.

When the predictor’s judgment depends on the same internal deliberative process that produces the act, those two commitments pull apart. The predictor’s location is causally upstream of the bodily motion (you cannot affect where Death now is), yet it is logically correlated with your decision procedure. By evaluating at the moment in which the decision procedure is still unresolved and using unconditional credences that reflect that very uncertainty, CDT delivers a moving target. In cases where predictor accuracy is high but imperfect, the target is not only moving; it is dynamically repulsive—tiny self-updates push one away from equilibrium.

This diagnosis suggests why proposals that merely tweak numbers or introduce randomization cannot fully fix things: they leave intact the synchronic causal-probability recipe that makes expected utility depend on the oscillator p.

6. Classical Escapes and Why They Fall Short  

6.1 Mixed Strategies  

One can introduce deliberate randomization: decide to go to Aleppo with probability exactly 0.2 and Damascus otherwise. At p = 0.2 the expected utilities tie; CDT is then indifferent, and the instability vanishes. But in ordinary practical contexts humans do not wield entropy sources precise enough to generate objective 0.2 randomness; more importantly, aiming for exactly p = 0.2 presupposes that one already knows how the predictor’s bias and reliability cash out to three significant digits. In many realistic cases one lacks that information. So the remedy is fragile and in any case concedes the main point: CDT must move from pure acts to lottery recommendations, a form of “policy mixing” its original statement was designed to avoid.

6.2 Ratifiability  

Jeffrey suggested that a rational act must be “ratifiable”: it should still look optimal upon learning that one will perform it. Formally, A is ratifiable if EU(A | ‘I shall do A’) ≥ EU(B | ‘I shall do A’) for every alternative B. Ratifiability plugs the instability by forbidding recommendations that would undermine themselves. Unfortunately, it throws out many intuitively sensible choices. In a simple Prisoner’s Dilemma with a low but nonzero chance of mutual cooperation, defection is not ratifiable; yet defection is what every mainstream decision theory prescribes. Jeffrey famously concluded that ideal agents must sometimes be “incorrigibly uncertain” about what they will do, which is tantamount to denying that they can ever settle conviction about their own act. That is a high price to pay for patching a flaw that arises only in predictor cases.

6.3 Fixing Probabilities at the Start  

Another proposal: compute expected utilities with the unconditional probabilities you had at the *outset* of deliberation, before you started manipulating p. Then the recommendation no longer bounces around. But deliberation is partly an information-gathering process: as you think, you learn things about your character, resolve ambiguities, notice salient considerations. A theory that freezes probabilities at an ex ante snapshot implicitly forbids you to use hard-won self-knowledge. That again seems unacceptably restrictive as a general prescription.

Moreover, if you announce in advance that you will freeze probabilities no matter how your opinion evolves, a sophisticated predictor like Death will take that policy into account. You have merely displaced the correlation problem to an earlier time slice, not eliminated it.

7. Toward Deeper Remedies  

Philosophers sympathetic to functional or updateless decision theories take the instability as evidence that CDT is tracking the wrong causal structure. What matters is not the bodily motion of walking to Aleppo but the abstract algorithm by which you settle that question—the same algorithm the predictor tries to simulate. Evaluation should therefore apply to *policies* or *computations* considered as abstract objects. On such accounts, you one-box in Newcomb’s Problem and stay in Damascus here, not because your motion reaches Death but because your decision function’s output is subjunctively linked to what Death predicted. Whether one endorses such radical reconstruals, it is worth noting that they eliminate the oscillatory dependence on p; the expected utility of a policy is fixed prior to and independent of the policy’s local probability of being executed at one instant.

A milder possible repair is “two-stage CDT.” Stage 1: pick a *probabilistic policy* (e.g., ‘choose Aleppo with 0.2’) by maximizing expected utility using prior credences about how predictors respond to whole mixed policies. Stage 2: implement that lottery. This variant inherits the attractive stability of the first stage while retaining a recognizably causal spirit. But its departure from classical CDT is substantive: the locus of evaluation moves from individual acts to probability distributions over them, and the background probability measure is fixed before the second-stage randomness rolls. In effect, two-stage CDT collapses into a form of updateless evaluation.

8. Comparative Note: EDT and the Symmetry of Instability  

Is the problem unique to CDT? Superficially EDT also makes expected utilities a function of Pr(Aleppo), because the probability that Death is in Aleppo given that you go there is close to 0.9. However, in Death-style cases EDT usually recommends Damascus and (unlike CDT) its recommendation is *stable*. Why? Because EDT conditions on the act under evaluation, so its expected utility functions are pulled to near extreme values—there is negligible region in which EU(A) crosses EU(D). The instability thus reflects a specific interaction between CDT’s use of unconditional credences and the moderate (not near-perfect) reliability of the predictor. In that sense the defect is indeed distinctive of CDT.

9. Summary of the Case Against Dependence  

We can now summarize why CDT’s dependence on act probabilities is a genuine problem, not a merely technical quirk:

1. Dynamic instability: The recommendation predictably undermines itself, leaving conscientious agents with no convergent directive.  
2. Independence violation: Rational choice should not hinge on introspectively contingent second-order beliefs about one’s own propensity.  
3. Structural mismatch: CDT treats the predictor’s location as causally insulated from the act, ignoring the common source in the deliberative algorithm.  
4. Inadequacy of patches: Standard fixes (randomization, ratifiability, probability-freezing) either fail in typical cases or impose objectionable restrictions, confirming that the issue is deep-seated.

10. Conclusion  

Death in Damascus exposes a fracture line in orthodox CDT. Where an observer exploits correlations between your decision process and an outcome outside your causal control, CDT lets your flickering self-confidence feed back into the very utilities it asks you to maximize. The resulting guidance is unstable, normatively unpersuasive, and hard to square with decision theory’s practical aims. Attempts to save CDT by ad hoc modifications illuminate the source of the difficulty but do not remove it. The moral is that a satisfactory theory of rational choice must evaluate policies or decision functions in a way that is robust under endogenous shifts in self-assessment. Whether one travels the path of ratifiability, two-stage choice, or the more radical route of functional decision theory, the journey begins with recognizing that CDT’s dependence on act probabilities in Death-type scenarios is not a harmless curiosity but a symptom of a deeper conceptual lesion.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Suppose, like the traveller in the “Death in Damascus” fable, you know two things: (i) Death is 90 % reliable at predicting which of two cities you will visit tomorrow, and he will wait for you in the city he predicts; (ii) when Death is uncertain he has a mild predictive bias toward Damascus. Tonight you must decide where to go. A textbook application of Causal Decision Theory (CDT) instructs you to calculate, for each act, its causal expected utility: the utility you expect conditional on performing that act, holding fixed unconditional probabilities for states of the world not causally downstream of your act. But in this set-up the probability that Death is in Damascus is exactly the probability that you will go to Damascus—hence the very number you are trying to determine in the course of deliberation. As your credence in “I shall go to Damascus” shifts, the causal expected utility of going to Damascus shifts with it, and CDT’s recommendation can oscillate back and forth. The specter of an “unstable” deliberation—one that never settles or that settles arbitrarily—has led many philosophers to wonder whether CDT harbours a hidden flaw.

My thesis is two-part.

A. Yes: CDT’s dependence on the agent’s current act-probabilities is a genuine problem, because it makes the theory normatively self-undermining. When the value a theory assigns to an option fluctuates solely in virtue of the agent’s fleeting shades of credence about which option she will pick, the theory cannot offer action-guiding advice that the agent can coherently follow. In the Death in Damascus family of cases CDT collapses into a game of “guess what you will guess”, and that is no way to steer rational action.

B. The deeper source of the problem is CDT’s insistence on evaluating acts using unconditional probabilities for states it deems “causally independent”. In Newcombish situations—including Death in Damascus—the predictor’s state is not, from the agent’s functional point of view, causally independent. The agent’s algorithm and the predictor’s algorithm are coupled. Once we recognise this, either (i) we must revise CDT so that it treats the predictor’s act as downstream of the decision process (e.g. by adopting Functional Decision Theory or some fixed-point decision rule), or (ii) we must supplement CDT with a ratifiability constraint that severs the fatal feedback loop between credence and recommendation. Unmodified CDT therefore fails, but a corrected version shows how to preserve CDT’s core causal scruples without the instability.

The argument proceeds in five steps: (2) a careful diagnosis of CDT’s calculations; (3) proof that the resulting deliberative dynamics are unstable; (4) rebuttal of two lines of defence; (5) articulation of two repairs and their implications; and (6) conclusion.

2. How CDT Computes in Death in Damascus

Let U(city) be the utility of ending up in a given city alive; let −M be the disutility of meeting Death (M for “mortality”). For simplicity set U(Aleppo)=U(Damascus)=0, and −M=−100. Let p be your present credence that you will go to Damascus; by the story, your credence that Death is in Damascus is

Pr(Death in D) = 0.9·p + 0.1·b,

where b>0.5 captures the bias toward predicting Damascus if Death is unsure. For concreteness take b=0.6, so Pr(Death in D) = 0.9p + 0.06.

CDT tells you to evaluate each act using these unconditional probabilities:

EU(Damascus) = 0·(1−Pr(Death in D)) + (−100)·Pr(Death in D) = −100(0.9p+0.06).

EU(Aleppo) = −100(1−Pr(Death in D)) = −100(1−0.9p−0.06) = −100(0.94−0.9p).

Observe that EU(Damascus) is decreasing in p, whereas EU(Aleppo) is increasing in p. Solve for the indifference point:

EU(Damascus) = EU(Aleppo) ⇒ −0.9p−0.06 = −0.94+0.9p ⇒ p* = 0.44.

Therefore:

• If p > 0.44, EU(Damascus) < EU(Aleppo): CDT says “Go to Aleppo.”
• If p < 0.44, CDT says “Go to Damascus.”

The expected utilities cross exactly at the credence 0.44. Nothing seems amiss until we remember that p is not fixed by the world; it is fixed by you while you deliberate. By merely raising your credence that you will go to Damascus across the 0.44 threshold you flip CDT’s verdict, which in turn should instantaneously lower your credence, which in turn flips the verdict back, ad infinitum. CDT has produced a non-convergent deliberation.

3. Why the Deliberative Dynamics Are Pathological

Rational deliberation is supposed to guide action by a stable procedure: start with evidence, weigh options, and settle on the act with maximal expected utility. CDT’s dependence on p breaks this picture in three ways.

a) Self-Referential Instability. The theory assigns value to an act partly in virtue of the agent’s instantaneous estimate of that very act’s probability. That is a feedback loop: change the estimate, change the value, change the estimate… In dynamical-systems language the fixed point p* = 0.44 is repelling, not attracting; small perturbations cause runaway oscillation. A decision rule that lacks an attracting fixed point offers no coherent advice.

b) Violation of “Deliberation Crowds Out Prediction.” A platitude of practical reasoning is that assenting to “I shall Φ” is the terminus of deliberation, not its object. CDT turns the attitude “I assign 0.6 to my Φ-ing” into evidence about the world to be folded back into the utility calculus. That collapses the methodological divide between choosing and predicting, leaving the agent entangled in self-prediction rather than decision.

c) No Action-Guidance. Imagine trying to implement CDT minute by minute. At t₀ your p=0.3; CDT says “Damascus,” so you resolve to go to Damascus, thereby updating to p=0.8; at t₁ CDT now says “Aleppo,” so you flip; update; flip… You either never act or you act arbitrarily when the taxi driver demands an answer. A normative theory whose literal application prevents rational action is, to that extent, defective.

4. Two Failed Lines of Defence

4.1 “This Is Just Subjective Uncertainty; Live With It.”

One might say: “All theories depend on subjective probabilities. If your probabilities oscillate, so will any expected-utility calculation. CDT is no worse off.” The reply is that CDT’s oscillation is not driven by ordinary evidential learning but by bootstrapping on your own shifting intention, which is under voluntary control. Compare: If new meteorological data makes me revise the chance of rain upward, everyone agrees the expected utility of carrying an umbrella should rise. That is healthy sensitivity to evidence. In the Damascus case, however, the only ‘evidence’ that flips the calculation is my fleeting self-belief. That is pathological self-reference, not healthy responsiveness.

4.2 “Freeze p at the Start (or the End) of Deliberation.”

A second proposal is to legislate that p be treated as exogenous—e.g. its initial value when one begins deliberating, or its limit as deliberation concludes. But which? Any such freeze is arbitrary, delivers different recommendations for infinitesimally different freeze-times, and worse, violates the principle that rational belief is sensitive to available information. The moment one notices that one is, say, firm in intending Damascus, one’s best unconditional probability for “Death waits in Damascus” must update. Freezing p is equivalent to instructing the agent to ignore her own intentions even when she becomes certain of them—hardly decent epistemic advice.

5. Two Positive Repairs

Recognising the failure of pure CDT, philosophers have pursued two strategies: ratifiability and algorithmic causation. Each can tame the instability, but they do so by amending CDT’s causal vision.

5.1 Ratifiability: Fixed-Point Expected Utility

Jeffrey and Skyrms proposed that a rational act must be ratifiable: it must maximize expected utility under the assumption that one will perform it. Formally, choose Φ only if EU(Φ | deliberation concludes with Φ) ≥ EU(Ψ | deliberation concludes with Φ) for all Ψ. In Death in Damascus the ratifiability condition eliminates oscillation, because only the mixed strategy “choose Damascus with probability 0.44” is ratifiable. The agent can approximate that by, say, tossing a biased coin. Ratifiability therefore selects a stable solution.

However, adopting ratifiability means abandoning CDT’s use of unconditional probabilities. The EU in the ratifiability test is conditional on the decision outcome, hence computed with different probability measures for different candidate acts. That is in effect a tilt toward Evidential Decision Theory. Additionally, ratifiability delivers indeterminate advice in many ordinary cases (both “buy the car” and “don’t buy” can be ratifiable), so it does not integrate smoothly with everyday CDT practice.

5.2 Functional Decision Theory and Algorithmic Dependence

A more radical correction is to revise the causal model. From the perspective of the agent’s decision algorithm, the predictor’s output is not causally independent: both outputs are functions of the same input (the traveller’s decision-procedure). On this view, the correct causal graph places a common-cause node linking “my decision output” and “Death’s location.” Once that link is acknowledged, the probability that Death is in Damascus conditional on “I go to Damascus” becomes ~0.9 or 1, not the unconditional 0.9p+0.06. CDT, applied to the right model, now advises “stay away from where the predictor believes you will go,” which, given that you control the choice, points to Aleppo with probability one. Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and Updateless Decision Theory (UDT) work along these lines and navigate Death in Damascus without instability.

This fix preserves the causal spirit—only genuine causal independencies license probability “surgery”—but insists that logical or algorithmic dependencies can ground a causal connection in the relevant sense. Advocates argue that CDT’s instability is diagnostic evidence that it omits such dependencies; once we add them, the act-probabilities drop out of the computation, and the oscillation vanishes.

6. Wider Implications and Conclusion

The Death in Damascus pathology is not an exotic edge case. Any scenario where a sophisticated predictor correlates her move with yours (Newcomb, Transparent Newcomb, Counterfactual Mugging, many bargaining games) will threaten similar feedback loops if a decision rule severs the correlation at evaluation time but leaves it alive at meta-deliberative time. CDT’s dependence on act-probabilities is thus symptomatic of a mismatch between how the theory draws causal boundaries and how real-world predictors couple to us.

To recapitulate:

1. CDT says: evaluate acts using unconditional probabilities for predictor states.
2. In Death in Damascus, those probabilities are p-dependent, where p itself is set by deliberation.
3. That dependence makes CDT’s recommendation unstable; no fixed point exists except at delicate knife-edge mixtures.
4. Instability undermines the theory’s capacity to guide action and violates basic norms of deliberation.
5. Patch-up attempts that simply freeze p or shrug at the oscillation fail.
6. Serious repairs revise CDT either by (a) adding a ratifiability constraint that replaces unconditional with conditional probabilities, or (b) enlarging the causal model to treat predictive correlations as causal links. Both fixes abandon a central plank of old-school CDT.

Therefore the dependence on act-probabilities is indeed a problem for CDT: it reveals an internal inconsistency between the theory’s epistemology (how probabilities are assigned) and its decision rule (how utilities are computed), forcing us either to reshape CDT or to replace it with a successor theory that respects the causal entanglement between our decisions and the world’s predictions of them. The traveller who wants stable, action-guiding counsel had better look elsewhere—or upgrade CDT so that Death’s scythe no longer lurks in the loops of self-prediction.

Deliberation, if all goes well, is a window through which an agent surveys the world in order to decide what to do.  What she sees through that window may change as she gathers new information, but once all the strictly factual evidence is in, her probabilities about the external world should stop oscillating merely because she is engaging in further reflection.  In Skyrms’s memorable phrase, deliberation ought to be “a biological process, not a metaphysical one”: it should produce a decision, not amplify‐feedback in the epistemic representation of the decision itself.  Standard Causal Decision Theory (CDT), however, can turn that sensible ideal on its head in “self‐reference” cases such as Death in Damascus.  Because its expected-utility formula conditions on the unconditional probability of states that are not causally downstream of the act, CDT makes the expected utility of each available act a function of the agent’s current credence that she will perform that very act.  As those act‐probabilities shift during ordinary deliberation, CDT can flip its prescription back and forth, producing an unstable, potentially indefinitely cycling decision procedure.

My thesis is that this dependence on act probabilities is indeed a deep problem for orthodox CDT—not a mere technical embarrassment.  It violates a desideratum I will call deliberative invariance, undermines diachronic coherence, and exposes CDT agents to prudent-bet money pumps.  The phenomenon shows that CDT’s epistemic severing of acts from their upstream correlates is too crude once the agent herself is known to be predictable.  The instability is not cured merely by counseling the agent to “play mixed strategies” or by insisting that the credence in one’s future act be treated as exogenous.  Rather, the pathology points toward a need for a more global or updateless perspective on choice—one that evaluates whole policies (or decision algorithms) rather than choice moments treated in isolation.

I proceed in five steps.  (1) I rehearse the Death in Damascus case and derive the CDT equations that generate the dependence.  (2) I articulate the normative ideal of deliberative invariance and show how CDT violates it.  (3) I exhibit a money-pump that turns the CDT oscillation into guaranteed loss, thereby connecting the epistemic instability to practical irrationality.  (4) I consider two well‐known “fixes” for CDT—deliberation equilibria and the appeal to causal mixed strategies—and argue that they either smuggle in an evidential perspective or else merely postpone the difficulty.  (5) I sketch a policy-level alternative that preserves CDT’s causal scruples while avoiding the reflexive incoherence.

1.  How CDT Gets Entangled with Its Own Probabilities  

Versions of the Death in Damascus story vary, but the following template is enough.  Death is an excellent, albeit not perfect, predictor of your movements.  If he predicts you will go to Damascus, he awaits you there tomorrow; otherwise he goes to Aleppo.  You care solely about staying alive.  You know that Death’s reliability is, say, 80 %.  You also know he has a mild bias toward predicting Damascus: ceteris paribus, if he is unsure, he guesses Damascus.  At t₀ you must decide whether to flee to Aleppo or remain in Damascus.

Let A be the act of going to Aleppo, D the act of staying in Damascus.  
Let AD be the state ‘Death is in Aleppo’, DD ‘Death is in Damascus’.  
Let P(AD|A) = 0.20 and P(AD|D) = 0.80, matching Death’s reliability.  Importantly, these conditional probabilities still depend on the agent’s credence that she will perform A or D, since Death’s bias is keyed to that credence.  To model that, let x = P(A), the agent’s current subjective probability that she will go to Aleppo.  Given the bias, suppose Death adopts a prior of 0.6 that you go to Damascus, modulates that by his reliability, and you incorporate that via Bayes.  One convenient representation is:

P(DD) = 0.6·0.8 + 0.4·0.2 = 0.56 if P(A) ≈ 0.4, etc.

However we fill in the numbers, the crucial fact is that P(DD) is a continuous function of x, and hence the expected utilities EDT would compute:

EU(A) = P(AD|A)·1 + P(DD|A)·0 = P(AD|A)  
EU(D) = P(DD|D)·0 + P(AD|D)·1 = P(AD|D)

are each functions of x.  CDT, by contrast, insists on stripping away the evidential correlation between act and predictor.  It uses the unconditional probabilities of AD and DD—that is, it insists on treating Death’s location as probabilistically independent of your act.  But those unconditional probabilities were themselves derived from your earlier degree of confidence that you will do A versus D.  Hence:

EUᴄᴅᴛ(A) = P(AD)·1 + P(DD)·0 = P(AD)  
EUᴄᴅᴛ(D) = P(DD)·0 + P(AD)·1 = P(DD)

with P(AD) = 1 − P(DD) = f(x).  As the meta-level credence x wobbles in the course of deliberation, f(x) wobbles, and CDT’s max-EU recommendation can alternate between A and D.

2.  The Normative Ideal of Deliberative Invariance  

By deliberative invariance I mean: once a rational agent has fixed all the ordinary empirical probabilities, the advice of decision theory should not depend on fleeting variations in her self-locating probability about which act she will finally perform.  The advice is supposed to *determine* which act she shall do; it should not *depend on* her moment-by-moment credence about that determination in progress.  Compare: a calculator’s answer to 547×23 should not constantly change as it computes; only the final settled output matters.

To dramatize CDT’s violation of invariance, suppose the agent begins with a hazy 50 / 50 credence about her eventual act, so x = 0.5.  At that credence CDT tells her to go to Aleppo, because with x = 0.5 Death is more likely to expect Damascus, making Aleppo safer.  But as she starts forming the intention to head for Aleppo, x drifts upward toward 1.  Once x crosses a threshold (in this toy model, 0.6), the unconditional probability that Death is in Aleppo now exceeds 0.5, switching the safer city to Damascus.  The agent, tracking CDT’s prescription, reverses course; x drifts back down; CDT flips again; ad infinitum.

The problem is not merely that the agent deliberates longer than necessary.  The oscillation can fail to converge, because the only fixed point is where x equals the mixed-strategy equilibrium (here, 0.6): a state in which the agent’s future act is genuinely randomised.  But CDT never advises *choosing* that mixed strategy; it is reached, if at all, only as the accidental limit of pathological vacillation.  As Skyrms noted, a decision theory that tells you to intend whatever you currently assign lower probability to intending is self-defeating.

3.  A Money-Pump Against the CDT Vacillator  

Suppose an enterprising bookmaker overhears the CDT agent musing aloud, and can instantly offer small, fair bets on whether the agent will go to Aleppo.  At each oscillation the agent’s credence about A shifts (say) from 0.55 to 0.65.  Just before it rises she is willing to sell a $1 lottery ticket that pays $1 if she goes to Aleppo for 55 cents; just after the flip she buys it back for 65 cents.  Net loss: 10 cents.  Because CDT provides no internal mechanism to halt the cycle, the bookmaker can pump an arbitrary amount of money out of the agent before t₀, at which point the agent ends up in exactly the mixed state she would have reached for free had she chosen it initially.  This shows that the CDT dynamics are not merely psychologically awkward but expose the agent to sure loss given only fair odds.  That is ordinarily taken as a mark of irrationality.

Notice that the bookie’s exploit presupposes no violation of causal principles.  She is not influencing Death; she is exploiting the fact that CDT agents treat their own developing intentions as negotiable pieces of probabilistic information.  A rational update rule should not generate buy-high-sell-low cycles in full view of the agent.

4.  Two Popular Repairs, and Why They Do Not Save CDT Proper  

4.1  Deliberation Equilibria  

Skyrms’s proposal is to locate *equilibria* of the deliberation dynamics: mixed strategies x* at which CDT’s advice stops flipping.  The idea is that the rational act is to randomise with probability x*, i.e. to adopt the policy “draw a private Bernoulli variate with parameter x*; if heads go to Aleppo, tails to Damascus.”  At x* the unconditional probability of Death’s location exactly balances the expected utilities so that neither pure act is strictly better.

Yet the equilibrium fix tacitly abandons a central CDT commitment: that what matters is the causal impact of *acts* considered one at a time.  Mixing is a way of *correlating* your eventual move with external states by exploiting the predictor’s imperfect accuracy.  But correlation is precisely what CDT was designed to ignore; it treats the external state as probabilistically independent of your act.  Introducing equilibrium mixing, therefore, covertly smuggles in an evidential perspective: the agent chooses a *policy* because she expects the choice of that policy to be informative about Death’s location.

Moreover, the set of equilibria can be unhelpfully large or empty, and the selection problem re-emerges at the policy level.  So while the move is ingenious, it is not a mere patch inside CDT; it amounts to a partial retreat toward an evidential or updateless vantage.

4.2  Causal Mixed Strategies  

Joyce and others have replied that CDT, properly understood, can evaluate *mixed strategies causally*: the probability that Death is in Damascus is conditionally independent not of the pure act but of the *randomisation device*, which is causally upstream of both pure acts.  Therefore, once the agent adopts a coin-flip policy with parameter x, the unconditional P(DD) no longer depends on her “settled-on” pure act, and the oscillation is dissolved.

This proposal, however, has teeth only because the randomiser is stipulated to be causally prior to Death’s prediction.  If the random coin toss occurs after Death has already set out, it makes no causal difference to his location.  But the way the case is set up, Death decides before the agent.  So either we require agents to install upstream randomisers in advance of every choice in which they might later be predicted—a demand bordering on foresight of all practical dilemmas—or we still face the original problem.
