More fundamentally, once we let the agent evaluate lotteries over her own pure acts, *the same mixed act probability x re-enters the CDT calculation*: EUᴄᴅᴛ(A-mix) = x·P(AD|A) + (1 − x)·P(AD|D).  If Death is a sufficiently competent interpreter, he will treat the choice of lottery as evidence about the probability distribution of acts, and the regress restarts.  This is a shell game, not a cure.

5.  Toward a Policy-Level Causal Theory  

What emerges from the foregoing is that CDT’s instability is a symptom of a deeper limitation: it treats decision nodes as *temporally and epistemically local*, ignoring the fact that in predictable‐agent problems the act’s very *decision procedure* leaks information upstream.  Once that leakage is recognised, we need a theory that evaluates whole *policies*—specifications of what the agent will do in every informational situation—without conditioning on the policy’s local output.  The guiding idea is “updatelessness”: decide ex ante, behind the veil of later self-prediction, which strategy maximises expected causal value given only the objectively open causal forks.

In the Death in Damascus scenario, an updateless causal agent would solve:

Maximise over policies π: {always-Aleppo, always-Damascus, Bernoulli(x)…}  
EU(π) = Σ_s P(s | π causes) · U(π(s), s)

where P(s | π causes) is computed holding fixed the policy as a *whole*, not the act that a particular branch of π outputs.  Because Death predicts by simulating your entire policy, the unconditional probabilities in the sum are genuinely fixed—they do not wobble with the human in-the-moment credence that she will do A vs D.  On plausible numbers, the always-Aleppo policy beats the always-Damascus policy once the predictor’s Damascus bias is factored in; and *that verdict stays fixed throughout deliberation*, satisfying deliberative invariance.  Crucially, this policy-level evaluation is still causal: we imagine interventions on which policy we adopt, then examine how the causal fabric of the world—including Death’s predictive method—responds.

One might notice that this policy-causal view converges, in the Death in Damascus family of cases, with the recommendation of Evidential Decision Theory: both pick the act that correlates best with safety.  The convergence is not accidental.  When the environment contains sophisticated predictors and copies of yourself, purely causal reasoning at the micro-act level becomes too poor an information diet: the policy you choose is itself a causal factor for the distant state.  A consistent causal theory must therefore be applied at the right grain.  Once that shift is made, the dependence of EU on moment‐to‐moment act probabilities vanishes.

Conclusion  

CDT’s act-probability dependence in Death in Damascus cases is not just an artefact of toy mathematics.  It signals a normative flaw: advice that hinges on unstable self-locating credences violates deliberative invariance, enables money pumps, and collapses under modest predictive feedback from the environment.  Attempts to rescue CDT by importing deliberation equilibria or causal randomisation either smuggle in evidential considerations or leave the instability untouched when predictors look one level higher.  The clean solution is to move CDT’s point of application from *local acts* to *global policies*.  Once we do, the expected utility of a policy no longer oscillates with the agent’s shifting view of her own future act, and rational choice regains stability.  Whether one then still calls the resulting theory “CDT” or acknowledges that the border between causal and evidential reasoning has blurred is largely terminological.  What matters is that by stepping back we avoid the self-referential mire into which orthodox CDT sinks whenever the world can guess what we are about to decide.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) has long been sold as the best way to reconcile two thoughts that sit uneasily together: first, that rational choice should aim at maximizing expected utility; second, that the expectations that matter are those that track causal rather than merely evidential correlations. But the much-discussed “Death in Damascus” story seems to reveal an internal tension in the view. As I shall argue, the tension is real and serious. CDT’s expected-utility calculation makes the value of an act a function of the agent’s own present probability of performing that act. During deliberation that probability predictably changes, and—alarmingly—the theory’s recommendation can flip back and forth in response. This dependence produces three inter‐locking pathologies: (i) diachronic instability (the agent can cycle forever); (ii) practical incoherence (the agent’s all-things-considered evaluation of an option presupposes a credence in that very option that the evaluation itself is meant to settle); and (iii) vulnerability to “manipulable games” in which others can exploit the instability. The upshot, I claim, is that CDT in its standard form fails to satisfy a minimal norm of deliberative stability. Fixes are available, but each either abandons CDT’s causal-only spirit or collapses it into a more global choice procedure akin to what recent writers call “policy-based” or “functional” decision theory. Pace some defenders, then, the dependence on act probabilities is not a harmless curiosity; it is a structural vulnerability that forces a theoretical re-orientation.

I develop the argument in five stages. Section 2 rehearses the Death in Damascus case and shows formally how act probabilities enter the CDT calculus. Section 3 diagnoses the three pathologies just mentioned. Section 4 surveys and critiques the main CDT-friendly replies: (a) the “screen-off self-knowledge” reply, (b) the “ratifiability” reply, and (c) the “tick-tock” or “deliberation dynamics” reply. Section 5 sketches a recomposition of CDT into a policy-level view that blocks the problem but at a cost: it ceases to be recognizable as orthodox CDT. I close with a brief moral about what the episode teaches us concerning the relation between causal reasoning and agency.

2. How act probabilities get inside the CDT formula

2.1 The setup

Suppose you learn that the Grim Reaper—call him “Death”—will appear tomorrow evening in whichever of two cities he predicted you would visit that day. Death’s predictive accuracy is high but not perfect: conditional on your going to Damascus, he is there with probability .9; conditional on your going to Aleppo, with probability .95. You also know that Death is somewhat biased toward predicting Damascus: ex ante, before factoring in what you will do, he is 60 % likely to choose “Damascus.” You value survival at 0 and death at –1000. Travel costs are trivial. Which city should you choose?

2.2 CDT’s standard recipe

CDT evaluates each act by summing utilities over the possible causal antecedents of that act—world-states that are *not* themselves effects of the act. For each such state S and act A, CDT plugs in the “causal probability” P(S | do(A)), i.e. the probability of S conditional on a hypothetical intervention that fixes A, then multiplies by the utility of the outcome that results when one performs A in S.

In Death in Damascus the only state variable that matters causally upstream of your act is where Death will be. Let D be the event “Death is in Damascus,” ¬D the event “Death is in Aleppo.” Your choice of city does not cause Death’s location—he is already en route—which makes his location upstream. Hence:

V_CDT(Damascus) = P(D | do(Damascus)) · (–1000) + P(¬D | do(Damascus)) · 0
V_CDT(Aleppo)    = P(D | do(Aleppo)) · (–1000) + P(¬D | do(Aleppo)) · 0.

2.3 Where the dependence enters

The causal probabilities P(D | do(A)) are not purely exogenous; they depend on how confident you currently are that you will do A. Why? Because Death’s earlier prediction is highly correlated with the very evidence you are now using to estimate your action: your total body of information about your deliberative tendencies, dispositions, and so forth. Precisely insofar as you assign some live probability p to your visiting Damascus, you should assign approximately the same p to Death’s having predicted Damascus (modulo his Damascus bias and reliability coefficients). A quick Bayesian calculation gives:

P(D | do(Damascus)) = .9 p + .05 (1–p)  
P(D | do(Aleppo))   = .1 p + .95 (1–p).

Substituting, we get:

V_CDT(Damascus) = –1000[.9 p + .05 (1–p)]  
V_CDT(Aleppo)   = –1000[.1 p + .95 (1–p)].

Simplify:

V_CDT(Damascus) = –1000(.05 + .85 p)  
V_CDT(Aleppo)   = –1000(.95 – .85 p).

Notice what now drives choice: if p > .5, Damascus has the smaller negative expected utility; if p < .5, Aleppo does.

2.4 The feedback loop

But p is (in part) under your deliberative control. If you currently lean 60 % toward Damascus (p = .6), CDT tells you Damascus is safer (–565 vs –255). Acting on that advice will push p toward 1, which in turn further entrenches the judgment that Damascus dominates. Conversely, if you start at p = .4, Aleppo looks safer; switching allegiance nudges p down toward 0, vindicating the new plan. The CDT recommendation thus tracks a moving target—the very credence it presumes in its input—creating a self-referential loop. Nothing in the bare theoretical apparatus tells you where the loop stops.

3. Three problems generated by the loop

3.1 Diachronic instability

An ideally reflective agent is supposed to converge on a choice after sufficient calculation. Yet CDT permits perpetual oscillation: I begin with p = .49, judge Aleppo safer, revise p toward 0. But mid-way, as p dips below some threshold, the “tendency toward Damascus” built into Death’s bias can pull expected utilities the other way; noticing this, I revise p back up, and so on ad infinitum. In economic terms the decision problem lacks a Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies because the payoff matrix is endogenous to the mixed proportions.

3.2 Practical incoherence

More subtly, CDT violates what John Pollock called the “deliberative constraint”: an agent should not be asked to conditionalize on probabilities of actions whose very purpose is to be settled by the deliberation. When CDT multiplies utilities by a factor containing p, the agent must input a number for p. But prior to deciding, the only coherent value for p is indeterminate or at best an interval (“somewhere between 0 and 1”). The evaluation is therefore under-determinate. A theory that instructs us to compute something we cannot coherently specify, on pain of circularity, falls short as a practical guide.

3.3 Exploitability

Because your choice hinges sensitively on your credence about your own choice, a wily adversary can nudge that credence and thereby bend your action. Suppose a rival agent can broadcast (credible) statistics about people “like you” showing they usually go to Damascus. Learning this raises p, steering you into Damascus—just where the adversary has laid a different trap. Ordinary CDT offers no defense: updating on the data is epistemically mandatory; the ensuing act switch follows mechanically.

These three pathologies do not merely make CDT inconvenient. They cast doubt on its claim to capture the norms of rational agency, for rationality includes living with one’s future self in stable accord, possessing coherent deliberative procedures, and avoiding predictable exploitation.

4. Can orthodox CDT evade the charge?

Four principal strategies have been proposed.

4.1 Screen-off self-knowledge: “take p = ½”

One thought is to quarantine the special evidence you have about your own tendencies. Use instead a “pre-deliberative state” in which you treat your action as causally open with equal odds, setting p = ½. Then:

V_CDT(Damascus) = V_CDT(Aleppo) = –525.

Symmetry breaks only when you factor in the .05 bias toward Damascus guesses, pushing Damascus slightly better. So you should go to Damascus, full stop. Problem solved?

Not quite. First, the move is ad hoc: why ½ rather than evidentially supported numbers? Second, the screening violates CDT’s core mandate to condition on all upstream information. Third, even granted, the bias toward Damascus can be arbitrarily small; then the prescription remains hostage to our choice of “fair” baseline p. The instability re-emerges.

4.2 Ratifiability

Jeffrey and later Sobel proposed that a rational decision must be *ratifiable*: the agent, upon learning she is about to choose A, should not regret A. That requirement filters out choices whose expected value would flip once you include the information “I’m (just about to) do A.” In Death in Damascus there is no ratifiable pure strategy. The only ratifiable option is a 50-50 mixed strategy in which you randomize. This defeats the dependence on p because p is no longer contingent. However, ratification is a blunt instrument. It counsels randomization even when a tiny tweak in the game, e.g. an extra penny of cost for Aleppo, would make Damascus uniquely best by any common-sense standard. Worse, ratification is silent on how to implement the coin flip in a way Death cannot predict (a point flagged by Hofbauer and Sigmund 1988). So while ratifiability obviates cycling, it introduces pragmatic absurdities.

4.3 Deliberation dynamics or “tick-tock CDT”

Another family of replies says: treat the changing p’s as stages in a dynamical system and stipulate that deliberation stops at the first fixed point. If I foresee that continued reflection will raise my p beyond .5 and thus entrench Damascus, I jump straight there. But this begs the question: which fixed point counts if more than one exists? In the standard parameterization (.9/.95 accuracy and .6 bias) both p = 0 and p = 1 are stable. Choosing either is license-compatible with CDT. The theory again under-determines choice.

4.4 Interlude: why the replies falter

Each of these maneuvers patches local symptoms yet clashes with deeper CDT commitments. Screening ignores evidence; ratifiability discards CDT’s causal-expectation core in favor of what amounts to a consistency norm; dynamical stipulation smuggles in new decision rules. The persistence of patches hints that the problem is fundamental.

5. Toward a policy-level alternative

5.1 Where the trouble really lies

CDT treats the agent’s present option as an *event* divorced from the algorithm that selects it. That abstraction is sensible when the option’s causal ancestry is independent of the selection algorithm, as in mundane errands. But in predictor cases the ancestry runs, via the opponent’s model, straight through the algorithm. The conditional probabilities CDT needs cannot be coherently specified without modelling the algorithm. Hence the self-reference. Any adequate fix must therefore relocate the locus of evaluation one level up, from acts to *policies* (choosing mechanism plus act). Once the object of choice is a policy, the dependence on the probability of a single act evaporates, because the policy fully determines that probability.

5.2 Sketch of a policy-based CDT

The simplest policy-upgrade says: evaluate a policy π by the expected utility of the (act, state) pair that results when the world contains an implementation of π. Formally:

U(π) = ∑_s P(s | World implements π) · u(Outcome(π, s)).

An agent then selects the policy that maximizes U. Importantly, “implements π” is a *causal* description that screens off the agent’s later internal coin flips; it fixes them by stipulation. Because the predictor has access to π (by assumption in predictor problems), P(s | implements π) is well-defined. A variant of CDT—call it Policy-CDT—thus retains the central causal intervention idea but expands the intervention variable to the entire decision function.

5.3 How Policy-CDT solves Death in Damascus

There are only two deterministic policies of interest:

π_D: “Go to Damascus.”
π_A: “Go to Aleppo.”

Compute utilities:

P(Death in Damascus | π_D) = .9  
P(Death in Damascus | π_A) = .05.

Hence:

U(π_D) = –900  
U(π_A) = –50.

π_A strictly dominates. No instability arises; the result ignores the agent’s credence in her future act because the act is fixed by the policy. (If stochastic policies are allowed, the optimum remains π_A for the given parameters.)

Notice that the recommendation—go to Aleppo—contradicts the baseline CDT cycles, illustrating how the policy shift is not cosmetic but substantive.

5.4 Relation to Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and Updateless EDT

The move parallels contemporary “program-based” approaches (Yudkowsky & Soares 2017) that urge agents to act as though choosing the *output* of their decision procedure, taking into account how others might predict that output. Policy-CDT coincides with FDT in standard predictor cases but diverges in others where causal networks contain structural arrows from policy to outcome bypassing predictors. What matters here is that the upgrade can be motivated entirely from inside CDT’s causal commitments: the decision variable was mis-identified; fix that, and the looping pathology vanishes.

5.5 Does this abandon CDT?

Purists will object: CDT’s charm is its local-act perspective; once we move to policies we smuggle in evidential reasoning. I reply that policy-level causation is still causal: adopting π causes both your bodily motions and the predictor’s expectation. If that feels evidential it is because in predictor scenarios the causation routes through shared source code rather than physical force. The moral is that agency is realized in code; any theory blind to code-level causal pathways will mis-fire.

6. Objections and replies

Objection 1: “Policy choice is incoherent; one can only choose an act at the moment.”  
Reply: ordinary deliberation involves selecting in advance how one will respond to contingencies—think of pre-commitment contracts. Nothing incoherent about choosing code one instant earlier than its execution.

Objection 2: “Policy-CDT collapses into Evidential Decision Theory.”  
Reply: only if every upstream variable correlating with the policy is treated as causally downstream. But policy itself can be surgically set via an intervention, preserving causal neutrality.

Objection 3: “Won’t Policy-CDT mis-behave in cases without predictors?”  
Reply: where others cannot predict your code, the conditional probabilities factor so that Policy-CDT reduces to ordinary CDT. The extension is conservative.

7. Lessons and Conclusion

Death in Damascus reveals a fault line in orthodox CDT: by confining its causal analysis to local acts while treating antecedent mental states as evidentially but not causally linked to those acts, CDT gets trapped in a feedback loop where its own input (credence in the act) depends on the very output it seeks to generate. The resulting diachronic instability, deliberative circularity, and exploitability are not fringe anomalies; they show that agency cannot be cleanly decomposed into “act now, update later.” Rational choice must treat the *algorithm* as part of the causal fabric of the world, for agents and predictors routinely interact at that level.

Once we elevate the unit of choice to policies, a refined CDT regains its composure. That refinement, however, transforms the theory into something closer to functional or program-based decision rules—no longer act-centric, no longer indifferent to logically upstream correlations. The dependence on act probabilities is therefore not a superficial glitch but a sign that CDT, in its original locus, is too small a theory of agency. Decision theorists must either enlarge CDT or adopt an alternative; clinging to the status quo is untenable.

I. The Shape of the Worry

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) begins from a seemingly simple recipe: for every act A under consideration, evaluate its causal consequences, weight the utilities of those consequences by the probability that they occur if—​in the purely causal sense—​you do A, and choose the act with the highest resulting expected utility.  The “Death in Damascus’’ story appears at first to be a straightforward test of that recipe.  You wake up in Baghdad.  You know that Death, who is an extremely good but not perfect predictor of your behavior, plans to meet you today in whichever of the two nearby cities he predicted you would visit, and that an encounter with Death is terminally bad for you (-100).  A peaceful day in the other city is neutral (0).  You also know one further empirical quirk: when Death is uncertain he guesses Damascus slightly more often than Aleppo.  Currently your credence that Death is in Damascus sits at 0.6, and your credence that you will in fact go to Damascus hovers at 0.5.  You start deliberating.

Here is the CDT cookbook applied naïvely:

EU(Damascus) = (Prob(Death in Damascus | you go to Damascus) × –100) + (Prob(Death not in Damascus | you go to Damascus) × 0).  
EU(Aleppo) = (Prob(Death in Aleppo | you go to Aleppo) × –100) + …

Because you regard Death’s location as independent of the city conditional on your act (that is, you take yourself not to causally influence where Death already decided to wait), you set

Prob(Death in Damascus | go to Damascus) = Prob(Death in Damascus) = 0.6  
Prob(Death in Aleppo | go to Aleppo)     = 0.4.

So Damascus looks worse: –60 vs –40, and CDT tells you to flee to Aleppo.

Yet an odd phenomenon now kicks in.  The very moment you form the resolution “I’ll go to Aleppo,” you reduce your credence that you will actually go to Damascus—​after all, you now regard heading to Damascus as quite unlikely.  Suppose the credence of going to Damascus falls from 0.5 to 0.1.  But reflection on Death’s reliability tells you that if you probably go to Aleppo, Death probably predicted Aleppo.  Your unconditional credence that Death waits in Aleppo therefore creeps upward.  Run the CDT numbers again and you may discover that going to Damascus now has the higher causal expected utility.  And round you go: whichever city looks better under CDT, deciding for it shifts your act credences, which shifts your belief about Death’s location, which reverses the decision.  There need be no stable point.

The question before us:  Is this dependence of CDT’s recommendations on the agent’s current act-probabilities a genuine defect of the theory?  My answer is Yes.  I will argue that the dependence produces three interlocking problems—​pragmatic instability, epistemic circularity, and normative inadequacy—​each of which violates CDT’s own guiding motivation.  I will then examine the best-known defenses and show why they fall short, before sketching a repair that preserves CDT’s causal core while excising the malignant self-reference.

II. Pragmatic Instability: The Guidance Failure

The first task of a decision theory is to guide choice.  Guidance requires what James Joyce calls “deliberative stability”: once an agent has run the decision procedure, she should be able to treat its output as a fixed point and act on it.  Classic CDT in Death-like cases fails that test, because the recipe uses as an input the very quantity—credence in performing A—​that the output is supposed to determine.

One might insist that the theory delivers a determinate directive at every instant and that the swirl of shifting credences simply reflects the fact that the agent is still deliberating.  But real-time guidance is not enough.  A usable decision procedure must also allow an agent to settle her intention, stop internal bookkeeping, and execute.  CDT here resembles a faulty thermostat whose sensor is mounted inside the heating element it controls: measure, react, overshoot, measure again, and so on in a potentially endless loop.  When the device meant to terminate dithering instead perpetuates it, something has gone wrong with the design.

III. Epistemic Circularity: The Counterfactual Confusion

CDT’s own philosophical selling point is that it cares about causal up-shots rather than mere correlations.  But in Death, the probability figure on which the evaluation of Damascus versus Aleppo turns is not a causal probability at all; it is the bare unconditional probability that Death is in a given city, which the agent updates by conditioning on her current self-estimate about her act.  That act-estimate, in turn, is inferred from the agent’s current preference between the options.  So the “causal” expected utilities smuggle in, through the back door, evidence about what one is likely to choose—​exactly the sort of evidential dependence CDT was erected to exclude.

Put schematically:

(1) EU_CDT(A) = Σ_s Prob(s) × U(s ⊗ A),  
where s ranges over states not downstream of A.

But the agent’s credence function Prob_t at time t is itself a function of t’s output of EU_CDT.  That renders EU_CDT implicitly self-referential.  A genuine causal evaluation should vary only with facts about the causal system, not with introspective facts about how sure I currently am that I will press the left or right button.  When those introspective facts alter the result, the calculation ceases to be an assessment of the act’s independent causal potency and instead becomes a hall of mirrors.

IV. Normative Inadequacy: The Ratifiability Crash

Gibbard and Harper introduced the concept of ratifiability: a recommendation is ratifiable if, upon believing that you will follow it, you still endorse it.  Death-style cases show that CDT frequently issues unratifiable advice, advice whose acceptability evaporates the moment you take it.  Such self-effacing prescriptions are not merely psychologically awkward; they contravene the normative rationale of CDT.  The whole point of isolating causal influence was to secure advice that the agent could regard as epistemically stable irrespective of what she currently believes about her own behavior.  When ratifiability collapses, the theory contradicts its founding aspiration.

V. Three Standard Replies and Their Limits

Reply 1: “Freeze probabilities at the outset.”  
Defenders sometimes maintain that the relevant unconditional probabilities are those that obtain before deliberation begins; once we fix that prior, CDT yields a single recommendation, Aleppo, and we are done.  Unfortunately, serious deliberation is itself a source of evidence.  Reflection on your emerging intention—​a twitch toward the motor plan for Aleppo, say—​is as epistemically relevant as noticing which way the wind blows.  A decision theory that orders you to ignore perfectly good evidence about where Death likely is (namely, evidence about your nascent choice) disconnects decision from belief-updating in an ad hoc way.  Worse, the “freeze” maneuver generalizes poorly.  In more realistic settings an agent rarely knows when deliberation starts or finishes; immobilizing credences is both unprincipled and impractical.

Reply 2: “The mixed-strategy fixed point.’’  
Another suggestion is that stability is restored if the agent adopts the probabilities that make her indifferent between Damascus and Aleppo—​in effect, play a mixed strategy whose chance component the agent somehow implements.  But CDT provides no resources for preferring the unique mixed strategy to any pure strategy; indeed, standard CDT regards mixed acts as dominated, because tossing a coin has all the same causal consequences as going straight to Damascus or Aleppo but with added disutility from delay.  Introducing mixed strategies here is a patch imported from game theory, not something CDT can justify internally.

Reply 3: “Causal modeling with the do-operator.’’  
A sophisticated line holds that the dependence on act-probabilities is irrelevant once we distinguish between conditioning on A and intervening on A (Pearl’s do(A)).  Prob(Death in Damascus | do(Aleppo)) is, by hypothesis, 0.6 regardless of what I currently think I will do.  Therefore EU_CDT is stable.  The difficulty is that, in Death, the very same structural model that licenses the do-calculus says there is a causal arrow from my deliberative state to Death’s earlier prediction (because Death predicted on the basis of evidence about my dispositions).  A clean do-intervention would have to cut that arrow, but then the model no longer represents the scenario.  The do-calculus thus obtains stability only by stipulating away the predictor’s correlation—​in effect, making Death a stranger who guesses at random.  That is not a defense of CDT in the original case but a re-description of the case into one in which the phenomenon disappears.

VI. Digging Deeper: Where the Self-Reference Comes From

Step back.  Why does CDT need probabilities of non-downstream states at all?  The answer is that CDT endorses a one-shot act-evaluation perspective: hold fixed everything you do not causally affect and compare the worlds.  In most mundane settings, the probabilities of those background states are exogenous to the decision and hence stable.  In prediction cases they are not: because the predictor’s state is itself a causal descendant of your character traits, deliberation provides evidence about that state.  So the background/non-background distinction on which CDT relies becomes porous.  The predictor’s location is downstream of your long-term dispositions, but not downstream of the momentary muscular contraction that sends you to Damascus or Aleppo.  CDT’s act-level granularity is too coarse to register that subtle causal structure.  The result is that evidence about downstream-of-you variables is illegitimately imported into the calculation.

VII. A Better Way: Policy-Causal Decision Theory

We might conclude that CDT is hopeless, but the core idea—care only about consequences you can causally influence—​is intuitively attractive.  The trick is to shift the unit of analysis from acts to policies.  Call the alternative Policy-CDT (PCDT):

PCDT Prescription:  
1. Treat the agent’s entire disposition to act in response to her epistemic state—​what game theorists call a pure strategy—​as the causal intervention variable.  
2. For each candidate policy π, compute EU(π) = Σ_s Prob(s) × U(s ⊗ π(s)), where s now ranges over complete histories up to the choice-point, including the predictor’s earlier observations.  
3. Choose the policy with maximal EU.

Because a policy is selected before the predictor gathers data, Death’s location is downstream of the causal variable.  Hence the unconditional probability of Death being in Damascus given policy π is sensitive to π but wholly independent of the agent’s real-time credence that she will execute Damascus at the final moment.  There is no self-reference.  In the Death case, the policy “always go to the city the predictor is less likely to select’’ yields higher expected utility than its rival and is stable under ratification.

The shift from acts to policies is not ad hoc.  It aligns CDT with the interventionist credo: manipulate the aspect of the world you genuinely control.  You do not causally manipulate your muscular spasm in isolation from the process that gives rise to it; you manipulate the deliberative procedure that determinately issues in that spasm.  Once we see that, the need to consult real-time act-probabilities evaporates.

VIII. Does PCDT Abandon Core CDT?

No.  What CDT really cares about is screening off mere evidential correlations from causal efficacy.  Policy-level appraisal preserves that spirit while avoiding the mathematical pathology.  The dependence on act-probabilities was never a constitutive commitment of CDT; it was a pragmatic shortcut that works when predictors are absent.  PCDT keeps the shortcut where safe and avoids it where not.

IX. Objection and Reply

Objection: “Policy evaluation is computationally intractable; human agents cannot survey all contingencies, so CDT needs an act-based rule.”

Reply:  Normative principles need not match human bandwidth.  Besides, policy evaluation can proceed incrementally: one need only compare the currently salient policies, not the power-set of possibilities.  More importantly, tractability is not worth a theory that yields advice an idealized version of oneself cannot stably endorse.  Guidance for bounded agents can be layered atop a sound ideal theory; it cannot rescue an unsound one.

Objection: “The predictor’s reliability need not stem from your policy; it may stem from microphysical cues emitted milliseconds before choice.  Then your policy does not causally influence Death’s earlier decision.”

Reply:  Fine-grained versions of the predictor scenario raise deep questions about personal identity across time scales.  If the micro-cues are causally downstream of your deliberation, PCDT treats them as such; if not, then even EDT (evidential decision theory) cannot exploit them.  The dependence of Death’s location on your gradual choice-formation is what makes the example arresting.  When that dependence is broken, the case collapses into one where CDT and common sense agree.

X. Wider Implications

1. Newcomb’s Problem.  The same analysis explains why many philosophers have the intuition to one-box.  The one-box policy, chosen earlier, causally controls the filling of the opaque box via the predictor; the two-box policy does not.

2. Dynamic Consistency.  Policy-level CDT meshes with sophisticated choice in game theory, where agents adopt strategies that remain optimal at every node given knowledge of the strategy.  It thereby restores the link between causal decision theory and the principles of sequential rationality.

3. Implementation in AI.  Current work in “counterfactual planning’’ for AI safety already moves toward policy-level evaluation.  The need to inoculate agents against nasty predictor feedback loops is practical, not merely philosophical.

XI. Conclusion

Yes, CDT’s dependence on the agent’s fluctuating act-probabilities in Death-type scenarios is a genuine problem.  It produces guidance failure, smuggles evidential correlations back into an allegedly causal calculus, and issues unratifiable advice.  Attempts to rescue the standard act-based formulation by freezing priors, by recommending mixed strategies, or by invoking the do-operator without a matching causal model, all misfire.  The root of the trouble is that CDT evaluates local acts rather than global policies, thereby ignoring that predictors exploit evidence about the very process that issues in the act.  Once we raise the grain of causal intervention from acts to policies, the instability disappears.  The resulting Policy-CDT retains CDT’s motivational core while avoiding epistemic circularity and pragmatic self-defeat.  That, I submit, is how a genuinely causal decision theory should proceed—​and why the traditional dependence on act probabilities is not only a blemish but a structural fault that demands repair.

A Problem for Causal Decision Theory: Deliberative Unrest in Death-in-Damascus

1. Introduction and Thesis

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells an agent to pick the act whose causal expected utility is highest, where the expectation is taken with respect to her unconditional credence distribution over states that are not causally downstream of the act. In Death-in-Damascus cases that distribution is not exogenous: what city one ends up crediting Death with predicting depends partly on how likely one now takes oneself to be to go to that city. Consequently the causal expected utility of each act slides around as one’s own act-probabilities shift during deliberation. I shall argue that this dependence is not a mere curiosity but signals a deep flaw in CDT. The core of the worry is that CDT’s evaluating rule presupposes a stable set of unconditional probabilities, yet in self-referential environments it requires the agent to consult probabilities that are themselves being reshaped by the very deliberation the rule is supposed to guide. That renders CDT normatively unstable: the “ought” that it delivers is hostage to arbitrary, flickering credences about what one is about to do. In such environments CDT cannot even guarantee the existence of a deliberatively stable recommendation short of trivial or dominated courses of action, and so fails to give determinate, reason-giving advice.

The argument proceeds in six steps. (i) I lay out a stylised Death-in-Damascus model and show how CDT’s expectation formula imports act-probabilities. (ii) I exhibit the resulting phenomenon of deliberative seesawing. (iii) I distinguish three potential diagnoses—epistemic, psychological, structural—and show why only the structural one targets CDT itself. (iv) I argue that the instability violates a ratifiability requirement implicit in rational deliberation. (v) I rebut two CDT-friendly replies: the claim that rational agents should assign degenerate act-probabilities, and the suggestion that the right object of choice is not an act but a mixed strategy. (vi) I sketch two paths forward—policy selection and counterfactual-entropy decision theory—to indicate how one might repair the defect, though each involves abandoning a key CDT commitment.

2. Formalising Death-in-Damascus

Suppose you wake knowing that today Death will take you unless you avoid being in the city he predicted you would visit. Death’s prediction mechanism is 90 % reliable and has a built-in bias toward guessing Damascus: ceteris paribus his prior probability of guessing Damascus is 0.6, Aleppo 0.4. You value survival at 10 utils and death at −10. Travel is costless.

Denote acts by A (go to Aleppo) and D (go to Damascus). The relevant upstream states encode Death’s prediction, noted as PA and PD. Outcomes are:

A & PA  safe  10  
A & PD  dead  −10  
D & PD  safe  10  
D & PA  dead  −10  

Let P(PA) = 0.4, P(PD) = 0.6 before deliberation. Death’s reliability β = 0.9 means P(PA | A) = β and P(PD | A) = 1 − β, and symmetrically for going to Damascus. CDT’s prescription is to evaluate each act by causal expected utility (CEU):

CEU(A) = Σs P(s) U(outcome given A, s).

Because the states include Death’s prediction but exclude your act, CDT uses the unconditional probabilities P(PA) and P(PD), not the conditional probabilities given the act. So at t₀ one computes:

CEU₀(A) = 0.4·10 + 0.6·(−10) = −2  
CEU₀(D) = 0.6·10 + 0.4·(−10) = 2

So CDT initially recommends going to Damascus. But—and this is the kicker—those unconditional probabilities were derived from your original credence about what you would do. If during deliberation you come to regard A as more likely than D, you must revise the priors about Death’s guess correspondingly (because you took his bias and reliability to be features of his predictor). Suppose halfway through you now think you will choose Aleppo with probability 0.7. Updating mechanically yields new priors P(PA) = 0.58, P(PD) = 0.42 and hence:

CEU₁(A) = 0.58·10 + 0.42·(−10) = 1.6  
CEU₁(D) = 0.42·10 + 0.58·(−10) = −1.6

The preferred act has flipped. Nothing in the world outside your head has changed; only your act-probabilities have shifted, yet CDT’s advice has reversed. Another round of reflection reverses the credences again, generating a deliberative oscillation with no fixed point.

3. Diagnosing the Oscillation

One might suspect three culprits.

Epistemic: perhaps the agent mismanages conditionalisation. But she is updating her credences about Death’s guess via perfectly ordinary Bayesian conditioning on her own behavioural evidence. No epistemic norm is violated.

Psychological: maybe real humans cannot sustain such rapid endogenous updates. Yet the worry here is normative, not empirical. Even an ideally rational agent following CDT’s rule would feel the seesaw.

Structural: the instability stems from CDT’s very formula because it treats the unconditional probabilities over predictor states as inputs, whereas they in fact depend on the outputs—her contemplated act probabilities. This is the correct diagnosis: CDT assumes independence between the choice variable and the prior over upstream variables, an assumption that fails in self-referential setups.

4. Ratifiability and the Need for a Fixed Point

Jeffrey introduced the notion of ratifiable choices: an act is ratifiable when, after learning that one will perform it, one would still endorse it. Viewed through that lens, the Death-in-Damascus oscillation shows that CDT can recommend acts that are unratifiable relative to the very credences it uses in the expectation calculus. At t₀ CDT says “go to Damascus,” but the moment one embraces that advice one’s credence that one will go to Damascus spikes, driving up P(PD) and turning Damascus into the option with negative CEU. The choice undermines the grounds on which it was chosen. Conversely, any act that is ratifiable must solve the fixed-point equation CEU(a; P⁰) ≥ CEU(b; P⁰) for all alternatives b, where P⁰ are the priors that incorporate the fact that one chooses a. In our toy numbers neither pure act satisfies that equation; the only fixed point is a mixed strategy that equalises the unconditional priors (choose each city with probability 0.5, so Death’s bias is neutralised). CDT, however, was never designed to select mixtures; its locus of evaluation is the act actually issued at the decision node. Hence it generates recommendations that self-sabotage.

More generally, any theory of rational choice should possess what we might call deliberative stability: following its advice should not predictably undermine the expected-utility comparison that constituted the advice. CDT lacks that property in predictor environments.

5. Two CDT-Friendly Replies and Why They Fail

Reply 1: “A rational agent should assign her own future acts probability one. Intentions settle probabilities; once you intend D, P(D)=1, so no oscillation arises.”  
Rebuttal: CDT’s recommendation is supposed to guide the formation of that very intention. Before the intention is fixed, a non-degenerate distribution over acts is appropriate. Imposing degenerate self-credences at the outset amounts to smuggling a bootstrap principle—“decide, then evaluate”—that empties the theory of normative force.

Reply 2: “The real options are not acts but mixed strategies. CDT ought to compare lotteries over acts, find the Nash equilibrium at 0.5/0.5, and there stability is restored.”  
Rebuttal: (a) CDT as standardly formulated treats intentional acts, not self-probabilising lotteries, as the decision objects. (b) Even if we retrofit it, the theory’s core motivational story collapses. The reason CEU(A) was attractive originally is that A would causally produce safe outcomes when Death predicted Aleppo. Introducing a mixed strategy means the act chosen at the decision node is still deterministic; the lottery occurs earlier in a hypothetical randomiser independent of your brain. The causal influence structure thereby changes, and it is no longer clear that CDT evaluations over policies deliver the same causal counterfactuals it was meant to model. In effect, the repair morphs CDT into a kind of policy-selection Evidential Decision Theory.

6. Why the Instability Is a Problem for CDT Itself

The defender might still say, “Sure, CDT is silent in weird self-referential scenarios, but so what? Decision theory’s main job is ordinary causal choice.” That answer is unsatisfying for two reasons.

First, Death-in-Damascus is not an isolated pathology. Any environment containing predictors—financial markets anticipating trades, opponents in repeated games, even one’s own future self in dynamic choice—injects precisely the same feedback loop. If CDT cannot supply determinate guidance in these commonplace strategic contexts, its range of applicability is cramped.

Second, rival theories cope better. Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) keeps the unconditional probabilities conditioned on the evidence of one’s act, thereby factoring in that performing A is evidence that Death predicted A. EDT therefore stably recommends a 0.5/0.5 mixture, in line with ratifiability. Functional Decision Theory (FDT) and policy-selection accounts also generate determinate advice without deliberative oscillation. The comparative failure of CDT counts against it.

7. Possible Repairs and Their Costs

Path A: Ratifiable CDT. Demand that an act is choice-worthy only if it is a fixed point of CDT evaluation. In Death-in-Damascus this selects either the mixed strategy or the dominating option “stay home,” if available. But this supplement is ad hoc; it changes CDT’s decision criterion from maximising causal expected utility to maximising causal EU subject to ratifiability, and in Newcomb-like problems it pushes CDT toward EDT verdicts, undermining the distinctive motivation for CDT.

Path B: Policy-Selection CDT. Shift the unit of agency from an act at a node to a global policy mapping predictor beliefs to acts. One then computes causal EU relative to policy-level counterfactuals that hold the algorithm fixed across worlds. That eliminates feedback during deliberation because the act-probabilities are buried inside a policy that is treated as exogenous at evaluation time. But this is essentially the move Yudkowsky and Soares call Functional Decision Theory; adopting it forsakes CDT’s insistence on local, act-level causal independence.

Either fix illustrates the moral: to restore deliberative stability one must abandon the standard CDT formula.

8. Conclusion

Dependence on act probabilities is indeed a problem for CDT. It is not merely a technical nuisance but a symptom of a mismatch between CDT’s act-level, one-shot evaluation rule and the reflexive structure of real-world deliberation in which beliefs about what one will do feed back into beliefs about non-downstream states. The resulting oscillation violates ratifiability, deprives CDT of determinate recommendations in predictor-rich environments, and forces either a retreat to degenerate self-credences or a theoretical overhaul that abandons CDT’s core principles. A decision theory whose advice evaporates the moment one begins to follow it is normatively defective. The Death-in-Damascus puzzle therefore reveals a deep instability at the heart of causal decision theory.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) is advertised as a way of isolating the part of the world an agent can truly influence—her causal downstream—and then telling her to maximise expected utility with respect to that causal structure.  In ordinary cases that looks impeccable.  In the family of Death-in-Damascus (DiD) problems, however, the very act of deliberation alters the probabilities that CDT plugs into its expectation formula, and the theory’s advice wobbles accordingly.  I shall argue that this sensitivity to an agent’s shifting act-probabilities is not a harmless curiosity but a structural defect.  It leaves CDT without a stable decision rule, exposes an agent to exploitation, and ultimately betrays the purported motivation for CDT—namely, to separate what you can control from what you merely learn about.  The only workable repairs (ratifiability, policy selection, or fixed-point requirements) amount to abandoning a core commitment of orthodox CDT.  So yes, the dependence is a genuine problem.

2. The Set-Up: Death in Damascus

Suppose you wake in Baghdad knowing Death is looking for you today.  You may flee to Aleppo or Damascus.  Death is an able predictor: with probability .9 he guesses the city you will choose.  When he guesses right, he waits there; when he guesses wrong, he mistakenly goes to the other city.  If he finds you, you die (utility = 0).  If you miss him, you live (utility = 10).  Finally, you have a prior belief that Death slightly prefers guessing Damascus: P(D predicts Damascus) = .6 in the absence of further information.

Two features generate trouble.

a) Your survival depends on the match (or mismatch) between a prediction that is not causally downstream of today’s choice and the act you end up performing.

b) The conditional probability of the predictor’s location given that you go to Damascus is itself a function of how likely you currently think you are to go there.  The more firmly you intend Damascus, the more confident you become that Death predicted as much.

3. How CDT Computes in DiD

Let α be your current subjective probability of going to Damascus.  (1-α) is your probability for Aleppo.  CDT advises:

EU(Damascus) = 10 × P(Death in Aleppo | do(Damascus))
EU(Aleppo)    = 10 × P(Death in Damascus | do(Aleppo))

Because Death guesses correctly 90 % of the time,

P(Death in Damascus | do(Damascus)) = .9 + .1 × P(D predicts Damascus | do(Damascus) & Death mispredicts)
But the misprediction clause collapses: if you do go to Damascus that fact is excellent evidence that Death predicted Damascus.  More compactly,

P(Death in Damascus | do(Damascus)) = .9 × P(D predicts Damascus | do(Damascus))
                                    + .1 × P(D predicts Aleppo | do(Damascus))  = .9

Similarly,

P(Death in Damascus | do(Aleppo)) = .1 × P(D predicts Damascus | do(Aleppo))
                                 + .9 × P(D predicts Aleppo | do(Aleppo)).

Those conditional prediction probabilities depend on α.  Using Bayes’ rule one obtains

P(D predicts Damascus | do(Aleppo)) = (.6 × .1) / (.6 × .1 + .4 × .9) = f(α),

and a symmetric expression for the other term.  The algebra is less important than the moral: as α slides around during deliberation, these conditional credences change continuously, and so CDT’s EU numbers drift.

4. The Instability: Chasing the Moving Target

Suppose you start with α = .6.  You therefore expect Death probably predicted Damascus.  EU(Damascus) ≈ 10 × .9 = 9; EU(Aleppo) ≈ 10 × .1 = 1.  CDT cries: “Flee to Aleppo!”  But the moment you start leaning towards Aleppo your α falls, and you begin to think Death is less likely to have predicted Damascus.  Lower α raises the conditional probability that Death predicted Aleppo, which increases the danger in Aleppo and reduces the danger in Damascus.  Soon EU(Damascus) is larger again and CDT reverses itself.  Back and forth the recommendations flip with no stable resting point except the knife-edge where α is exactly that value for which the two expected utilities tie.

Orthodox CDT thus offers guidance only after you have first solved the fixed-point equation: “Adopt that mixture of acts whose very adoption makes you indifferent between acts.”  But CDT itself never mentions fixed points; the need is smuggled in by the demand for deliberational stability.

5. Three Symptoms of The Deeper Problem

5.1 Lack of Action-Guidance

A decision rule should tell you what to do; CDT in DiD instead hands you a differential equation for your credences.  Even the sophisticated agent able to solve for the equilibrium must first notice that CDT’s advice is oscillating.  Nothing in the axioms explains why she should privilege the equilibrium over the oscillations.  So CDT fails the basic practical test: provide determinate, self-endorsing guidance.

5.2 Dutch Books and Money Pumps

Andy Egan (2007) exploits a variant to money-pump a CDT agent.  Offer a cheap binding contract to send her to whichever city she currently thinks safer; repeated oscillations guarantee she buys and sells the contract indefinitely, bleeding utility.  A theory that exposes fully rational agents to sure loss is at least pragmatically defective.

5.3 Violation of Motivational Rationale

CDT was sold on the slogan “only causes matter to decision, correlations do not.”  Yet the reason its expectations wobble is precisely that correlations with your own act re-enter through the back door: the conditional probability P(prediction | act).  CDT thus covertly relies on information it officially disdains.  The instability is the revenge of the correlations that causal purists hoped to ignore.

6. Can CDT Be Defended?

Proponents have tried three lines of rescue.

6.1 Exogenous Determinism

“One’s act-probabilities should be 0 or 1,” say Joyce, Levi, and others.  Decision takes place after probabilities about one’s own act have collapsed.  Unfortunately this means you must (somehow) choose before consulting CDT, then ask CDT to ratify the choice.  The direction of dependence—guidance versus post-hoc vindication—is reversed, nullifying CDT’s practical use.

6.2 Ratifiability

Jeffrey’s notion of a ratifiable act is one that maximises expected utility conditional on performing that very act.  Applied here, the only ratifiable mixture is the fixed-point mixed strategy.  However, two problems remain.

a) Non-existence.  In variants with three options sometimes no mixture is ratifiable.

b) Dominance.  The ratifiable act can be stochastically dominated by an unavailable but conceivable commitment (e.g., paying $1 for a coin flip that biases you slightly towards the safer city).  So ratifiability is neither guaranteed nor obviously desirable.

6.3 Counterfactual Miracles

Lewis and Pearl suggest computing probabilities in a graph where “do(Aleppo)” severs all informational links from the act to upstream nodes.  If one could insist that Death’s prediction is upstream, then P(Death predicts Damascus | do(Aleppo)) = .6 regardless of α, erasing the instability.  The price is high: it treats one’s beliefs about Death’s prediction as eternally fixed, independent of any information gleaned during deliberation.  An agent who actually realises she is inclining to Aleppo thereby gets genuine evidence about the prediction; forbidding her from updating on that evidence is tantamount to hobbling Bayesian conditionalisation.

To summarise: each defence either strips CDT of the ability to learn from introspection or yields a different decision rule in disguise.

7. Diagnosing the Malady: Deliberation Dependence

Where exactly does the pathology arise?  CDT feeds into its expectation formula the probabilities P(s | do(a)).  But the agent’s credence function is itself dynamically linked to her uncertainty about which do-operator will be executed.  The formalism assumes an exogenous “act node” that one may wiggle independently of upstream parents; deliberation in realistic agents means the upstream parents obtain evidence about the eventual wiggle.  CDT’s representation of agency is thus idealised in a way that breaks down precisely when other predictors model the agent.

In game-theoretic language, CDT treats a decision problem as a one-move game against nature; DiD reveals the need for an equilibrium concept sensitive to self-locating uncertainty and modelling mirrors.  What the agent selects is not, strictly speaking, an act but a policy: a mapping from informational states (including introspective ones) to acts.  Once the unit of choice is the whole policy, upstream predictors correlate with the policy rather than the particular act produced on one occasion, and the oscillation disappears.  But that is essentially the shift from act-focused CDT to policy-focused Functional Decision Theory or Updateless Decision Theory.  The cure is available only by changing theories.

8. An Illuminating Variant: The Small-Switch Cost

Add a trivial cost ε (say, a penny) each time you change cities mid-deliberation.  Because CDT’s recommendation flips infinitely often as you refine your credences, you pay an unbounded expected switch cost: for any finite N there is some stage of deliberation where you have already switched more than N times.  Yet an oracle offering to freeze your first impulse for $1 would save you an expected fortune.  That is a dominance argument: some available strategy weakly improves on whatever CDT leads you to do.  The deliberation dependence is not a mild inefficiency; it can be exploited to extract unbounded utility.

9. Novel Framing: The Control–Evidence Spectrum

The DiD pathology suggests a two-dimensional space of decision situations.

Dimension 1: Degree of causal control over the outcome.
Dimension 2: Degree of evidential correlation between your deliberation trajectory and the outcome.

Standard CDT handles high-control/low-correlation cases beautifully.  Newcomb problems are low-control/high-correlation and favour EDT.  DiD occupies the mixed interior: moderate causal control entangled with moderate correlation.  Any satisfactory theory must handle the whole spectrum.  CDT’s deliberation dependence shows it is limited to a boundary region.  This reframing reveals that the traditional CDT-v-EDT dichotomy was never exhaustive; a deeper synthesis (policy selection) is forced upon us by interior points like DiD.

10. Objection and Reply

Objection: “Oscillation merely shows that the agent lacks self-knowledge.  A perfectly rational agent would have sharp credences about her eventual act from the outset, eliminating α’s drift and stabilising CDT’s advice.”

Reply: The objection conflates foreknowledge with rationality.  A rational deliberator can be uncertain about the outcome of a stochastic or even a deterministic internal process—after all, she has finite computational power.  Forbidding such self-locating uncertainty would turn CDT into a decision theory for omniscient gods, not bounded agents like us.  Moreover, if an agent really did have deterministic foreknowledge (“I will go to Damascus”), then conditional on that knowledge the question of deliberation no longer arises; the theory has merely been applied outside its domain of interest.

11. Relation to Other Puzzles

The same deliberation dependence arises in:

a) The “Transparent Newcomb” problem where seeing two boxes makes one’s credence about what the predictor forecast hinge on whether one is reaching for one or two.  
b) The “Abstention” variant of voting paradoxes where contemplating abstention changes the expected causal effect of a vote.  
c) Sequential medical testing where each provisional intention to test or not test updates the chance that one’s disease was previously caught.

Seeing these as instances of a single structural weakness suggests a research programme: systematically classify scenarios where CDT’s input probabilities depend on the agent’s introspective state, and develop a unified replacement decision theory.

12. Toward a Normative Constraint: Deliberation-Invariance

A promising patch is to require:

Deliberation-Invariance: A rational decision rule’s recommendation must be invariant across belief states that differ only with respect to the agent’s current, revisable probability for the very acts under consideration.

CDT violates this constraint in DiD; policy-based theories satisfy it because the unit of evaluation is a deliberation-stable object (the policy).  If deliberation-invariance is accepted as a desideratum, CDT is normatively inadequate.

13. Conclusion

CDT’s dependence on shifting act-probabilities in Death-in-Damascus cases is more than an oddity.  It yields unstable advice, enables exploitation, and contradicts CDT’s motivating idea of attending solely to what one can causally influence.  Defenders can insulate CDT only by grafting on principles—ratifiability, commitment devices, policy selection—that either excise the very probabilities that cause trouble or else reconstrue the object of choice.  Once those moves are made, the resulting theory is no longer orthodox CDT.

The lesson is not merely that CDT mishandles one fanciful puzzle.  It is that a decision rule tied to single-act causal influence but blind to the evidential feedback from one’s own epistemic state cannot hope to be deliberation-invariant in a world containing other predictors and mirror-like regularities.  Rational agency requires evaluating whole policies or algorithms whose causal fingerprints extend upstream.  Death, in Damascus or elsewhere, drives the point home.

Death has left Damascus for Aleppo.  
Or so he will have done, if—and only if—you go to Aleppo.  
If instead you remain in Damascus, Death will already be waiting for you there.  
So runs the familiar fable.  In Jeffrey‐style form:

    Act options:  A = go to Aleppo,  D = stay in Damascus  
    State options:  a = Death is in Aleppo,  d = Death is in Damascus  
    Pay-offs:  U(survive) = 0,  U(die) = –1000

Death is remarkably—but not perfectly—good at prediction.  Let
    r = the reliability of Death’s guess (0.9, say)  
    b = his built-in bias toward guessing Damascus (0.6, say).

Nothing you do now can causally influence the earlier prediction, but the prediction is exquisitely correlated with what you will in fact do.  Consequently

(1) P(d) = r·P(D) + (1 – r)·P(A) + (b – ½)·f(r, b, P(D)),

where P(D) is your present credence that you will go to Damascus.  
Because P(d) feeds directly into the expected utility of each act, the CDT ranking of acts is itself a function of P(D).  As your credence about your own future move shifts while you deliberate, CDT’s verdict about which move is utility-maximizing shifts with it.  The question before us is whether that dependence is a defect in Causal Decision Theory.  I shall argue that it is, for two interconnected reasons:

Thesis.  (i) Because CDT’s expected-utility rankings vary continuously with the agent’s unstable self-credences, the theory can fail to supply determinate action guidance to a perfectly informed but still deliberating agent; and (ii) the phenomenon reveals a deeper structural flaw—CDT evaluates single acts in isolation when the real objects of control in predictor cases are policies or earlier decision algorithms.  Rectifying the flaw requires a reformulation of CDT, not merely better bookkeeping.

The route to this conclusion will be as follows.  Section 1 formalises the dependence on P(D) and exhibits the “wandering recommendations” phenomenon.  Section 2 argues that wandering recommendations deprive CDT of what a decision theory is for—stable deliberative guidance.  Section 3 considers three prominent rejoinders and shows why each leaves the underlying problem intact.  Section 4 diagnoses the root of the trouble: CDT’s act-centric, moment-by-moment perspective in contexts where what really matters is an earlier, policy-level causal node.  Section 5 sketches an updateless, policy-centred variant of CDT that escapes the instability while preserving the causal spirit.  The final section extracts two broader morals about the interface between causation, prediction, and rational choice.

1.  The mathematics of shifting recommendations  
——————————————————————————————

Write r = .9 and b = .6 for concreteness.  Then, conditional on act A:

    EU(A) = (1 – P(d)) · 0  +  P(d) · (–1000)  = –1000·P(d).

Similarly,

    EU(D) = –1000·(1 – P(d)).

Hence CDT recommends Aleppo iff P(d) > ½, Damascus iff P(d) < ½, and is indifferent at exactly ½.  But by Bayes,

    P(d) = r·P(D) + (1 – r)·P(A) + b – ½.

Substituting and simplifying:

    P(d) = (2r – 1)·P(D) + b.

With r = .9 this gives

    P(d) = .8·P(D) + .6.

Plugging back, CDT recommends Aleppo whenever

    .8·P(D) + .6 > ½   ⇒   P(D) > –.125.

Since P(D) is necessarily between 0 and 1, the inequality is always satisfied.  So in the numerical example CDT stably prefers Aleppo.  Why, then, the alleged problem?

Because the example can be tuned so that the crossing point falls inside (0,1).  Let r = .8, b = .6.  Now

    P(d) = .6·P(D) + .6.

CDT prefers Aleppo iff .6·P(D) + .6 > ½, i.e. P(D) > –1/6 (always true).  Still no shift.  Push r farther down.  Set r = .55, b = .6:

    P(d) = .1·P(D) + .6.

CDT prefers Aleppo iff .1·P(D) + .6 > ½   ⇒   P(D) > –1.  Again, Aleppo.  What happened to the instability?

It surfaces once the bias b is less strong than the reliability advantage r confers on the accurate guess.  Let r = .9 as before but b = .4 (Death still slightly favours Damascus, but not by much).  Now

    P(d) = .8·P(D) + .4,

and CDT prefers Aleppo when P(D) > .125, Damascus when P(D) < .125.  If your initial hunch is that you’ll end up in Damascus with probability, say, .20, CDT tells you to go to Aleppo.  The moment you take that advice seriously, your credence that you will in fact go to Damascus dips below the .125 threshold, flipping CDT’s recommendation to Damascus—leading you to revise your credence upward, which flips the recommendation back, and so on ad infinitum.  In the limit, no act is ratifiable: neither is the unique maximum of its own expected utility given that choosing it would alter the very credences on which that expectation was calculated.

2.  Why wandering recommendations matter  
———————————————————————

A decision rule is supposed to do two jobs:

Guidance.  It should tell a deliberating agent what to do.  
Evaluation.  It should vindicate or criticise acts after the fact.

The second job survives intact; CDT can still declare, of the person who ended up in Aleppo and lived, that her act had higher causal expected utility relative to the credences she in fact had at the last moment of choice.  The first job, however, is threatened.  When the act ranking is a continuous function of the agent’s unstable self-credences, advice becomes self-frustrating.  No matter which option the agent tentatively resolves upon, CDT immediately announces that, given this very resolution, a different option is preferable.  The theory thus fails to output an answer that an ideally rational but finitely introspective deliberator could implement.

That failure is not a merely practical inconvenience.  A core selling point of CDT over Evidential Decision Theory (EDT) is its promise of dynamic coherence: because CDT conditions only on causal predecessors, it purportedly immunises the agent against the evidential blackmail and Newcombish traps that bedevil EDT.  Yet in Death‐in‐Damascus cases the causal independence of past prediction is precisely what drives the instability.  CDT therefore loses the guidance advantage it advertises.

3.  Three attempted repairs  
———————————————

Repair 1.  “Treat P(D) as exogenous.”  
Joyce (2012) suggests that a rational agent should not regard P(D) as a free variable.  It is a belief about her own future act formed on the basis of self‐knowledge and background data.  As such it should be treated as a hard datum during the very act it describes; deliberation aims to discover, not to alter, what you are going to do.  If P(D) is fixed, the instability evaporates.

Reply.  Two problems.  First, the discovery model is psychologically implausible: we do in practice revise credences about our own future behaviour while reflecting on reasons.  Second, even stipulating fixity, CDT provides no criterion for which prior to fix.  An “updateless” prior from the previous evening?  The first credence that occurs to you after reading the problem?  Unless some canonical choice is supplied, the prescription is indeterminate.

Repair 2.  “Randomise.”  
Arntzenius (2008) proposes intentional mixing.  You can choose a lottery that sends you to Damascus with probability p.  Expected utility is now a continuous function of p over which you have direct control, and it has a maximum at a fixed point of the earlier equations.  Pick that p and the instability is resolved.

Reply.  Two objections.  (i) The availability of costless randomisation is an artificial assumption; one can run versions of the case where tossing coins is itself observable by Death or where randomisation is legally or physically impossible.  (ii) More importantly, the solution shifts CDT from an act evaluator to a mixed-strategy optimiser.  Once that move is on the table, nothing prevents an evidentialist from making the same move, so CDT’s distinctive selling point again disappears.

Repair 3.  “Embed CDT in an extensive form.”  
Skyrms (1996) treats the predictor as part of a larger game between you and Death.  Solve for the equilibrium of the game, and the recommendation emerges.  Typically the unique subgame‐perfect equilibrium is “go wherever Death guessed you would,” restoring stability.

Reply.  But CDT’s original mandate was to decide what a lone agent ought to do given her causal beliefs, not to recommend equilibria of an intertemporal game she does not consciously play.  The game-formulation changes the subject: it smuggles in strategic considerations that CDT, as ordinarily stated, does not countenance.

4.  The deeper diagnosis: act-centrism in predictor problems  
——————————————————————————————————————

Why does CDT stumble precisely where its causal scruples should help?  Because the theory chooses too late.  The causal graph of a Death-in-Damascus scenario looks like this:

Earlier psychological state S  →  Death’s prediction P  
                     ↓                    ↓  
              later action A        outcome (live/die)

Both P and A are downstream of S.  From the perspective of the time-slice at which you already know that P has occurred (though not its content), A and P are probabilistically but not causally linked.  CDT, in evaluating A, keeps the distribution over P fixed.  Unfortunately that distribution is itself a function of the distribution over S, and S includes whatever decision algorithm you are currently running.  By altering the algorithm, you alter P, even though by the lights of the current time-slice A cannot causally influence P.  CDT’s prohibition on conditioning on A blinds the agent to the fact that, one time-slice up, altering her algorithm would indeed have screened off the correlation.  The instability is a symptom of that blindness.

Put differently: the decision you control is not merely “A or D now” but “which algorithm shall I have been running all along?”  Once that earlier node is recognised as the locus of genuine control, the correlation between prediction and act is comfortably causal after all, and the dependence on unstable credences disappears.

5.  Updateless Policy CDT (UPCDT)  
———————————————

UPCDT proceeds in three stages:

Stage 1:  Prior.  Before you learn the content of the predictor’s guess, fix a probability distribution over the full causal network.

Stage 2:  Policy choice.  Evaluate entire input‐output policies—functions from possible observations to acts—by the expected utility they would have given Stage-1 credences, holding fixed only the physical facts not causally downstream of the policy node.  One policy is: “If I find myself in the Death-in-Damascus set-up, go to Aleppo.”  Another is: “Go wherever I currently believe I am less likely to go.”  Compute expected utility for each.

Stage 3:  Implementation.  Upon arrival in the diagnostic situation, execute the act mandated by the previously chosen policy without re-deliberating at the act level.

UPCDT is resolutely causal: when scoring a policy it holds constant the prior probabilities of nodes that the policy cannot causally influence.  But because the policy is selected at the point where your algorithm branches, it properly treats the correlation between prediction and final act as downstream of the policy.  The result is a unique policy ranking that does not shift as your moment-to-moment credences flutter.  In typical parameter settings, “Always go to Aleppo” strictly dominates, and the instability never arises.

6.  Two morals and a coda  
—————————————

First moral.  In predictor cases the unit of rational control is not the isolated act but the earlier algorithm that produces both the act and the predictor’s correlated state.  Any decision theory that ignores this temporal binding will mis-identify which probabilities are truly exogenous and will risk recommendation instability.

Second moral.  Guidance and evaluation pull apart if your decision rule takes as input a quantity (like P(D)) that the very act of following the rule predictably perturbs.  To secure guidance, a theory must guarantee what Skyrms calls “ratifiability”: the chosen act (or policy) must remain optimal conditional on the fact that it is chosen.  Act-centred CDT fails that guarantee in Death-type set-ups; policy-centred variants succeed.

Coda.  Does all this vindicate Evidential Decision Theory?  Not directly.  EDT, too, can be reformulated at the policy level (as “Updateless EDT”), and when so reformulated it shares the same recommendations as UPCDT in Death-in-Damascus.  The upshot is not that causation is irrelevant.  It is that the distinction between causal and evidential conditioning does its normative work only when applied at the right temporal grain.  Shift your focus from isolated acts to earlier algorithmic choices, and the quarrel between the two theories looks less like a fight about which probabilities to enter into the utility formula and more like a subtler dispute about which counterfactuals represent genuine control.

Conclusion.  CDT’s dependence on deliberational act probabilities is indeed a problem—not because it relies on subjective credences per se, but because in predictor scenarios those credences are endogenous to the very choice being made.  The resulting feedback loop robs CDT of stable guidance.  A policy-level, updateless reconstruction restores that guidance and reveals that the real lesson of Death in Damascus is about the temporal location of agency, not about the pros and cons of causal versus evidential conditioning.

Death in Damascus and the fragility of causal expected utility

1. Setting the stage  

Causal Decision Theory (CDT) tells an agent to maximise expected utility with probabilities computed by the “causal do‐operator”: P(state | do(act)).  States that lie outside the future light-cone of the contemplated act are to be treated as causally independent of it, so their probabilities should not be altered when one counterfactually intervenes on the act.  In ordinary choice problems—choosing apples over oranges, keeping or discarding a lottery ticket—that rule behaves well.  But in the Death in Damascus family of cases the act’s expected utility is a function of the probability the agent currently assigns to performing that very act.  During deliberation those probabilities shift, and with them CDT’s recommendation.  The question is whether this self-referential dependence is an embarrassment for CDT.

My thesis: the dependence is not a merely technical quirk; it exposes a deep instability in CDT’s guidance.  In Death in Damascus, CDT fails to deliver a recommendation that is (i) deliberationally stable, (ii) dynamically consistent, and (iii) compatible with the very causal-statistical picture from which CDT draws its authority.  Two consequences follow.  First, an agent who tries to be a “CDT-ist” can be money-pumped or forced into endless vacillation.  Second, the underlying cause of the instability generalises: whenever an upstream predictor tracks deliberative states, CDT’s machinery yields advice that predictably disintegrates.  A satisfactory decision theory must therefore move to a level on which an agent evaluates policies, algorithms, or dispositions, not momentary acts conditioned on their shifting credences.  Functional Decision Theory (FDT), “updateless” CDT, or policy-based causal reasoning offer ways to repair the flaw, but orthodox CDT taken straight cannot.

2. Reconstructing Death in Damascus carefully  

Here is a slightly formalised version that brings out the dependence on act probabilities.

• Background facts  
   – Death is a superb but fallible psychologist.  
   – He consults your “mental file” at t₀ and travels to whichever city he then predicts you will visit the next day at t₁.  
   – If you meet Death you lose 100 utiles; otherwise you lose nothing.  
   – Travel costs are negligible.

• Probabilities you hold at t₀.  Let p be your current subjective probability of choosing Damascus (D); 1−p is the probability of choosing Aleppo (A).  Death’s reliability is 90%, but he has a base-rate preference for placing himself in Damascus when unsure.  Concretely,

   P(Death in D | you end up in D)  = 0.9  
   P(Death in D | you end up in A)  = 0.6  

(Because of the base-rate bias, the conditional probability that Death is in Damascus goes down when you assign more mass to A.)

• Expected utilities according to CDT at t₀.  CDT instructs you to compute P(Death in city | do(act)), i.e. treating the act as an intervention that severs all incoming causal arrows.  Since your eventual act is (plausibly) not a cause of Death’s earlier prediction, the conditional probabilities above are left intact.  Hence

   EU(D) = −100 × 0.9 = −90  
   EU(A) = −100 × 0.6 = −60  

So CDT recommends Aleppo—if your p is still the old p.  But note what happens if, during deliberation, you decide you are very likely to go to Aleppo after all.  Your internal credence p falls from, say, 0.4 to 0.1.  That change reduces the base-rate part of Death’s bias toward Damascus.  Conditional on “I am the kind of person who is 90% likely to go to Aleppo”, your best estimate becomes

   P(Death in D | you end up in D) ≈ 0.97  
   P(Death in D | you end up in A) ≈ 0.11.  

Plugging these into CDT’s formula now yields

   EU(D) = −100 × 0.97 ≈ −97  
   EU(A) = −100 × 0.11 ≈ −11,  

so Aleppo is still favoured but by a wider margin.  Suppose, however, that Death’s bias were even stronger.  In some parameter ranges the update flips the recommendation: as your credence in Damascus shrinks, the disadvantage of D grows, until the expected utilities cross; CDT then tells you to go back to Damascus.  The very act of deciding destabilises the inputs into the decision.

3. Why dependence on p is philosophically troubling  

3.1 No deliberational fixed point  

A decision rule worth following must have what Jeffrey called “deliberational stability”: if you begin to run the rule, its verdict should not be undermined by learning facts that are feedback products of the rule’s own operation.  CDT fails that test here.  The function f mapping “current p” to “recommended act” has no fixed point.  Start with p=0.5; CDT tells you “Go Aleppo”; you update p downward; f now tells you “Go Damascus”; you update back; f flips again.  The agent can ping-pong forever or until bounded rationality arbitrarily halts the process.  That is a sign of a defective prescription rather than mere incompleteness in a theory of rational belief change.

3.2 Dynamic inconsistency and money pumps  

Suppose your dialectical pendulum slows enough that you actually board the Aleppo bus.  En route you recall that were you now to jump off and taxi back to Damascus Death would almost surely remain in Aleppo (he already left), yielding a higher expected utility.  CDT therefore reverses itself after the ticket has been bought.  A wily ticket-seller could exploit this by offering infinitesimally priced switches between buses, extracting an unlimited sum—an analogue of the “Dutch book” but in decision rather than belief space.  Any decision theory that is exploitable by predictable, costless offers falls afoul of widely accepted rationality desiderata.

3.3 The causal model rebels  

At first glance CDT can insist, “Death’s location is causally prior, so do‐interventions leave its probability unchanged.”  But the practical perspective reveals a mismatch between the formal severing of arrows and the lived epistemic situation.  The only reason the probability tables above contain the skewed values (.9, .6, etc.) is that Death’s earlier act is statistically responsive to stable features of your decision procedure.  Intervening to change only the output of that very procedure while holding fixed everything upstream is an ill-defined surgical fantasy.  In Pearl’s terms, “soft interventions” that rewrite the value of a downstream variable without touching the mechanism that normally determines it can be metaphysically coherent yet pragmatically useless if the mechanism encodes the very information that made the probabilities what they are.  The dependence on p is an empirical symptom of that deeper incoherence.  CDT attempts to use do-calculus in a setting in which the appropriate causal graph contains a node for “decision function F” that itself determines the act.  Treating do(act) as primitive bypasses F and yields paradox.

4. Objections and attempted repairs
