Objection 1: “Rational credences in one’s own act should be 0 or 1; you eventually see what you will do, eliminating p-dependence.”  
Reply: That view confuses knowledge that you will decide with advance certainty about which decision you will reach.  Serious deliberation is precisely the process of resolving a state of indeterminacy.  Denying that intermediate credences exist trivialises the decision problem and abandons the predictive explanation of Death’s reliability.

Objection 2: “Adopt a ratification constraint: perform an act only if you would endorse it upon learning that you do in fact perform it.”  
Reply: Ratifiability cuts the knot in some cases but here yields underspecification.  Both “always Damascus” and “always Aleppo” are ratifiable, as are mixed strategies, so the theory trades one instability for an arbitrary selection problem.  Moreover, adding ratification is to revise, not defend, core CDT.

Objection 3: “The dependence on p is harmless because it disappears once decision costs are accounted for; endless vacillation is never free.”  
Reply: Cost can damp oscillation but does nothing about the normative question of what ought to be chosen given a single, costless opportunity.  A rationality notion that relies on external friction to work cannot claim foundational adequacy.

Objection 4: “A more fine-grained causal graph, on which do(act) does alter upstream beliefs about Death’s prediction, salvages CDT.”  
Reply: If do(act) is allowed to influence Death’s earlier choice via the common cause ‘decision function’, CDT ceases to be purely causal and collapses into something closer to Functional Decision Theory.  That route is promising but amounts to abandoning the orthodox version under discussion.

5. A positive direction: policy evaluation rather than act evaluation  

The diagnosis suggests a remedy: freeze the feedback loop by evaluating policies—mathematically, functions from informational states to acts—instead of evaluating individual acts relative to shifting credences.  Let π be the policy “always go to Aleppo.”  The ex ante expected utility of π is −60.  The policy “always go to Damascus” yields −90.  Mixed or stochastic policies have intermediate values.  Because one’s credence about implementing π is 1 (the policy is self-advertising), Death’s prediction probabilities become fixed once π is fixed, and deliberational instability disappears.  Crucially, the ranking of policies is p-independent.  Choosing the best policy, then executing it, is dynamically consistent.

This move is precisely what Functional Decision Theory and Updateless CDT formalise.  They agree with orthodox CDT on standard Newcomb cases in which the predictor keys directly off the algorithm, but they do not suffer the vacillation pathologies.  In short, the dependence of act expected utility on p is a problem for CDT because the theory’s fundamental object of evaluation is mis-chosen.

6. Generalising the lesson  

Any scenario with the following structure will break CDT in the same way:

   (i) An upstream predictor P observes some correlate of your decision algorithm.  
   (ii) Outcomes depend on P’s prediction matching your eventual act.  
   (iii) During deliberation your credences about your own act shift, feeding back into the conditional distribution of P’s action.

Examples include:  
• The “XOR blackmail” puzzle where paying the blackmailer depends on whether you are predicted to pay;  
• Transparent Newcomb with small box penalties;  
• Sophisticated adversaries in cyber-security who prepare defences depending on forecasts of your specific exploit path.

In all these cases, CDT’s act-by-act evaluation yields cycles, whereas a policy-level CDT (or FDT) yields a single, stable recommendation.

7. Conclusion  

Dependence of expected utilities on one’s current act probabilities is not an innocuous by-product of CDT; it is a symptom of a deeper misalignment between the theory’s causal counterfactuals and the epistemic realities of prediction-sensitive environments.  The resulting lack of deliberational fixed points, exposure to money pumps, and implicit reliance on an untenable “surgical” interpretation of do(act) collectively indict orthodox CDT.  The cure lies in shifting the unit of evaluation upward—from momentary acts to abstract decision policies that are self-locating in the causal fabric.  That shift preserves CDT’s causal spirit while escaping the Death in Damascus trap; without it, CDT is indeed in mortal danger.

1. Introduction and Thesis

How tightly must an agent’s heart be tethered to the concrete beneficiaries of her action for that action to have moral worth? Common wisdom—invoking charges of “moral fetishism” (Williams) or “alienation” (Stocker)—says: very tightly indeed. On this view a person who saves a drowning child merely because “it is the right thing to do” lacks full-blooded concern for the child; the motivational distance diminishes the act’s praiseworthiness. I shall argue that this common wisdom is mistaken. A de dicto desire to do what is morally right can, by itself, suffice for moral worth. What makes such purely dutiful action praiseworthy is not affective proximity to the child but (i) the agent’s robust rational sensitivity to the right‐making features of situations, and (ii) her commitment to guide herself by those features because they are right‐making—that is, because she respects moral reasons as such. Far from being fetishistic, this posture expresses an agent’s practical identity as a self-governing moral person. When successful, it manifests a distinctive virtue: respect for morality. My aim is not to deny the moral beauty of concern or empathy, but to vindicate a parallel path to moral worth available even to the austere moralist.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

Two distinctions will structure the debate.

a. De dicto vs. de re motivation. An agent acts from a de re moral motive when she desires to alleviate that child’s suffering, or to keep a promise to Pat: her desire latches onto the very property that makes the act right (reduce suffering, fidelity). A de dicto motive, by contrast, is a second‐order desire: to perform whatever act is morally right, whatever that happens to be in the circumstance.

b. Moral rightness vs. moral lawfulness. “Doing what is morally right” can be read either as “doing what the correct moral principles require” or as “doing what happens, as a matter of fact, to be morally necessary.” I use the latter: rightness is a property of acts, not merely their conformity to a code the agent endorses.

The skeptic’s conclusion is that de dicto motivation alone cannot yield moral worth. Their argument (sketched roughly) runs:

(1) Praiseworthy action must be motivated by what morality is really about—namely, the concrete values or persons implicated.  
(2) Purely de dicto motivation bypasses those concrete considerations.  
(3) Therefore such motivation cannot supply moral worth.

Call this the “aboutness argument.”

3. Why the Standard Objection Overstates Its Case

The aboutness argument conflates two views:

Internal Claim: For an act to be right, it must be explained by certain facts (the child’s danger, promisee’s reliance).

Psychological Claim: For an act to be morally worthy, those very facts must be the agent’s motivating reasons.

Only the psychological claim is at issue; (1) slides illicitly from the internal to the psychological domain. An agent can acknowledge that the drowning child’s stake explains the act’s rightness while nevertheless being causally moved by a rational commitment to do whatever such stakes morally require. After all, “I should do whatever those stakes require” is itself a way of relating to the stakes: a way that runs through reflective endorsement rather than spontaneous emotion.

4. The Positive Account: Respect Responsiveness

I propose that de dicto motivation generates moral worth provided that it realizes what I call Respect Responsiveness:

RR: An agent acts with moral worth iff she (a) is disposed to track what the right-making considerations are across relevantly close situations, and (b) chooses the act she sincerely takes to be right because she recognizes those considerations as morally authoritative.

Crucially, clause (b) does not say the considerations must be the occurrent cause of action; it says the agent must regard them as the source of authority. The de dicto desire “do the right thing” is therefore not empty. It is a higher-order policy that licenses first-order action precisely by treating the right-making considerations as decisive. Moral respect is thus a distinct virtue, analogous to scientific intellectual honesty: what earns a physicist praise is her determination to follow the empirical evidence wherever it leads, not the fact that she has a personal fondness for quarks.

5. Why Respect Responsiveness Is Not Fetishistic

Fetish objects are valued utterly apart from the properties that made them significant in the first place. But the morally respectful agent values an act precisely as embodying “whatever it is that makes things right.” If she were reliably insensitive to those underlying properties, she would fail clause (a). The fetish charge bites only at caricatures—agents who treat “rightness” as a magic label detachable from the facts that ground it. But such detachment is excluded by RR’s tracking condition. Indeed, the dutiful agent is sensitive in a modality that empathy alone cannot guarantee: she cares not just that this child be saved but that any person, in any context, receive the consideration morality demands.

6. Comparison with Kant and Contemporary Defenses

Kant speaks of reverence for the moral law. Recent Kantian interpreters (e.g., Tamar Schapiro, Sergio Tenenbaum) insist that reverence can coexist with full recognition of material values. My account agrees but adds a reliability condition reminiscent of virtue epistemology: moral worth tracks rightness across counterfactuals. This enables us to address a classic worry. Suppose the agent mistakenly believes donating to a scam charity is obligatory. Her de dicto desire moves her to do “the right thing,” but she misidentifies it. On my view, she lacks moral worth because she fails component (a): the relevant counterfactuals (had she investigated minimal evidence) would still have led her astray. Moral respect involves competent sensitivity, not mere intention.

7. Examples Doing Philosophical Work

Example 1: The Stoic Lifeguard. Marta has trained herself to remain emotionally even-keeled; she does not feel empathic surges. A child falls into rough surf. Marta’s internal dialogue: “Morally, I must rescue anyone in grave danger if I can do so without comparable risk.” She dives in and saves the child with practiced efficiency. The standard view calls her alienated; she seems admirable but cold. Yet Marta satisfies RR: she tracks the right-making features (serious peril, minimal cost to herself) and acts because they are morally decisive. Her absence of affect is neither here nor there.

Example 2: The Exhausted Nurse. Tai, after a 14-hour shift, notices his patient’s pain medication will lapse in five minutes. All he feels is fatigue; nothing in him wells up for the patient. What galvanizes him is the disciplined thought, “I promised that every patient would receive care in a timely manner; it is right to honor that promise.” Tai sets the IV. The promisee’s welfare is protected, though Tai’s motive is sheer fidelity to rightness. Intuitively we still owe him praise. Indeed, given his exhaustion, his respect for duty is especially admirable: it forestalls moral slippage where sentiment would wane.

These cases are not Platonic fables; they map actual domains—military ethics, medicine, law—where de dicto commitment sustains conduct precisely when empathy fatigues.

8. Addressing Deep Objections

Objection A: Alienation revisited—Surely the moral life is partly about standing in caring relations.  

Reply: I grant that robust moral excellence includes relational virtues. But moral worth is scalar and plural. A chess player merits praise for positional foresight even if she lacks tactical flair; analogously, respect-responsiveness earns moral credit even where care is absent. The skeptic conflates “sufficient” with “optimal.”

Objection B: De dicto motivation is too abstract to guide without hidden concrete desires.  

Reply: Guidance vs. initiation. The dutiful agent still needs factual beliefs to specify which act token is right; but the motivational engine is the higher-order desire. Autonomy often proceeds this way: my desire to honor a contract motivates me, although I must also represent the contract’s clauses to know what to do.

Objection C: Doesn’t RR smuggle in the very de re concern it claimed to replace, by requiring sensitivity to right-making facts?  

Reply: No. RR requires epistemic sensitivity, not motivational content. Compare a reliable thermometer: it tracks temperature without “caring” about warmth. Similarly, the dutiful agent’s caring is directed at rightness, not at each beneficiary. The tracking condition safeguards correctness, not emotional texture.

9. Distinguishing Moral Worth from Moral Beauty

Part of the dialectic trades on an equivocation between praiseworthiness (desert of moral credit) and attractiveness (the virtue we find endearing). A soldier who defuses mines because she “swore an oath to protect civilians” may not ooze tenderness, yet she deserves moral admiration. By segregating these two dimensions we can concede that de re motives contribute to moral beauty, while insisting that de dicto motives suffice for moral worth.

10. The Normative Payoff: Autonomy and Universality

A final advantage of my view is that it honors two ideals many theories cherish:

a. Autonomy. The agent governs herself by principles she reflectively endorses. Emotional empathy is serendipitous; respect-responsiveness is chosen.

b. Universality. Concrete affections cluster parochially (family, compatriots). De dicto respect scales readily: whoever falls under the moral principle’s scope is owed compliance.

Thus, vindicating de dicto sufficiency does not merely patch a corner case; it reveals a powerful channel through which ordinary agents realize core moral ideals.

11. Relation to Empirical Psychology

Empirical studies (e.g., Daniel Batson on altruism) show that empathic concern is statistically unreliable across diffuse victims; moral identity centrality, by contrast, predicts rule-consistent helping even in anonymous contexts. Respect-responsiveness thus maps onto motivational patterns already observed to sustain pro-social behavior where empathy is silent—supporting, albeit indirectly, my claim that such responsiveness has independent moral value.

12. Taking Stock

I have argued:

1. The standard “aboutness” objection mislocates the deficit: it confuses explanatory with motivational roles.  
2. Moral worth hinges on Respect Responsiveness, which a purely de dicto motive can instantiate.  
3. Such motivation need not be fetishistic, provided the agent tracks right-making features competently.  
4. Examples from real-world institutional life illustrate the point.  
5. Critics’ deepest worries relate to moral beauty or relational intimacy, not to praiseworthiness per se.

13. Conclusion

One need not wear one’s heart on one’s sleeve to merit moral praise. The person who acts solely from a de dicto desire to do what is right manifests a distinctive moral virtue: standing under the authority of moral reasons as such. When that virtue is connected, through competent deliberation, to the features that actually make acts right, the resulting conduct possesses moral worth—even if no warm sentiment courses through the agent’s veins. Far from evincing alienation, de dicto motivation honors the fundamental point of morality: that what ultimately matters is not whom we happen to care about, but whether we successfully respond to the reasons we objectively have. Acting from duty, then, is not a pale substitute for compassion; it is a robust, autonomous, and praise-deserving mode of moral agency in its own right.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

The prevailing objection to Kant’s famous claim that only actions done “from duty” have moral worth is that a merely de dicto concern—“do the morally right thing, whatever that is”—looks bloodless. A good person, the thought goes, rescues the child because the child is in peril, not because a moral principle somewhere issues the command “rescue!”  I argue that this criticism presupposes an unduly thin picture of what a de dicto desire to do what is right can be. Once we notice the cognitive and volitional complexity that can be packed into such a desire, it becomes clear that acting solely from duty can in many cases suffice for full moral worth.  

My positive proposal has two parts. (i) A de dicto moral motive can be morally substantial rather than fetishistic when it functions as a higher-order regulative commitment that organizes and sustains the agent’s first-order deliberation. (ii) Such a motive is praiseworthy because it manifests a form of respect for practical reason itself—a respect that equips the agent to respond correctly across an open-ended range of moral situations, including hard cases in which no single concrete consideration is salient enough to carry the deliberative day. I call this the “Regulative Respect” account.  

2. Clarifying the Target: De Dicto vs. De Re Motives  

We need sharper distinctions than the literature usually draws. Let us call:  

• A de re moral motive: a desire whose content is a specific right-making feature F (e.g., “the child will drown unless I jump”).  
• A de dicto moral motive: a desire whose content is simply “do what is morally right,” without yet specifying the right-making feature.  

Critics such as Michael Stocker (“The Schizophrenia of Modern Ethical Theories”), Susan Wolf (“Moral Saints”), and Peter Railton (“Alienation, Consequentialism, and the Demands of Morality”) treat the de dicto motive as thin and motivationally deficient. Yet they overlook a further distinction between:  

(a) A superficial de dicto desire—e.g., the student who says, “I guess I’ll do what’s right, whatever” but has no idea how to identify it, and  

(b) A regulative de dicto commitment that governs an agent’s deliberation in a way that is epistemically responsible and substantively responsive to evidence about concrete moral features.  

Only (b) is my target. Critics have shown that (a) is inadequate; they have not refuted (b).  

3. Why the Standard Objections Miss Their Mark  

3.1 The Fetishism Charge  

In Liam Murphy’s terminology, a fetishistic agent treats morality “as an object of intrinsic fascination,” caring more about moral status than about people. But fetishism requires *substitution*: the agent substitutes the property of rightness for the properties that make the act right, treating the former as if it had independent normative force. The regulative de dicto motive involves no such substitution. The agent directs her will toward acting on whatever reasons there are, precisely because she recognizes that those reasons are what ultimately matter—even if at the moment of action she cannot specify them individually. Rather than displacing first-order reasons, she takes up a standing second-order policy to respect them.  

3.2 The Alienation Charge  

Railton complains that a morality dominated by de dicto considerations alienates us from our personal projects and the people we love. But the regulative desire I defend is compatible with rich first-order attachments. It functions like a moral gyroscope: it keeps the agent stably oriented toward rightness while allowing local motives—love, friendship, creativity—to supply specific content whenever they are consistent with morality. Where conflict arises, the de dicto motive takes precedence, but that is a feature, not a bug: it prevents partiality from devolving into injustice.  

3.3 The Schizophrenia Charge  

Stocker holds that modern ethical theories split motives from reasons, rendering ordinary moral psychology “schizophrenic.” Yet a regulative de dicto desire *integrates* the two. The agent’s standing commitment to rightness ensures that her motives track her reasons across time, rather than leaving the connection to chance.  

4. A Positive Model: Regulative Respect  

The central idea is borrowed from hierarchical theories of agency (Frankfurt, Railton, Hieronymi): practical identity is structured by higher-order commitments that regulate first-order impulses. Respect for morality is one such higher-order commitment. But unlike Frankfurtian volitional necessity, the commitment here is rational and revisable: the agent holds herself answerable to moral reasons precisely because she sees herself as a participant in the practice of giving and asking for reasons (to adapt Brandom).  

Regulative Respect has three components:  

(1) Epistemic Orientation: The agent treats moral facts as discoverable but fallible. She actively seeks evidence about what morality requires.  

(2) Volitional Priority: When the agent judges that φ is morally required, that judgment is decisive in action unless outweighed by defeating reasons she has overlooked.  

(3) Correctibility: The agent is disposed to revise both her first-order judgment φ and her higher-order principle if better moral reasoning or testimony indicates error.  

These components ensure that the agent is *responsive* to the very right-making features that critics think she ignores, albeit indirectly. Responsiveness is mediated by, but not replaced by, the higher-order commitment.  

5. Two Test Cases  

Example 1: Moral Uncertainty at the Triage Tent  

A battlefield nurse must decide, under severe time pressure, whether to allocate the only available ventilator to Soldier A or Soldier B. She cannot attend to the full array of morally relevant details (probabilities of survival, responsibility for injury, prior service). What she can do, and does, is act on a standing policy: “Do the action that accords with the morally best rule I have most reason to believe applies under uncertainty,” e.g., a lottery between equal claims. She implements the lottery *because* she is committed to doing what morality requires, not because she takes delight in spinning wheels. Her action is morally worthy precisely because the de dicto motive allows action guided by fairness in circumstances where concrete de re motives are epistemically inaccessible.  

Example 2: The Newly Enlightened Reformer  

Consider an affluent heir who has recently come to believe—through reading Iris Marion Young or Amartya Sen—that inherited wealth is unjust in a world of severe deprivation. He writes a large check to an effective-altruist fund. The immediate motive is: “This is morally required.” He does *not* yet feel special concern for distant children, nor does he find pleasure in giving. Still, we (and he) regard the donation as praiseworthy. What makes it so is that his higher-order respect for morality overrides prior self-interest and orients him toward justice; in time, concrete empathetic concern may follow, but moral worth does not await its arrival.  

6. Why De Dicto Suffices: Three Independent Arguments  

6.1 The Argument from Agency  

Morality, whatever its substance, claims *practical authority*. To treat that authority as reason-giving in its own right is to relate to morality in the agency-constituting way characteristic of rational beings. An agent who wills an action because it is morally required is thereby expressing the right kind of agency. Therefore such an action has moral worth, absent defeating conditions.  

6.2 The Argument from Reliability  

Suppose (with Arpaly and Schroeder) that an action’s moral worth depends on how reliably the agent’s motivational structure produces right action across varying contexts. A standing commitment to rightness—especially when coupled with the three Regulative Respect components—is an excellent reliability mechanism. By contrast, a patchwork of isolated de re motives may track rightness in familiar circumstances but fail in novel ones. Therefore, de dicto motivation is at least as good a candidate for moral worth as any set of local motives.  

6.3 The Non-Fungibility Argument  

Some moral demands cannot be cashed out fully in first-order terms. Consider the demand to “treat each person as an equal.” The norm is abstract, yet it applies ahead of any specific welfare interest or relationship. A motive that *recognizes* and *respects* that abstract equality is precisely a de dicto moral motive. If moral worth required exclusively de re motives, we could never act worthily when the moral demand itself is abstract. Therefore de dicto motivation must suffice at least in such cases.  

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The view licenses cold, calculative moralism that disrespects personal projects.  
Reply: Regulative Respect requires epistemic humility—attentiveness to particularities—for its implementation. Someone who bulldozes personal projects has failed the epistemic orientation and correctibility conditions; her stance is not one of genuine respect for moral reasons but of dogmatism.  

Objection 2: The view collapses into Kant’s, and we know Kant faces Schön/böse will problems.  
Reply: Kant indeed values acting “from duty,” but he conflates the regulative and the motivational levels: for him the *object* of the will is duty itself. My view separates them: the object of choice is still the concrete act; “duty” names the agent’s higher-order policy of practical deference to moral reasons. Thus we resist both fetishism and Kant’s rigorism.  

Objection 3: Moral education suggests the contrary; we train children to care about others, not about “rightness.”  
Reply: Developmentally, cultivating de re motives comes first because it is cognitively simpler. Precisely for that reason, growing moral maturity requires the further step of a de dicto commitment that can adjudicate among competing de re motives when they conflict. The argument is not developmental but structural: both forms of motive are valuable, but the de dicto is indispensable for adult agency under conditions of pluralism and uncertainty.  

8. Comparative Assessment  

Let us locate Regulative Respect relative to three prominent views.  

• Kantian Internalism: Shares the idea that moral worth flows from respect for the moral law, but avoids Kant’s formalism by embedding respect in a broader deliberative ecology that includes empirical evidence and revisability.  

• Aristotelian Particularism: Shares the emphasis on sensitivity to particulars, but explains that sensitivity as the downstream effect of a higher-order commitment; thereby preserves moral unity across cases that exceed the grasp of phronēsis alone.  

• Sentimentalist Accounts (e.g., Humean, Nussbaumian): Acknowledges the motivational force of emotions but denies that emotions exhaust moral worth, which also depends on how the agent regulates emotions in light of reflective endorsement of moral reasons.  

9. Broader Payoffs: Autonomy, Community, and Moral Progress  

Because the regulative commitment is correctible, it opens space for moral learning and collective deliberation. Agents disposed to act from duty in my sense are ideal interlocutors in public moral discourse: they hold their own judgments provisionally, they revise in light of new evidence, and they integrate concrete concerns into an overarching commitment to justice. Such agents are thus not just individually praiseworthy; they are the backbone of moral progress.  

10. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for moral worth, **provided** the desire functions as a higher-order, epistemically responsible, and correctible commitment—Regulative Respect. What makes such dutiful action praiseworthy is not its abstraction but its role in expressing a distinctive form of practical agency: one that gives morality pride of place while remaining open to the concrete values that make morality worth caring about in the first place. De dicto motivation, far from being a moral fetish, is the glue that holds our diverse first-order concerns together in a coherent life of respect for persons.

1. Introduction and Thesis  
A perennial worry in moral psychology holds that the naked desire “to do what is morally right” is too thin a reed to sustain genuine moral worth.  If an agent salutes the abstraction “morality” while remaining motivationally indifferent to the concrete considerations that make her act right—another’s pain, an avoidable injustice, an urgent need—many critics think her agency is at best second-rate, at worst fetishistic.  I shall argue, to the contrary, that acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can—under certain recognizable conditions—confer full moral worth.  What makes such action praiseworthy is not sentimental resonance with the right-making features but the agent’s higher-order responsiveness to the moral reasons those features constitute.  Moral worth attaches to agential structures that reliably track and are governed by moral reasons; a de dicto motive can supply precisely that structure without incurring the charges of alienation or fetishism.

The argument proceeds in six steps.  (i)  I sharpen the de dicto / de re distinction and catalogue the main objections.  (ii)  I distinguish two importantly different kinds of de dicto motive, only one of which is vulnerable to the charge of fetishism.  (iii)  I develop a reasons-responsiveness account of moral worth and show that the richer kind of de dicto motive satisfies it.  (iv)  I defend this claim against three prominent critiques: Stocker’s charge of motivational schizophrenia, Railton’s worry about detached moralism, and Wolf’s concern about moral sainthood.  (v)  I show that the proposed view has positive advantages: it fosters impartiality, counters bias under normative uncertainty, and underwrites reflective autonomy.  (vi)  I close by noting limits and clarifying why sentiment and de dicto concern need not be rivals.

2. Clarifying the Target: De Dicto versus De Re Motivation  
Following Gregory Kavka, call a de dicto moral desire one whose content is simply “to do what morality requires” (or “what is right”), without encoding any particular moral reason.  A de re moral desire, by contrast, is directed at the concrete right-making consideration itself—e.g., “to relieve Sita’s suffering,” “to keep a promise,” “to respect Ahmed’s autonomy.”  The usual intuition is that genuine virtue engages the world: I rescue a child because she will drown, not because I am chasing the abstraction Rightness.

This intuition powers three classic objections.  
(1)  Motivational Schizophrenia (Stocker): an agent who values only doing her duty must, in acting, suppress the very motives—friendship, love, concern—that make the act right; the two stand in tension, producing moral alienation.  
(2)  Moral Fetishism (Smith, Railton): exclusive focus on rightness treats morality like a shiny object detached from human goods, a fetish rather than an ethical orientation.  
(3)  Diminished Worth (Arpaly, Wolf): because de dicto motivation is insufficiently responsive to the right-making reasons, such action lacks the quality of attention or care deserved by the beneficiaries; hence it earns less praise.

These objections proceed on the assumption that de dicto motives are motivationally blind to the values at stake.  The next section complicates that picture.

3. Two Species of De Dicto Motive  
Call the first, shallow species “rule-fetishist desire.”  Here the agent’s aim is to tick the “morally permissible” box, treating morality as an external badge of honor or purity.  She might know little and care less about why an act is right; avoiding wrongness is a symbolic self-regarding project.  This is what critics rightly disdain.

The second, richer species I term “reflective moral commitment.”  The agent endorses morality not as a fetish but as the authoritative set of reasons she ought, upon reflection, to be guided by.  Her de dicto desire functions as a higher-order disposition: whatever concrete facts ultimately make an act right, she is prepared and motivated to respond to them because they are right-making.  Two features distinguish the reflective commitment:

   A. Reason-Linking: The agent’s disposition is to act for whatever reasons turn out to be decisive; it is a standing policy of normative governance.  
   B. Cognitive Uptake: In typical cases she does grasp the concrete right-makers and would revise her judgment if new information revealed that the act was not, after all, right.

Thus, although the ultimate motive is de dicto, it is not blind; it is mediated by cognition of de re considerations.  It is the difference between “I will do whatever the law of the land says” and “I will comply with the law so far as it is just”; the latter expresses critical uptake of the law’s point.  Only the shallow species invites fetishism.

4. A Reasons-Responsiveness Account of Moral Worth  
Suppose moral worth (following Kant but also contemporary responsibility theory) attaches to actions produced by an agentive mechanism that is:

   (i)  Sensitive to moral reasons: it would lead the agent to act differently were the relevant moral reasons different.  
   (ii)  Guided by the agent: the mechanism is integrated into her practical identity.  

On this view the sentimental texture of motivation—whether sympathetic concern, beneficent joy, or austere duty—is secondary.  What matters is the pattern of counterfactual responsiveness and the internal endorsement of the guiding principle.

A reflective de dicto motive satisfies both conditions.  Because its scope is “whatever is morally required,” it is maximally sensitive to moral reasons: change the moral landscape, and the agent’s intention, by definition, changes with it.  And because the motive is an expression of her practical self-conception (“being moral is who I aspire to be”), it is genuinely hers.  Hence, in normal circumstances, acting from such a motive confers full moral worth.

5. Meeting the Classical Objections  

5.1 Stocker’s Schizophrenia  
Stocker’s hospital visitor, motivated solely by “duty,” cannot muster warm concern and so alienates the patient.  Yet the argument equivocates between motivational exclusivity and motivational sufficiency.  A reflective-duty agent can be solely motivated by duty at the decisive moment while still possessing, cultivating, and even expressing sentiments of concern.  What renders the act worthy is the de dicto motive’s causal efficacy, not its monopoly on the agent’s psychology.  Moreover, situations abound—triage, whistle-blowing, resisting peer pressure—where sentiment misleads and the steady hand of duty is morally preferable.

5.2 Railton’s Fetishism  
Railton imagines a husband who buys flowers for the abstract reason that “it is morally right to please one’s spouse.”  The act seems affection-less.  But notice: the lack of affection, not the abstractness, does the normative damage.  If the husband’s de dicto motive co-opts affectionate sentiments as part of the right-making reasons (pleasure, intimacy), he acts both from duty and from love.  No fetish appears.  The real target is motivational attenuation, not the formality of the aim.

5.3 Wolf’s Moral Sainthood  
Wolf worries that saints animated solely by morality become dull, lacking non-moral hobbies and attachments.  This is a perfectionist rather than an internal critique: perhaps such saints miss out on the good life, but that is consistent with their actions being morally worthy.  Nothing entails that a reflective-duty orientation must crowd out non-moral pursuits; it merely governs cases where moral reasons are decisive.  Indeed, its abstractness may leave more space for diverse projects than concrete passion does, because it does not tether worth to any particular sentiment.

6. Positive Advantages of the De Dicto Motive  

6.1 Impartiality and Bias-Resistance  
Concrete sentiments track salient particulars—often the familiar or vividly presented—whereas morality ranges over persons impartially.  A de dicto disposition buffers against partiality by forcing the agent to ask, in each case, “What do moral reasons demand?” rather than “How strongly do I feel?”  Under conditions of scarce attention or empathic fatigue (think online charity choices), this mechanism is more reliable.

6.2 Navigating Normative Uncertainty  
Agents frequently face disputed moral terrain (climate ethics, data privacy).  A de re sentimental orientation may have no applicable feeling.  But a reflective de dicto motive, combined with epistemic diligence, directs the agent to inquire, deliberate, and act on the best available moral reasons.  The motivational structure is adaptable across contexts precisely because it is content-neutral at the first order.

6.3 Reflective Autonomy  
Kant’s insight: to act from the moral law is to legislate for oneself under the idea of freedom.  The de dicto motive expresses second-order endorsement: “I will be guided by what, upon reflection, I ought to do.”  This stance embodies an ideal of agency that treats the self as accountable to reasons, not merely pushed by subpersonal affects.  Such self-governance is itself worthy of esteem.

7. Illustrative Example  
Consider Dr. Rao in an overcrowded emergency ward.  Two patients need the last ventilator: her close friend Maya and an unknown janitor, Suraj.  Dr. Rao’s sympathy inclines her toward Maya; her abstract de dicto commitment to do what is right directs her to the hospital’s just triage protocol, which favors Suraj (greater chance of recovery).  Acting from duty she intubates Suraj, then sits with Maya, offering comfort from genuine, albeit frustrated, affection.  Here duty is both sole motivator of the decisive act and manifestly worthy: it overcomes predictable partiality and aligns action with impartial justice.  Far from alienation, Dr. Rao honors both friendship (insofar as permitted) and morality; her de dicto motive integrates, rather than suppresses, other concerns.

8. Distinguishing Form and Object of Motivation  
A recurring confusion treats the de dicto form (“because it is right”) as excluding attention to the right-making object (“because she will live”).  The proper conceptual distinction is orthogonal:

   Form: the regulative principle (duty, sympathy, self-interest).  
   Object: the specific reason recognized (her survival, promised word, etc.).

An agent can possess a de dicto form while taking in the de re object cognitively and even affectively; what matters for praiseworthiness is that the form guarantees alignment with the object across contexts.  Critics wrongly infer from “duty is the form” to “agent is indifferent to the object.”  Once the axes are disentangled, the alienation worry loses its bite.

9. Limits and Coexistence with Sentiment  
Acknowledging sufficiency is not denying that sentimental motives often enhance moral worth.  Empathy can deepen appreciation, sustain motivation under stress, and enrich relationships.  The claim is conditional: when sentiments are absent, unavailable, or suspect, the de dicto motive can still underwrite praiseworthy action.  Moreover, real agents are motivationally pluralistic; the healthiest moral psychology may layer de re sentiments atop a de dicto core, yielding both warmth and principled reliability.

10. Conclusion  
Acting “from duty alone” need not be bloodless moral fetishism.  Properly understood, a reflective de dicto desire is a higher-order commitment to be governed by moral reasons wherever they lead.  Because such a disposition is maximally reasons-responsive, integrated into the agent’s self-governance, and resilient against bias, actions issuing from it possess full moral worth.  We do—and should—admire the whistle-blower who speaks up because it is right, the judge who sets aside personal sympathy to uphold justice, and the ordinary person who, uncertain yet conscientious, asks “What should I do?” and then does it.  Their worth lies precisely in the motive some have disparaged: a principled, reflective devotion to rightness as such.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Kant thought that “the moral worth of an action lies in the maxim,” and many contemporary Kantians maintain that an agent who acts “from duty”—because she takes the act to be what morality requires—can earn the highest praise.  But a broad coalition of critics (Stocker, Wolf, Smith, Arpaly) protests that a merely de dicto desire to do what is right is too abstract, too cold, even fetishistic to ground moral worth.  On their view, genuinely admirable agents must be moved by the very considerations that make the act right—other people’s suffering, the beauty of promise-keeping, the importance of gratitude—not by the thin thought that “this is required by morality.”  Otherwise the agent is alienated from the value she supposedly honors.

I argue that the coalition is partly correct: a merely formal wish to “do the right thing” is insufficient.  Yet the conclusion many draw—that therefore duty itself cannot suffice for moral worth—doesn’t follow.  The problem is not the de dicto shape of the motive; it is the poverty of a certain content-free version of it.  What is praiseworthy, I claim, is a richer species of de dicto desire—call it a Respectful Reflective Agency commitment (RRA commitment).  Such a commitment is:

a. second-order: it is a standing policy to regulate one’s first-order motives by moral reasons;  
b. value-laden: it is animated by respect for persons as sources of reasons, not by fascination with “Morality-as-such” as a fetish object;  
c. epistemically loaded: it includes the dispositions required to recognise which concrete considerations count as moral reasons in situ.

An agent who acts solely from this kind of duty can be fully praiseworthy even when no further first-order concern—friendship, compassion, beneficence—plays a causal role.  The moral worth lies in the successful exercise of the agent’s distinctively rational capacity to govern herself by the moral law conceived as the publicly sharable system of reasons we owe one another.

2. Some Background Distinctions  

2.1 De dicto vs de re motivation.  
A de re desire to relieve Mei’s suffering has direct reference to Mei; a de dicto desire to “do the morally required thing” is indexed to a description.  Critics worry that the latter cannot engage with what really matters on the ground.  My defense will show that this worry confuses two very different kinds of de dicto desire.

2.2 Pure-formalist duty vs respect-laden duty.  
The fetish charge hits a picture on which “Morality!” is a talisman—an object of fascination detached from persons, reasons, or value.  Kant himself sometimes writes as if this austere attitude suffices, but elsewhere (especially in the Doctrine of Virtue) he insists that the moral law commands us to adopt obligatory ends such as others’ happiness.  I follow the latter strand: a duty-motive worthy of praise already contains implicit concern for concrete reasons.

3. The Standard Case against Duty as Sole Motive  

A brief rehearsal:

Stocker’s Hospital Visitor: Friend A visits the hospital because she cares; Friend B visits because “it is my duty.”  Intuitively A is warmer and more admirable.

Wolf’s Moral Saint worries: the single-minded dutiful agent crowds out non-moral projects; she ends up, if lovable at all, only by accident.

Smith’s Moral Fetishism: to desire X because it is right is like wanting Y because it is fashionable—an empty, heteronomous dependence on an external label.

Arpaly’s Argument from Worth: praise tracks how well the agent responds to the very moral reasons that make the act right.  A pure duty motive, she claims, fails this tracking requirement.

All four arguments presume that the duty-motive brackets or ignores the concrete values at stake.  If that were the only possible structure for a duty-based motivation, moral worth would indeed require something further.  But there is another structure.

4. The Respectful Reflective Agency (RRA) Account  

4.1 The Core Thought  
Human beings are not only passively moved by sympathies; they are also reflective agents capable of recognising, endorsing, and acting from reasons.  A central locus of praise, I suggest, is the competence to represent “what morality requires” and to make that representation the immediate ground of decision.  When one succeeds in acting from such a competence, one manifests respect for others as reason-bearing equals.  This manifestation, not the sentiment of compassion itself, is what earns distinctively moral esteem.

4.2 Three Conditions on a Praiseworthy Duty-Motive  

Condition 1 — Second-order governance.  
The agent has adopted a standing policy: “When I judge that morality requires φ-ing, I will φ.”  This policy regulates first-order impulses without needing to recruit any independent emotions.

Condition 2 — Value-laden content.  
The policy is sustained by the thought that persons are ends in themselves, that moral reasons are authoritative for creatures like us.  Therefore it is not a fetish with morality’s label; it is a commitment grounded in respect for the bearers of rights and claims.

Condition 3 — Epistemic competence.  
The same standing policy includes dispositions to gather information, to listen, to deliberate honestly.  Without reliable uptake of concrete reasons, the policy would be mere formalism.

When these conditions are satisfied, acting “solely from duty” (i.e., no first-order sympathy plays a causally necessary role on that occasion) is nevertheless an exercise of morally admirable agency.

5. Why the RRA Motive Is Sufficient for Moral Worth  

Argument 1: Reliability across contexts.  
First-order sympathies are narrow-band.  Compassion may motivate generous giving to a salient victim yet leave distant beneficiaries ignored.  A de dicto RRA motive, by contrast, is designed to track the whole domain of moral reasons, making the agent reliably responsive even where spontaneous sentiment is silent.  Reliability is a mark of moral worth.

Argument 2: Recognition-respect is a fundamental moral value.  
Darwall distinguishes “appraisal respect” (esteem) from “recognition respect” (regarding someone’s claims as constraining one’s will).  The RRA motive just is the disposition to accord recognition respect.  To manifest it in action is therefore to honor an essential moral value directly.

Argument 3: Avoiding moral luck in sentiment.  
Whether I happen to feel compassion for Mei today can be a matter of mood or salience.  Basing worth on such contingencies risks moral luck.  Praiseworthiness rooted in the agent’s standing policy, by contrast, reflects something stably attributable to her character.

6. Answering the Main Objections  

Objection A (Alienation): The dutiful visitor seems cold; the patient feels uncared-for.  
Reply: The patient’s interest in feeling liked is a genuine reason.  A competent RRA agent will register that reason: visiting “because it is right” will include visiting in a manner that assuages the patient’s loneliness.  What triggers the visit is duty, but the way the visit is conducted integrates concern for the person.  No alienation arises.

Objection B (Fetishism): Wanting the morally right is like wanting the fashionable—heteronomous.  
Reply: Fashionability is arbitrary; its normative force depends on others’ approval.  Morality’s authority, on the RRA account, derives from the equal status of rational persons.  The agent’s desire is therefore not for a label but for the actuality that justifies the label.  When morality is rightly understood, desiring “what is morally required” is desiring to comply with the reasons that every affected person could in principle endorse.

Objection C (Comparative Warmth): Surely a compassionate act is more admirable than a bare duty act.  
Reply: Sometimes yes, because additional virtues add value.  But sufficiency is weaker than optimality.  My claim is not that duty-only acts are maximally praiseworthy, but that they cross the threshold for moral worth.  Extra motives may enhance admiration without rendering the base motive insufficient.

Objection D (Epistemic Failure): Agents who rely on conscience alone may misidentify what morality requires.  
Reply: The third condition (epistemic competence) guards against this.  A misguided crusader who acts on a distorted conscience fails to possess the relevant competence; hence her deed lacks moral worth by my lights, even if it is “from duty” in her sense.

7. The Positive Payoff: Two Illustrative Cases  

Case 1: The Exhausted Resident  
A medical resident finishing a 28-hour shift discovers that the homeless patient in Room 12 has no way to refill his antibiotics prescription.  She is numb, her empathic reserves depleted.  What moves her to pick up the phone, arrange funding, and walk the form across the street is the stark consideration: “I promised to care for my patient, and this is what ethical practice requires.”  No warm feeling animates her.  Still, we praise her precisely for sustaining respect for her patient’s claim despite emotional fatigue.  The RRA account explains this verdict; a sentiment-dependence theory would wrongly withhold praise.

Case 2: The Global Tax Proposal  
A legislator votes for an unpopular carbon tax.  He tells constituents: “It is simply the right thing to do; future generations have a claim on us.”  Critics say he fetishizes morality, but imagine that he has studied climate science, listened to coastal communities, and internalised impartiality as a legislative virtue.  His vote is causally grounded in the single abstract thought, yet that thought encodes the concrete reasons.  We can intelligibly admire him—even if he personally dislikes the bill’s immediate consequences for his district—because he governs himself by the reasons that all affected parties share.

8. Comparisons with Alternative Views  

8.1 Sentimentalism.  
Michael Slote and David Hume locate moral worth in benevolent feelings.  The RRA account allows that sentiments are often laudable but argues they are neither necessary (see Exhausted Resident) nor sufficient (sentimentally loyal mafiosi).  The hallmark of the moral is respect for universalizable reasons, not merely warm affect.

8.2 Arpaly’s “Accidentally Right” Cases.  
Arpaly notes that Huck Finn’s sympathetic concern leads him to help Jim even though he believes it morally wrong.  She concludes motive worth can outrun moral belief.  The RRA account concurs, but explains the phenomenon differently: Huck’s act has worth because his de re concern for Jim manifests recognition respect at the concrete level, partly compensating for his faulty de dicto belief.  The case shows de re motives can suffice when de dicto fails; it does not show de dicto can never suffice.

8.3 Wolf’s Reasonableness Condition.  
Wolf says praiseworthy agents must be both moral and sane, capable of engaging with non-moral values.  The RRA motive does not crowd out the aesthetic, the comic, or the personal; it merely governs them when they conflict with persons’ claims.  One can cheer at a baseball game, write avant-garde music, and still reserve decision priority for moral reasons.  So RRA survives the Moral Saint worry.

9. Substantive Implications  

Implication 1: Education.  
Moral education should inculcate the standing policy, not merely sentiments.  Programs that combine perspective-taking with principled deliberation better approximate RRA than empathy-only curricula.

Implication 2: Institutional Design.  
We should design professional codes (medicine, law, engineering) that scaffold second-order duty commitments—checklists, audits, peer review—because such structures enable agents to act from duty even under affective fatigue.

Implication 3: Praise and Blame Practices.  
Public praise should highlight the agent’s respect-manifesting stance: “Dr. Lee went above and beyond because she recognised her obligation to her patient,” thereby reinforcing the norm of RRA rather than celebrating idiosyncratic compassion alone.

10. Possible Extensions and Research Questions  

a. Can artificial agents possess an RRA-type motive?  The account suggests a route: endow them with rule-following architectures that approximate recognition respect.  
b. Does RRA explain supererogation?  Perhaps supererogatory acts are those the basic duty policy does not require, thus adding a layer of excellence beyond sufficiency.  
c. How does RRA intersect with virtues like courage or wisdom?  These may be enabling traits that secure the epistemic and executive prerequisites of the duty policy.

11. Conclusion  

Acting from duty can indeed suffice for moral worth, but only when “duty” is understood as a Respectful Reflective Agency commitment: a second-order, value-laden, epistemically competent policy to govern oneself by the reasons one owes to others as equals.  Such a motive is not a fetishistic attachment to an empty label; it is the practical expression of recognition respect.  It earns praise because it manifests the agent’s distinctive rational power to treat persons, including herself, as bearers of claims that override contingent impulses.  Sentimental motives, when present, may add warmth and flourish, yet the cool clarity of duty—properly conceived—is neither cold nor empty.  It is the heat of reason, and when it alone moves an agent to right action, the act is fully worthy of moral esteem.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Is an agent who acts “solely from the motive of duty”—understood as a de dicto desire to do whatever is morally right—necessarily deficient in moral worth? I shall argue that the standard charge of “moral fetishism” is overstated. A purely dutiful motive can, under certain conditions, suffice for praiseworthy action. The key is to see duty not as an arid fixation on an abstract property, but as a higher-order practical commitment that orchestrates the agent’s first-order motivational economy. When duty functions in this role, (i) it expresses a form of autonomous self-governance, (ii) it manifests epistemic humility in the face of normative complexity, and (iii) it offers others a distinctive kind of assurance. These three features together ground the moral worth of dutiful action—without denying the independent value of richer first-order concerns such as sympathy or friendship.  

I proceed in five steps. Section 2 clarifies the de dicto / de re distinction and diagnoses why fetishism worries arise. Section 3 introduces a novel distinction between opaque and transparent de dicto motivation; only the former is suspect. Section 4 develops a positive account of duty as a higher-order, second-personal commitment that can itself confer moral worth. Section 5 rebuts four leading objections. Section 6 concludes with two upshots for contemporary moral psychology.

2. Why Duty Looks Fetishistic  

2.1 De dicto and de re moral motivation  
A de re motive picks out a concrete right-making consideration (say, the child’s welfare) and moves the agent via that very feature. A de dicto motive, by contrast, is content-neutral: “I want, whatever it is, to do the morally right thing here.” Kant’s famous shopkeeper, who charges a fair price because “it is his duty,” is the paradigm.  

2.2 The fetishism charge  
Michael Smith and others claim that a de dicto motive “fetishises” the property of rightness: the agent seems fascinated by an abstract label rather than by people, needs, or suffering. The apparent pathology has two parts. First, it seems motivationally thin—what, exactly, pushes the agent if not concrete concern? Second, it threatens alienation: the beneficiary suspects that the agent is not moved by her plight but only by some cold ideal.  

2.3 Hidden assumptions  
The fetishism worry presupposes that: (a) concrete reasons are always psychologically available, and (b) responding to them is always superior. Both assumptions are doubtful. Morally salient features can be opaque or contested in real time (consider climate policy), and agents often confront normative uncertainty. In such contexts, a higher-order desire “to do whatever is right” may be the most reliable tether to morality available.

3. Opaque versus Transparent De dicto Motivations  

We need a sharper lens. Merely marking an agent “de dicto motivated” collapses two importantly different psychologies.

• Opaque duty: The agent is insensitive to what makes an act right. She prizes the property of “rightness” as a fetish object; if told tomorrow that morality required cruelty, she would comply. Such an agent is alienated indeed.

• Transparent duty: The agent’s first project is to track whatever the right-making reasons turn out to be. She says, “I shall do what morality requires,” where this very stance includes openness to (and if time allows, active search for) the considerations that render the act right. If confronted with new evidence about others’ welfare, she revises her plan.  

Only opaque duty deserves the pejorative label; transparent duty does not. The fetishism literature rarely distinguishes the two, thereby indicting duty in toto for sins of a subset.

4. The Moral Worth of Transparent Duty  

4.1 Autonomous self-governance  
Acting from duty transparently understood is an exercise of autonomy in the Kantian (but not exclusively Kantian) sense: the agent authors her will under the idea of a law she gives herself. The moral law’s content is admittedly external to her immediate desires, yet by treating it as authoritative she governs her motivational set rather than being governed by it. Insofar as morality commands respect, such self-rule is intrinsically worthy.

4.2 Epistemic humility  
Real agents face moral disagreement, cognitive bias, and limited information. A de dicto orientation functions like a compass: “Whatever the terrain, point me toward moral north.” On this view duty is a regulative placeholder for the right-making reasons the agent cannot yet fully grasp. This stance is ethically valuable because it acknowledges, rather than suppresses, one’s epistemic limits. Praiseworthiness accrues to someone who structures her agency so that, when ignorance lifts, action will still converge on what is required.

4.3 Social assurance  
From the perspective of others, a transparently dutiful agent is reliable in a distinctive way. Someone motivated by fluctuating sympathy might falter if her sentiments cool; someone moved by self-interest will help only when incentives align. The dutiful agent signals: “Irrespective of how I feel about you, I will do right by you.” Especially in asymmetric power relations (doctors, judges, employers), such assurance is not cold but comforting. The patient can trust that care will be delivered even if she is annoying or ungrateful.

5. Four Objections Reconsidered  

Objection 1: Alienation is inevitable because the agent is not moved by the victim’s welfare.  
Reply: Alienation is a relational notion. What repels the beneficiary is disregard for her status, not disregard for a particular feeling of sympathy. A transparently dutiful agent’s stance—respecting the other precisely as a bearer of moral claims—treats her as a moral equal. Respect can be as intimacy-affirming as empathy; sometimes more so. The alienation worry conflates absence of a specific sentiment with absence of regard.

Objection 2: De dicto motivation is motivationally inert; “rightness” has no causal oomph without some de re substrate.  
Reply: Psychologically, higher-order desires routinely energise action (think of dieters whose only occurrent motive is “stick to the diet plan,” not any love of kale). Neuro-cognitive studies show that abstract rule adherence activates prefrontal circuitry linked to goal maintenance. Moreover, transparent duty typically recruits auxiliary motives—curiosity, planning, aversion to wrongdoing—that the agent endorses. The causal chain is as robust as any ordinary desire-based explanation.

Objection 3: Moral worth demands sensitivity to the *right* reason; a de dicto agent is only accidentally right if her moral beliefs are mistaken.  
Reply: Moral worth is compatible with unavoidable error so long as the agent’s reasoning is *competent*. The epistemic standards we apply to engineers or physicians (reasonable, evidence-responsive care) apply here. If she marshals the best evidence, consults peers, and deliberates sincerely, her action displays virtue even if—ex hypothesi—her community’s moral code is later overturned. Blame rests with collective ignorance, not with her dutiful orientation.

Objection 4: The story works only if duty is supplemented by first-order concern. But the question stipulates “solely from duty.”  
Reply: “Solely” can mean two things: (a) no other motive is present at all, or (b) other motives are present but they are normatively inert. Critics take (a), I grant only (b). Even on (b) the case is interesting: the agent’s *decisive* motive is duty; sympathy might float around but does no causal work. Kant’s “cold philanthropist” saved out of respect alone exemplifies (b). Such action is still praiseworthy *because* what clinches the decision is the self-conscious commitment to rightness. If literal motivational monism (a) ever occurs in human psychology, my account predicts its moral worth would depend on the same structural features—as long as autonomy, humility, and assurance are maintained.

6. Illustrative Cases  

Case A: The Lifeguard under Uncertainty  
A beach lifeguard notices two swimmers flailing. He cannot tell which one is closer to drowning, and time is short. Remembering the rescue-protocol manual, he chooses the child, explicitly “because that is the right thing to do.” His motive is de dicto: he cares mainly about conforming to the rescue duty. The decision exemplifies epistemic humility (he follows a rule precisely because he lacks concrete knowledge) and social assurance (any swimmer can expect fair treatment). Far from fetishistic, the motive channels his professional role into reliable action.

Case B: The Impartial Judge  
A judge presides over a case involving a former friend. She consciously brackets her affections, reminding herself, “My duty is to apply the law impartially.” She feels no personal warmth toward the litigant she ultimately favours. The de dicto motive secures justice precisely by disabling parochial sympathy. Observers praise her integrity, not her affect. The case shows how duty can outperform first-order concern when partiality is a risk.

7. Implications for Moral Psychology and Ethical Theory  

First, the debate over duty’s sufficiency has suffered from an overly coarse taxonomy of motives. Introducing the opaque/transparent distinction helps reconcile apparently conflicting data: some dutiful agents repel, others inspire. Researchers in empirical moral psychology can operationalise transparency (e.g., sensitivity to new moral evidence) to predict when de dicto motivation correlates with pro-social behaviour.  

Second, the analysis illuminates a neglected pathway to moral development. Moral education often tries to cultivate empathy or particular virtues. But cultivating *transparent* dutifulness—training agents to seek, track, and integrate right-making reasons—might be a sturdier strategy in pluralistic societies where we cannot assume shared sentiments.  

8. Conclusion  

Acting “solely from duty” need not be morally anaemic. When the higher-order desire to do what is right is transparent—open to the considerations that make acts right—it embodies autonomy, epistemic responsibility, and a publicly reassuring commitment to justice. These features jointly ground moral worth. Fetishism arises only where duty becomes opaque, cut off from the reasons it is meant to honor. Moral philosophy should therefore shift focus: the real task is not to replace de dicto motives with de re ones, but to cultivate transparent duty that integrates, rather than eclipses, the world’s concrete moral textures.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Is an abstract desire to “do the morally right thing”—call this a de dicto moral desire—good enough to confer moral worth on an action? An influential line of thought says “no.” It insists that genuine praiseworthiness requires being moved by the concrete right-making considerations themselves: the stranger’s suffering, the partner’s need for honesty, the refugee’s vulnerability, and so on. Someone who acts from a purely de dicto motive, critics urge, displays a kind of moral fetishism and is alienated from what morality is really about. 

I argue that this widespread skepticism is overstated. A de dicto desire to do what is morally right can, by itself, suffice for moral worth, provided that it satisfies two further conditions:

(1) Tracking Condition: The de dicto desire must be reliably sensitive to the right-making reasons—it must dispose the agent to act as those reasons require across relevantly nearby situations.

(2) Ownership Condition: The de dicto desire must issue from the agent’s own critical practical agency rather than from blind deference (e.g., servile conformity or mere obedience).

When these conditions are met, acting from a purely de dicto motive manifests the very capacities that make agents deserving of moral praise: practical rationality oriented toward the moral domain and self-governance that takes morality as authoritative. Far from being a fetish, such motivation expresses a structurally higher-order concern: “Whatever the moral reasons are, I shall treat them as decisive.” That stance is admirable even when the agent is not also moved by the first-order considerations that happen to make the act right. 

The argument proceeds in five steps. Sections 2 and 3 clarify the concept of a de dicto moral desire and the charge of fetishism. Section 4 develops the positive account of how the Tracking and Ownership conditions convert bare de dicto motivation into praiseworthy action. Section 5 engages leading objections—alienation, emotional deficit, and motivational fragility. Section 6 draws larger implications.

2. Two Kinds of Moral Desire

We need a precise map of the territory. Following Markovits and Arpaly, distinguish:

De dicto moral desire: a higher-order aim describable only as “to do what is morally right (whatever that is).” It is formally contentful but materially unspecific.

De re moral desire: a first-order aim for the very properties that render the act right (to relieve suffering, to keep a promise, to respect autonomy, etc.).

Critics worry about cases where the de dicto desire appears motivationally isolated from any de re concern. For instance, “Principle Pete” donates 10% of his income because “that’s what duty requires,” but he reports no fellow-feeling for the beneficiaries. His affect seems cold; his gaze is fixed on the moral law in abstraction. Is Pete worthy of praise?

3. The Fetishism and Alienation Charges

Two families of arguments target the sufficiency of de dicto desire.

3.1 Moral Fetishism (Smith 1994). The fetish charge says that the de dicto agent treats morality itself as a mere object of desire—like collecting stamps—not as what confers normative authority. This looks perverse: morality should guide action because it is good for people, or respects autonomy, not because “morality” as such attracts me.

3.2 Moral Alienation (Stocker 1976; Wolf 1982). The alienation complaint points to an experiential deficit. A lovable person helps a friend out of concern for the friend, not out of “duty.” Sole de dicto motivation signals a gustatory distance from the human point of morality.

Both critiques assume that de dicto motivation crowds out or replaces the first-order motives that ground right-making features. I contend that this assumption is false. A de dicto desire can be functionally integrated with sensitivity to first-order reasons without being identical to them.

4. A Functionalist Defense of De Dicto Motivation

4.1 Tracking Condition

Think of a de dicto moral desire as a policy: “Act as morality requires.” Whether that policy produces morally correct behavior depends on a guidance system that tracks moral reasons across varying contexts. Praiseworthiness, I submit, attaches not to the internal phenomenology of warm concern but to the agent’s competence at following the moral truth. 

Compare: A mathematician who yearns “to believe what is mathematically true” (a de dicto aim) is intellectually virtuous if she reliably deduces truths, revises errors, and follows proof wherever it leads. The virtue lies in truth-tracking competence, not in loving prime numbers for their own sake. Likewise, a de dicto moral agent is praiseworthy when her abstract allegiance issues in action that registers and responds correctly to the relevant concrete reasons.

4.2 Ownership Condition

Mere conformity to duty under threat or mindless deference is not yet praiseworthy. What we admire is self-governing commitment: the agent endorses morality’s authority on reflective grounds and thereby adopts the de dicto motive as hers. That ownership secures the agent’s freedom and explains why her success counts as an achievement rather than a happy coincidence or coercion.

4.3 Putting the Conditions Together

Where both conditions hold, the de dicto motive functions as a higher-order regulator, analogous to a thermostat. It does not encode each right-making property but is calibrated to keep behavior within the morally acceptable range. Because it operates reliably (Tracking) and from self-authorization (Ownership), its operation expresses precisely the capacities—responsiveness to reason and autonomous commitment—that underwrite moral praise. 

One may worry that this treats concrete empathy as optional. I deny that. The Tracking condition often requires cultivating emotional sensitivity; compassion and empathy are excellent epistemic detectors of others’ welfare. What matters is that these sensitivities are recruited instrumentally by the higher-order de dicto policy, even if they are not always occurrently motivating.

5. Responding to Objections

5.1 The Emotional Deficit Objection

“But Pete lacks the warm concern we find admirable.” Two replies. First, praiseworthiness in the moral sphere is not identical to lovability. We can separate the virtue of benevolence from the virtue of principled justice. Second, nothing in the de dicto model forbids emotional engagement; it only declines to make such engagement criterial for moral worth. If Pete’s abstract commitment reliably produces benevolent behavior, his emotional style may be less endearing but still morally admirable.

5.2 The Wrong Reasons Objection

Suppose Pete gives because he craves moral approval or heavenly reward. Such external incentives fail the Ownership test; they are not the agent’s recognition of morality’s authority but rather self-interested derivatives. My view predicts that such cases lack moral worth, thereby accommodating intuitive verdicts.

5.3 The Motivational Fragility Objection

Critics note that a de dicto desire seems informationally impoverished: “Do the right thing” specifies no actionable plan. Won’t it collapse when the agent is uncertain what morality requires? This is where the Tracking condition is essential. A praiseworthy de dicto agent possesses the capacities—deliberative, affective, imaginative—to discover what duty demands and to revise her judgment under new evidence. She is resilient, not fragile, in the face of moral uncertainty.

5.4 The Supererogation Worry

Can a purely de dicto motive explain supererogatory sacrifice? Yes. Agents may accept an overriding de dicto norm like “promote the greatest moral good, even beyond strict duty.” If they own that norm and reliably track the relevant reasons, their morally extraordinary acts flow from their de dicto stance.

6. Examples That Do Real Work

Example 1: The Lab Technician

Ada is a laboratory technician overseeing an experiment that releases mild irritants if safety protocols fail. She notices a parameter out of range. She is unmoved by the imagined discomfort of distant subjects (she finds such mental imagery hard to conjure) but acts instantly because “the moral thing is to shut the trial down.” Her reliable practice emerged from years of training herself to treat moral requirements as decisive. Ada’s intervention prevents harm. Despite lacking empathic resonance, her action is praiseworthy: she acted competently, tracked the harm-related reasons, and owned her policy.

Example 2: The Conscientious Juror

Brianna serves on a jury in a politically charged case. She wants above all “to reach the morally right verdict.” Her personal sympathies lie with the defendant, but the evidence convinces her of guilt. Over three days she reviews testimonies, studies jury instructions, and consults her sense of justice. She votes to convict, tears in her eyes. Her de dicto desire did not anesthetize empathy; it disciplined it. The moral worth of her vote flows precisely from her readiness to bracket first-order feelings when they conflict with what the best reasons require.

These cases show that the de dicto motive, properly functioning, secures moral reliability and expressive autonomy—core bases of praise.

7. Comparative Evaluation with De Re Motivation

Does my view discard the value of de re motives? Not at all. Often, being motivated by the right-making features is an excellent way to satisfy the Tracking condition, because concrete concern facilitates accurate perception of moral reasons. What I deny is necessity. The structure of moral worth is multiple-realizable: diverse motivational profiles can manifest the same competent responsiveness to moral reasons. Insisting on de re motives risks moral parochialism, for it privileges emotional temperaments over principled commitment and could rate a warm but erratic benefactor above a principled but affectively muted agent—contrary to many judgments about reliability and responsibility.

8. Distinguishing Two Kinds of Praise

We should also separate evaluative layers:

Agent-neutral value: The goodness of the outcome.

Agentive moral worth: The praiseworthiness of the agent’s contribution.

Something similar occurs in aesthetics. One may admire a minimalist architect not for sensuous warmth but for disciplined elegance. Likewise, moral praise can attach to disciplined structure of will.

9. Broader Implications

9.1 Moral Education

Moral pedagogy that inculcates a higher-order respect for moral reasons may better accommodate pluralistic societies. Children taught to ask “What is the right thing?” learn a portable deliberative skillset. Later they can fill in substance—welfare, fairness, rights—without having each possible right-making feature already emotionally loaded.

9.2 Artificial Agents

Debates about moral A.I. often assume that genuine moral worth is impossible without empathetic feelings. My account suggests a path: If an artificial system could own a de dicto norm under functional analogues of Tracking and Ownership, its actions would at least bear the structural marks of moral worth, whatever further metaphysical worries remain.

10. Conclusion

The motive of duty, construed de dicto, need not be a cold fetish. When integrated into a reliable, self-endorsed guidance structure, it can underwrite actions that manifest the core virtues morality demands: sensitivity to reason and autonomous commitment. Therefore, acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can indeed suffice for morally worthy conduct. Its praiseworthiness derives not from sentimental warmth but from reason’s capacity to guide itself by moral norms—a capacity as worthy of admiration as any tender feeling.

1. Framing the Question  

Imagine two physicians rushing to treat a stranger who has collapsed on the pavement.  Dr. Grace is moved by vivid empathy: she can almost feel the victim’s pain and is propelled by concern for his welfare.  Dr. Hale is moved instead by a single all‐purpose resolution: “It is morally right to help, and that is decisive.”  She finds the patient’s specific plight motivationally inert except as evidence that helping is required.  Is Hale’s conduct—motivated solely by a de dicto desire to do the morally right thing—less worthy of praise than Grace’s?  Many philosophers think so.  They accuse Hale of “moral fetishism” (Stocker), “alienation” (Williams), or an impoverished moral psychology (Wolf, Hursthouse).  According to this critique, praiseworthy agents must be fired by the very considerations that make the act right—welfare, justice, promise‐keeping—and not merely by an abstract wish to be morally up‐to‐date.

I will argue that the critics have aimed at the wrong target.  A purely de dicto desire to do what is right can, under certain conditions, suffice for moral worth, and sometimes it is the best motive an agent could have.  What makes such action praiseworthy is not warm emotional resonance with the right‐making features, but the manifestation of two higher‐order capacities that are themselves morally valuable:  

A. Rational responsiveness: the agent’s de dicto desire is reliably regulated by her best judgment about which concrete reasons obtain.  

B. Diachronic coordination: the desire furnishes an executive framework that integrates the agent’s conduct across heterogeneous contexts, thereby expressing a stable commitment to treat persons according to the demands of morality, whatever they turn out to be.  

When these conditions are met, the “duty motive” does not alienate the agent from morality’s substantive point; rather, it efficiently channels her agency toward it.  The allegedly fetishistic appearance arises only in defective variants—where the de dicto desire is insulated from reason or functions as a self‐regarding badge of moral status.  

The argument proceeds in four stages.  (§2) I clarify what a de dicto moral desire is and distinguish two functional roles it can play.  (§3) I diagnose the standard fetishism objection.  (§4) I defend the positive proposal, supplying examples and replying to three leading counterarguments.  (§5) I draw two upshots for debates about moral worth and moral psychology.

2. What Is a De Dicto Moral Desire?  

To want, de dicto, “to do what is morally right” is to have a standing higher‐order disposition: whenever one believes that some act φ is morally required, that belief by itself motivates one to φ.  The desire is content‐general; it points, not to any particular value (welfare, fairness, autonomy), but to whatever features make actions right, whatever they might be.  Still, the motive can function in two very different ways.

2.1 The Regulative Role.  Here the desire operates as an executive summary of first‐order reasons.  The agent forms the belief that φ is morally required because φ will relieve suffering or honor a promise.  The de dicto desire gets her out of the chair; the concrete reasons selected the target.  Call this the transparent duty motive.

2.2 The Insulated Role.  Alternatively, an agent may cherish an identity as “someone who always does the right thing” while remaining motivationally indifferent to the right‐making facts.  She cares that φ is morally required, but not why.  Call this the opaque duty motive.

The critics’ cases typically focus on opaque versions.
