But nothing in the idea of a de dicto desire entails opacity; indeed Kant’s own description of acting “from duty” presupposes transparency, since the good will must act “for the sake of the law” as it applies to the particulars.  The question, then, is whether transparent duty can itself ground moral worth.

3. Diagnosing the Fetishism Charge  

The charge has two strands.

Alienation.  Acting from abstract duty allegedly fails to engage appropriately with the people or goods at stake.  This is thought to cheapen the moral value of the act, just as giving a gift solely to satisfy social convention seems less generous than giving out of friendship.

Perverse Valuing.  A de dicto desire seems to prize moral rightness as an object, turning morality into a collectible rather than a relation to persons.  That, says the critic, is morally perverse.

Both worries trade on the same assumption: to *appreciate* a moral reason just is to be *motivated by* that very reason.  If the motive’s content differs, appreciation is missing.  I reject that assumption.  Appreciative understanding can be registered in judgment, while motivation is supplied by a higher‐order desire to act as judged.  Plato’s “spirit,” to use an older model, need not mirror the “reason” that commands it; what matters is that spirit listens to reason faithfully.

4. A Positive Case for Dutiful Motivation  

4.1 The Coordination Argument  

Morality’s demands are numerous, heterogeneous, and occasionally in tension.  Agents need a unifying executive policy for how to respond to whatever conglomerate of grounds—welfare here, fidelity there, fairness elsewhere—turn out to be decisive in a given case.  A content‐general desire “to do what is morally right” performs that coordinating task elegantly.  It functions like a legal principle instructing courts to apply “the law”—without specifying in advance which statutes and precedents will matter in each suit.  By contrast, a portfolio of discrete benevolent sentiments, each keyed to a particular value, leaves motivational gaps where unfamiliar or conflicting values arise.  (History is replete with kind masters who nonetheless perpetuated injustice because their humane sympathy failed to register to their slaves’ equal moral status.)  A duty motive that tracks our best moral judgment is more reliable across changing circumstances and hence a locus of praiseworthiness.

4.2 The Respect Argument  

Second, to value rightness as such is to value persons *as* moral equals.  The content of moral rightness—whatever ethical theory ultimately decides—centrally concerns how we must treat others if we are to respect them.  A general commitment to rightness therefore embodies respect in a deep form: it is an acknowledgment that others’ claims exert authority over one’s will.  That relational stance can be present even when the agent is not moved by tender concern or sympathetic resonance.  Indeed, a judge who sentences a relative out of duty, suppressing partial affection, displays respect for the citizenry’s equal status precisely through a de dicto moral motive.

4.3 The Reliability Argument  

Praiseworthiness is partly a matter of credit.  We praise agents, not for lucky conformity to morality, but for manifesting stable dispositions that *would* lead them to act rightly under a variety of counterfactual conditions.  A transparent de dicto desire that is sensitive to deliberative updates passes this modal test.  Empathic concern, by contrast, is notoriously context‐sensitive and subject to bias (Small, Loewenstein & Slovic 2007).  If Hale’s general duty reliably counteracts her implicit partialities, she is more creditworthy than Grace, even if Grace happens on this occasion to act equally well.

4.4 Objection 1: Emotional Impoverishment  

“But,” the critic replies, “isn’t something missing if the agent feels no compassion?”  Two answers.  (i) Compassion may indeed enhance moral worth, but sufficiency is a weaker claim: Hale’s act is *enough* for praise even if it is not maximally admirable.  (ii) In many cases emotional neutrality is positively appropriate: surgeons suppress empathy to avoid trembling hands; auditors avoid friendship to maintain impartiality.  What matters is fitness to role.

4.5 Objection 2: Wrong Kind of Reason  

Some maintain that appealing to moral rightness is the “wrong kind of reason” for action, akin to playing chess because the rules say so rather than to checkmate.  Yet in morality, the rules are not arbitrary constraints; they *express* the point—respect for persons.  The chess analogy therefore misfires.  A better comparison is scientific inquiry: one may investigate a phenomenon simply because one wants the truth.  No scientist is accused of “truth fetishism.”

4.6 Objection 3: Empty Formalism  

Finally, consider the worry that a de dicto desire is vacuous because *anything* could count as right if the agent’s ethical beliefs are misguided.  Transparency again matters.  The desire must be *responsive to reasons*: the agent is disposed to revise her view when confronted with evidence, argument, or lived experience.  A racist who clings to bigotry “out of duty” lacks such responsiveness; hence her motive is not praiseworthy.  The sufficiency claim is conditional on the duty motive being properly connected to the normatively relevant facts.

4.7 Illustrative Case: The Anonymous Donor  

Suppose an epidemiologist donates 30% of her salary to effective global‐health charities.  She feels little emotive pull toward distant beneficiaries; instead, she adheres to a policy: “Whenver a donation would do more good than any competing use of my resources, morality requires me to donate, and I therefore shall.”  Critics might deem her cold.  Yet her policy channels resources to those in need more reliably, and with less bias, than the intermittent sympathy of most donors.  Her action structure demonstrates respect for the lives at stake; it displays rational responsiveness to evidence about cost‐effectiveness; and it bears diachronic stability.  That seems fully praiseworthy.

5. Broader Implications  

First, the analysis nuances Kantian moral worth.  The venerable slogan “only actions done from duty have moral worth” often strikes modern ears as implausibly austere.  Read through the lens of the transparent duty motive, Kant’s claim is more plausible: he was emphasizing that what merits special esteem is an act that issues from the agent’s commitment to *act on reasons as such*—a commitment which, in a finite rational being, remains necessary even when sympathetic drives concur.

Second, the account illuminates moral education.  Early moral development cannot feasibly install a distinct sentiment for each value.  What teachers cultivate, at least initially, is a general resolution: “Do what is right and take trouble to find out what that is.”  Later, richer value‐specific emotions may blossom, but they are not indispensable to worth.

6. Conclusion  

Acting from the motive of duty need not be a form of moral fetishism.  When the de dicto desire (i) tracks an agent’s best, constantly revisable judgment about concrete moral reasons and (ii) coordinates her agency across contexts, it embodies precisely the capacities—respect, rational governance, reliability—that make moral conduct praiseworthy.  Warm feelings and direct concern for welfare are welcome supplements, often deepening the beauty of moral life, but they are not the essence of moral worth.  In many real‐world situations—where partial sympathies, fatigue, or fear threaten to sway us—a principled higher‐order commitment to “do what is right, whatever that turns out to be” is not merely adequate; it is the most admirable motive we can have.

Thesis  
Yes. A de dicto desire to “do what is morally right” can on its own ground an action’s moral worth, provided that (i) the desire is reason-responsive in the right way and (ii) its operation manifests the agent’s distinctive form of regard for others that Kant called respect. Where those two conditions are met, acting solely “from duty” is neither fetishistic nor alienated; it is an elegant higher-order strategy for reliably tracking the very first-order considerations critics think it neglects.  

I. Mapping the Terrain  
Contemporary critics—A. Arpaly, S. Wolf, P. Railton, among others—accept the following syllogism:  
1. To have moral worth, an action must be motivated by the right-making considerations.  
2. A purely de dicto wish “to do the morally right thing” is motivationally blind to those considerations.  
∴ Therefore a purely de dicto wish cannot confer moral worth.  

The argument looks powerful because (1) enjoys wide support: what we praise is not bare conformity with duty but a quality of will that takes the relevant reasons to heart. The real work therefore occurs in premise (2). I shall argue that (2) equivocates between two very different kinds of de dicto orientation. “Moral fetishism” is a problem only for one of them.  

II. Two De Dicto Desires: Deferential vs. Deliberative  
Call a desire “deferentially de dicto” when its content is simply “Do whatever the moral law says,” where that law is treated as an external oracle. Agents of this type outsource moral cognition; their pattern is: (i) find out moral verdict, (ii) obey. They would, as critics point out, obey the oracle even if the right-making features inexplicably changed. Such motivation is indeed disturbingly fetishistic: the oracle, not the underlying value, is doing the guiding.  

Contrast a “deliberatively de dicto” desire: “Do what is morally right, where ‘morally right’ is whatever is supported by the weightiest impartial reasons.” The crucial difference is that the second desire incorporates a deliberative role for first-order considerations. It directs the agent to seek out, weigh, and respond to the very considerations that constitute rightness. The de dicto form functions like a higher-order filter that says: “Track whatever considerations turn out to matter.”  

Once this distinction is in place, premise (2) loses its grip. Only deferential de dicto desire is motivation-blind. Deliberative de dicto desire is better understood as an *architecture* for being guided by the substance.  

III. A Working Example  
Suppose Mira is hurrying to catch a train when she sees a stranger collapse. Two motivations stir: (a) empathic concern—“That person must be terrified and in pain”; (b) a deliberative de dicto concern—“It would be wrong to leave her unaided.” Critics say only (a) can ground moral worth. But imagine an alternate case: Mira’s empathic capacities are temporarily numbed by shock. All she can register is that someone is in medical peril, a fact she recognizes as morally weighty though she feels no sympathy. Her de dicto desire to do what morality requires kicks in, producing swift, competent aid. Does she act with moral worth? Intuitions diverge less sharply than the literature suggests: we still want to praise her. What does the praising track? Not warm feelings, but a steadfast commitment to respond to objective need—manifested here via the deliberative de dicto route.  

IV. Respect as the Underlying Valuable Attitude  
Why does the deliberative de dicto motive deserve praise? Because it manifests *respect*. Kantian respect is neither emotion nor empathy but a recognition of persons (or sentient beings) as loci of value whose claims make legitimate demands on one’s will. Respect is naturally expressed in a higher-order form: “I shall do what these beings rightly require of me,” even if I currently lack the sentimental dispositions that would make those requirements motivationally vivid. De dicto desire is precisely that form of respect, made operational.  

V. The Quality-of-Will Criterion Revisited  
Most contemporary theories of moral worth—whether Kantian, contractualist, or Scanlonian—cash it out in terms of quality of will. The question is not “Which psychological token directly energized the arm muscles?” but “What quality of will did the action express?” If a de dicto desire is shaped by respect and is sensitive to the content of moral reasons, it expresses a high quality of will. The fact that it is a higher-order desire does not by itself diminish that quality; indeed, it can enhance reliability across contexts where first-order sentiments falter.  

VI. Two Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Epistemic Alienation. A deliberative de dicto agent is still one step removed from concrete value; she cares about rightness, not people.  
Reply: The objection assumes that “caring about rightness” is motivationally isolating. But deliberative de dicto desire includes a mandate to *recognize* and *respond to* people’s needs as constitutive of rightness. It therefore integrates, rather than screens off, first-order value. It is analogous to caring about health by caring about whatever physiological states constitute health.  

Objection 2: Motivational Overbreadth. Because the deliberative de dicto desire is content-neutral—ready to act on *whatever* turns out right—it lacks the selectivity that shows genuine attachment to moral features.  
Reply: Selectivity is not always a virtue. We prize generosity over parochial altruism precisely because the former is not tied to familiar faces. Similarly, the breadth of deliberative de dicto desire reveals humility and impartiality: the agent is committed to value wherever it lies, not just where her sentiments happen to gravitate.  

VII. Three Necessary Conditions for Worthy De Dicto Action  
To forestall fetishism, dutiful action must satisfy three joint conditions:  

1. Correctness: The agent’s normative belief must in fact align with the right-making features. False moral beliefs vitiate worth even if sincerely acted upon.  
2. Explanatory Role: The de dicto desire must non-accidentally explain the action. Mere causal accompaniment (e.g., “I also happened to think it was right”) is insufficient.  
3. Reasons-Responsiveness: Were the underlying moral reasons absent or outweighed, the agent would withhold action. This counters the oracle-obedience model.  

If these are met, dutiful action earns full moral credit.  

VIII. Why Preferring Concrete Motivations Can Mislead  
Two sociological facts cloud the debate. First, empathy comes cheaply in paradigm cases (saving a visible child), so we conflate its motivational vividness with moral worth. Second, many real-world duties—paying wages on time, implementing fair algorithms, preventing climate harms—are too abstract for empathic traction. Here a well-tuned de dicto disposition is indispensable. Our praise practices should not penalize agents whose moral ecology stresses complex duties.  

IX. A Rejoinder to Aristotelian Virtue Ethics  
Virtue theorists argue that fully developed virtue integrates reason and emotion, so an agent acting *solely* from duty exhibits an impoverished character. Two replies. (a) Diagnostic: the question concerns whether duty can *suffice*, not whether it is *ideal*. I grant that a richer motivational set is preferable; sufficiency is a lower bar. (b) Empirical: in pluralistic societies agents often face emotionally neutral quandaries (e.g., systemic injustices) where Aristotelian sentiment is silent. Duty-based motivation then preserves moral responsiveness. Sufficiency again kicks in.  

X. Implications for Moral Education  
If the analysis is right, educators should cultivate both sympathetic and duty-based motivations. The latter acts as a moral “backstop” when sentiment falters or conflicts. Training agents to reason about rightness—and to care, de dicto, about tracking it—is therefore pedagogically urgent. Far from producing moral robots, it produces resilient moral agents.  

XI. A Final, Counter-Intuitive Benefit  
Because de dicto motivation operates at a higher level of abstraction, it is uniquely positioned to correct for biases embedded in our affective systems. Studies in social psychology show empathy vectors toward identifiable victims and in-group members. A commitment to do what is morally right—even when my emotions are silent or counter-suggestive—is a mechanism for justice across distance, anonymity, and time. That seems not fetishistic but laudably vigilant.  

Conclusion  
Acting “from duty alone” is praiseworthy when the agent’s de dicto desire is deliberative, respect-based, and reasons-responsive. Such a desire is no mere fetish; it is a principled commitment to be guided by exactly the considerations that make actions right, deployed from a vantage point that secures impartiality and reliability. Where those features are in place, duty is not an alien force but a clear lens through which moral reality is seen and acted upon.

1. Introduction and Thesis

Critics from Stocker to Wolf have insisted that a merely de dicto desire “to do the morally right thing” cannot ground fully praiseworthy action. They argue that the agent whose sole motive is duty is either morally fetishistic—treating morality itself as a talisman rather than caring about what morality is about—or alienated from the concrete values (welfare, autonomy, justice) that make her action right. I shall defend the contrary view. Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is right can be morally worthy, provided that the desire is the right kind: a transparent, higher-order commitment that regulates deliberation by making the agent appropriately sensitive to the concrete right-making features of situations. Such an agent’s praiseworthiness stems from two sources: (i) the epistemic and practical excellence manifested in navigating moral uncertainty through an abstract but content-sensitive principle, and (ii) the expression of respect for morality’s authority, which itself is a morally valuable attitude. This account avoids fetishism and alienation because the de dicto desire governs the agent’s responsiveness to the very concrete considerations critics champion; it does not displace them.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

2.1 De dicto vs. de re moral motivation  
A de re moral motive is a desire for some specific feature that makes an act right—e.g., the pedestrian’s welfare. A de dicto moral motive is a desire directed at the property of being morally right, without specifying which concrete feature confers that status. An agent can, of course, possess both kinds of desire; the controversy arises when only the de dicto motive is present.

2.2 Moral worth and praiseworthiness  
Following Kant, an act is morally worthy when its motive makes the agent deserving of moral praise, where praise is the fitting response to the agent’s exercise of moral virtue or excellence. Moral worth lies primarily in what the action expresses about the agent’s character and rational capacities, not merely in its consequences.

2.3 Two forms of de dicto desire  
I propose distinguishing:

• Opaque de dicto desire: “I want to do whatever is right, full stop,” with no further regulative structure.  
• Transparent de dicto desire: “I want my conduct to conform to the set of considerations that actually make actions right.” The desire is higher-order and includes an instruction to discover, track, and be guided by those considerations.

The opaque form is prone to fetishism; I defend the transparent form.

3. The Standard Anti-Fetishist Argument

The familiar complaint runs as follows:

Premise 1. Morally worthy action must be motivated by the same substantive considerations that make the action right.  
Premise 2. A purely de dicto motive is abstract and therefore not the right-making consideration.  
Conclusion. Purely de dicto motivation cannot ground moral worth.

Support is drawn from several perceived costs:

a) Alienation: The dutiful agent seems detached from values people ordinarily care about.  
b) Coldness: The motive seems affectively thin, lacking compassion or solidarity.  
c) Bad selectivity: The agent might latch onto any principle she thinks is right, leading to moral mistakes without culpability.

4. A Positive Case for De Dicto Sufficiency

4.1 The functional role of the transparent de dicto desire  
Such a desire does not compete with de re motives; it scaffolds them. By aiming to track whatever makes actions right, the higher-order desire organizes inquiry, corrects partiality, and mobilizes instrumental reasoning. It tells the agent: “Find out which concrete considerations are relevant and let them move you.” When this plan is executed competently, the causal pathway from the de dicto desire to action necessarily passes through sensitivity to the concrete right-makers. Hence Premise 1 in the anti-fetishist argument is satisfied: the agent’s decision actually depends on those concrete considerations, albeit indirectly.

4.2 Respect for morality’s authority  
Morality, if anything, claims authority over our conduct wherever its requirements apply. A stable disposition to treat rightness as action-determining—the core of the de dicto motive—therefore expresses respect for that authority. Respect is itself a morally significant attitude; an action that embodies it is pro tanto worthy of praise.

4.3 Epistemic and practical excellence under uncertainty  
Agents are often ignorant of the specific right-making features of situations. The transparent de dicto desire provides a regulative ideal that motivates moral inquiry, humility about one’s own biases, and resolution in the face of normative complexity. These are virtues. An action that issues from them, even if affectively cool, can manifest a distinctive moral reliability—the capacity to do the right thing across varying contexts—which is intuitively praiseworthy.

5. Illustrative Cases

Case 1: Foggy Rescue  
A hiker hears cries from dense fog. She cannot tell whether it is a human or an animal nor what help is required. She asks herself, “What is the right thing here?” Deciding that investigating is morally obligatory, she proceeds. Her motive is simply to do whatever is right; she lacks any concrete benevolent emotion toward whoever cries out. Yet her deliberation is praiseworthy: it acknowledges moral uncertainty, commits to resolving it, and drives her to undertake the rescue. The transparent de dicto desire did all the work.

Case 2: The Exhausted Doctor  
A triage physician at the end of a 48-hour shift feels numb. She no longer feels direct compassion toward the endless line of patients; what keeps her going is a single thought: “These people have a right to care and it is my duty to provide it.” Her continuing to treat patients diligently is morally admirable, not fetishistic. The de dicto motive sustains moral performance when affective de re motives are drained.

Case 3: The Mercenary-Turned-Kantian  
A former soldier, habituated to obeying orders, adopts the maxim “Act only according to that principle you can will as universal law.” He now refuses lucrative assassination contracts even when the prospective target is vicious. He has little love for the victims. Praiseworthiness here derives from self-governance by an impartial moral principle that systematizes respect for persons.

These cases show that the de dicto motive (i) can recruit sensitivity to the morally relevant facts once they are discovered (Foggy Rescue), (ii) can sustain right action when ordinary affective motives fail (Exhausted Doctor), and (iii) can correct prior immoral habits (Mercenary). In each, the action is morally worthy even though concrete concern is absent or secondary.

6. Replying to the Main Objections

6.1 Fetishism  
The fetishism charge presumes the agent treats “rightness” as a mysterious good independent of its grounds. That worry targets the opaque form of de dicto desire. But a transparent higher-order desire is conceptually structured to be mediated by right-making reasons; it therefore cannot be a fetish.

Analogy: a scientist’s de dicto desire to “believe what is true” is not epistemic fetishism. It organizes her inquiry into de re truths. Similarly, wanting one’s conduct to be “morally right” is not moral fetishism if it organizes inquiry into justice, welfare, autonomy, etc.

6.2 Alienation from value  
Alienation is avoided because the agent’s deliberative route inevitably includes acknowledging right-making considerations. She may not feel warmth, but affective empathy is only one way of being related to value; cognitive recognition and voluntary responsiveness suffice for respect.

Moreover, ordinary moral life includes roles—judges, auditors, safety inspectors—where personal concern is inappropriate. Their detached but principle-governed motives are widely regarded as virtuous precisely because they prevent favoritism.

6.3 Coldness and motivational richness  
Praiseworthiness does not scale with emotional vividness. Over-reliance on sympathy can produce morally regrettable partiality. The de dicto motive delivers impartial coverage while being compatible with, though not dependent on, sympathetic feelings. A balanced moral psychology may contain both kinds of motives; my claim is only sufficiency, not exclusivity.

6.4 Bad selectivity: “But the agent might pick the wrong morality”  
True, epistemic failure is possible. Yet the same is true for de re motives: compassion can be ill-informed or misdirected. What matters are the agent’s deliberative virtues—careful evidence gathering, openness to criticism—not the mere type of motive. When the transparent de dicto desire is executed with those virtues, mistakes are culpability-mitigated in the familiar way.

7. Comparative Dialectic: De Re Alone vs. De Dicto Alone

Suppose we contrast two minimalist agents:

• Warm Sam: moved solely by compassion for whomever he can vividly imagine.  
• Duty Dana: moved solely by the transparent de dicto desire.

Sam performs praiseworthy acts in salient emergencies but ignores distant harms he cannot picture. Dana donates to effective charities after reading cost-effectiveness studies. Which is morally worthier? Not obviously Sam. The comparison suggests that a purely de re motive can fall short on universality and deliberative rectitude, whereas a purely de dicto motive can excel in those respects.

8. A Hybrid Picture and Its Normative Edge

The debate often assumes a zero-sum competition: either concrete care or abstract duty. But empirical psychology indicates that human motivation is plural and context-sensitive. The transparent de dicto desire can function as a regulatory controller that triggers, coordinates, or substitutes for various de re motives. On this view:

• When sympathy is available and reliable, the higher-order desire licenses acting from it.  
• When sympathy conflicts with impartial moral reasons (e.g., nepotism), the de dicto desire overrides.  
• When sympathy is absent (Exhausted Doctor), the desire itself motivates right action.

Rather than being redundant, the de dicto motive is the glue that integrates our motivational economy into a coherent moral agency. Its praiseworthiness lies in manifesting the virtue of practical wisdom—phronesis—under conditions of motivational heterogeneity.

9. Wider Implications

9.1 Moral education  
Teaching children merely to “care about others” risks partial compassion; teaching them also to “do what is right” instills a regulative framework that scales with growing cognitive capacities.

9.2 Moral testimony and deference  
A transparent de dicto desire justifies moral deference to experts when one lacks direct understanding. Critics of moral deference worry about alienation; but my account treats testimony as a rational extension of the desire to align with rightness under epistemic limitation.

9.3 Collective agents and institutions  
Institutions lack affect. Yet we want them to act rightly. What motivates them, metaphorically speaking, is a de dicto desire instantiated in rules and procedures responsive to right-making reasons (justice, efficiency, rights). Hence institutional morality vindicates the sufficiency claim.

10. Novel Insight: De Dicto Desire as Second-Personal Commitment

Stephen Darwall argues that moral obligations are irreducibly second-personal: they arise from relations in which one can address claims to another. The transparent de dicto desire can be reframed as a standing second-personal commitment: I desire to do what any addressee could legitimately demand of me. That structure inherently encodes responsiveness to the concrete interests of moral fellows without requiring the motivational texture of empathy. This synthesis deflects both fetishism (because the desire is relational, not object-directed at a fetish) and alienation (because its content is precisely others’ authority).

11. Potential Limitations and Further Questions

My argument establishes sufficiency, not necessity. Some actions may lack moral worth if performed exclusively from duty—e.g., spontaneous loving generosity arguably loses something when overtaken by sober obligation. Further work must articulate when de re motives confer incremental worth over the baseline provided by duty.

Additionally, cultural variance in how people conceive “morality” may affect how the de dicto desire functions; in communities with distorted moral codes, the desire may misfire. Addressing this requires coupling the desire with virtues of critical reflection and openness to moral progress—features I have tacitly assumed.

12. Conclusion

An exclusive focus on concrete benevolent motives underestimates the moral value of higher-order, principle-governed agency. When an agent’s sole motive is a transparent de dicto desire to do what is morally right, and when that desire operates through competent deliberation that tracks right-making reasons, her action is morally worthy. The praiseworthiness derives from respect for moral authority, from practical and epistemic virtues manifested under uncertainty, and from the agent’s reliable sensitivity to the very values the anti-fetishist camp wishes to honor. Far from being a mere fallback or an alienating fetish, acting from duty can be an exemplary expression of mature moral agency.

1. Introduction and Thesis  

When we praise an agent for acting well, we usually want to say that she acted “for the right reasons.”  But what exactly must figure in her motivational set?  One influential view—going back to Aristotle and revived by contemporary sentimentalists and neo-Aristotelians—holds that she must be moved by the very considerations that make her act right: the friend’s need, the stranger’s pain, the promisee’s reliance.  A mere abstract desire to “do the morally right thing” smells, to these critics, like moral fetishism: the agent’s gaze is fixed on moral rectitude itself rather than on the concrete goods morality is supposed to protect.  

I shall defend the contrary thesis: a purely de dicto desire to do what is morally right can by itself ground full moral worth, provided it is embedded in a certain kind of practical competence.  What makes such dutiful action praiseworthy is not the presence of warm moral sentiments, but the exercise of a self-regulating capacity to reliably track moral reasons across situations—call it moral self-governance.  When that capacity is manifested, acting from duty is neither fetishistic nor alienating; rather, it is the distinctive way finite, fallible agents can respect the moral law while acknowledging the limits of their epistemic access to right-making features.  

I proceed as follows.  §2 clarifies the de dicto / de re distinction and the fetishism complaint.  §3 argues that moral worth is primarily a matter of exercising self-governance, and that a de dicto motive can manifest this exercise.  §4 develops two further, non-Kantian advantages of the de dicto motive—epistemic humility and value-integrative robustness—that the de re view undervalues.  §5 replies to four standard objections (alienation, coldness, motivational weakness, and the “dutiful robot”).  §6 synthesises these points into a competence account of praiseworthiness and illustrates it with a pair of cases.  §7 concludes.

2. Duty, De Dicto Motivation, and the Charge of Fetishism  

Let us mark two contrasts.

a) De dicto vs. de re desire.  To want, de re, to help Sarah is to be motivationally keyed to Sarah herself.  To want, de dicto, to do “whatever is morally right in these circumstances” is to be keyed to the rightness property, whatever token instantiates it.

b) Right-making vs. motivating reasons.  The fact that Sarah is in pain may make helping her obligatory.  Whether that fact also operates as the agent’s motivating reason is a further question.

The fetishism objection (Smith 1994; Railton 2006; Arpaly 2003) alleges the following:

1. Morality is about concrete values (welfare, autonomy, etc.).
2. The de dicto motive ignores those values and focuses on rightness itself.
3. Therefore it is fetishistic—like loving someone solely because she is “the legally recognised spouse,” not because of her own qualities.
4. Because of this mismatch, dutiful action lacks full moral worth.

Proponents of the fetishism charge often invoke everyday phenomenology.  The Good Samaritan, they say, rushes to aid not because “helping is required,” but because the wounded man bleeds.

3. Moral Worth, Self-Governance, and the De Dicto Motive  

Kant famously claims that nothing is unconditionally good except a good will—one that acts “from duty.”  Critics counter that Kant mistakes a secondary motive (respect for law) for the primary motive (concern for persons).  We can grant that respect for persons supplies the content of the moral law yet still ask: what kind of psychological state constitutes acting “for the sake of that law”?  

My proposal: moral worth consists in the agent’s successful exercise of moral self-governance, where this is a disposition

(i) to take the set of moral reasons as providing decisive practical guidance,  
(ii) to identify correctly what those reasons require, and  
(iii) to conform action to that requirement because it so requires.

All three elements matter.  (i) supplies the de dicto end: do what morality requires.  (ii) introduces a cognitive component: the requirement must be tracked correctly (fallible but non-accidentally).  (iii) ensures motivational efficacy.  When these conditions are satisfied, the action is praiseworthy—even if no de re sentiment toward the beneficiary plays a motivating role—because the agent’s will is governed by the authority of moral reasons themselves.  

Why should that count as praiseworthy?  Two considerations:

A. Autonomy of reason.  To treat moral considerations as decisive just because they are moral is to acknowledge them as reasons that apply to one’s will irrespective of inclination.  Exercising that capacity realises a form of autonomy that is central to our most basic moral practices of praise and blame.  Blame condemns failures of governance; praise recognises its successful exercise.

B. Reliability across contexts.  The de dicto disposition is portable.  A lover of animals may reliably refrain from cruelty to dogs but forget fish; someone committed to moral rightness per se will generalise across cases, provided her deliberative competence is intact.

4. Two Further Virtues of the De Dicto Motive  

4.1 Epistemic Humility  

Agents are often ignorant of the actual right-making features of their situations.  Consider Sophie, a doctor in triage.  She can neither fully probe each patient’s prospects nor fully weigh their social roles.  What she can do is resolve: “I shall do what justice in allocation requires.”  This second-order commitment is not a substitute for trying to discern first-order facts; it is the practical stance that keeps her deliberation anchored to whatever those facts turn out to be.  The de dicto motive thus honours epistemic humility: when you do not know precisely what makes an act right, the best you can do is aim at rightness itself.  By contrast, a purely de re sentimental motive risks misfiring: affectionate concern may privilege the wrong patient if the true right-maker is, say, prognosis or prior claim.

4.2 Value-Integrative Robustness  

Moral life is pluralistic.  Altruistic concern, respect for autonomy, fairness, special obligations, and so on push in different directions.  A de re motive locks on to whichever of these considerations happens to grip the agent most immediately.  Over time, that can produce a patchwork of inconsistent responsiveness.  By contrast, the de dicto stance functions as an integrator: it instructs the agent to adjudicate among competing first-order values according to their moral weight, not according to their affective salience.

Hence the supposed deficit of abstraction is in fact a resource: it prevents any single first-order concern from hijacking the deliberation, thereby promoting a balanced response to the full structure of moral reasons.

5. Four Objections Revisited  

Objection 1: Alienation.  Acting from duty estranges the agent from the concrete value of, say, her child’s well-being.

Reply: Nothing in the competence account forbids the agent to feel love.  It claims only that love is not required for moral worth.  Indeed, in contexts where love conflicts with impartial duties (e.g., favouring one’s child over many strangers in life-boat cases), the de dicto motive prevents wrongful partiality.  Far from alienating, it secures the agent’s allegiance to the morally significant features in their proper proportion.

Objection 2: Coldness.  Praiseworthy action should display warmth; the dutiful agent seems icy.

Reply: Warmth is aesthetically pleasing, but moral worth tracks normative governance, not interpersonal temperature.  We admire the steady, principled judge more than the mercurial empath who sways with feelings.  Moreover, motivational warmth can be reconstructed as evidence of reliable governance in many ordinary cases; it is not constitutive of it.

Objection 3: Motivational weakness.  A mere abstract desire to do right is too etiolated to overcome strong counter-incentives.

Reply: This is an empirical prediction, not a conceptual point.  The historical record (e.g., whistle-blowers who sacrifice careers) shows that principled commitment can exhibit extraordinary motivational strength.  Besides, sentimental motives can also be weak: sympathy evaporates under stress.  Strength depends on how deeply the motive is integrated into the agent’s identity, not on whether it is de re or de dicto.

Objection 4: The Dutiful Robot.  Imagine a perfectly programmed android whose only desire is de dicto rightness and who unfailingly computes it.  Do we praise the robot?  If not, de dicto desire seems insufficient.

Reply: What is missing in the robot is not the de re affect but the capacity for autonomous self-governance under the moral law—i.e., the very exercise of practical rationality that grounds responsibility.  The competence account can therefore say: the android lacks moral worth because it lacks the rational agency conditions that make praise apt, not because its motive is too abstract.

6. Toward a Competence Account of Praiseworthiness  

We can now articulate the positive proposal:

An action has moral worth iff  
(1) the agent is guided by a de dicto practical commitment to comply with moral requirements;  
(2) she exercises sufficient deliberative competence to form a non-accidental, correct judgement about what morality requires in the circumstances; and  
(3) she succeeds in acting on that judgement.

Condition (2) avoids deviant causal chains and lucky guesses; it makes moral worth responsive to the agent’s epistemic situation.  It also answers the “fetishism” concern: because the agent’s judgement must accurately track the right-making reasons, she is not indifferent to them; they figure in her appreciation even if not as separate first-order motives.

Two contrasting cases illustrate.

Case A: Junction John.  Driving in a storm, John sees a stranger’s car skid.  He thinks, “Helping is the morally right thing; therefore I must.”  He pulls over, his deliberation sound.  Though he feels no sympathy (he is emotionally exhausted), he scores high on the three conditions.  We rightly praise him.

Case B: Reactive Ren.  Ren is flooded with empathy for the skidding driver and stops.  Unbeknownst to him, stopping blocks the only path for an ambulance.  Because Ren never weighed competing duties, his act is wrong.  His warm motive does not spare him from blame.

The comparison reveals that moral worth tracks reliable responsiveness to moral reasons, not their affective colouration.

7. Conclusion  

The fetishism charge relies on a too-narrow picture of what motivation must look like to manifest moral concern.  By focusing on first-order sentimental alignment, it overlooks the second-order structure of our normative agency: finite creatures must often act under uncertainty and value conflict.  A de dicto commitment to do whatever morality requires, when coupled with competent deliberation, is the mechanism that allows us to steer through these obstacles.  Far from being a cold, alien abstraction, it is the practical expression of respect for the authority of moral reasons in their entirety.  When that self-governing capacity is exercised, action is fully praiseworthy—even if no single right-making feature supplied the agent with a de re motivational push.  Acting from duty, then, need not be morally second-best; properly understood, it is the paradigm of moral worth.

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can, contrary to a familiar charge of “moral fetishism,” confer full moral worth on an action—provided that the desire is (i) practically integrated with the agent’s capacity to recognize concrete right-making features of situations and (ii) expressive of a stance of respect toward others rather than of self-regarding moral narcissism. On the account I shall defend, what makes such dutiful action praiseworthy is not the presence of some further benevolent, sympathetic, or otherwise “substantive” motive, but the way a de dicto orientation toward “the right” manifests a distinctive value: second-personal respect for persons as such. When an agent reliably does what morality requires because it is required—and does so in a manner that is reasons-responsive and epistemically conscientious—her conduct embodies the very point of the moral enterprise rather than being alienated from it.  

My argument proceeds in six steps. (1) I clarify the target: what it is to act “solely from duty” and why that motive is thought objectionable. (2) I expose a conceptual conflation in the standard critique between the content of a motivating desire and the considerations that justify acting on it. (3) I develop a “respect-first” account on which a de dicto moral motive suffices for moral worth because it realizes the core moral attitude of honoring others’ authority over how one may act toward them. (4) I answer three leading objections: the fetishism objection (Smith), the alienation objection (Stocker, Wolf), and the “wrong-reason” objection (e.g., Arpaly). (5) I illustrate the view with two cases that disentangle duty from sympathy and from self-interest. (6) I conclude with some implications for moral education and moral psychology.

1. Why Duty Looks Suspicious  

Kantians famously claim that only actions done “from duty” possess moral worth, yet a host of critics insist that the duty motive is too abstract to ground praise. The intuitive idea is easy to state. Compare:

Altruistic Nurse: Sophia donates her Saturday to vaccinate children because she cares about their welfare.  
Scrupulous Nurse: Adrian donates the same Saturday solely because he believes doing so is morally required.

Many judge Sophia the more admirable. They worry that Adrian’s attitude is one of moral fetishism (Smith): he attaches intrinsic value to a property—being morally permissible—that is valuable only derivatively; or of alienation (Stocker): he fails to be “for” the very values morality is about (health, flourishing, etc.). The underlying assumption is that moral worth requires motivational continuity with the concrete reasons that make an action right, not with an abstract de dicto desire.

Yet the assumption rests on two questionable premises:

P1. A de dicto desire to do what is right cannot embody concern for the values that make actions right.  
P2. Moral worth consists in being moved directly by those values.

I shall reject P1 and qualify P2.

2. Clearing a Conceptual Tangle  

The debate trades on an ambiguity between the justificatory and the motivational roles of reasons. To be motivated by a consideration C is not the same as recognizing C as the justification for one’s act. The shopkeeper in Kant’s famous example sells at fair prices because it is good for business; he is motivated by self-interest, but he may still believe—and even accurately state—that fairness is what justifies fair pricing. Conversely, one can be motivated by duty—even “solely” by it—while transparently acknowledging that others’ welfare is why duty requires what it does. The de dicto desire functions as a practical directive: “Do whatever morality demands.” To execute that directive, the agent must track the right-making features in situ; otherwise she will not know what morality demands. Hence a competent duty-motive is necessarily world-sensitive.

Critics often depict the duty-bound agent as heedless of the concrete. But that depiction conflates motivational priority with informational input. My desire “to keep promises” directs me to ask which acts count as promise-keeping; answering that question forces attention to promissory practices, the expectations of promisees, and so on. Likewise, a general desire “to do what is right” does not bypass, but rather mobilizes, engagement with the very values that make particular acts right. The upshot is that P1 is false: a de dicto motive can embed a concern for underlying values through its deliberative implementation.

3. A Respect-First Account of Moral Worth  

We can now frame a positive proposal. The duty motive, when properly structured, is valuable because it realizes a distinctive moral attitude: respect. As Stephen Darwall argues, morality is fundamentally second-personal; it is about what persons can reasonably demand of one another. To act from duty is to acknowledge those demands’ authority over one’s will. What earns praise is not mainly that the agent benefits others, but that she acknowledges their standing as equal co-legislators of norms. Call this the Respect Principle:

RP: An action possesses moral worth if and only if it issues from a reliable, reasons-responsive disposition to comply with valid moral requirements out of recognition of their authoritative status, where that recognition expresses respect for the persons whose claims constitute the requirements.

RP renders a de dicto motive sufficient because “recognition of authoritative status” just is the desire-cum-commitment to do what is morally required. Sympathy may deepen the psychological ease of moral action, but it is neither necessary nor sufficient for respect. (One can help from pity that demeans; one can refuse wrongdoing though emotionally indifferent.)

Why, then, prefer RP to the “value-first” view that motives should track concrete goods like welfare? Because welfare, fairness, autonomy, etc. enter moral deliberation under the guise of what persons may rightly expect of one another. Acting “for the sake of those values” without acknowledging their claim on one’s will does not yet relate to others in the normative register morality governs. Respect is thus the constitutive moral attitude.

4. Answering the Objections  

4.1 The Fetishism Objection  

Michael Smith likens the duty motive to a fetish: an abnormal fixation on a property valued only because it predicts deeper goods. Yet respect is not an abnormal fixation; it is the appropriate stance toward beings with authority to address claims to us. To call it “fetishistic” is to treat persons’ normative authority as dispensable. But once we see morality as an interpersonal practice of accountability, the fixation flips from pathological to fitting. The purported fetish is more like fidelity to a promise: attachment to the norm precisely at the point where its content binds us.

4.2 The Alienation Objection  

Stocker worries that a duty-bound agent is alienated from friends, lovers, or patients, because she helps them “for the sake of duty” rather than out of love. But RP does not forbid additional motives; it only requires that, if other motives fade, the agent’s respect-based commitment remains. Imagine a fatigued physician who no longer feels fresh compassion yet continues to treat patients conscientiously because it is her duty to them as persons. Far from alienated, she honors them by refusing to let fluctuating emotion dictate their care. Alienation arises only when the duty motive crowds out all other attachments. That is a psychological hazard, not a conceptual necessity.

4.3 The Wrong-Reason Objection  

Nomy Arpaly and others note that one can do the right thing “from duty” while being epistemically negligent or dogmatic—for example, the over-scrupulous vegetarian who refuses animal products not because she understands animal suffering but because “the moral law demands it,” parroting authorities. Such cases have low moral worth. RP explains why: moral worth requires a reasons-responsive disposition. Dogmatism short-circuits responsiveness; therefore it fails the sufficiency condition. Once reasons-responsiveness is built in, the objection dissolves.

5. Two Cases That Test the View  

Case 1: The Tempted Whistle-blower  

Dana discovers that her employer is dumping toxins. She feels no personal sympathy for the distant villagers affected; indeed exposing the wrongdoing will cost her friends and job security. Nevertheless, she reports the crime because “it is the morally right thing to do.” She conscientiously reviews the evidence to ensure accuracy, anticipates counterarguments, and acts. According to RP her act has full moral worth: Dana defers to the villagers’ claim not to be poisoned, a claim that overrides her convenience. Her de dicto motive does not belittle their welfare; it treats that welfare as normatively authoritative over her.

Case 2: The Warm-hearted Racist  

Ben volunteers at a homeless shelter because he feels strong compassion. Unfortunately, he refuses to serve immigrant families, believing they “take welfare from real citizens.” His sympathy is selective. When challenged, he answers, “I help the truly deserving because I care about them.” Ben’s actions that do help some homeless people are good, but they lack the moral worth of Dana’s whistle-blowing. His benevolence is not guided by a respect-based commitment to equal moral claims; it is contingent on partial feelings. The cases illustrate that duty can ground praise where sympathy cannot, and that concrete motives ungoverned by the moral law can undermine worth.

6. Implications and Conclusion  

If the respect-first account is right, three consequences follow:

a) Moral education should cultivate, alongside empathy, a capacity for principled responsiveness: the habit of asking “What is the morally permissible course?” and acting on the answer even when emotion falters.

b) The traditional Kantian verdict that only dutiful action has moral worth is defensible once “duty” is read as respect for persons, not as focus on an abstract property detached from their claims.

c) The debate about moral fetishism hinges on a mischaracterization. The de dicto duty motive is not a fetish but the structural core of moral agency; it secures allegiance to whatever concrete values are, in fact, morally authoritative.

In sum: Acting solely from the desire to do what is morally right suffices for moral worth whenever that desire is instantiated as a reasons-responsive commitment that expresses respect for persons’ normative authority. Such action is praiseworthy because it epitomizes the moral point: acknowledging others as ends in themselves. Far from betraying a fetishistic or alienated stance, the dutiful agent stands in the very relation of accountability that gives morality its distinctive significance.

1. Setting the Stage  

A century of moral psychology has made one thing vivid: people can do the right thing for very different reasons. I check on my elderly neighbour because I enjoy her company; you do so because you pity her; a third person does so because Kant taught that helping those in need is a perfect duty. The present debate asks whether that last person can earn full moral credit if the only motive in play is a de dicto desire—“to do what is morally right, whatever that is.”  Many philosophers (from Slote to Smith to Arpaly) object that such an agent is a “moral fetishist,” someone whose eyes never leave the austere abstraction “rightness,” and who therefore fails to respond to what morality is really about—people’s concrete needs, suffering, and flourishing.  

My thesis is that acting solely from the motive of duty can indeed suffice for moral worth, provided the motive is understood correctly.  A de dicto moral desire is not a motivational black hole; it is a higher-order practical commitment that (i) is necessarily rooted in responsiveness to the very right-making features that critics fear it neglects, and (ii) manifests a valuable second-order stance toward one’s own agency—namely, a principled readiness to let moral reasons govern.  When those two conditions are met, dutiful action is praiseworthy even if no independent de re concern (e.g. sympathy) is present.  The hostile label “fetishism” gains its bite only from an empirically implausible and conceptually confused picture of what de dicto motivation must be.  

The argument unfolds as follows.  §2 clarifies the distinction between de dicto and de re moral motivation and diagnoses why the fetishism worry seems tempting.  §3 shows that any minimally reflective de dicto desire is unavoidably tethered to an appreciation of right-making considerations, defeating the charge of concrete blindness.  §4 explains why the higher-order structure of duty-motivation adds moral worth by expressing the agent’s practical autonomy and equal respect for all persons.  §5 rebuts three leading objections: the “empathy deficit,” the “cold-hearted benefactor,” and the “accidental rightness” challenges.  §6 closes by articulating a new dispositional criterion that reconciles duty-based moral worth with the intuitive importance of substantive moral emotions.

2. De dicto vs. De re: A Distinction Too Quickly Drawn  

The de dicto/de re distinction comes from philosophy of mind and language.  To want de dicto to do what is right is to desire an act under the description “right,” with no further specification.  To want de re to relieve Ms. Nguyen’s loneliness is to be motivated by that concrete aspect of the situation.  Critics claim that only the latter kind of desire “hooks onto” the true reasons for action.  But two premature conclusions often slide in unnoticed:

A. The Over-Formalization Thesis:  A purely de dicto desire is content-thin; therefore, it cannot discriminate between right-making and wrong-making features.  It is like a heat-seeking missile that locks onto whichever target its guidance system labels “hot,” indifferent to what the heat really is.

B. The Alienation Thesis:  Because the desire is fixed on a moral abstraction, the agent is detached from what morality is about—namely, the well-being of creatures who can suffer.  Her beneficence is thus cold or inauthentic.

Both theses assume that a de dicto motive operates in isolation from any grasp of the moral landscape.  Yet this is psychologically unlikely and, more important, conceptually unnecessary.  Nothing about the formal description “doing what is right” rules out knowing what makes things right; indeed, as we shall see, some such knowledge is required to form an all-things-considered judgment that an act is right.  The critic therefore owes us an argument for why de dicto motivation must be blind or alienating rather than seamlessly integrated with a grasp of concrete moral grounds.

3. Why De dicto Duty Necessarily Tracks Concrete Moral Reasons  

Consider how practical deliberation actually proceeds in the head of a conscientious agent:

Step 1: She surveys the non-moral facts—Ms. Nguyen is isolated, visits alleviate loneliness, doing so costs little.  
Step 2: She consults her moral standards (principles, intuitions, role-conceptions) and arrives at a verdict: visiting is morally required.  
Step 3: The higher-order desire “to do the right thing” couples with that verdict to produce action.

Notice two features.  First, the verdict in Step 2 depends on weighing exactly the concrete facts the critic says are ignored.  Having the de dicto desire is useless until one figures out what is right, and figuring that out requires sensitivity to others’ welfare, autonomy, desert, and so on.  The motivational structure therefore guarantees—not incidentally but constitutively—that the right-making considerations are cognitively consulted.  

Second, the agent’s motivational affection can run entirely through the de dicto desire without erasing this cognitive sensitivity.  She need not also feel warmth or empathy toward Ms. Nguyen; what moves her bodily to walk next door is the thought “this is morally required.”  Still, had the welfare facts been different—say the visit would exacerbate Ms. Nguyen’s trauma—her moral verdict would switch, and so would her action.  The “guidance system” therefore locks onto welfare differences in the way that matters: it performs the right-making tracking function.

The fetishism charge confuses direct motivational content with evidential uptake.  An epistemically conscientious scientist values truth de dicto—she wants true beliefs, whatever they are—but that desire forces her to attend to concrete evidence, not ignore it.  Analogously, the conscientious moral agent’s de dicto desire forces her to attend to concrete moral evidence.  Moral fetishism, if it exists, would require someone who both (i) desires to do what’s right and (ii) refuses to look at what makes things right; but (i) and (ii) are in tension.  Once we see this, the over-formalization thesis collapses.

4. The Higher-Order Value of Dutiful Agency  

If a de dicto motive already involves due sensitivity to concrete moral reasons, what extra contribution could it make to moral worth?  My answer: it confers a distinctive kind of practical self-governance.  Two ideas are crucial.

4.1  Moral Obedience as Second-Order Endorsement  
The de dicto desire is best understood as a second-order commitment: “I will allow whatever turns out to be morally required to override other projects.”  This stance expresses recognition of morality’s authority over the self, a form of respect sometimes called “acknowledgement respect.”  Acting from duty therefore showcases a valuable meta-attitude: a willingness to treat all persons (oneself included) as objects of impartial moral consideration.  That willingness is praiseworthy because it constitutes the agent as a moral equal among equals, rather than as someone who helps only when it pleases her sympathies or aligns with her projects.

4.2  Reliability Across Variation  
Because the de dicto motive plugs directly into moral verdicts, it promises a robustness ordinary sympathy lacks.  The beneficent sentimentalist may help Ms. Nguyen but not Mr. Ogun in the next apartment if she dislikes his gruff demeanor.  The dutiful agent helps both, provided the moral reasons are identical.  This counterfactual reliability is what Kant had in mind when he spoke of actions “from duty” having a special moral worth.

A quick illustration:  A climate-controlled space station loses power.  The sentimentalist happily helps ventilate the habitat where her friends live but not the one where strangers live; her empathy is weaker there.  The dutiful agent, hearing that all habitats face lethal temperatures, methodically apportions aid according to need.  The de dicto motive’s impartial structure is what underwrites that even-handed response.

5. Objections and Replies  

5.1  The Empathy Deficit Objection  
“Surely,” says the critic, “an agent who saves a child without feeling any concern for her suffering is less praiseworthy than one moved by compassion.”  I grant the comparative claim but deny the sufficiency inference.  Moral worth is not a zero-sum race for first prize; multiple motivational structures can each reach the threshold of praiseworthiness.  Compassion may add an extra layer of value—call it the expressive virtue of fellow feeling—but the absence of that layer does not evaporate the worth already secured by dutiful self-governance.

Analogy: a mathematician who proves a theorem for its own sake is admirable.  One who also feels aesthetic rapture at the proof is even more so.  Yet the first mathematician’s achievement remains praiseworthy.

5.2  The Cold-Hearted Benefactor Objection  
Suppose an agent helps others only reluctantly, complaining “I wish morality demanded less of me.”  Is that action truly worthy?  Here we must distinguish motivational source from accompanying attitude.  The presence of grouchiness may reduce moral worth because it signals grudging compliance, but not because the underlying motive is de dicto.  A grouchy empath is also less admirable than a joyful empath.  The right conclusion is that ancillary attitudes modulate moral worth; they do not make duty-motive per se defective.

5.3  The Accidental Rightness Objection  
“Couldn’t an agent fetishising ‘rightness’ latch onto a mistaken moral belief and do terrible things, all the while acting from duty?”  Two points.  First, moral worth tracks the reasons the agent actually possesses, not the objective facts she fails to know.  A carefully deliberating but misinformed agent may still be praiseworthy if her error is excusable.  Second, the same problem arises for de re sympathy: one might help someone in ways that are secretly harmful.  Fallibility is a universal human condition, not a special flaw of duty-motivation.

6. A New Dispositional Criterion: Principled Sensitivity  

The above defenses may still leave a residual unease: empathy seems to manifest direct concern for people, whereas de dicto duty feels mediated, almost bureaucratic.  To capture what is right in that intuition without abandoning the sufficiency of duty, I propose a dispositional criterion for praiseworthy duty:  

Principled Sensitivity:  A de dicto-motivated agent is morally worthy only if she is disposed to (i) seek out the right-making facts, (ii) revise her moral verdicts in light of new evidence, and (iii) cultivate cognitive and affective capacities that improve such responsiveness.  

This criterion does two things.  First, it rules out the caricatured fetishist who worships “rightness” while studiously avoiding contact with human need.  Such an agent fails condition (i).  Second, it explains why many de dicto agents naturally develop a repertoire of emotions—sympathy, guilt, indignation—not as competing motives but as epistemic tools that help satisfy (i)-(iii).  On this view, empathy’s value is partially instrumental: it sharpens our perception of others’ welfare.  A duty-bound agent lacking all affect may be praiseworthy in principle, but in our actual cognitive ecology she will rarely meet the sensitivity requirement.

Compare morality with chess.  To value “making the right move” de dicto is compatible with (indeed, conducive to) studying openings, memorizing endgames, and cultivating an aesthetic sense for elegant combinations.  Similarly, valuing right action motivates a wise agent to enrich her motivational palette, not impoverish it.  The fetishist worry arises only if we imagine an agent who paradoxically refuses the very tools that would help her track moral reasons.

7. Reconciling Anti-Alienation Intuitions  

Finally, does dutiful action alienate us from what morality is “really about”?  Here is a conciliatory diagnosis.  What anti-fetishists rightly sense is that morality has a point: promoting the flourishing of sentient beings.  They fear that the abstraction “rightness” can float free of that point, becoming an idol.  My dispositional account shows why the idol image is misleading: a genuine commitment to rightness cannot float free because its deliberative content is anchored in flourishing; to judge that something is right is already to see it as serving persons’ autonomy, welfare, or dignity.  The agent who seeks rightness therefore reaffirms, rather than obscures, morality’s point.  

If you worry that the language of “duty” sounds cold, imagine resituating it in second-person discourse: “I owe you this.”  To act from duty is precisely to let that normative fact, owed to another, govern one’s will.  Far from alienating, it is the form of agency that takes the other’s claim most seriously.

8. Conclusion  

Acting solely from the motive of duty can suffice for moral worth because:

1. Cognitive tracking: One cannot act from a de dicto desire without engaging the right-making features.  The alleged blindness is a mirage.  
2. Higher-order respect: The motive expresses a second-order readiness to let moral reasons rule, displaying impartial self-governance.  
3. Reliability: It delivers counterfactual consistency across cases where sentiment may flag.  
4. Dispositional enrichment: Properly understood, duty-motivation carries a built-in disposition to cultivate those very sensibilities—sympathy, imagination, humility—that critics prize.

What makes such action praiseworthy is not an ascetic focus on an empty abstraction but the union of principled governance and concrete responsiveness—a union captured in the Kantian image of a good will.  Those who worry about “moral fetishism” are right to prize engagement with others’ welfare, but wrong to think that dutiful agency cannot deliver it.  The fetishist spectre evaporates once we see that the desire to do what is right, if sincere and reflective, is already the desire to let the concrete moral facts speak with full authority in one’s practical life.

1. Setting the Stage  

Suppose a nurse named Jordan dislikes her patient—a verbally abusive man who reminds her of a childhood bully. When the man presses the call button, Jordan’s spontaneous feelings incline her to delay. Instead she tells herself, “He has a right to adequate care; that makes it morally required,” and she administers the pain medication at once. Nothing else figures in her conscious motivation—no surge of sympathy, no warm concern for the patient’s welfare. Was Jordan’s act morally worthy, or merely correct?  

Critics of “moral fetishism” say Jordan’s motivation is defective. She cares, they say, about the property of being-right rather than about the concrete value that makes relieving pain worth doing. On this view moral worth requires the agent to be moved by those very considerations—here, the patient’s suffering—not by an abstract concern for morality.  

I will argue that the critics are mistaken. Acting solely from a de dicto desire to do what is morally right can, under the right internal architecture, suffice for full moral worth. What makes such action praiseworthy is that the de dicto desire manifests the agent’s practical identity as a self-legislating moral subject: it is a second-order commitment that reliably regulates first-order conduct by responding to the balance of moral reasons, while remaining poised to incorporate those reasons more concretely when circumstances permit. The objection of fetishism stems from conflating (a) what the agent explicitly attends to during deliberation with (b) what her governing commitment represents and tracks. Once we keep these apart, the worry dissolves.  

The argument proceeds as follows. Section 2 clarifies the distinction between de dicto and de re moral motivation and situates the debate. Section 3 outlines three reasons to regard pure dutiful motivation as sufficient for moral worth: reliability, reflexive self-governance, and developmental plasticity. Section 4 answers four leading objections—fetishism, alienation, motivational fragility, and moral misunderstanding. Section 5 states a set of conditions under which duty-only action is praiseworthy, illustrated by new examples. Section 6 briefly situates the view within Kantian and contemporary virtue-ethical landscapes and concludes.

2. De dicto versus De re Moral Motivation  

A de re desire for φ is aimed at φ under a particular description expressive of the value that makes φ worth pursuing: “relieve this person’s suffering.” A de dicto desire to do what is right is aimed at whatever action falls under the description “morally required,” whatever its specific content. When this de dicto attitude is the agent’s sole occurrent motive, we have the hard case: she acts because it is right, all things considered, while remaining motivationally silent about the first-order values that ground the rightness.  

Sidgwick, Kant, and Ross each give the duty motive a central place, but recent philosophers—Stocker, Railton, Wolf, Smith—suggest it is, at best, an emergency back-up. The nurse who saves you “because it is required” rather than “because you are in pain” seems chilly, perhaps even disrespectful. The intuitive tug of that reaction fuels the fetishism charge. Yet intuitiveness is not argument; we need to test the reaction against a more precise account of moral worth.

3. Three Grounds for Praiseworthiness  

3.1 Reliability under Moral Uncertainty  

First, a purely dutiful motive is often the most reliable regulator of action across fluctuating motivational environments. Empathic concern is sensitive to vividness, proximity, and personal affinities; a de dicto commitment to do what morality requires abstracts from those morally irrelevant variables. That is why we build duties into professional oaths—doctors pledge to treat all patients, not only those they find likable. Reliability is not everything, but it is a core dimension of moral worth: a disposition to act rightly because it is right respects the universality of persons’ claims.  

3.2 Reflexive Self-Governance  

Second, duty-only motivation exemplifies a distinctive form of rational self-governance. The agent takes up a second-order stance toward her first-order proclivities, endorsing or vetoing them on grounds of rightness. This is not mere heteronomous rule-following; it expresses a practical identity as a law-giver to oneself. When Jordan overrides her irritation and acts from duty, she enacts the same capacity that makes praise, blame, and moral dialogue intelligible. Such reflexivity is itself a value—call it “respect for the authority of reason”—and actions manifesting it possess moral worth even if companion emotions are absent.  

3.3 Developmental Plasticity: The “Training-Wheels” Model  

Third, a de dicto motive is cognitively portable: it can guide action in unfamiliar circumstances before the agent has acquired the nuanced emotional repertoire that virtue theories prize. Children, moral novices, and even sophisticated adults confronting novel moral terrain can rely on the maxim “Do what is right” as a heuristic that triggers inquiry into what rightness requires here. Seen this way, duty is like training wheels: initially load-bearing, gradually internalized, and never entirely discarded because it continues to steady us when other motives wobble. The capacity to act rightly while purely duty-driven is therefore an important developmental achievement rather than a moral deficiency.

4. Answering Four Objections  

4.1 The Fetishism Charge  

Railton’s original formulation: to care about an action “because it is right” is to fetishize a “mysterious moral property” detached from the worldly facts that make rightness right. This misunderstands the representational content of the de dicto attitude. “Because it is right” is a placeholder for the best available justification. The agent may not rehearse the concrete grounds in consciousness, but her motivational state is still counterfactually dependent on them: if she learned that administering the medication was not, after all, required (say the dosage is contraindicated), her duty motive would cancel. That dependency shows that the so-called fetish tracks precisely the concrete reasons the critic wants highlighted. A fetish that dissolves once the value conferring property disappears is not a fetish.  

Analogy: A scientist who seeks “the truth” may not recite every evidential reason at each step, yet her de dicto love of truth is not epistemic fetishism. It is a higher-order regulative ideal that contains an implicit commitment to the concrete considerations constituting truth in each domain.  

4.2 Alienation from Value  

Susan Wolf worries that the dutiful agent is alienated from the goods that give life meaning; she values them “at a distance.” Here the distinction between occurrent focus and dispositional endorsement again matters. The nurse’s attention is on obligation because she needs to override contrary affect. But nothing prevents her from appreciating, during reflective moments, the patient’s intrinsic worth or the value of alleviating pain. Occurrent motivational silence does not imply dispositional indifference. Indeed, agents often compartmentalize focus for functional reasons. A surgeon concentrates on procedural checklists rather than the concrete value of saving life so as to minimize error; she is not thereby alienated from the value of life.  

4.3 Motivational Fragility  

Critics worry that purely dutiful agents will falter once the concept of duty loses salience. Empirical work on “moral abstraction fatigue” shows some support. Yet a second-order commitment can be motivationally resilient when routinized. Professional norms, military codes, and religious vows exhibit such durability. Moreover, the alternative—relying on shifting sympathetic affects—has its own fragilities. The better response is pluralistic: cultivate both direct concern and duty, letting each shore up the other. The present claim is only that duty alone can suffice, not that it is always preferable.

4.4 Moral Misunderstanding  

A final objection: if rightness is misapprehended, de dicto motivation could lead to wrongdoing excused by ignorance but not praiseworthy action. True, but the same is so for de re sympathy: acting from misplaced compassion (e.g., giving heroin to an addict) is not praiseworthy. The relevant comparison, then, is action that is in fact right and believed right under conditions of normal epistemic responsibility; within that set, dutiful action can possess full worth.

5. Conditions for Dutiful Praiseworthiness  

We can now articulate more precisely what must obtain for a duty-only action to be morally worthy:

C1. Rightness Awareness: The agent accurately judges that the action is morally required (or permissible and most supported).  

C2. De dicto Motivation: The primary occurrent motive is the desire to do what is right, not fear of sanctions or self-interest.  

C3. Counterfactual Sensitivity: Had the balance of right-making reasons shifted, the agent’s motivation would have changed accordingly.  

C4. Reflective Integration: The duty motive is anchored in the agent’s endorsed practical identity; she sees herself as accountable to moral reasons and would, under reflective equilibrium, affirm the substantive values those reasons embody.  

C5. Competent Execution: The action is performed competently and without negligence; the motive successfully guides implementation.  

When these conditions hold, duty-only action deserves the same praise we accord action grounded in direct concern.  

Illustration 1: Impartial Juror. A juror votes to acquit because he believes the prosecution has not met the burden of proof. He feels no particular warmth toward the defendant. His de dicto desire “to do what justice requires” suffices for worth because it manifests respect for the rule of law (C4) and is counterfactually sensitive to the evidence (C3).  

Illustration 2: Triage Physician. Exhausted and emotionally numb, a physician places patients on ventilators according to a utilitarian triage protocol because “it is the fairest system.” Her numbed state precludes vivid compassion, but her duty motive reliably coordinates scarce resources. Meeting C1–C5, her action is clearly laudable.  

Illustration 3: Early-Career Environmental Inspector. Unsure why a small wetland matters ecologically, an inspector nevertheless fines a developer because regulations require protection of such areas. The de dicto motive buys time until she learns the ecosystem science; meanwhile, the wetland survives. The moral worth of the fine rests not on ecological comprehension but on responsible deference to moral authority under uncertainty.

6. Duty and Virtue: Convergence, Not Rivalry  

Virtue ethicists emphasize acting “for the right reasons in the right way.” Are we, then, conceding that duty-only agents lack full virtue? Not necessarily. The loyalty-of-duty is itself a virtue—call it moral conscientiousness. Aristotle acknowledged that a just person can be motivated by the noble (to kalon) without explicit affective sympathy; what matters is the agent’s stable orientation to the good. Kantian respect and Aristotelian nobility may differ in flavor, but both describe a posture of will directed at the moral point of view. Accordingly, duty-only action may fall short of the richest kind of virtue that harmonizes emotion and reason, yet it need not fall below the threshold of moral worth.  

Indeed, a mature moral psychology typically layers motives: sympathy, solidarity, respect, aesthetic appreciation of the good, and the regulative idea of rightness co-function. The virtue theorist should cheer the presence of conscientious duty because it supports virtuous reliability; the Kantian should welcome sympathetic concern because it eases compliance and enriches human life. The present thesis therefore reconciles, rather than opposes, de dicto duty with concrete value-oriented motivation.

7. Conclusion  

Acting solely from a desire to do what is morally right can suffice—sometimes magnificently—for moral worth. The key is to understand the de dicto duty motive not as a fetishistic fixation on an abstract property but as a higher-order commitment that tracks and defers to the very considerations critics champion. When that commitment is epistemically responsible, reflectively integrated, counterfactually sensitive, and effectively executed, the resulting action merits full moral praise.  

Jordan the nurse, then, is no moral minimalist. In overriding resentment to honor her patient’s right, she manifests respect for persons, steadiness in the face of partiality, and allegiance to the moral point of view. If later she also cultivates warm concern, so much the better. But she need not wait for such feelings to emerge before her conduct counts as morally worthy. Moral life would be perilous indeed if worth depended on affective states that suffering, fatigue, or mere temperament can withhold. Conscience, in its abstract simplicity, remains enough.

1. Introduction and Thesis

A long tradition, from Aristotle through contemporary sentimentalists, holds that morally worthy action must be animated by “the right sorts” of concrete concerns—love of friends, fellow‐feeling, sympathy for the suffering.
