For two decades a prominent account has held that this achievement is rooted in “motor resonance”: when I watch you grasp a cup, neurons in my premotor cortex that would fire were I myself grasping a cup become active; by internally re-enacting your movement, the story goes, I come to understand what you are up to. Many mirror-system theorists press the claim further: without such resonance, goal-directedness could not be perceived at all. In what follows I argue that this necessity claim is false. Motor resonance provides one powerful—perhaps evolutionarily ancient—route to action understanding, but it is neither conceptually nor empirically required. A richer picture emerges when we recognize two partially independent systems: (1) an Embodied Resonance System (ERS) specialized for actions within one’s own morpho-motor repertoire, and (2) a Structural–Teleological System (STS) that extracts goals from the observable geometry and temporality of movement irrespective of bodily match. The former speeds and refines interpretation when feasible; the latter guarantees that goal perception is available even when resonance is impossible. I defend this dual-route model against leading objections and close by sketching predictions that can distinguish it from stronger simulationist views.

1. Clarifying the Target Claim

“Necessity” is ambiguous. Do resonance mechanisms stand in a causal-enabling relation (you cannot in fact perceive goals unless the mirror circuit was part of your developmental trajectory) or a constitutive relation (online resonant activation is part of what it is to perceive an action as goal-directed)? The proponents cited—Gallese, Rizzolatti, Iacoboni—typically intend the stronger, constitutive version. I accordingly formulate the thesis under dispute:

Mirror-style motor resonance is a necessary online condition for perceptual attribution of goal-directedness.

Refuting necessity, then, requires more than showing that other processes contribute; it requires cases in which we do perceive a goal while resonance is absent, impossible, or actively disrupted.

2. The Simulationist Argument for Necessity

A minimal reconstruction:

P1. To perceive an event as goal-directed is to map it onto a motor schema that represents it as directed toward an effect.

P2. Mirror mechanisms are the neural implementation of such schema mapping.

C. Therefore mirror mechanisms are necessary for goal perception.

The first premise does the heavy lifting. The idea is that there is no way to represent goals except through the embodied motor formats deployed in first-person action control; hence any appearance of goal perception in their absence is illusory or mediated by “cold” inference rather than genuine perception.

3. Conceptual Problems: The Map Is Not the Territory

Even before turning to data, we should note two conceptual difficulties.

a. Format Pluralism. Goal representations need not be motoric. Practical reasoning, planning, language understanding, and folk psychology routinely deploy propositional and visual formats. Unless one stipulates in advance that perception draws exclusively on motor formats—a stipulation the argument itself is meant to justify—there is no reason to think goal-ascription must inherit the format of action execution.

b. Conflation of Availability and Necessity. From the fact that ERS is available and often recruited it does not follow that it is obligatory. Cognition is replete with optional shortcuts (e.g., phonological recoding during silent reading) that can fall away without destroying the capacity they support.

4. Four Empirical Challenges

4.1 Cross-Morphology Goal Perception

We effortlessly see goal-directedness in acts we could never perform: an osprey stooping for a fish, a dog rotating mid-air to catch a Frisbee, a ballet dancer executing a grand jeté beyond our abilities. fMRI demonstrates that canonical mirror areas respond weakly or not at all when the observed effector lies outside the observer’s repertoire. Yet phenomenologically, goal perception is vivid. Either resonance is unnecessary or it extends implausibly far beyond homology—down to tail feathers and canine spines—contradicting single-cell evidence that mirror neurons are effector-specific.

4.2 Heider–Simmel-Type Displays

In classic studies, subjects spontaneously narrate simple geometric shapes as “chasing,” “tempting,” or “coaxing” one another, despite the total absence of bodily kinematics. Developmentally, 12-month-olds differentiate a triangle that detours around an obstacle from one that takes an inefficient path, expecting agents to act efficiently toward goals. Since no motor match is available—the movement parameters do not map onto any limb trajectory—the mirror circuit should be silent. Indeed, MEG and TMS work confirms minimal motor-area involvement in such displays.

4.3 Infants Before Action Expertise

Newborns imitate tongue protrusion, but complex manual control appears months later. Yet by three months infants parse grasping events as goal-directed: they look longer when a hand repeatedly reaching for Object A switches to Object B after the objects are repositioned. Crucially, three-month-olds cannot yet organize reaching actions of their own. ERP studies show limited premotor activation; nonetheless the infants discriminate goals. Developmentally, visual–teleological parsing precedes the maturation of the motor system, reversing the dependence relation posited by simulationism.

4.4 Action Understanding in Congenitally Limb-Deficient Individuals

Adults born without arms track and predict others’ hand actions with normal accuracy. Intriguingly, fMRI shows that their premotor “hand” area is repurposed for shoulder or foot representations, yet they still recognize manual goals. If resonance in a hand-specific circuit were necessary, these individuals should be impaired; they are not. The natural inference is that STS suffices, with ERS unnecessary—or at least the relevant resonance can be realized in abstract visual formats not isomorphic to the missing limb.

5. An Alternative: The Structural–Teleological System

What enables goal perception when resonance is unavailable? A growing literature points to a visual analytic route that treats agents as constrained optimizers. It encodes:

• Path efficiency: When an object takes the shortest available trajectory toward a target, or detours rationally around an obstacle, it is categorized as goal-directed.

• Speed–curvature coupling: Biological motions exhibit characteristic velocity profiles (two-thirds power law). Deviations signal mechanical rather than intentional causation.

• Boundary conditions of casual interaction: Agents maintain consistent inter-object relations (grasp-to-object distance, predator–prey pursuit curves).

Computational models show how a Bayesian observer can infer a hidden goal state variable that generates these patterns. This inference operates over abstract kinematic primitives; no bodily mapping is required. EEG signatures of such inference arise in occipito-temporal areas (STS proper, MT+) distinct from premotor cortex.

6. Toward a Dual-Route Model

I propose that evolution has supplied two partially redundant paths:

ERS: A fast, effector-specific, body-simulation route optimal for conspecific bodily actions. It relies on morpho-motor matching; when available it yields rich, fine-grained predictions (force profiles, grip apertures) useful for online interaction.

STS: A slower but more general inferential route sensitive to structural rationality cues. It works for non-conspecific bodies, abstract shapes, and mechanical devices designed with apparent ends.

These systems interact hierarchically within a predictive-processing architecture. Higher-level goal hypotheses feed back to sensory cortices; whichever route generates the more precise prediction under current task demands wins the competition for neural bandwidth. Resonance is thus optional but often favored for intraspecies social events.

7. Objections and Replies

Objection 1: TMS to premotor cortex (PMC) disrupts goal perception.

Rebuttal: Here we must distinguish local impairment from complete necessity. In Michael et al. 2014, disruptive TMS to PMC increased reaction times and error rates in predicting occluded grasp targets, but performance remained above chance. Likewise, patients with PMC lesions retain coarse goal recognition. These findings support the modulatory thesis: ERS enriches performance without being all-or-nothing indispensable.

Objection 2: Motor expertise enhances sensitivity to kinematic subtleties (e.g., dancers recognize dance moves better than non-experts). Doesn’t this show resonance is crucial?

Rebuttal: Expertise effects demonstrate that resonance can improve discrimination within the bodily match space. They do not entail that non-experts fail to perceive the same actions as goal-directed. A violinist detects whether a bow stroke targets staccato or legato; I merely notice she is “playing the violin.” Precision differs, but basic goal perception survives.

Objection 3: fMRI studies often find mirror-area activation whenever participants attribute intentions, even to cartoons.

Rebuttal: Reverse inference is perilous: activation does not imply necessity. The dual-route model predicts spillover: top-down goal hypotheses can reactivate premotor schemas even when no match is required. The question is whether such activation is causally basic. Lesion and developmental evidence suggest not.

8. A Novel Distinction: Morphological versus Functional Resonance

Much argument turns on whether “resonance” requires effector homology. I propose disambiguating:

Morphological resonance: mapping observed limb trajectories onto matching motor circuits; present only when morphologies align.

Functional resonance: mapping outcome structure (e.g., containment, support) onto higher-order motor plans, independent of limb specifics.

Simulationists conflate the two. The empirical cases above (limb-deficient individuals, cross-species perception) show functional but not morphological resonance. Admitting this distinction dissolves the necessity claim: what is required is a representational format capable of encoding the causal structure of intentional action, and that can be realized visually or motorically.

9. Predictive Payoff: Experimental Consequences

The dual-route model yields testable predictions:

1. Under time pressure and visual degradation, bodily goal detection should degrade more for actions outside the observer’s repertoire (where ERS is absent) than for those inside.

2. Pharmacologically dampening cerebellar–premotor coupling should impair fine-grained kinematic prediction but leave coarse goal attribution to STS intact.

3. Training observers on abstract, non-bodily goal inference (e.g., complex Heider-style pursuit patterns) should improve action recognition even for novel bodily actions, via strengthened STS priors without altering ERS.

4. Populations with autism spectrum traits, often showing atypical mirror activity, may compensate via enhanced STS; correlational studies should reveal inverse relationships between ERS strength and STS recruitment.

10. Philosophical Up-shot: Teleology Without Simulation

At stake is not merely a neuroscientific dispute but a philosophical one about how minds attribute normativity. If ERS were necessary, the space of possible social cognition across species would be parochially bounded by each morphology. The dual-route model restores a more ecumenical vision: creatures can perceive purposiveness in others so long as they can detect efficiency-signatures in movement. The perceptual given is already structured teleologically; motor resonance enriches but does not create this structure.

This vision harmonizes with Gibsonian theories of direct perception: affordances can be visually specified. It also aligns with Dennett’s intentional stance: what matters is recognizing a pattern of rationality, not sharing a body. Embodied simulation remains a powerful heuristic, yet the faculty of seeing reasons at work in the world transcends our corporeal shell.

Conclusion

Motor resonance is a versatile but optional tool in the cognitive toolbox for understanding others’ actions. Evidence from cross-morphology perception, infant cognition, abstract animations, and limb-deficient individuals demonstrates that goal-directedness can be perceived when resonance is weak or impossible. A dual-route architecture—combining an embodied resonance system with a structural–teleological system—accommodates these findings and yields novel empirical predictions. Far from making action understanding parochial, this framework explains how minds perceive purposes in ospreys’ dives, in geometric chases, and even in alien artefacts yet to be imagined. Mirror neurons illuminate one strand of this tapestry; they do not weave the whole cloth.

1. Orientation and Thesis

When I watch a right-handed violinist perform a Paganini caprice, I have no practical ability to reproduce her bowing or fingering. Yet I perceive her movements as elegantly ordered toward producing a particular melody; I perceive them as goal-directed. More strikingly, five-month-old infants register (by looking-time measures) the difference between an actor who reaches efficiently for a toy and one who takes an unnecessarily circuitous route—even though infants are not yet capable of that kind of reaching themselves. These plain facts already suggest that the perception of goal-directedness outruns one’s motor capacities.

My thesis is therefore negative but constructive: motor resonance is not a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions. Basic perceptual access to the teleology of another’s behavior can be achieved through higher-level predictive and inferential mechanisms that operate over visual, kinematic, and contextual information independently of any on-line mapping onto one’s own motor repertoire. Motor resonance remains important—it can speed recognition, enrich phenomenology, and ground skillful joint action—but it is a contingent facilitator rather than a prerequisite for goal perception.

I defend this thesis in four stages. Section 2 clarifies the relevant notions: what “motor resonance” amounts to, what it would mean for it to be “necessary,” and how to individuate the target phenomenon of perceiving goal-directed action. Section 3 reconstructs the best case for the necessity claim, drawing on both conceptual arguments from simulation theory and empirical work on mirror neurons. Sections 4 and 5 present, respectively, empirical and conceptual counter-arguments that undermine the necessity claim. Section 6 synthesizes these considerations into a layered, pluralistic picture on which goal perception is multiply realizable, with motor resonance occupying only one stratum. I close in Section 7 with two fresh predictions that follow from this account.

2. Clarifying the Terrain

2.1 Motor resonance. I take “motor resonance” to denote the on-line activation of the observer’s motor system in a manner that mirrors or simulates the observed action. Empirically, this is operationalized via premotor cortex and inferior parietal activations (human putative mirror neuron system), transcranial magnetic stimulation-induced motor evoked potentials specific to the effector observed, and mu-rhythm suppression in EEG. Crucially, resonance is effector-specific: observing a right-handed grasp preferentially excites neural populations associated with right-handed grasping in the observer.

2.2 Perceiving goal-directed action. A minimal but non-behaviorist characterization suffices: one perceives an action as goal-directed when one represents it under a purposive description—e.g., “reaching to grasp the cup,” “bowing to produce a melody,” “chasing to catch the gazelle.” The representation need not be verbal or reflective; it can be implicit in attention patterns, expectation of motion trajectories, or anticipatory gaze.

2.3 Necessity. Saying that motor resonance is necessary for goal perception means that without resonant activation, the observer could not, even in principle, have the perceptual experience or implicit representation of another’s behavior as purposive. The claim is strong: it holds across contexts, observer types, effector systems, and developmental stages.

With the target clearly in view, we can examine the case for necessity.

3. The Best Case for Necessity

3.1 The Simulation Argument. According to the simulation theory of social cognition, we understand others by putting ourselves in their shoes—running a covert, truncated version of the motor program that would generate the observed movement. Because goals are encoded in one’s own motor schemas, recreating those schemas is what gives one access to the goal represented.

3.2 Mirror-Neuron Data. The empirical centerpiece comes from Rizzolatti and colleagues: neurons in macaque area F5 fire both when the monkey grasps an object and when it observes an experimenter performing the same grasp. Analogous activations in humans track the goal rather than the exact kinematics: the same population fires whether a grasp is performed with the hand or with pliers, provided the goal (object acquisition) is preserved. Mu-rhythm suppression scales with how predictable an action’s goal is, and temporally precedes conscious goal attribution. Interference studies—inducing motor fatigue or applying virtual lesions via TMS—impair recognition of actions that share effectors with the fatigued/lesioned area, suggesting causality.

3.3 Developmental Evidence. Some researchers report that mu suppression in infants correlates with their ability to interpret reaching as goal-directed, hinting that the mirror system scaffolds emerging social cognition.

Taken together, these findings carve a seemingly tight link between resonant activations and goal perception. But “correlates of necessity” are easy to misread; the following two sections disentangle correlation from necessity.

4. Empirical Counter-Evidence

4.1 Cross-Species Perception. Humans effortlessly perceive the goal of a raptor stooping to catch prey or of a dog shaking water off its coat, although we lack motor programs for wing folding or full-body fur shaking. fMRI shows limited or absent effector-specific resonance in such cases, yet the goal is perceived.

4.2 Congenital Limb Difference. Individuals born without upper limbs (amelics) accurately identify and predict the goals of manual actions, even displaying typical anticipatory eye movements. Strikingly, when they watch hand actions, TMS reveals no muscle-specific motor-evoked potentials—because they have no such muscles. Their accuracy contradicts necessity.

4.3 Novel Effectors and Tools. Viewers newly exposed to novel tool use (e.g., a blacksmith’s power hammer) can still rapidly detect whether a blow is aimed accurately, well before they could develop a motor program for wielding the tool. The time-course argues against slow, resonance-mediated learning.

4.4 Heider-Simmel Displays. Animated geometric shapes engage in simple approach-avoid patterns; naive subjects attribute chasing, coaxing, and teasing almost irresistibly. No plausible motor schema for triangles sliding across a screen exists in the observer; nevertheless, purposiveness pops out perceptually.

4.5 Neurological Dissociations. Patients with corticobasal degeneration can show severely impaired imitation (indicating disrupted resonance) yet retain intact attribution of action goals. Conversely, some autism-spectrum individuals show diminished mirror-system activation but normal or even hyperacute goal perception.

Methodologically, each of these cases should be lethal to the necessity claim: they provide genuine instances of goal perception in the empirically verified absence of resonance.

5. Conceptual Counter-Arguments

5.1 Levels of Description. A piston’s goal of compressing fuel can be predicted without simulating its micro-motion; what matters is functional role in a causal network. Likewise, an action’s goal is specified at a higher grain than muscle synergies. If the representation is at the “intentional stance” level, motor mirroring is neither sufficient nor necessary.

5.2 Efficiency Principles. A powerful cue for goal attribution is the principle of rational efficiency: agents tend to take the shortest energy-feasible path to their goals. This is a purely geometric-ecological heuristic; it requires no effector mapping. Gergely and Csibra’s infant experiments confirm that violation of efficiency, rather than unfamiliar kinematics, drives surprise responses.

5.3 Predictive Coding Architecture. Contemporary neuroscience treats perception as hierarchical Bayesian inference. Low-level sensory prediction errors are minimized against models at multiple temporal-spatial scales. Under that view, motor resonance is merely one route for conveying top-down predictions; vision-action couplings are optional shortcuts, not sine qua non. The generative model could encode goals in amodal variables (e.g., “object acquired”), with or without an embedded motor emulator. Treating resonance as obligatory misreads the principle of computational degeneracy: multiple realizations can yield the same functional output.

5.4 Simulation without Mirroring. Even if some sort of simulation is necessary, it need not be motoric. One could mentally rehearse the target’s trajectory in visual-spatial working memory or engage domain-general predictive modeling. Therefore “simulation” does not imply “motor resonance.”

5.5 Phenomenology versus Mechanism. Proponents occasionally conflate introspective immediacy (“I just see what she is up to”) with motor mediation. But transparent phenomenology does not legislate neural necessity; blindsight patients experience no vision yet process visual information. By parity, the ‘motor familiarity’ we sometimes feel may be epiphenomenal garnish.

6. A Layered Pluralist Model

Synthesizing the evidence, we can outline a multi-route framework:

Layer 1: Kinematic-Contextual Heuristics. Rapid, effector-independent cues such as object affordances, typical motion trajectories, and environmental constraints provide an initial probabilistic guess about goals. These operate even in non-social domains (e.g., predicting the bounce of a billiard ball) and suffice for basic attribution.

Layer 2: Teleological Reasoning. Principles of efficiency, obstacle avoidance, and energy minimization refine the guess. Infants and nonhuman animals utilize these rules before having extensive action repertoires.

Layer 3: Motor Resonance. Where the observer possesses a matching motor program, mirror circuitry can run a forward model, yielding finely grained temporal predictions. This layer boosts speed and precision, and undergirds cooperative interaction (e.g., joint musical performance), but it is optional when higher layers already settle the goal.

Layer 4: Mental-State Enrichment. Sophisticated theory-of-mind mechanisms integrate social conventions, prior knowledge, and contextual cues (“He’s raising his hand not to swat a fly but to hail a taxi”).

On this architecture, disabling Layer 3 impairs certain tasks—subtle anticipation of timing, empathy grounded in embodied feeling—but leaves intact the core ability to perceive purposiveness.

Two decisive virtues follow. First, the model honors empirical plurality: it predicts both facilitative mirror-neuron findings and their numerous exceptions. Second, it locates resonance in a teleofunctional story: its role is to reduce prediction error when motor codes are cheap and available, not to underwrite the very possibility of goal perception.

7. Objections Considered

Objection 1: “Hidden Resonance.” Perhaps observers recruit homologous proximal effectors (e.g., trunk muscles) even when specific effectors are absent; resonance is merely hard to detect.

Reply: Amelic participants show near-baseline activation in premotor regions overall, yet their accuracy matches controls. If generic trunk activations sufficed, one should observe graded impairments proportional to effector similarity, which is not borne out. More crucially, a necessity claim that retreats to unfalsifiable micro-resonance loses empirical content.

Objection 2: “Developmental Scaffolding.” Even if adults can perceive goals without resonance, infants might bootstrap goal concepts through early mirroring; thus resonance is developmentally necessary.

Reply: Longitudinal work with motor-delayed infants (cerebral palsy) reveals typical teleological reasoning once visual exposure is matched, despite minimal motor practice. Furthermore, chicks raised in darkness exhibit spontaneous preference for efficiently moving agents. Developmental indispensability is thus doubtful.

Objection 3: “Expertise Domains.” In sports, anticipation of an opponent’s next move improves with motor experience. Doesn’t this show necessity?

Reply: Expertise studies actually support the layered model: For fast, fine-grained predictions (whether a tennis serve will go wide), motor familiarity grants an edge, but novices still perceive the goal at a coarser grain (serve toward left box). Expertise effects show that resonance refines resolution, not that it is required.

8. Novel Predictions

Prediction 1: In virtual-reality setups where one sees zero-gravity agents perform impossible-for-humans corkscrew motions yet still pursues clear goals (e.g., aligning blocks), observers should correctly anticipate goal states while showing diminished or absent effector-specific mu suppression. This dissociation is testable via EEG.

Prediction 2: Pharmacologically dampening premotor excitability (e.g., low-dose benzodiazepines) should impair time-to-contact estimation for familiar actions but leave untouched categorical goal identification, providing a double dissociation between Layer 3 and Layer 1–2 processing.

9. Conclusion

The allure of motor resonance as the master key to social cognition is understandable: it offers a tidy neural mechanism and resonates (so to speak) with our embodied self-experience. Yet, as with many beguiling simplifications, the data and deeper conceptual analysis refuse to cooperate. Perceiving another’s actions as purposive is an achievement of the perceptual-cognitive system as a whole, one that can be—and often is—realized without recourse to the observer’s own motor repertoire. The mirror system is a versatile collaborator in this enterprise, not its indispensable architect. Appreciating this pluralism clarifies why both comparative zoology and human neuroscience yield such varied results, and it opens space for richer theories of how we understand one another in all our diverse, sometimes un-mirror-able forms.

Does Seeing an Intention Require Simulating It?
              A Philosophical and Empirical Analysis of Motor Resonance in Action Perception
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Orienting the Debate  
The claim that “motor resonance is necessary for perceiving goal‐directed action” has become a common refrain since the discovery of so-called mirror neurons.  On the strongest reading, we can perceive an action as reaching, grasping, or chasing *only if* our own motor system covertly enacts the appropriate reaching, grasping, or chasing commands.  I will argue that this necessity claim is false.  Motor resonance is a highly useful—perhaps even default—route to understanding what others are up to, but the perceptual system has multiple, mutually compensating ways of extracting goal‐directed structure from the environment.  When resonance is blocked, missing, or anatomically impossible, human (and sometimes non-human) observers still perceive the relevant goals.  

Thesis.  Motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically necessary for the perception of goal-directed action; it is one of several partially redundant mechanisms that together constitute a degenerate (i.e., multiply realizable) system for social perception.

2. Clarifying the Key Notions  
a. Motor resonance.  I reserve this term for the on-line activation of a motor representation that *corresponds topographically* to the observed effector.  Without such somatotopic matching—e.g., hand areas for hand movement—talk of resonance loses its empirical bite.  
b. Perception of goal-directed action.  This is an *experiential* phenomenon: the observer sees the reaching as “for the cup,” the turn of the steering wheel as “aimed at changing lanes.”  It is importantly different from *conceptual inference* (figuring out afterwards what someone probably intended) and from *mere kinematic registration* (seeing a limb trace a trajectory).  

With these clarifications on the table, the necessity thesis amounts to: “Unless an observer’s motor cortex rehearses an isomorphic act, she cannot experience the reaching as reaching-for the cup.”  

3. Why One Might Believe the Necessity Thesis  
Three lines of argument have been offered:  

i. Argument from common coding.  According to the ideomotor tradition (Prinz, 1997), perceptual and motor representations share a “common currency.”  If true, only by accessing the motor side of that currency can an agent generate perceptual content that is richly intentional.  

ii. Explanatory parsimony.  Mirror activity appears within ~150 ms of movement onset—much faster than high-level inference.  So, the thought goes, resonance is the simplest proximate cause of our immediate grasp on others’ goals.  

iii. Correlational evidence.  fMRI, TMS, and EEG studies show that motor areas activate more when we view goal-directed than when we view purposeless motion; disruption of premotor cortex impairs anticipation of others’ goals (e.g., Avenanti et al., 2013).  Such correlations, interpreted causally, seem to support necessity.  

4. Cracks in the Necessity Wall  
Each of these arguments faces empirical counterexamples and conceptual tension.  I organize the discussion around four classes of cases.

Case 1: Goal Perception without the Relevant Motor Repertoire  
Adults readily perceive a dog as *trying to catch* a frisbee or a bird as *taking off*.  The somatotopic requirement fails: humans have no tail-wagging or wing-flapping region to resonate with.  The defender of necessity might retreat to an abstract, effector-independent resonance; but that concession already abandons the strong claim that the same motor code must run.  Worse, TMS studies targeting generic premotor regions do not impair human perception of canine or avian goals, even when they impair perception of human hand goals (Kilner et al., 2007).

Case 2: Individuals Lacking the Necessary Motor Circuits  
Congenitally limb-absent observers perceive reaching and grasping intentions in others with near-typical accuracy (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2016).  Their motor cortex has never executed the corresponding limb movements.  If resonance were necessary, their action understanding should be systemically impaired; it is not.  

Case 3: Situations in which Resonance is Pharmaceutically or Neurophysiologically Blocked  
Bach et al. (2020) administered a GABA agonist that dampens motor excitability.  EEG confirmed reduced mu suppression (a proxy for resonance), yet participants’ speed and accuracy at detecting action goals was unaffected.  Likewise, deep continuous theta-burst stimulation over M1 disrupts corticospinal resonance but leaves goal judgment intact (Cattaneo et al., 2009).  

Case 4: Novel Actions Acquired Perceptually Before Motorically  
Infants perceive certain means–end relations months before they can perform the act.  Nine-month-olds distinguish “reaching for” from “merely touching” an object (Woodward, 1998), although they cannot yet perform precise reaching themselves.  The necessity theorist might reply that even immature reaching circuits fire; but imaging studies reveal weak or absent somatotopic activation at that developmental stage (Marshall & Meltzoff, 2014).

5. How Is Goal Perception Possible Without Resonance?  
I propose a *multiple-cues, winner-cooperates-take-all* architecture.  The visual system supplies at least three non-motor sources of information that can specify goal-directedness:  

A. Kinematic Patterns.  Goal pursuit often has characteristic velocity profiles (e.g., minimum-jerk trajectories) and error-correcting submovements.  These “signature kinematics” can be detected purely visually (Flanagan & Johansson, 2003).  

B. Environmental Constraints.  The spatial relation between agent, obstacles, and target makes certain endpoints more probable, enabling a rational‐planning inference akin to Dennett’s “intentional stance.”  Gergely & Csibra’s classic bouncing-ball demos show that even toddlers, and some non-human animals, exploit such rationality cues without any plausible motor match.

C. Affordance Structure.  Gibsonian perception links object properties (grasp-ability, sit-ability) directly to possibilities for action.  If I see your hand approach a handle at the correct aperture and orientation, the handle itself signals that “grasp” is the relevant goal.  No motor rehearsal is needed; the affordance carries the intentional information.  

These three sources can converge or trade off.  When motor resonance is available, it acts as a fast heuristic, weighting candidate goals by how easily they can be executed in one’s own repertoire.  But when it is absent or unreliable, the system defaults to the other cues.

6. Addressing the Hardest Objection: Covert, Effector‐Independent Resonance  
A savvy defender will concede that literal hand-area activation is not required; instead, there is *higher-order motor resonance*—perhaps a supra-modal motor schema that even wingless humans can deploy to simulate flying.  Yet this move faces two problems:

(i) **Empirical minimality**: The broader we construe “motor resonance,” the less content the necessity claim retains.  If any neural resource that predicts future positions counts as “motor,” then ordinary visual motion detectors (MT/V5) would qualify, trivializing the thesis.

(ii) **Individuation**: Neural decoding studies show distinct patterns for predictive visual processing vs. genuine motor planning.  When participants merely predict the future path of a ball, premotor patterns differ systematically from those evoked when they plan to strike it (Schubotz & von Cramon, 2009).  Observers of animal motion exhibit the former but not the latter.  So there is independent evidence that prediction can occur without motor emulation.

7. Comparative and Cross-Modal Considerations  
Reading a novel vividly depicting a fencer’s riposte, one may *imagine* the goal despite no visual input and no muscle activation.  Conversely, silent CCTV footage of someone manipulating an unfamiliar tool yields enough information to label the act as “fixing,” even without linguistic scaffolding.  Goal perception, then, generalizes across sensory and representational formats in ways that outstrip the motor domain.  

Notably, individuals with locked-in syndrome, who have severely attenuated or absent motor feedback, can still interpret film clips of athletic feats as purpose-laden.  That empirical fact demolishes the assertion that motor *execution* circuits must feed back into perception.  

8. Theoretical Up-shot: Degenerate, Not Hierarchical, Organization  
Rather than a single “royal road” from perception to intentional content, the cognitive system exhibits *degeneracy*: multiple structurally different mechanisms yield the same functional output (Edelman & Gally, 2001).  Motor resonance is one such path, but ecological layout analysis, affordance detection, and planar causality modules provide alternate entries.  Evolutionarily, this redundancy is sensible: early mammals needed to recognize predatory intent without being able to replicate a hawk’s stoop.  Social primates later co-opted motor resonance to enrich and speed up this capacity for conspecific actions.  

9. Experimental Predictions of the Degeneracy View  
A good philosophical account should guide future science.  My view predicts:  

P1.  When kinematic and environmental cues are highly diagnostic, disrupting motor cortex will not impair goal detection; when these cues are degraded (e.g., blurred video), motor disruption will have a larger effect.  (An interaction, not a main effect.)  

P2.  Observers with superior visual statistical learning but poor motor imagery (e.g., some autism subgroups) will rely more on environmental-constraint cues; neural decoding will show heightened activity in parietal but not premotor regions.  

P3.  Training observers on unfamiliar effector actions (e.g., mouth-tool use) will *speed* but not *enable* perception of those goals—resonance enhances efficiency, not possibility.  

These predictions distinguish the degeneracy account from both strict necessity and strict sufficiency theses.

10. Philosophical Payoff: Rehabilitating the “Seeing‐as” Distinction  
Wittgenstein’s duck/rabbit teaches that perception can be imbued with conceptual organization.  The debate over motor resonance risks collapsing this into a single mechanism, obscuring the pluralistic nature of seeing-as.  Recognizing multiple routes clarifies why the *phenomenology* of action perception can vary: an expert dancer may “feel” the pirouette in her legs (resonance-heavy), whereas a naïve spectator experiences it more pictorially (affordance-heavy).  Both legitimately *see* the pirouette as goal-directed.  

11. Objection: What About the Neuropsychological Double Dissociation?  
If degeneracy is correct, we should observe cases where perception is intact and resonance gone *and* cases where resonance survives but perception fails.  The former we’ve already reviewed.  The latter obtains in ideomotor apraxia: patients may exhibit mirror activity to observed gestures yet cannot specify their purpose (Buxbaum et al., 2005).  Such a double dissociation is precisely what one expects if the mechanisms are only partially overlapping.  

12. Conclusion  
The allure of the necessity thesis lay in its promise of explanatory elegance: a single, biologically grounded mechanism accounting for our swift grasp of other minds.  But the empirical record speaks against monism, and conceptual reflection reveals that the thesis over‐extends the concept of simulation.  A more adequate picture is pluralistic and degenerate.  Motor resonance is a fast, evolutionarily recent, and phenomenologically salient *shortcut*; it is not the *sine qua non* of goal perception.  Recognizing this point frees both philosophy and cognitive science to investigate how visual kinematics, ecological affordances, rationality expectations, and motor simulation cooperate—sometimes competitively, often synergistically—to underwrite one of the most remarkable feats of perception: seeing intention in motion.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Toward a Pluralistic Cue-Integration Account
≈ 2,050 words

1. Introduction and Thesis  
When I watch an Olympic archer loose an arrow, I seem to apprehend her action as aiming at the bull’s-eye, despite never having drawn a bow myself. Some philosophers and cognitive scientists maintain that such perception is possible only because, covertly, my motor system “resonates” with the archer’s movement—that is, maps her kinematics onto my own motor repertoire. Call this the Necessity Thesis:

(NT) Motor resonance is a necessary condition for perceiving another’s action as goal-directed.

I argue that NT is false. Goal-directed action can be and often is perceived in the absence of motor resonance. Resonance is one among several information sources that the visual system can flexibly recruit; it is neither constitutively nor causally necessary. I defend a Pluralistic Cue-Integration Account: perceptual systems integrate multiple cues—affordances, environmental constraints, statistical regularities, rational‐teleological expectations, and sometimes motor simulation—to yield a robust representation of another’s goal. Resonance increases precision when available but is dispensable in principle and often in practice.

The argument proceeds as follows. §2 disentangles four distinctions often blurred in the debate. §3 surveys empirical evidence usually marshaled for NT and shows it supports, at most, a contributory role. §4 presents positive evidence for perception without resonance. §5 articulates the pluralistic account and explains why resonance, though useful, is unnecessary. §6 anticipates and replies to five objections. §7 briefly concludes.

2. Four Preliminary Distinctions  
Clarity about terms avoids dialectical gridlock.

2.1 Perceiving vs. Predicting  
To perceive an action as goal-directed is to attribute an objective of some sort—catching a ball, opening a door—whereas predicting the kinematic unfolding of the action is to forecast its future trajectory. Resonance may aid fine-grained prediction without being required for categorical goal attribution.

2.2 Causal vs. Constitutive Necessity  
NT is sometimes read strongly (constitutive: resonance partly composes the perceptual content) and sometimes weakly (causal: normal perception cannot occur without prior resonance). I target both readings.

2.3 Motor Resonance vs. Generic Simulation  
Motor resonance is a specific, bodily emulation tied to one’s effector repertoire (mirror-neuron firing, cortico-spinal facilitation). Generic simulation includes high-level analogical or inferential modeling independent of shared motor circuits. NT concerns the former.

2.4 Goal-Directedness Levels  
Goals may be overt (pressing a switch), distal (turning on the light) or mentalistic (wanting to read). Evidence for resonance at one level does not generalize automatically to others.

3. Evidence Commonly Cited for the Necessity Thesis  
Mirror-neuron research underwrites much of NT. Briefly:

(a) Neural Correlation: fMRI and single-cell studies show premotor regions active both when grasping and when observing grasping, suggesting shared coding.  
(b) Disruption Studies: TMS over premotor cortex impairs recognition of unusual actions.  
(c) Developmental Findings: Infants’ own emerging motor abilities correlate with their sensitivity to others’ goals.  

Taken to establish necessity, these findings face three problems.

3.1 The Fallacy of the Inferred Necessity  
Neural correlation is not evidence of necessity. Vision of color and auditory signals co-activate multimodal cortex, yet color perception survives when those areas are lesioned.

3.2 The Scope Problem  
Disruption effects are selective: TMS over premotor areas impairs discrimination of biomechanically awkward grasps but leaves intact comprehension of everyday actions and of distal goals. The impairments concern kinematic fine-detail, not the perception of agency or purposiveness per se.

3.3 The Developmental Equifinality Problem  
Infants who cannot yet perform a specific action often still understand its goal. Six-month-olds unable to crawl nevertheless expect an agent to circumvent an obstacle to reach a toy (Liu et al., 2019). Correlation between own-action repertoire and action understanding may reflect parallel maturation or shared environmental learning, not necessity.

4. Positive Evidence for Perception Without Resonance  

4.1 Congenital Motor Deficits  
People born without upper limbs (amelics) show normal abilities in recognizing others’ manual actions and predicting their goals (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2016). Because they lack the motor schema for hand actions, resonance—as mirroring of a missing effector—is unavailable. Their success falsifies causal NT.

4.2 Cross-Species and Cross-Effector Perception  
Humans effortlessly perceive goal-directedness in an octopus manipulating shells, in a dog burying a bone, or even in a Roomba vacating a corner. Since our motor repertoire lacks tentacular, pawed, or vacuum‐based actions, resonance cannot underwrite these perceptions.

4.3 Minimal-Cues Displays  
Heider-Simmel animations of geometric shapes elicit robust perception of chasing, inviting, thwarting—goals plentifully ascribed despite the absence of biological motion cues capable of triggering mirror neurons.

4.4 Sensory Substitution Cases  
Vision-substituted blind observers using tactile arrays understand others’ actions despite reduced or qualitatively different motor resonance. They exploit spatiotemporal patterns embedded in the stimuli, not shared motor plans.

4.5 Virtual Avatars With Impossible Kinematics  
Observers readily perceive the intention of avatars whose joints bend at impossible angles, provided environmental cues specify a coherent distal outcome (Kim & Waldrop, 2021). Mirror neurons tuned to realistic biomechanics cannot resonate with impossible limbs.

5. A Pluralistic Cue-Integration Account  

5.1 The Computational Motivation  
Perception under uncertainty profits from integrating heterogeneous cues. Predictive-processing models treat the brain as minimizing prediction error via hierarchical generative models. Multiple priors can combine to yield robust inference. Nothing dictates that the motor prior be indispensable.

5.2 The Cue Set for Goal Perception  
Five chief cue classes suffice, singly or jointly, for goal attribution:

1. Affordance Cues: Objects suggest actions (a cup affords grasping).  
2. Environmental Constraints: Obstacles and paths shape rational action trajectories; viewers infer goals via the ‘teleological stance’ (Gergely & Csibra, 2003).  
3. Kinematic Regularities: Biological motion patterns carry statistical signatures of purposeful behavior (e.g., minimum-jerk law).  
4. Social-Pragmatic Signals: Gaze direction, facial expressions, linguistic cues.  
5. Motor Resonance: First-person motor schemas.

The system weights these cues by reliability and context. When resonance is absent—watching an octopus, or being tremor-paralyzed—remaining cues compensate.

5.3 Why Resonance Persists  
If resonance is dispensable, why keep it? Motor emulation offers (i) temporal precision for fine-grained prediction needed in real-time interaction and (ii) low-level noise reduction for familiar actions. It is adaptive but not indispensable—akin to stereo vision in depth perception: helpful, yet monocular depth cues usually suffice.

5.4 Constitutive vs. Epistemic Reduction  
Perceptual content is not constituted by specific neural patterns but by their success in tracking distal properties. Multiple realisability defeats any constitutive necessity claim.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: Premotor lesions sometimes impair verb comprehension (‘to hammer’). Doesn’t that show constitutive necessity?  
Reply: Lesions produce subtle lexical-semantic deficits that group with tool conceptualization, not action goal perception per se. Patients still identify the intention (to drive a nail) though they struggle to pantomime. The impairment concerns motor praxis codes used in language, not perceptual attribution of goals.

Objection 2: TMS disrupting mirror areas decreases accuracy on “why” (goal) questions, not only “how” (kinematic) ones.  
Reply: Decreased accuracy reflects slowed or noisy cue integration when a normally reliable source is down-weighted. Necessity is neither implied nor required; binocular occlusion similarly worsens depth judgment without making stereo vision necessary for depth perception.

Objection 3: The amelic evidence may rely on vicarious resonance through remaining body parts; could they map hand actions onto foot motor schemas?  
Reply: fMRI shows no compensatory foot-area mirroring for hand actions in amelics. Moreover, they succeed even for mouth or head actions for which they also lack effector correspondence.

Objection 4: Heider-Simmel cases involve high-level inference, not genuine perception. Isn’t the debate about perceptual, not cognitive, attribution?  
Reply: Behavioral and ERP studies find early (~200 ms) modulations in visual cortex for goal-oriented dot motion, paralleling low-level visual processing. The attribution is automatic, fast, and exhibits signature features of perception (resistance to counter-evidence, phenomenological vividness).

Objection 5: Pluralism risks unfalsifiability—any failure of resonance can be hand-waved away by appealing to other cues.  
Reply: The account yields testable predictions: in contexts where all non-resonance cues are degraded (e.g., night-vision of unfamiliar actions), removing motor resonance should measurably impair goal perception. Conversely, when resonance is impossible but other cues are intact, performance should remain near-normal. Existing data conform to this pattern.

7. Conclusion  
Motor resonance enriches action perception but is not its sine qua non. A pluralistic cue-integration system—evolutionarily prudent and computationally efficient—explains both the utility of resonance when available and its dispensability across species, pathologies, and exotic contexts. Rejecting NT frees us to investigate how diverse information sources combine to yield the exquisite human capacity to see what others are up to, even when they act with bodies, tools, or trajectories radically unlike our own.

References (abbr.)  
Gergely & Csibra (2003) “Teleological reasoning.” Liu et al. (2019) Developmental Science. Kim & Waldrop (2021) J Virtual Reality. Vannuscorps & Caramazza (2016) PNAS.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Why Simulation is Helpful but Not Necessary                                                   

1. Introduction and Thesis  
Mirror-neuron research has inspired a bold claim: my capacity to see your reaching as aimed at a cup depends on covertly rehearsing that reach in my own motor circuitry. Without such motor “resonance,” we are told, your behaviour would look like meaningless motion. I argue that this necessity claim is false. Motor resonance is (i) one among several routes by which the visual system can gain information about others’ goals, (ii) a highly efficient but not obligatory route, and (iii) dispensable in principle and in some real-world cases. A multi-level “teleo-predictive” framework—combining ecological specification of affordances with non-motor predictive inference—accounts for the same phenomena while explaining evidence that resonance neither always occurs nor is always available. Resonance earns an important, modulatory role, but goal perception can survive its absence.

2. Clarifying the Debate: Three Distinctions  
Before arguments are traded, we must disambiguate three pairs of notions that fuel confusion.

2.1 Perceiving versus Inferring Goals  
To perceive a hand-movement as “grasping a cup” is not merely to form a cold belief that a grasp will occur; it is to experience the movement as already organized toward that outcome. Whether such perceptual content is built from simulation or from “theory-like” inference is the question at hand. Importantly, none of the protagonists deny that we often infer hidden intentions; the dispute concerns the *perceptual* registration of directedness.

2.2 Necessary versus Enabling versus Modulatory Conditions  
A *necessary* condition must be present on every occasion of goal perception. An *enabling* condition must only hold in the background (e.g., neurons need oxygen). A *modulatory* factor improves speed or accuracy without being indispensable. The motor-necessity thesis claims resonance is necessary; my alternative casts it as modulatory.

2.3 Motor Resonance Proper versus Predictive Coding  
Mirror activity is sometimes portrayed as the motor branch of a domain-general predictive brain. If so, failing mirror neurons might be compensated by other predictive hierarchies (visual, conceptual). The necessity claim tacitly assumes no such redundancy. My strategy is to show empirical pockets where the redundancy in fact does the job.

3. The Case for Necessity: What Needs Answering  
The literature offers three main arguments.

A. Intelligibility Argument (Gallese 2001): Purely visual motion lacks information about *why* it occurs; motor simulation supplies the “motor vocabulary” that renders a kinematic pattern intelligible as grasping, giving perception its goal-content.  

B. Developmental Coupling (Meltzoff & Iacoboni): Infants begin to recognize others’ actions as goal-directed around the same time they can execute similar acts, suggesting sensorimotor coupling is causally critical.  

C. Neural Correlation: fMRI and TMS show motor-system activation tightly time-locked to observing goal-directed action and predicting its completion; disrupting premotor cortex impairs prediction. If resonance is turned off, so is goal perception (or so the argument goes).

To refute necessity, I need only one counterexample in which goal-perception obtains without resonance. I will offer several, then explain why they undermine each of the above arguments.

4. Evidence Against Necessity  

4.1 Developmental Dissociations  
Newborn chicks (Mascalzoni et al., 2010) prefer motion that results in goal-states (a smaller dot nestling under a bigger dot) despite lacking any motor capacity to perform such “covering” themselves. Likewise, 3-month-old human infants who cannot yet reach nevertheless look longer at changed-goal tests, indicating they encoded earlier reaches in terms of goals (Luo, 2011). Developmentally, then, recognitional capacity can precede production.

4.2 Neuropsychological Dissociations  
• Ideomotor apraxia (Sirigu et al., 1995): Patients cannot imitate or plan certain actions but are still able to recognize others performing them and identify the intended object.  
• Higher-level spinal cord injuries: Quadriplegic observers with no kinesthetic feedback and dramatically altered motor maps identify action goals at normal speed (Verri et al., 2018).  
• Parkinson’s disease: Dopaminergic depletion dampens motor resonance (reduced MEPs), yet recognition of familiar goal-actions remains near-typical (Pohl et al., 2016).

4.3 Cross-Species and Impossible-Body Evidence  
We effortlessly perceive the goal of a dog jumping for a frisbee or of a bird snatching a worm. These actions lie outside our motor repertoire: no human can flap feathered wings. Simulation theorists reply that resonance works at an abstract level (grasping schema). But what is the content of such a schema if it no longer mirrors the observer’s motor code? The abstraction moves us away from neural motoric detail and toward visual-kinematic or amodal representations, conceding the essential point that motor matching in one’s *own* repertoire is dispensable.

4.4 Tool-Use and Remote Action  
Surgeons operating a robotic arm or gamers directing avatars still visually parse those robotic movements as slicing, gripping, etc., even though the causal chain runs through a joystick and the geometric articulation scarcely resembles a human limb. Goal recognition here rides on learned mappings between *external* kinematics and outcomes, again bypassing a shared motor format.

4.5 Blind Expertise in Sports Broadcasting  
Radio commentators who have never themselves executed a double-axel in figure skating nevertheless track complex motions in real time, predicting jumps and labeling them “attempting a triple lutz.” The fluency persists even when watching skeletal animation devoid of muscle cues. Vocal-motor rehearsal, if any, is enormously abstract.

These pockets collectively render resonance *contingent*: often present, sometimes absent, never strictly required.

5. Why the Positive Data Are Compatible With Contingency  

5.1 Finely Tuned Notoriety  
When experiments compare intact versus TMS-disrupted premotor areas, they typically measure *anticipatory eye movements* or *time-to-completion estimation*. These tasks tap *predictive accuracy*, not the sheer perceptual *possession* of goals. A slightly delayed prediction is not a failure to perceive directedness. The data thus show that resonance boosts efficiency—a modulatory role.

5.2 Cofounding Task Demands  
Some fMRI contrasts pit goal-directed versus random motion. Random motion is noisy; goal-motion is stereotyped; different low-level visual statistics alone can drive differential activation. That the motor system is *also* active may reveal recruitment, not necessity. Lesion evidence (Section 4.2) carries higher inferential weight and points the other way.

5.3 Correlation Isn’t Constraint  
Neural correlation plausibly reflects the brain’s bias toward opportunistic reuse: if motor circuits can help, they will. But reuse does not entail dependence. Vision recruits knowledge of gravity (vestibular) when available; astronauts lacking gravity still *see* objects as falling on Earth. An analogy: people sometimes subvocally rehearse text while reading; yet inner speech is not necessary for reading, as evidenced by sign-language users. Resonance stands to goal perception as subvocal rehearsal stands to comprehension.

6. A Teleo-Predictive Alternative  

6.1 Ecological Specification of Affordances  
Following Gibson, the visually ambient energy array carries higher-order invariants—changes in hand aperture relative to object width, velocity profiles that saturate near contact—that specify prospective control laws. These invariants are ecological, not motoric: they can in principle be detected by any organism with the right filters, no bodily matching required. Carruthers’ “action pragmatism” adds that perceiving the directedness is perceiving *affordances-in-the-making*, not mental states behind the scene.

6.2 Hierarchical Bayesian Prediction  
Predictive-processing models allow multiple generative pathways to hypothesize distal outcomes. Vision could predict “cup will be grasped” by referencing a goal library stored in associative cortex, while motor cortex remains silent. Error signals would still cascade down the hierarchy, refining hypotheses. Motor resonance is one possible predictor, but a visual-conceptual path can substitute.

6.3 Why Evolution Keeps Resonance Around  
If non-motor routes suffice, why keep mirror systems? They are quick, low-dimensional, and energy-efficient for familiar actions that the organism itself performs. For social primates engaged in frequent turn-taking, speed may confer fitness. But evolution often supports redundancies: binocular vision is not necessary for depth perception (monocular cues suffice), yet both are maintained.

6.4 The Division of Labor  
The resulting picture is pluralistic:

• Visual-kinematic invariants supply basic goal perception.  
• Motor resonance accelerates prediction and enables vicarious motor noise (empathy, motor learning).  
• Conceptual-semantic systems handle unfamiliar or abstract actions (stock-market trading).

Crucially, the first route does not rely on the second, though they often co-operate.

7. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The apraxia and paralysis cases might retain degraded yet sufficient mirror activity below detection thresholds.  
Reply: Even if tiny residual resonance exists, the necessity thesis demands *complete* failure of goal perception in its absence. Demonstrations with congenitally limbless individuals (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2015) show no correlation between missing limbs (and hence missing limb motor maps) and deficits in perceiving corresponding limb actions in others.

Objection 2: Cross-species perception piggybacks on high-level analogical mapping that still invokes one’s own motor system at a schematic level.  
Reply: A schematic level that no longer preserves effector geometry or muscle synergies is not “motor” in any robust neuroscientific sense. The mirror network’s hallmark is somatotopy; watching birds activates extrastriate body areas, not premotor hand fields. The burden of proof shifts back to the necessitarian to specify what counts as motor.

Objection 3: Eye-tracking shows infants anticipate goal-objects only when they can perform the reach themselves.  
Reply: Contradictory data already cited (Luo 2011). Moreover, anticipation is distinct from perceptual attribution. An infant might *see* the reach as goal-directed yet lack the motricity to forecast endpoint timing. Again: facilitation, not necessity.

8. Broader Philosophical Implications  

8.1 Against Embodiment Extremism  
The contingency of resonance weakens strong “embodied cognition” claims that bodily formats ground all social cognition. A moderate embodiment stays: bodies matter, but they are one format among several.

8.2 Direct Perception Rehabilitated  
If goal-content can be specified by visual invariants, then perceiving agency need not pass through opacity-providing intellectual inference. We can be direct realists about others’ goals without being motor simulationists.

8.3 Moral and Clinical Payoffs  
Understanding that resonance is optional opens avenues for autism therapies that enhance visual-conceptual parsing without trying to “fix” mirror neurons; likewise, brain-machine interface designs need not replicate human kinematics to be intuitively interpretable by surgeons.

9. Conclusion  
Motor resonance is a versatile, evolutionarily sensible shortcut for decoding familiar goal-directed action. Yet the empirical and conceptual landscape shows it is neither logically nor causally necessary. Goal perception survives in infants too young to act, in patients unable to move, across species boundaries, and in tool-mediated contexts where geometric mismatch nullifies any literal mirroring. A teleo-predictive account—combining ecological invariants with multi-route Bayesian inference—preserves the merits of resonance while explaining its dispensability. Recognizing the contingency of motor simulation frees philosophy and cognitive science to explore richer, pluralistic pictures of how we see others as agents.

Motor resonance is the poster-child of the “embodied turn” in cognitive science.  Ever since the first reports of mirror neurons, many philosophers have claimed that when I watch you reach for an apple, what makes the movement intelligible as goal-directed is the covert activation of my own motor code for grasping.  Strip away that resonance, they say, and all that would remain is a meaningless trajectory through space.  In this essay I argue that this is a mistake.  While motor resonance can enrich and stabilize action perception, it is not a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directedness.  I defend a pluralist, “multi-cue teleological” account on which goal-directed actions can be—and often are—perceived independently of resonance mechanisms.  I proceed as follows.  Section 1 disentangles the thesis at issue, drawing distinctions between causal contribution, constitutive dependence, and modality-specific sufficiency.  Section 2 reconstructs the best case for the necessity claim.  Sections 3–4 develop two complementary lines of critique: a conceptual argument that the necessity thesis trades on a category mistake, and an empirical argument from cases in which action goals are perceived despite absent or impossible resonance.  Section 5 offers a positive model that integrates kinematic, contextual, and normative cues without requiring motor simulation.  Section 6 replies to three objections on behalf of the resonance theorist.  I close by sketching implications for developmental psychology, social robotics, and the philosophy of mind.

1. Clarifying the Target Thesis

Talk of “necessity” is notoriously liable to equivocation.  We must ask:

a. Logical necessity: Is it conceptually incoherent to attribute goal perception without resonance?

b. Constitutive necessity: Is resonance part of what it is to perceive goal-directedness (in the way that retinal stimulation is part of what it is to see)?

c. Causal/empirical necessity: In biologically typical humans, does goal perception never occur unless resonance is also occurring?

The boldest mirror-theoretic papers often blur (b) and (c).  For present purposes I grant that resonance is often present; the live question is whether (b) holds, and whether (c) survives careful empirical scrutiny.  I shall argue that both answers are negative.

We also need clarity about “goal-directed action perception.”  I will reserve the term for the perceptual availability of an action’s telic organisation—the “aboutness” toward an outcome—prior to or independent of explicit theoretical inference.  In vision science this corresponds to the ability to anticipate the action’s completion point, to assign a privileged segmentation of movement phases, and to treat agent and patient as bound in a causal nexus.

2. The Best Resonance-Necessity Argument

Mirror theorists marshal three considerations.

2.1 Phenomenological immediacy.  When I watch Serena Williams serve, I do not see brute arm angles; I see “preparing to launch” and “driving through the ball.”  The claim is that only by covertly rehearsing the serve does the motion attain that intentional gestalt.

2.2 Timing and prediction.  Motor cortex activity in observers is time-locked to the observed kinematics and leads peak velocity by ~100 ms, supporting the idea that the observer’s motor system forward-models the impending goal.  Disrupting premotor cortex with TMS impairs prediction of an action’s endpoint.

2.3 Developmental mirroring.  Infants show both early mirror-EEG rhythms and early sensitivity to the goals of grasping—suggesting a maturational coupling rather than a late learned inference.

From these data the necessity thesis infers: if mirror activation is always present when goal perception occurs and if interfering with it sometimes disrupts prediction, then resonance is a prerequisite.

3. Conceptual Problems: A Category Mistake

The resonance-necessity thesis rests on conflating “vehicle” with “content.”  Perceiving goal-directedness is an achievement at the level of representational content: I apprehend the telic structure “grasp-for-apple.”  Motor resonance, by contrast, specifies a particular neural vehicle in the perceiver.  But content and vehicle stand in a many-to-many relation: the same content can in principle be implemented by distinct vehicles—linguistic description, abstract imagery, logical form, or motor codes.  Unless a bridging principle is supplied, the mere fact that a certain neural dynamic often carries the content does not entail that no other vehicle could.  The necessity claim thus over-generalises from habitual co-occurrence to constitutive indispensability.

An analogy: When expert chess players swiftly recognise a mating net, fMRI shows motor-planning activity in premotor regions (associated with “grasping” the piece).  Yet no one would claim that motor planning is necessary for seeing a chess threat; a paralysed mathematician could appreciate the position without it.  The burden is on the mirror theorist to show that the action case is disanalogous.

4. Empirical Counter-Evidence

4.1 Morphological mismatch cases.  Humans readily perceive the goal structure in actions they cannot possibly execute: the soaring trajectory of an eagle diving for prey; the hydraulic pistoning of industrial robots on an assembly line; an octopus manipulating a jar with eight arms.  Fine-tuned kinematic sensitivity and anticipatory gaze are preserved (Flanagan & Johansson 2003) despite the absence of any executable motor homologue.

4.2 Congenital limb absence.  Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) studied individuals born without upper limbs.  Despite lacking motor programs for grasping, they show normal performance in visual tasks requiring anticipation of hand-action goals, and their ventral premotor cortex still displays mirror-like selectivity.  Either resonance is not necessary, or the brain opportunistically re-uses other bodily schemas, but then the specificity thesis collapses.

4.3 Tool novelty and rapid adaptation.  Observers quickly perceive goal structure in newly introduced, culturally unfamiliar tools (e-g., a mechanised apple-peeler).  The speed of comprehension (within a single demonstration) outpaces the time needed to form a reliable motor program for that tool, suggesting that visual-contextual inference suffices.

4.4 TMS dissociations.  Although disrupting premotor cortex can impair fine-grained kinematic prediction, it does not abolish categorical goal attribution (Pobric & Hamilton 2006).  Participants still judge “he is reaching for X” with high accuracy; what suffers is reaction time or trajectory extrapolation.  That points to a facilitatory, not necessary, role.

4.5 Infants before motor mastery.  Six-month-olds, who cannot yet perform means-end cloth-pulling to retrieve a toy, nevertheless look longer at inefficient cloth-pulls, implying goal expectation (Sommerville et al. 2005).  Their resonance system for that action is, at best, immature.

5. A Multi-Cue Teleological Model

If resonance is not required, how do we see goals?  I propose a three-layer account.

5.1 Kinematic heuristics.  Human vision is exquisitely sensitive to a non-accidental relation between velocity profiles and invariant outcomes (the “minimum-jerk” principle).  Movements that conform to efficient paths through joint space are classified as intentional rather than mechanical noise (Csibra 2008).  This analysis is modality-general: any system that learns the mapping from trajectories to stable distal states can exploit it.

5.2 Affordance mapping.  Vision simultaneously parses the scene for affordances: graspable size, reachable distance, obstructing barriers.  When an agent’s motion reduces the gap between its effector and an affordant object, the motion is encoded under the relational predicate “toward.”  Crucially, this is a relational visual property, not a motor rehearsal; it can occur for spiders and drones.

5.3 Normative pragmatics.  Perception of goals is also shaped by stored scripts of what beings of that type typically want.  Call this the “teleological prior.”  It is updated by statistical learning and can override kinematics (e.g., seeing a zig-zag path as “dodging obstacles” rather than “aimless”).  This layer accounts for cultural actions whose kinematics are opaque but contextually meaningful, like a priest raising a chalice.

Motor resonance enters this architecture as an optional booster pack: because my motor system embodies efficient action knowledge, simulating your movement provides a shortcut to identifying kinematic heuristics and affordances.  But the heuristics and affordances are conceptually independent and can be computed via purely perceptual and associative resources.

We can express the dependence graph formally:

Goal Perception  ←  {Kinematics, Contextual Affordances, Teleological Priors, (Motor Resonance)}

where curly braces denote jointly sufficient but individually defeasible inputs, and parentheses denote an enhancing but dispensable channel.

6. Replies to Three Objections

Objection 1: “Latent resonance.”  Perhaps observers covertly map the action into motor schemata at a more abstract level (e.g., ‘effect-controlled descriptors’) even when the effector morphology differs.

Reply: To salvage necessity, the theorist must stretch “motor” to include any abstract effector-independent code for causal generation of outcomes.  But that gambit empties the thesis of empirical content: the purportedly distinctive mechanism becomes indistinguishable from general predictive coding.  A claim so general cannot explain the specific mirror physiology originally motivating it.

Objection 2: “Developmental primacy.”  Infants might initially rely on resonance to bootstrap goal perception, even if adults later add visual heuristics.

Reply: The developmental evidence points the other way.  Neonates track the goal states of a grasping motion before they can grasp and before canonical mu-rhythm suppression appears (Filippi et al. 2020).  An ontogenetic story that posits resonance first must assume unobserved prenatal motor simulations without proprioceptive calibration—less parsimonious than assuming early-maturing visual heuristics.

Objection 3: “Clinical deficit.”  Apraxic patients with impaired motor planning also show deficits in action understanding, supporting necessity.

Reply: Apraxia rarely isolates resonance mechanisms; it involves widespread fronto-parietal damage that also compromises spatial attention and working memory.  Moreover, “action understanding” tasks in apraxia studies often demand verbal explanation, dragging in executive functions.  Double-dissociation evidence (e.g., patients with spared comprehension but impaired imitation) undermines the one-to-one mapping.

7. Broader Implications

7.1 Development.  On the multi-cue model, infants tune to goal-related kinematic regularities before fine motor control, shedding light on the paradox of “smart” expectations in action naïfs.  This predicts that altering environmental kinematic statistics—through unconventional puppet shows—should recalibrate goal perception without any change to the infant’s motor abilities.  Preliminary data support this.

7.2 Social robotics.  If robots must be intelligible to human observers, designers need not equip them with human-like joints; instead they must produce motion obeying efficient-trajectory heuristics and expose affordance cues.  Conversely, building resonance algorithms into our own recognition systems may be helpful but is not mandatory.

7.3 Philosophy of mind.  The multi-cue story vindicates a “teleological stance” as perceptual and non-inferential while denying a strong form of the embodiment thesis.  It suggests that intentional objects can be visually given without motor identification, challenging enactivist claims that understanding is “skillful coping all the way down.”

Conclusion

Motor resonance is an elegant and powerful component of social cognition, but mistaking it for the sine qua non of goal perception confuses frequent accompaniment with necessity.  Conceptually, goal perception is contentful whereas resonance specifies one family of vehicles.  Empirically, humans and other animals perceive goal-directed structure in actions they cannot perform, and individuals lacking matching motor programs do so as well.  A multi-cue teleological framework—integrating kinematics, affordances, and normative priors—explains how goal-directedness becomes perceptually transparent while leaving resonance as an optional facilitator.  Recognizing that perceptual systems can represent telic organization independently of embodiment not only resolves puzzles in developmental psychology and neuropsychology but also widens the space of viable artificial agents.  We should thus retire the necessity thesis in favor of a pluralist, layered account that more faithfully captures the richness of our social perceptual life.

Motor resonance—the covert activation of one’s own motor system when observing another agent’s bodily movement—has become a centerpiece of contemporary theorizing about social cognition. Ever since mirror neurons were first reported in macaques, philosophers and cognitive scientists have suggested a strong claim: mapping the observed kinematics onto one’s own motor repertoire is a necessary condition for perceiving goal-directed actions at all. If I cannot in some sense “do it in my head,” the thought goes, I cannot so much as see what you are doing. I will argue that this necessity claim is false. Motor resonance is one useful—but dispensable—resource in the perceptual economy that underwrites goal-ascription. 

My thesis has three parts.

1. Conceptual: The debate has conflated three different modalities of necessity—constitutive, enabling, and facilitating. Only the strongest, constitutive claim is worth defending, but that claim is untenable.  
2. Empirical: Whole classes of cases—cross-species perception, tool-mediated actions, and perceivers with motor deficits—show that people successfully perceive goals in the absence of resonant mapping. Neurophysiological data, when carefully interpreted, support a facilitative rather than necessary role for resonance.  
3. Theoretical: A more adequate model treats goal-perception as a predictive, multi-level process in which kinematic, causal, and contextual information are combined. Resonance supplies one source of constraints on the inferential process, but other sources can substitute when resonance is weak or unavailable.

By distinguishing kinds of necessity, canvassing the counter-evidence, and offering a generative replacement model, I aim to move the discussion beyond a mirror-neuron monoculture toward a pluralistic, hierarchically organized view of social perception.

I. Three kinds of “necessity”  
Philosophers often prosecute the resonance thesis as though there were just one modal register, but talk of a “necessary condition” can be unpacked in at least three ways:

• Constitutive necessity: Resonance is part of what it *is* to perceive an action as goal-directed; without resonance, there is no such perception—analogous to how color experience constitutively involves hue.  
• Enabling necessity: Resonance is a background capacity whose intactness is required, even if not occurrent in every episode, like having a visual cortex is required for seeing red.  
• Facilitating or epistemic necessity: Resonance expedites or stabilizes goal-perception in ordinary conditions, though alternative routes exist.

Most proponents of the motor theory slip across these senses. Gallese & Sinigaglia, for instance, sometimes write as if resonance “grounds the *very possibility* of understanding action,” suggesting constitutive necessity; elsewhere they speak more modestly of a “direct and efficient route.” The empirical record thus far bears out only the facilitative reading. To defend the stronger claims, proponents would need both conceptual argument and incompatibility data—cases in which goal-perception demonstrably fails *because* resonance is impossible. As we shall see, no such data exist, and plentiful counter-examples do. 

II. Three empirical pressure points

1. Cross-species and morphologically novel actions  
Humans readily perceive a dog’s burying a bone, an octopus’s opening a jar, or a swarm of robots cooperating to move a block as goal-directed. Yet mapping these actions onto one’s *own* motor repertoire is impossible: I have neither prehensile tentacles nor hydraulic legs. A defender may reply that resonance operates at an abstract, effector-independent level. But the heavier the abstraction, the thinner the connection to the original, motoric notion of resonance; at some point it merely becomes predictive processing with motor *inspired* priors. Moreover, neuroimaging studies show diminished or absent mirror-area activity when participants view non-conspecific or biomechanically impossible movements, even while they make accurate goal judgments (Cross et al., 2010). This pattern strongly suggests that resonance is not required for success. 

2. Tool use and extended agency  
Suppose I watch a skilled carpenter spin a drill whose rotational dynamics I have never executed. I effortlessly register that the goal is to drive the screw flush. The drill’s operational degrees of freedom do not belong to my body schema; yet perception of the goal is immediate. Similar results arise in laboratory studies where participants view actors controlling cursors by unseen levers: goal-attribution tracks the distal cursor trajectory, not the proximal limb motion. If resonance with proximal kinematics were necessary, distal goal perception should collapse. It does not.

3. Motor impairment and developmental dissociations
