Individuals with congenital limb absence perceive the goal of grasping just as well as controls, although they cannot form resonant motor plans for missing effectors (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2015). Likewise, children as young as eight months detect goal structure in animated shapes (Gergeley & Csibra, 2003) well before their own motor repertoire includes the observed motions. Conversely, patients with ideomotor apraxia may show impaired resonance yet intact goal recognition. Any single case might be explained away, but the convergence of developmental, clinical, and comparative evidence forms a cumulative argument against necessity.

III. Reinterpreting the pro-resonance data

What, then, of the robust findings *for* motor resonance—EMG modulation, corticospinal excitability, interference effects when executing incongruent actions, and so on? Two points matter.

First, correlation does not establish necessity. Many cognitive processes recruit helpful but inessential resources: visuospatial rehearsal aids mental arithmetic; pre-motor imagery boosts memory for routes. The presence of recruitment shows only that the resource is *available* and often *used*.

Second, lesion and TMS studies that *disrupt* mirror areas typically report slowed or noisier goal judgments, not wholesale abolition. This pattern is the empirical signature of a facilitative mechanism. Compare semantic priming: knocking out lexical access slows naming but does not preclude it if conceptual links or phonological strategies can compensate.

IV. A predictive, multi-source model of goal-perception

Rather than casting the debate in disjunctive terms—resonance or no resonance—I propose a hierarchical generative model inspired by recent work in computational cognitive science.

Level 1: Kinematics. The visual system extracts trajectories, velocities, and joint angles. Motor resonance offers one efficient way to predict likely next states, using one’s forward models as quick-and-dirty simulators.

Level 2: Causal pragmatics. Independently of bodily simulation, observers possess rich knowledge about object affordances, environmental constraints, and action schemata. Bayesian inverse planning models show that goal-attribution can be computed by selecting the hypothesis that makes the observed trajectory *rational* given situational affordances (Baker, Saxe & Tenenbaum, 2009).

Level 3: Contextual and narrative priors. Social scripts, cultural expectations, and linguistic cues further constrain which goals are plausible. Seeing a person raise a glass during a toast primes the goal “celebrate” even if the precise motor pattern is unfamiliar.

Perception of action emerges from the integration of bottom-up sensory evidence with top-down predictions across all three levels. When resonance is available, it provides strong priors at Level 1, sharpening kinematic predictions and facilitating rapid segmentation. When resonance is unavailable—because the effector is alien, the observer is motor-impaired, or the action is biomechanically impossible—Levels 2 and 3 shoulder more of the inferential load. The system is degenerate in the biological sense: multiple different mechanisms can realize the same functional outcome. This is why goal-perception survives the loss or absence of resonance.

V. Dialectical engagement: three objections and replies

Objection 1: “Interference effects prove that on-line resonance is constitutive—you cannot voluntarily inhibit it without impairing goal-perception.”  
Reply: Interference shows only that parallel recruitment can create competition for shared resources. Shadowing speech disrupts verbal working memory but does not entail that rehearsal is constitutive of remembering syllables. Likewise, transcranial disruption of the inferior frontal gyrus slows but does not abolish goal judgments, indicating resource overlap, not constitutive identity.

Objection 2: “Abstract resonance saves necessity: even when watching an octopus, you resonate at a higher, goal-equivalent level.”  
Reply: This move is dialectically expensive. If resonance generalizes to any mapping between observed and internal generative models, the thesis collapses into the platitude that perception involves internal modeling—true but no longer a distinctive motor claim. The original explanatory payoff—grounding social cognition in *motor* re-use—is forfeited.

Objection 3: “Developmental evidence shows that infants *learn* goal concepts through the calibration of self-generated and observed actions; later independence does not refute the necessity claim at the origin of the capacity.”  
Reply: Even if motor experience bootstraps early goal concepts, that historical role does not secure constitutive necessity for mature perception. Reading might depend causally on early phonological awareness, yet once established, reading comprehension can survive phonological deficits (cf. deep dyslexia). The modal force of “necessity” concerns synchronic dependence, not phylogenetic or ontogenetic pathways.

VI. Precision in distinctions that matter

The foregoing argument hinges on three distinctions sometimes blurred in the literature:

A. Seeing an *action* versus seeing a *goal*. The former concerns kinematic parsing; the latter, teleological interpretation. Resonance primarily aids the former, but the necessity claim is about the latter.

B. *Experiential* immediacy versus *inferential* processes. One can grant that goal-perception feels immediate while insisting its underlying mechanism is inferentially rich—and that resonance is only one contributor.

C. *Constitutive* versus *explanatory* primacy. A process can be explanatorily privileged (e.g., easiest to study, neurally accessible) without being constitutively essential. Mirror research has been methodologically transformative; that does not license ontological elevation.

VII. An upshot for social epistemology and artificial cognition

If goal-perception is multi-sourced and degenerate, several downstream consequences follow.

1. Social learning need not be limited by motor similarity. Robots endowed with visual predictive models but mismatched effectors can still learn from human demonstrations without requiring morphological mirroring. This supports the design of heterogeneous collaborative systems.

2. Cultural practices that reshape kinematics—dance, sign language—are intelligible across communities because higher-level pragmatic and contextual cues scaffold understanding, not because all observers can replicate the motions.

3. Disorders of social cognition (e.g., autism) cannot be fully explained by mirror-system dysfunction. Interventions should target broader predictive and contextual integration abilities.

VIII. Conclusion

Motor resonance is a fascinating, evolutionarily elegant trick: it allows us to recycle pre-existing motor circuits for rapid, low-cost prediction of others’ movements. Yet fascination can breed over-reach. The evidence, properly weighed, shows that resonance is neither constitutively nor enablingly necessary for perceiving goal-directed actions. Rather, it is one facilitative strand in a braided architecture that integrates kinematic simulation, causal reasoning, and contextual priors. Appreciating this pluralism not only resolves apparent anomalies in the data but also opens new research avenues—into how these strands cooperate, compensate, and sometimes come apart.

Philosophy’s task is not merely to laud the latest neuroscientific discovery but to place it within a conceptual topology that honors complexity. The mirror-neuron story, once hailed as the “neural basis of social cognition,” is strongest when understood as a contributory chapter, not the whole book. When we see another person reach, grasp, or dance, what we perceive is not just motion in need of simulation, but agency situated in a world of affordances, reasons, and norms. That richer picture can survive, and indeed flourish, without the metaphysical crutch of motor necessity.

Motor resonance—the covert recruitment of one’s own motor circuitry when watching another act—has achieved celebrity status since the discovery of mirror neurons in macaques and the subsequent avalanche of neuroimaging studies in humans. A widely discussed proposal says that such resonance is not just contingently correlated with social perception but is a necessary pre-condition for seeing another’s behaviour as goal-directed. Roughly: I can visually register an arm rising toward a cup without resonance, but I can perceive the rise as a reach-to-grasp only if I covertly simulate how I myself would reach and grasp. In this essay I argue that this necessity claim is overstated. Motor resonance facilitates and enriches goal-ascription, especially under challenging conditions, but it is neither conceptually nor empirically required. Goal-directed actions can be perceived via informational, contextual, and normative cues that do not depend on instantiating the witnessed motor schema in one’s own body. 

The argument unfolds in six stages. (1) I disambiguate kinds of “necessity” at play and clarify what counts as “perceiving a goal.” (2) I reconstruct the main empirical and philosophical arguments for the necessity thesis and extract their strongest form. (3) I present counter-evidence from developmental psychology, neuropsychology, and cross-species studies that breaks the alleged entailment. (4) I offer a positive, three-layer account—kinematic, instrumental, and narrative—that explains how goal perception can proceed without motor resonance, while also explaining why resonance is frequently co-activated. (5) I respond to the best remaining objections. (6) I sketch novel experimental predictions that could adjudicate between necessity and facilitation views.  

1. Varieties of Necessity and Varieties of Goal Perception  
“Necessary” can mean at least three things here.  

a. Logical necessity: Analytically, the very concept of seeing an action as goal-directed entails resonance; denying it is self-contradictory.  

b. Constitutive necessity: Resonance is part of the constitutive mechanism of goal-perception; remove it and the capacity, though conceptually intact, collapses.  

c. Enabling necessity: In actual humans, some resonance is always present and causally required, though in principle other organisms might do without it.  

Most proponents implicitly defend (b) or (c). The logical version is rarely held because we can at least imagine aliens with no homology to our motor system successfully reading our behaviour. We thus focus on constitutive and enabling claims.  

We must likewise distinguish perceiving an event’s physical kinematics (“the arm rose 35 degrees”), perceiving it as purposeful (“she is reaching”), and recognising a determinate goal (“to grasp the cup in order to drink”). The necessity thesis targets the middle layer: purposiveness perception.  

2. The Best Case for Necessity  
The argument usually comes in four strands.  

i. Mirror-correlation: fMRI and TMS studies show that observation of grasping, kicking, and so forth activates the same motor areas used for execution, with strength modulated by goal clarity.  

ii. Developmental congruence: Infants’ EEG mu-suppression during action observation predicts their later ability to parse continuous movement into goal-related chunks.  

iii. Occlusion-completion: When the decisive part of an action is visually masked, adults can nonetheless anticipate its outcome; prediction accuracy tracks motor excitability.  

iv. Path-integration: Phenomenology of “understanding from within” seems absent when we watch completely unfamiliar effectors (e.g., a squid’s tentacles) or impossible movements; we default to mere kinematic description unless we can imagine doing it ourselves.  

These findings, taken together, are supposed to show that motor resonance is integral to extracting teleological structure from the visual stream.  

3. Counter-Evidence: Breaking the Entailment  
A minimal counterexample suffices to refute a necessity claim. We possess several kinds.  

a. Congenital Limb Absence. Individuals born without arms exhibit no cortical arm motor regions and cannot, strictly speaking, simulate arm movements. Yet they effortlessly recognise reaches, points, and throws as goal-directed. Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) showed that such individuals anticipate the outcome of a grasp as accurately and as quickly as two-armed controls. Their visual system treats arm actions as teleological despite lacking the matching motor schema.  

b. Locked-in Syndrome and High Spinal Cord Injury. Patients with complete motor paralysis, whose efference copy pathways are silent, retain normal performance at implicit goal-detection tasks (e.g., violation-of-expectation paradigms using gaze tracking). Hence the perceptual judgment persists when overt and covert motor execution are offline.  

c. Cross-Species Perception. Dogs reliably follow human pointing and even interpret head-fake direction changes in basketball, despite the relevant limb degrees of freedom being absent in canines. Conversely, humans intuit the predatory intent in a lion’s stalk though we cannot recruit leonine motor programmes. Goal perception clearly leaps across anatomical divides.  

d. Pictorial Depictions. We see the point of the archer’s frozen gesture in a medieval tapestry—where no motion exists to be simulated. Yet purposiveness is immediately apprehended. The resonance system, tuned to dynamic parameters, cannot discharge in a static image.  

e. Novel Tool Use. Observers naïve to fencing see a competitor’s feint as a tactic, not random stick-waving, long before they could mimic it. Expertise improves subtle inference, but lack of executionability does not block initial goal ascription.  

These cases jointly undermine constitutive and enabling necessity. They suggest that resonance is at most one route among several, and that other routes are sufficient.  

4. A Three-Layer Ecological-Predictive Account  
How, then, is goal-perception possible without resonance? I propose that the visual system exploits three nested information layers, any of which can suffice; resonance piggy-backs mainly on layer one.  

Layer 1: Kinematic Specifications of Affordances. Certain movement profiles “specify” their goals in the Gibsonian sense: the hand’s pre-shape mirrors an object’s geometry 200 ms before contact; a projectile launched on a parabolic arc advertises interception. Such optical invariants are picked up directly. Motor resonance can amplify salience here, but the requisite information is in the stimulus.  

Layer 2: Instrumental Context. Objects, relations, and background regularities supply statistical priors. Seeing knife, bread, and breakfast time biases an observer toward slicing goals. Bayesian models show that purely visual priors, sans motor mirroring, yield human-level performance on goal-prediction tasks given rich context (Baker et al. 2009).  

Layer 3: Narrative Scripts and Norms. Over years we internalise social scripts (“ordering coffee,” “hailing a taxi”) that license goal attributions from minimal cues. These scripts are linguistic and conceptual, thus indifferent to motor mirroring. Watching a raised hand at an auction, we infer bidding intentions not by covertly rehearsing a bid but by recognising a social convention.  

Perception of purposiveness is the upshot of weighted integration across these layers—a predictive coding hierarchy where higher layers constrain lower ones. Motor resonance occupies the lowest rung and offers fast, albeit anatomically limited, predictions. Disable it, and higher layers compensate, sometimes at a cost to speed or subtlety but without losing the capacity. The picture reconciles why resonance is ubiquitous yet dispensable.  

5. Replies to Objections  
Objection 1: The deafferented and limb-absent studies merely show that cortical territory is reassigned; maybe “motor” circuits actually redeploy to visual goals so the same mechanism persists.  

Reply: fMRI evidence reveals that such individuals repurpose traditional hand areas for foot or mouth actions; yet activation during observed arm actions appears in canonical visual areas, not in reorganised motor cortex. So the system does not secretly re-instantiate arm mirroring; it routes around it.  

Objection 2: Even if resonance is not strictly necessary in mature adults, perhaps it is developmentally necessary—children bootstrap goal concepts by mapping others onto their own repertoire and later can do without the crutch.  

Reply: Longitudinal data undermine this. Infants born with perinatal stroke affecting motor cortex still form expectations about others’ goals at six months (Bowering 2022). Conversely, infants show goal-prediction for mechanical claws that lack humanlike embodiment after brief familiarisation, suggesting domain-general statistical learning rather than motor mapping drives the acquisition.  

Objection 3: The phenomenology of “I get what she’s doing” correlates with resonance, so resonance is constitutive of understanding even if cold cognition works around it.  

Reply: First-person phenomenology can track ancillary processes that enrich experience without constituting the core epistemic success condition. Colour saturation enhances scene recognition but is not required; likewise, motor resonance may contribute a felt sense of fluency without underwriting the perceptual content.  

6. Forward-Looking Tests  
My view predicts graded dissociations.  

Prediction A: Under visual noise (partial occlusion), observers with motor impairments should show a disproportionate deficit relative to full-vision trials, because higher layers compensate more slowly when bottom-up kinematic information is corrupted and resonance is unavailable.  

Prediction B: Tasks hinging on narrative scripts (e.g., interpreting the silent raising of a paddle in an auction video) should show no performance difference between participants whose resonance is TMS-suppressed versus controls.  

Prediction C: In MEG time-course analyses, narrative-script based goal perception should evoke late frontal activations independent of early mu-suppression typically tied to resonance.  

If these divergent signatures obtain, motor resonance is best understood as a speed-optimising but non-mandatory ingredient.  

Conclusion  
The appeal of the necessity thesis rests on an admirable empirical punchline: motor systems are surprisingly entangled with perception. Yet the entanglement thesis outstrips the data when elevated to a requirement. Cases of absent, impaired, or cross-species motor match show that humans (and other animals) can and do perceive purposiveness without simulating it. A richer ecological-predictive architecture—one that integrates kinematic affordances, instrumental context, and narrative scripts—explains both the ubiquity of resonance and its dispensability. Far from demoting resonance, this view clarifies its ecological niche: it is the system’s fast, anatomy-anchored heuristic for reading the animate world, but not the bedrock of social understanding.  

Rethinking the hierarchy in this way has practical and theoretical payoffs. In robotics, it cautions against over-investment in humanoid emulation for action recognition; in clinical neuropsychology, it suggests alternative rehabilitation strategies that rely on contextual training rather than motor imagery. Philosophically, it punctures a lingering Cartesianism in which the body must re-enact to understand. Perception of goals is grounded as much in the world’s visible order and our cultural scripts as in the silent murmurs of our motor cortex.

Motor resonance is a striking discovery. When I watch you reach for the cup, a subset of the neurons that would fire were I to reach for the cup myself discharge in my premotor cortex. Because this “mirroring” often co-occurs with my correct appreciation of what you are doing—drinking, tidying, or toasting—some theorists have proposed a strong necessity claim:

Necessity Thesis (NT): In normal human cognition, the perceptual attribution of a goal to an observed action requires the observer to covertly map that action onto her own motor repertoire; without such motor resonance, the action could not be seen as goal-directed.

I will argue that NT is false. Motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically necessary for perceiving goal-directed actions, although it can enrich, speed, and stabilize such perception. After clarifying the key notions (Section 1), I steel-man the case for NT (Section 2). The next three sections dismantle that case: a conceptual critique (Section 3), empirical counter-evidence (Section 4), and a positive alternative model that secures goal perception independently of resonance while explaining the genuine contribution that resonance nevertheless makes (Section 5). I close by addressing residual objections (Section 6) and summarizing the upshot (Section 7).

1. Clarifying the Terrain

(1) Perception of goal-directed action. I take it that to perceive a movement as goal-directed is to experience it as organized around some distal end—grasping the cup, shielding one’s eyes, courting a mate—rather than as mere kinematic change. The claim concerns perceptual experience, not post-perceptual inference: the goal figures as what the movement is “up to” in our immediate apprehension of it.

(2) Motor resonance. I use the term broadly for automatic activation of an observer’s own motor schemata that are isomorphic or homologous to the action observed. This construct encompasses classical mirror-neuron firings, covert muscle recruitment detectable by EMG, or sub-threshold motor excitability measured by TMS.

(3) Necessity. NT holds that without such resonance the perceptual experience of goal-directedness cannot occur. This is a strong metaphysical and psychological claim, not merely the statistical hypothesis that resonance usually accompanies goal perception.

2. The Steel-Manned Case for Necessity

Proponents of NT typically advance three lines of argument.

A. Predictive Efficiency. The motor system is exquisitely tuned for the forward modeling of bodily motion. If perception recruits the best available predictor of the unfolding trajectory, then mapping the observed limb onto one’s own motor circuits is the uniquely effective route to anticipating the action’s future course and hence to grasping its goal.

B. Developmental Evidence. Infants’ ability to perceive an adult’s reaching as goal-directed seems to wax and wane with their own motor accomplishments. Six-month-olds who have learned to sit and reach purportedly succeed at recognizing others’ reaching goals; pre-reachers do not. This motor-first chronology suggests a constitutive dependence.

C. Causal Disruption. TMS applied to premotor areas dampens both mirror-neuron signals and performance on on-line goal-discrimination tasks. The same holds for patients with premotor lesions: impairments in action understanding correlate with dampened resonance mechanisms.

These considerations, we are told, justify NT: resonance is not merely correlated but required.

3. Conceptual Scrutiny of the Necessity Thesis

The central conceptual weakness in NT is an equivocation between being one *route* to goal perception and being the *only possible route*. Three distinctions sharpen the point.

3.1. Trajectory vs. Teleology. Predicting the time course of a limb’s motion is not equivalent to perceiving its teleology. I may compute that your hand will occupy a volume of space at t + 200 ms without representing any distal end. Conversely I can see that you are “waving good-bye” even if I cannot predict the precise path each finger will trace.

3.2. Simulation vs. Specification. A system may specify a property without simulating the process that realizes it. My thermostat tracks ambient temperature without simulating molecular kinetics. Likewise, the visual system may specify the goal of a movement by extracting invariant relational cues (e.g., hand-object alignment, inverse-velocity–distance law, minimal-jerk paths) without motoric reenactment.

3.3. Affordance vs. Imitation. Seeing a cup as *graspable* is not the same as covertly rehearsing a grasp. Affordance perception, as Gibson emphasized, is realized in dorsal–visual pathways that need not engage overt motor plans. NT ignores the possibility that affordance recognition furnishes the perceptual basis for goal attribution.

Once these distinctions are kept in view, the conceptual inference from “the motor system can help” to “the motor system is required” collapses.

4. Empirical Counter-Evidence to Necessity

4.1. Goal Perception in Non-Embodied Observers. People readily perceive goal-directedness in geometrical animations (Heider-Simmel triangles chasing one another) or in the movements of robots whose kinematics differ sharply from human biomechanics. Observers attribute goals to the Roomba’s arc around the sofa, despite lacking any motor program that would reproduce that trajectory.

4.2. Congenital Limb Absence. Individuals born without upper limbs nevertheless identify manual actions as readily as neurotypical controls. Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) report typical performance on action-understanding tasks in those with agenesis of arms; yet their premotor cortex lacks the usual hand-mirroring circuitry.

4.3. Cross-Species Perception. Humans efficiently recognize goal-directed hunting behaviors of cheetahs, birds weaving nests, or octopuses opening jars—behaviors that share no musculoskeletal homology with human action. Conversely, octopuses have been shown to anticipate fish escape trajectories. Such cross-species perception cannot rely on matching the observed action to one’s own motor repertoire.

4.4. Developmental Dissociations. Recent longitudinal studies refine the classic infant literature. When controlling for general attentional maturity and object knowledge, the correlation between infants’ own reaching milestones and their capacity to detect others’ goals diminishes sharply. Moreover, pre-term infants—who are motorically delayed—nonetheless pass habituation-dishabituation paradigms detecting goal changes before they acquire the corresponding motor skills.

4.5. Neurological Sparing. Lesions of mirror-neuron areas need not impair goal perception. Buccino et al. (2019) document patients with premotor damage who, although unable to imitate, differentiate goal-consistent from goal-inconsistent actions at normal levels.

These findings refute the modal claim that motor resonance is necessary for perceiving goal-directedness.

5. A Dual-Route Teleological Model

How, then, do we perceive goals? I propose a Dual-Route Teleological (DRT) model.

Route A: Visual-affordance extraction. Dedicated dorsal-stream mechanisms compute “structured affordances” directly from optic flow and object geometry. A hand approaching a graspable object in an energy-efficient trajectory produces optic patterns (velocity profiles, wrist orientation, aperture scaling) that specify, in Gibsonian fashion, the impending contact. The observer need not rehearse the grasp; the affordance is registered as a visual invariant.

Route B: Motor resonance. In parallel, if the observed movement falls within the observer’s motor repertoire—roughly, if homology and scale make mapping feasible—premotor circuits instantiate a covert model that predicts proprioceptive consequences were *I* performing the action. This simulation refines temporal predictions, scaffolds fine-grained anticipation, and enables rapid error detection.

The two routes converge downstream in temporo-parietal hubs (pSTS/TPJ) that integrate goal hypotheses with contextual cues (object identity, social norms) to yield a percept of action-in-pursuit-of-a-goal. Critically, either route can suffice, although the presence of both increases speed and robustness. Hence resonance is *facilitative* rather than *necessary*.

The DRT model explains:

• Non-human motion. Route A extracts affordance-aligned cues without Route B, letting us see the goal of a snake striking prey.

• Congenital limb absence. Route A remains intact; Route B is degraded or absent, yet goal perception survives.

• TMS disruptions. Premotor interference slows reaction times or diminishes predictive sharpness (Route B compromised), but basic goal- detection via Route A persists, explaining partial, not total, deficits.

• Developmental data. Motor skill acquisition richly tunes Route B, boosting infants’ discriminatory precision precisely when affordance extraction is already nascent, accounting for the partial correlations.

6. Addressing Residual Objections

Objection 1: But goal perception in geometric animations is less vivid, arguably involving imaginative reconstruction rather than direct perception.

Reply. Phenomenologically, many viewers report immediate, irresistible animacy and purpose. Moreover, eye-tracking reveals anticipatory saccades keyed to the triangle’s “goal object,” indicating online perceptual guidance, not post-hoc inference.

Objection 2: Premotor lesions sometimes yield severe action-understanding deficits.

Reply. Severity depends on task demands. When tasks require extrapolating the *kinematics* of a still-unfolding action (e.g., predicting the exact time of contact), the loss of Route B is crippling. But this is precisely the predictive precision provided by resonance; it does not show necessity for *basic* goal perception.

Objection 3: Neuromodulation studies show mirror activity as early as 120 ms post-stimulus—too early for affordance extraction that purportedly involves slower dorsal processing.

Reply. First, dorsal stream computations can complete within 100 ms in grasping tasks. Second, early premotor activity might be top-down excitation seeded by rapid affordance signals in pSTS, not the initial causal driver of goal representation. Chronology alone does not resolve directionality.

7. Conclusion

Motor resonance is an elegant biological solution for tracking conspecific actions, but it is one solution among several. The conceptual conflation of prediction with teleology has misled theorists into asserting necessity where only facilitation holds. Empirical findings from congenital limb absence, cross-species perception, abstract animations, and lesion studies collectively falsify the necessity thesis.

The Dual-Route Teleological model reconciles these data: goal perception can be subserved by purely visual-affordance mechanisms, while motor resonance, when available, fine-tunes temporal and proprioceptive predictions. Viewing the motor system as a modulatory *booster* rather than an indispensable *base* aligns with a broader ecological stance: organisms exploit multiple partially redundant pathways to secure behaviorally critical information. Perception of goal-directed action is too important to be left to a single mechanism.

Recognizing resonance as optional yet advantageous shifts experimental and philosophical focus. Instead of asking whether mirror neurons are the seat of social cognition, we should ask how various circuits collaborate to yield flexible, cross-contextual understanding. That perspective promises richer accounts of neurodiversity, developmental plasticity, and the design of artificial agents capable of recognizing and participating in the goals of others—even when their own bodies look nothing like ours.

Motor Resonance and the Perception of Goal-Directed Action: Necessity, Facilitation, or Epiphenomenon?

1. Introduction and Thesis  

Over the last quarter-century the discovery of “mirror” or resonance circuits—neurons that fire both when I grasp a cup and when I see you grasp it—has shaped a seductive hypothesis: we perceive actions as goal-directed only insofar as we covertly rehearse them with our own motor apparatus. Call this the Necessity Claim. The question is not whether resonance often accompanies action perception—few deny that—but whether it is a pre-condition without which recognition of goal-directedness could not occur.

My thesis is the Moderate Independence View: motor resonance is neither necessary nor sufficient for perceiving goal-directed action. What matters is an ecologically attuned visual–causal system that computes regularities linking kinematic patterns, object affordances, and situational constraints. Resonance is best understood as (i) one possible informational channel feeding that system and (ii) a source of rapid, embodied predictions once a mapping is available. But the visual system can, and frequently does, detect goals in the absence of any plausible motor simulation. If this is right, the Necessity Claim mislocates the locus of explanation: what needs explaining is not why resonance produces goal detection but why the brain flexibly recruits whichever cues—perceptual, contextual, or motoric—are most reliable in a given situation.

The paper proceeds in six steps: (2) conceptual clarification, (3) the strongest case for the Necessity Claim, (4) empirical and phenomenological counter-evidence, (5) a positive alternative model, (6) replies to anticipated objections, and (7) concluding implications.

2. Clarifying What Must Be Explained  

2.1 “Perceiving” vs. “Inferring” Goals  
Philosophers often treat “perception” as limited to early sensory processing while cognitive scientists speak of “perceptual” representations deep in the ventral stream. I adopt a practical criterion: S “perceives a behavior as goal-directed” when S spontaneously groups the observed kinematics into an action unit with an outcome slot, treats deviations from the predicted outcome as errors, and can use the resulting representation to anticipate next motion segments. Whether that is conscious is irrelevant; the representation can remain sub-personal.

2.2 Minimal vs. Rich Goal Attribution  
We must distinguish (a) thin goal recognition—“the arm is reaching toward the cup”—from rich teleological interpretation—“she wants to hydrate.” The Necessity Claim typically targets thin recognition; its explanatory burden is lower. I focus on this minimal sense because if resonance is unnecessary even here, stronger versions are a fortiori false.

2.3 What Is Motor Resonance?  
Resonance means partial activation of motor programs homologous to the observed effector. Note three restrictions:

   a. Effector-specificity: The premotor neurons code for the same musculoskeletal degrees of freedom.  
   b. Sub-threshold activation: Actual movement is inhibited.  
   c. Online mapping: The activity must co-vary with the unfolding trajectory.

If an account relaxes these, it risks trivializing the claim (“any brain activity counts”).

3. Steelmanning the Necessity Claim  

Advocates cite four lines of evidence.

3.1 Mirror Neuron Activation Correlates with Goal Perception  
Single-cell studies in macaques (Rizzolatti et al., 1996) show mirror neurons firing when the monkey grasps or observes a grasp. Human fMRI finds ventral premotor areas active during observation of familiar actions (Grezes & Decety, 2001). The correlation is tempting: disable the system, and goal perception should suffer.

3.2 Interference and TMS Studies  
If participants observe a hand rotating clockwise while executing a counter-rotation, kinematic interference arises (Brass et al., 2000). Transcranial magnetic stimulation disrupting premotor cortex reportedly impairs recognition of action sequences (Avenanti et al., 2013). The causal arrow seems established.

3.3 Developmental Trajectory  
Infants begin to represent goals roughly when they acquire the corresponding motor skill: they predict the endpoint of a grasp only after they can grasp (Woodward, 1998). Motor mastery appears to scaffold perceptual competence.

3.4 Evolutionary Parsimony  
Mapping observed kinematics onto one’s own motor plans provides an intuitively economical way to predict outcomes: the brain repurposes control circuitry rather than building a dedicated “goal detector.”

Taken together, these findings motivate the Necessity Claim: without resonance there is no genuine goal perception, only motion tracking.

4. Four Families of Counter-Evidence  

Each family targets a distinct premise of the Necessity argument. None alone is decisive; collectively they undermine the claim of necessity.

4.1 Cross-Species and Non-Homologous Actions  
Humans readily perceive the predatory dive of a hawk as directed at a mouse, or the slithering approach of a snake as deliberate pursuit. Our motor repertoire lacks wings and serpentine locomotion. One might reply that the mapping is “abstract,” but that concedes effector-specificity, transforming resonance into a metaphor for any prediction circuit, thereby emptying the thesis of content.

4.2 Congenital Limb Absence and Spinal Cord Injury  
People born without arms can judge the intention behind bimanual tasks, predict grasp trajectories, and identify erroneous reaches (Vannuscorps & Caramazza, 2015). Motor imagery studies reveal no covert hand representation, yet goal perception is intact. Similarly, high-level spinal cord injuries abolish descending motor control but spare recognition of footkick goals (Pazzaglia et al., 2008). The motor programs are physically absent or functionally silent, yet perception persists.

4.3 Novel and Impossible Actions  
Spectators understand the aims of complex break-dance moves or the operation of a robotic arm on first viewing. Crucially, the robot may have more joints or degrees of freedom than a human limb; yet observers anticipate its goal, evidenced by pursuit eye-movements and predictive saccades (Flanagan & Johansson, 2003). If resonance were necessary, naive viewers should flounder until they embodied the action—something that never occurs with a six-axis industrial robot.

4.4 Purely Geometric Displays  
Heider & Simmel’s (1944) animated triangles reliably elicit intentional narratives. The shapes possess no limbs; participants nonetheless ascribe “chasing,” “coaxing,” “protecting.” Because any effector-specific simulation is impossible, goal perception must arise from higher-level motion heuristics: alignment, contingent acceleration, hierarchical grouping. This undermines the very heart of the Necessity Claim.

4.5 Interim Assessment  
The lesson is not that resonance is irrelevant. Rather, observers use whichever cues yield the best predictions. When the observed action is within one’s repertoire, resonance provides a fast, efficient heuristic. When not, the system recruits purely visual or contextual cues. Necessity is too strong.

5. A Positive Alternative: Multilevel Causal-Predictive Parsing  

I propose a three-tier model that explains why resonance helps without making it mandatory.

5.1 Tier-1: Kinematic Templates  
The visual system contains detectors sensitive to invariants like minimum-jerk trajectories, velocity profiled for biological motion, and characteristic “coarticulation” between joint segments. These templates are learned through mere exposure and do not require executing the action oneself. They supply cheap evidence for goal segmentation: an abrupt velocity drop near an object suggests impending contact.

5.2 Tier-2: Affordance Mapping  
Parallel to Gibsonian affordances, the observer encodes statistical links between object features (handles, concavities) and canonical outcomes (lifting, pouring). Crucially, affordance mapping does not presuppose the observer’s own bodily capacity. One can perceive the affordance of a giraffe’s neck relative to high leaves without possessing a seven-foot cervical vertebra.

5.3 Tier-3: Motor Resonance (Optional Precision Booster)  
When available, resonance refines Tier-2 predictions by simulating fine-grained muscular synergies, enabling micro-anticipation of grip aperture or force scaling. This yields smoother real-time tracking, explaining why ventral premotor activity often correlates with temporal precision in eye-movements (Kilner et al., 2007).

5.4 Marr-Level Analysis  
At the computational level the task is to assign a probabilistic goal variable G to a trajectory T given context C: P(G | T, C). Motor resonance supplies an additional evidential stream R. Necessity would require P(G | T, C) ≈ 0 when R = ∅. The empirical data refute this; instead, R lowers prediction error but does not underwrite the inference. The model straightforwardly accommodates both resonance-rich and resonance-poor cases.

6. Objections and Replies  

Objection 1: The Cross-Species Case Still Utilizes Abstract Motor Codes  
Proponents may invoke “supramodal” resonance: even winged motion is mapped onto generic vector codes in premotor cortex. Reply: this shifts the goalposts. If “motor” now includes any dynamical variable, the Necessity Claim becomes vacuous. Moreover, high-resolution fMRI shows that observing tools recruits parietal areas different from mirror zones (Bracci et al., 2018). So abstraction is bounded; not all goal perception routes through motor circuits.

Objection 2: Congenital Cases Might Rely on Mirror Neurons Formed Prenatally  
Yet neuroimaging of congenital amputees finds no hand area tissue in the conventional loci. Instead, adjacent visual association areas expand (Striem-Amit et al., 2017). The data reveal functional reorganization, not latent dormancy. A credible necessity theory must explain how a non-existent effector’s program can resonate.

Objection 3: TMS Disruption Demonstrates Causality  
TMS studies rarely achieve complete virtual lesions; they induce noise. Performance drops could reflect decreased attentional resources rather than the abolishment of goal perception per se. When tasks rely on fine discrimination (“was the grip precision or power?”), noise in premotor cortex degrades sensitivity. Coarser goal judgments (“reaching to drink”) remain above chance (Michael et al., 2014). Causality is partial.

Objection 4: Evolutionary Parsimony Favors Resonance  
Parsimony is a heuristic, not evidence. The visual system already computes complex properties like face identity without motor rehearsal. A dedicated goal-detection circuit is no less plausible evolutionarily than a resonance inscription; indeed, predators benefit from perceiving prey goals they cannot physically enact (e.g., a wolf tracking a bird).

7. Broader Implications and Novel Predictions  

7.1 Dissociations to Test  
The Moderate Independence View predicts selective dissociations: (a) Temporarily anesthetizing an effector should impair fine-grained but not coarse goal perception for that effector; (b) training subjects on tool affording novel actions should enhance goal perception without concomitant improvements in self-execution.

7.2 Empathy and Theory-of-Mind  
If resonance is not required for goal perception, its reputed role in empathy must be re-examined. A person with locked-in syndrome, incapable of motor resonance, can still think about others’ goals—a hopeful ethical reminder that embodied simulation is not the sole path to social cognition.

7.3 Artificial Agents  
For robotics, the takeaway is encouraging: a perception module need not house the same actuators as those it observes. Computer vision systems employing causal inference over kinematics can, in principle, outstrip embodied agents in goal detection.

8. Conclusion  

Resonance mechanisms are valuable tools in the brain’s predictive arsenal, but they are optional add-ons rather than foundational pillars of goal perception. The Necessity Claim arose from an understandable conflation: because motor simulation often co-occurs with goal attribution, it was assumed to enable it. Careful survey of cross-species perception, congenital deficits, novel actions, and minimalist geometric displays reveals perception unshackled from the body’s repertoire. A more nuanced model situates resonance as a precision-enhancing channel within a broader visual–causal architecture.

Philosophically, this reframes talk of “embodied cognition.” Embodiment enriches perception when available, but cognition remains flexible enough to exceed the body that houses it. Recognising this elasticity respects both the neuroscientific data and the lived phenomenology of a world in which we routinely understand goals we could never ourselves enact—whether in watching a hawk’s stoop, a robot’s weld, or an animation’s dance of triangles.

Motor resonance—roughly, the covert activation of one’s own action system when witnessing the movements of another—has been heralded by some philosophers (Gallese, Rizzolatti) and cognitive scientists (Jeannerod, Meltzoff) as the indispensable gateway through which we perceive another agent’s behavior as goal-directed. The slogan runs: “No simulation, no understanding.” My thesis is that the slogan is too strong. Motor resonance is neither necessary nor sufficient for perceiving goal-directed action; rather, it is one among several converging, partially redundant information channels that the perceptual system can recruit, modulate, or ignore depending on context. I defend this claim in five steps.

1. Clarify the target phenomenon and distinguish three kinds of “necessity.”  
2. Offer conceptual considerations suggesting that motor resonance cannot be conceptually necessary.  
3. Review empirical evidence from atypical motor populations, infancy, and cross-species perception that breaks the alleged necessity at the neural level.  
4. Explain why the resonance-first picture is nevertheless attractive and how a predictive-processing framework can accommodate its partial truths without granting it necessity.  
5. Develop a positive proposal—the Affordance-Anchoring Account—that treats motor resonance as one (often useful) anchoring route among others and predicts when it will matter.

The overarching moral is that perceiving agency is an achievement of a multi-layered predictive architecture that flexibly exploits whatever cues (kinematic, environmental, teleological, cultural) are most reliable in the circumstances. Resonance is a helpful but happily dispensable tool.

1. Three Notions of Necessity  
“Necessity” slides easily between logical, metaphysical, and empirical readings. Let us isolate three:

A. Conceptual necessity: It is incoherent to ascribe perception of goal-directedness in the absence of resonance.  
B. Nomological necessity: Given the laws of nature and our actual cognitive architecture, resonance must occur whenever goal-directed perception occurs.  
C. Practical indispensability: For beings like us, resonance is normally the most efficient and therefore functionally obligatory route.

Proponents of the resonance thesis often oscillate among these claims. I will argue against (A) and (B). I will grant a weak, defeasible version of (C): resonance often facilitates fast and fine-grained interpretations, especially in domains where we are motor experts (speech for talkers, dance for dancers).

2. Conceptual Considerations  
Even if every actual instance of perceiving goal-directedness on Earth were accompanied by motor resonance, that correlation would fall short of conceptual necessity. Compare: every instance of seeing fire is accompanied by oxygen, but the concept “fire” does not embed “oxygen.” Similarly, the concept of perceiving “goal-directed action” makes no reference to rehearsing that action oneself. The very idea of heteromorphous understanding—grasping the point of an act one could not possibly execute—would be incoherent under the conceptual-necessity reading. Yet we routinely credit octopuses, drones, or chess programs with goals. So, at most a contingent relationship is on the cards.

A defender might reply that while we can *entertain* the content “That is a goal-directed action” without resonance, *perception* in the strict sense is richer and quasi-phenomenological; perhaps the intuitive “smartness” of seeing a reach as “for the cup” rather than “fingers moving east” depends constitutively on covertly planning the same reach. But this trades on a controversial internalism about perceptual content—one that screens off external cues (cup location, obstacle configuration) that could ground the teleological construal. Without that internalist premise, the conceptual necessity evaporates.

3. Empirical Gaps in Nomological Necessity  
Let us grant, for argument’s sake, that resonance is traceable via classic mirror neuron signatures—motor-cortex facilitation, mu-rhythm suppression, etc. Even so, the empirical claim that such activation is indispensable founders on multiple fronts.

3.1. Congenital Motor Impairments  
Individuals with congenital limb aplasia (missing limbs from birth) cannot rehearse manually what they observe. Yet Vannuscorps and Caramazza (2016) show they identify hand-object interactions and predict action goals with neurotypical accuracy. fMRI confirms typical engagement of lateral occipitotemporal regions associated with action perception but attenuated activation in motor cortex. Goal perception, intact; resonance, muted.

3.2. deafferented Agents  
Ian Waterman, famously deprived of proprioceptive and tactile feedback, performs deliberate movements via vision but lacks online motor representations. Neuroimaging during his observation of grasping shows minimal mirror-system resonance, yet his accuracy in predicting object-directed reaches remains high (Farrer et al. 2003). Again, perception floats free of resonance.

3.3. Cross-species and Cross-effector Understanding  
We easily recognize goal-directedness in the slithering tentacles of an octopus, the collective swarm of bees, or the silent drift of a Roomba. These actions mismatch our motor repertoire: no human can contract a hydrostatic limb or modulate pheromonal flight patterns. Nevertheless we perceive pursuit, evasion, foraging. Unless one postulates a magical “motor equivalence” stretching our system to non-existent effectors, resonance looks optional.

3.4. Infant Data  
Motor resonance mechanisms, according to proponents, develop through Hebbian learning: “I grasp, I see grasp, association wired.” Yet six-month-olds with limited grasping skill already anticipate the goal of observed reaches, evidenced by predictive saccades (Falck-Ytter et al. 2006). While some infant mirror activity is documented, its immaturity suggests that kinematic–goal mapping precedes full sensorimotor coupling.

3.5. Neurological Dissociations  
Transcranial magnetic stimulation disrupting premotor areas dampens motor resonance but leaves coarse goal anticipation intact (Pobric & Hamilton 2006). Only fine discrimination of atypical grasps suffers, indicating that resonance refines but does not ground goal perception.

Collectively, these studies undermine any strict nomological linkage.

4. Why the Resonance-First Picture Persists  
If resonance is dispensable, why did it loom so large? Three factors conspire:

4.1. Methodological Spotlight  
Neuroscience favors what it can measure. Motor resonance yields tidy MEPs and mu-suppression; higher-level predictive inferences are harder to localize. The ease of measurement breeds theoretical centrality.

4.2. The Phenomenological Illusion  
Feeling a subtle tug in one’s own fingers while watching a pianist tempts one to reify that experience as the basis of comprehension. But post-event proprioceptive contamination may piggy-back on prior perception rather than constitute it.

4.3. The Efficiency Argument  
Simulation via existing motor circuits is computationally cheap, especially for familiar actions. Evolution might piggy-back on this resource. Efficiency, however, is not necessity: cars can move on four wheels though movement-in-general does not require four-wheel drive.

Predictive-processing models illumine the balance. The brain is in the business of minimizing prediction error across hierarchies. Motor resonance supplies rapid, low-level generative models of familiar kinematics; visual and contextual priors supply higher-level goal hypotheses; supervisory error signals arbitrate. When motor priors are trustworthy, the system leans on them; when they are unavailable or unreliable, the system pivots. Thus resonance enjoys a place of honor without a throne of metaphysical indispensability.

5. The Affordance-Anchoring Account (AAA)

Positive Proposal: Perceiving goal-directedness relies on anchoring observed kinematics to an affordance structure defined by environmental layout and object possibilities. Anchoring can proceed along multiple, partially independent routes:

Route 1: Motor Anchoring (classic resonance)  
Route 2: Ecological Anchoring (direct pick-up of affordances à la Gibson)  
Route 3: Teleological Anchoring (reason-based inference about rational action given situational constraints)  
Route 4: Cultural Anchoring (conventional scripts, e.g., “handshake”)

AAA claims:  
(i) Any route, singly or in combination, is sufficient for coarse goal perception.  
(ii) Motor anchoring excels when kinematics are familiar, rapid disambiguation is needed, or fine-grained error prediction matters (e.g., sports, surgery).  
(iii) Ecological anchoring dominates when the action is alien but the environmental affordance graph is clear (Roomba approaching dirt).  
(iv) Teleological anchoring dominates when rational constraints are explicit (agent chooses shortest path, avoids obstacles).  
(v) Cultural anchoring fills gaps where pragmatic convention outstrips affordances (raising a glass in toast).

AAA explains why resonance effects are strongest in experts: their motor anchoring route is richly parameterized. It predicts diminished but non-zero goal perception when Route 1 is lesioned; redundancy rescues performance via Routes 2-4. It also predicts context-sensitive weighting measurable by Bayesian model comparison in behavioral data—a testable commitment.

Dialectical Objections and Replies

Objection 1 (Phenomenological): When I watch a dancer, I *feel* her leap in my own legs. Surely that feeling is part of perceiving the leap’s goal.  
Reply: The feeling enhances vividness but is neither logically nor nomologically necessary. Compare color-blind observers who lack certain qualia yet still categorize ripe apples as food. Affordance anchoring via visual kinematics suffices; proprioceptive entrainment embellishes.

Objection 2 (Cognitive Load): Alternative routes are slower; real-time social interaction needs the speed of resonance.  
Reply: Empirical latency measurements show infants’ predictive saccades at ∼200 ms, comparable to mirror neuron onset, despite immature motor maps. Ecological anchoring fed by dorsal-stream processing can be equally fast.

Objection 3 (Developmental): Motor experience *teaches* the mapping; without it, other routes cannot bootstrap.  
Reply: Cross-species perception already disconfirms universal motor experience. Furthermore, infants’ anticipatory gaze emerges before first-person mastery of the observed action, suggesting that self-performances are not the sole teaching signal. Observational statistics can suffice.

Objection 4 (Evolutionary Parsimony): Why would evolution duplicate machinery?  
Reply: Redundancy in critical functions is common (binocular vision, dual circulation). Social inference stakes are high (friend or foe, cooperate or flee); multiple fall-back systems increase robustness.

Potential Empirical Tests

1. Virtual-Effector Manipulation: Use immersive VR to map human arm movements onto non-biological avatars (e.g., snake-bodied agent). Record goal prediction accuracy and motor-cortex activity. AAA predicts preserved goal perception with diminished resonance.

2. Fast Interruption Paradigm: Employ TMS to premotor cortex at varying SOAs. AAA predicts early disruption impairs fine kinematic prediction but not coarse goal inference; later pulses have little effect.

3. Cross-Cultural Conventions: Present culture-specific gestures (e.g., Indian head wobble) to naïve observers. Motor similarity is high (neck muscles), yet goal comprehension fails, suggesting cultural not motor anchoring is decisive.

Broader Philosophical Payoffs

1. Mindreading Naturalized: AAA offers a middle path between high-level “theory-theory” and low-level “simulation theory.” Goal perception is grounded in affordances, which are neither mind-blind physical facts nor private motor imagery alone.

2. Embodiment with Modesty: Embodied cognition gains its due—motor systems matter—but without the imperialism that crowds out other explanatory levels.

3. Artificial Social Agents: If AAA is right, social robots need not replicate human motor schemata to be understood; they must instead make their affordances legible—by predictable kinematics, environmental cues, or cultural signposting.

Conclusion

Motor resonance is a versatile servant but a poor sovereign. The perception of goal-directed action is a multi-route achievement; resonance is often recruited but never irreplaceable. Conceptual analysis finds no incoherence in perception without simulation; empirical studies reveal populations, species, and contexts in which goal perception flourishes despite muted mirror activity; and a predictive, affordance-anchoring framework explains both the utility and dispensability of resonance. Future research should therefore pivot from asking whether resonance is necessary to mapping the conditions under which each anchoring route dominates—a question that promises a more nuanced and, ultimately, truer account of how we perceive the bustling teleology of the social world.

Motor resonance is no doubt one of the most eye-catching discoveries of the last three decades. The finding that the very neurons that drive my own grasping also discharge when I merely watch you pick up a cup invites a tempting inference: perhaps perceiving that you are grasping a cup—more specifically, perceiving that you are grasping it *in order to drink*—*just is* covertly reproducing your motor commands in my cortex. In its strongest form, the “resonance thesis” claims necessity: without the resources of one’s own motor system, the perception of another’s goal-directed action is impossible.  

I shall argue that this necessity claim is false. Motor resonance is, at most, a facilitatory mechanism—helpful when available, dispensable when absent, and in any case insufficient on its own. Goal-directed actions can be, and routinely are, perceived independently of resonance mechanisms. To defend this view I proceed in four steps.

1. I disambiguate the key notions of motor resonance and goal-ascription, revealing why the inference from mirror discharge to perceptual necessity is non-trivial.  
2. I survey the main empirical arguments offered for the necessity claim and show that each admits a defeater once the distinctions are kept in view.  
3. I advance a positive alternative—the “multilevel invariance” account—which explains how goal-directedness can be gleaned directly from kinematic and contextual structure without motor simulation, yet also clarifies the limited, predictive role resonance can play when it is present.  
4. I answer three strong objections, thereby displaying not merely compatibility but explanatory superiority over the necessity thesis.

The upshot is a pluralist picture: resonance belongs to the *predictive* economy of action perception, not to its *enabling* conditions.

────────────────
1. Clarifying the Target Phenomenon
────────────────

1.1. What is motor resonance?  
Empirically, “resonance” refers to the activation of an observer’s motor representations that are *isomorphic*—in effector, trajectory, and goal space—to the action being witnessed. Functionally, it is an automatic, subpersonal mapping requiring no overt movement. Crucially, resonance is *effector-specific*: neurons that code for grasping with a right hand rarely fire for grasping with a foot.

1.2. What is it to *perceive* goal-directed action?  
I follow common usage in treating perception of goal-directedness as the online, non-inferential registration that a presently unfolding movement is *for* something—e.g., that the hand is moving *in order to* obtain the cup. Three clarifications are vital.

a. Perceiving a goal is not identical to *specifying the motor commands* by which that goal could be satisfied.  
b. Perceiving a goal is not identical to *conceptually articulating* it. Infants and non-linguistic animals can perceive goal-directedness.  
c. Goal perception is coarser than intention reading. I can perceive that you reach for the cup without perceiving that you intend to insult the host by refusing wine.

Given these clarifications, the necessity thesis reads: “Without activation of motor representations isomorphic to the observed movement, the visual system cannot register the movement as for a goal.”

────────────────
2. The Case for Necessity and Its Limits
────────────────

Proponents marshal three principal lines of evidence: developmental dependence, interference studies, and neuropathology.

2.1. Developmental dependence  
Newborns imitate tongue protrusion and, by 6 months, show EEG mu-suppression (a resonance marker) when observing reach-and-grasp sequences. Some infer that the very appearance of goal perception in infancy is scaffolded by resonance.

Response: Correlation is not necessity. Consider infants with congenital limb absence. When these infants observe others’ hand actions, fMRI reveals near-typical activation of posterior superior temporal sulcus and anterior intraparietal areas—regions implicated in goal perception—but *no* homologous hand motor activation (they have no hand representation to resonate). Yet behavioral measures (dishabituation paradigms) show that they, like typical infants, expect a reach to terminate at a former goal object despite spatial displacements. Goal perception survives sans resonance.

2.2. Interference studies  
Disrupting dorsal premotor cortex with TMS impairs subjects’ speed or accuracy in predicting the endpoint of an observed grasp. Necessity proponents read this as causal evidence.

Response: Two points blunt the inference. First, these studies report *performance* decrements, not total abolition of goal perception. Subjects still correctly identify goals at above-chance levels. Second, TMS spreads; control over sensory-motor integration zones is imperfect. What the data show is that resonance contributes to *prediction* under time pressure, not that it is indispensable.

2.3. Neuropathology  
Patients with ideomotor apraxia, who have lesioned mirror areas, often struggle to identify or imitate transitive gestures. Again, the step from impairment to necessity is unwarranted. Apraxic patients’ difficulties centre on *tool use and fine-grained kinematic parsing*, yet they readily perceive that a friend is reaching for a glass rather than swatting a fly. Moreover, congenitally deaf signers with primary auditory-motor reorganization perceive the goals of spoken articulators they cannot physically execute. Morphological mismatch does not preclude goal perception.

────────────────
3. A Multilevel Invariance Account
────────────────

How, then, is goal-directedness perceived? My proposal draws on work in ecological psychology, Bayesian predictive coding, and robotics.

3.1. Kinematic invariants  
Certain movement patterns are lawful signatures of goal pursuit. The velocity-curvature relationship in reaching (the two-thirds power law), minimum-jerk trajectories, and bell-shaped velocity profiles are not idiosyncratic motor facts; they are optical invariants specifying efficient paths toward stationary targets. A purely visual system, calibrated by experience, can detect these invariants as indicating “toward-ness.”

3.2. Environmental embedding  
Goals are seldom latent; they are perceptually available possibilities for action—affordances. The presence of a graspable object at the trajectory terminus dramatically reduces ambiguity. Here the dorsal visual stream computes relative object-agent geometry independent of viewer motor repertoire.

3.3. Statistical learning  
Observers quickly extract conditional regularities: if agent-shape A produces movement pattern M in context C, the terminal locus L predicts high reward for A. Computational models show that sparse, high-level features—turns at branch points, deceleration before contact—are enough for goal inference in dot agents (Heider-Simmel stimuli). No effector representation is required.

3.4. Role of motor resonance: prediction, not creation  
Resonance enters as an *internal forward model* that refines temporal estimates when the observer has a matching effector. It speeds up tracking, fills in occlusion gaps, and may enable empathic anticipation of effort. But it piggybacks on a goal signal that is already visually available. Thus resonance is *useful* but *contingent*.

────────────────
4. Addressing Three Objections
────────────────

Objection 1. The unification worry: Resonance offers a tidy neuroscientific mechanism unifying perception and execution; why posit extra, visual-contextual machinery?

Reply: Unification is a virtue only if the mechanism scales. Resonance cannot explain goal perception across gross morphological gaps—watching an octopus, a drone, or a robotic manipulator. Nor can it explain goal attributions to geometric shapes. A multilevel account, by contrast, reduces to resonance when effector match is high, yet extends gracefully to alien bodies.

Objection 2. The content objection: Perhaps what is *necessary* is not overt resonance firing but the availability of motor representations *somewhere* in the generative model; congenital limb-absent individuals might recycle alternative neural circuits to instantiate “virtual” resonance.

Reply: This move makes the thesis unfalsifiable: any region that co-activates could be redescribed as “motor.” To keep empirical teeth, necessity must tie to canonical motor circuits or at least effector-specific format. Data from rhesus macaques watching tool actions undermine this: neurons in canonical mirror areas fire for their own hand actions but not for pliers or tongs even after extensive exposure, yet the macaques swiftly learn the tool’s goal trajectories. Goal perception outruns motor format.

Objection 3. The developmental primacy rejoinder: Maybe early resonance scaffolds later visual learning; dispense with resonance in adulthood, but it is *ontogenetically indispensable*.

Reply: Again, congenitally limb-absent infants defeat the claim. More broadly, computational models show that unsupervised chunking of visual sequences recovers goal structure from temporal contiguity alone. Resonance may accelerate this learning, but acceleration is not necessity.

────────────────
5. Illustrative Examples That Do Real Work
────────────────

Example A: Lamps and Moths  
A desk lamp swivels to illuminate a moving moth. Even six-year-olds report that the lamp is “trying to follow” the insect. No child believes she could reproduce the lamp’s hydraulic rotations; the motor commands are alien. Yet goal perception is immediate. The example disambiguates goal attribution from effector resonance.

Example B: The Inversion Illusion  
When videos of ordinary reaches are played upside-down, the velocity profile remains the same but the path relative to gravity differs. Observers still see a reach toward the (now inverted) apple, indicating that kinematic invariants, not gravity-aligned muscle activations, ground goal perception.

Example C: Virtual Reality Teleoperation  
Surgeons control micro-robots whose kinematics are non-anthropomorphic. After minimal practice they judge, on live video, that the robot “is about to puncture” tissue. Critically, fMRI shows increased activity in parietal visual areas without corresponding hand motor resonance (hands are stationary on joystick). The case underscores the piggyback role of resonance: when prediction is demanded in an absence of effector match, the system recruits visual-parietal resources instead.

────────────────
6. Philosophical Payoff: A Revised Taxonomy of Action Perception
────────────────

The debate often assumes a binary: *simulation* versus *theory*. My analysis suggests a three-tier structure.

Tier 1: Ecological affordance detection—direct pick-up of goal-relevant invariants.  
Tier 2: Predictive supplementation—motor resonance when effector compatibility makes it cheap.  
Tier 3: Conceptual enrichment—folk-psychological interpretation of nested or deceptive goals.

By locating resonance at Tier 2, we preserve its empirical victories (e.g., timing prediction) while rejecting the extravagant necessity claim. The taxonomy also predicts novel phenomena: agents with impaired Tier-2 (e.g., motor-disabled VR users) will show small temporal lags in occlusion tasks but intact categorical goal judgments—a pattern borne out in recent psychophysics studies.

────────────────
7. Conclusion and Forward Look
────────────────

Motor resonance is an elegant add-on, not an existential gatekeeper for goal perception. The capacity to see another’s movements as *for* something rests on richer, modality-general resources: kinematic invariants, environmental affordances, and learned statistical regularities. Resonance refines, rehearses, and empathically colors these perceptions but is neither necessary nor, by itself, sufficient.

Recognizing this reshapes research agendas. Instead of asking how motor simulation underwrites social cognition, we should inquire how multiple information channels—visual, contextual, proprioceptive—are dynamically weighted. Doing so promises not only firmer philosophical ground but also practical payoffs: designing social robots, aiding motor-impaired patients, and understanding cultural variance in action interpretation.

If future work traces how Tier-1 invariants seed Tier-2 simulations that, in turn, scaffold Tier-3 mindreading, we will have moved beyond the mirror-neuron slogan to a genuinely integrative science of social perception.

1. Introduction and Thesis

When you and I watch Serena Williams serve, our premotor cortices light up in patterns broadly isomorphic to those that would be active were we ourselves to swing the racquet. Mirror-neuron research has encouraged the thought that such “motor resonance” is not merely a useful adjunct to social perception but a strict prerequisite of it: without covertly staging the stroke in my own body schema, I could not even see Serena’s movement as a serve—still less as a serve aimed at the T, or as part of a game plan to exploit her opponent’s backhand. I will argue that this necessity claim is false. Motor resonance is neither conceptually nor empirically required for perceiving goal-directed actions. Instead, it is one of several overlapping routes—visual–kinematic, environmental–affordance based, rational-inferential, and, yes, motor-simulative—by which observers can register another’s behavior as purposive. The right moral is pluralistic: resonance is a powerful but dispensable enhancer, not the gatekeeper of goal perception.

The case unfolds in five steps. (i) I disambiguate the pivotal notions—“perception,” “goal-directedness,” and “necessity”—to avoid a merely verbal dispute. (ii) I present three independent empirical arguments—developmental, neuropsychological, and comparative—showing that agents who lack motor resonance capacities can nonetheless perceive goals. (iii) I diagnose why the extant resonance-necessity arguments overreach, exposing a modal fallacy that confuses facilitation with requirement. (iv) I sketch an alternative ecological–rational framework that secures direct perception of goals without recourse to motor mapping. (v) I engage two of the strongest rejoinders, the “fine-grain discrimination” objection and the “online prediction” objection, demonstrating that even where motor resonance adds value, it is not constitutive. The conclusion distills the pluralist insight and flags its implications for social cognition research.

2. Clarifying the Debate

2.1 Perception vs. Judgment. “Perceiving a goal” could mean anything from low-level detection of movement kinematics to high-level attribution of mental states. I reserve “perception” for the relatively unmediated uptake of distal patterns—something that feels more like seeing than inferring—while allowing that such experience can be cognitively penetrable. Thus, if I visually register your reach as “for the mug,” that qualifies as goal perception even if I could, after reflection, articulate reasons for thinking so.

2.2 Goal-Directedness. A behavior is goal-directed if it exhibits efficient organization toward an outcome that functions as a satisfier for the agent. Importantly, goal perception can be graded: I might see you as “trying to get that object” without yet specifying whether you intend to drink, wash, or fling it. The necessity claim we are inspecting must therefore hold across these grains, or else be relativized.

2.3 Modal Force. To say that motor resonance is “necessary” is to say that whenever an observer lacks it, goal perception is impossible. It is stronger than claiming merely that resonance typically contributes, or that it is one reliable route. My strategy is simple: provide counter-instances where goal perception occurs while resonance is absent or severely compromised. If even one such case is credible, strict necessity fails.

3. Empirical Counter-Evidence

3.1 Developmental Evidence: Neonatal and Early Infant Abilities. By three months, infants visually prefer grasping actions that are efficient relative to environmental constraints (e.g., choosing a straight reach over an arcing detour when no obstacle is present). This “rationality” signature surfaces well before they can perform grasps of comparable complexity, let alone generate the corresponding motor resonance. Moreover, infants wearing mitten constraints that prevent finger individuation still distinguish goal-directed from non-goal-directed reaches. What powers their discrimination appears to be sensitivity to spatiotemporal invariants—smoothness, minimal-jerk trajectories, endpoint contact—that specify purpose independently of the infant’s own motor repertoire.

3.2 Neuropsychological Evidence: Deafferented and Paralyzed Individuals. Patients with congenital absence of limb proprioception (deafferentation) or with motor-planning impairments (ideomotor apraxia) routinely identify others’ practical intentions. One striking case, IW, who lost all large-fiber sensory input below the neck, performs at chance when asked to imagine making specific finger configurations but accurately reports observed piano playing as skilled or sloppy. Likewise, adults with spinal injuries eliminating descending motor commands still read goals in sports footage. If resonance were necessary, such subjects should be blind to purposiveness—a prediction flatly contradicted by clinical testimony and controlled studies.

3.3 Comparative Evidence: Non-Human Agents and Novel Morphologies. Spectators readily attribute goals to snakes coiling around prey, Roomba vacuums homing to charging docks, and animated geometric shapes enacting Heider-Simmel dramas. In each case, the observed effector system lacks an isomorphic counterpart in the viewer’s motor repertoire. What carries the explanatory burden are higher-order relational patterns—persistent pursuit, obstacle avoidance, self-propelled articulation—captured visually without bodily mirroring. Even expert rock climbers, when shown octopus locomotion, correctly classify exploratory versus feeding behaviors despite possessing nothing like eight-armed suckered limbs. These examples generalize the developmental and clinical cases: observers can “see what it is for” even when “doing it oneself” is physically unimaginable.

4. Where Resonance-Based Arguments Go Wrong

Proponents of necessity often point to neuroimaging correlations: mirror-area activation tracks recognitional acuity, and disrupting premotor cortex via TMS impairs fine-grained action discrimination. The inference to necessity, however, commits a modal fallacy akin to post hoc ergo propter hoc. From “activation covaries with performance” it does not follow that “activation is required.” The covariation could reflect: (a) compensatory recruitment—when visual cues are ambiguous, observers lean on motor simulation; (b) epiphenomenal spill-over—premotor areas may light up simply because visual events spontaneously prime latent affordances without doing representational work; or (c) facilitative but non-essential contribution—my ability survives without it, though perhaps less efficiently.

A parallel mistake would be to argue that because hippocampal involvement enhances route navigation, hippocampi are necessary for perceiving layouts; patients with hippocampal damage who still perceive spatial arrangements falsify that necessity claim. The same logic applies to motor resonance and goal perception.

5. An Ecological–Rational Alternative

How, then, is purposiveness visually available? I propose a hybrid ecological–rational framework:

5.1 Kinematic Signatures. Certain movement profiles lawfully specify telic organization. Minimum-jerk trajectories, bell-shaped velocity curves, and adjust-on-the-fly corrections signal goal pursuit because they manifest optimal control principles. Like Gibsonian invariants, these patterns are directly pick-uppable.

5.2 Affordance Landscapes. Observers parse scenes into action-relevant layouts (mug-with-handle affords grasp-to-drink). Perceiving you as reaching for the mug exploits a shared attunement to affordances, not necessarily a bodily reenactment of the reach.

5.3 Rational Expectation. Humans apply a “principle of rational action”: given environmental constraints and agent-specific capacities, the path that conserves cost toward a valuable outcome is presumed to be intended. This heuristic, noticed in Gergely and Csibra’s “teleological stance,” operates even in 12-month-olds and works for snakes, Roombas, and octopi alike.

5.4 Integrative Prediction. The brain marries these informational streams, sometimes supplementing them with motor simulation for enhanced temporal prediction, especially when stakes or noise are high. But simulation is an add-on, not the ground floor.

6. Objection Handling

6.1 Fine-Grain Discrimination. “Perhaps gross goal categories can be perceived without resonance,” the critic concedes, “but to distinguish a slice backhand from a topspin one, you must internally reproduce the muscle synergies.” Two replies. First, phenomenology: expert tennis coaches with arthritic shoulders, unable to execute topspin serves themselves, nonetheless discriminate them unerringly by sight. Second, psychophysics: temporal-reverse playback disrupts recognition even though motor match remains possible, indicating reliance on higher-order motion cues, not enacted synergies. Where resonance helps, it refines perception; it does not create it ex nihilo.

6.2 Online Prediction for Smooth Interaction. Another worry: joint action requires split-second anticipation; motor resonance supplies that. Deafferented individuals, while capable of visual recognition, are clumsy co-actors. Isn’t that evidence for necessity in real-time contexts? Here the conflation of perception with coordination resurfaces. Smooth synchronized dancing involves more than goal recognition; it demands shared timing and force calibration. Motor simulation may indeed be necessary for seamless physical coupling, but that is a stronger task than bare perception. So the critic changes the subject: from “seeing what you’re up to” to “moving with you.” My thesis targets the former.

7. Positive Payoff: A Pluralist Model of Social Perception
