Specialized ion channels (HCN, calcium) form pacemaking membranes; Cycles of phosphorylation act as molecular gears; Output neurons project to sleep–wake and hormonal systems; Jet-lag is their misrepresentation. By the same token, a wristwatch is a prosthetic sensory organ for the human who consults it: they literally perceive the time by visually reading a device whose internal physical evolution reliably encodes elapsed time.

7. A Novel Distinction: Causal Source vs. Causal Condition

The causal-impotence objection conflates two roles:

Source condition: the property P itself must be the source of causal energy that alters S.  
Constraint condition: the obtaining of P must be a necessary condition, under background laws, for S occupying a certain state.

For standard exteroception (vision, audition), the two conditions coincide—photons both supply energy and their presence is required. For time-sense they come apart. Elapsed time is not a source but remains a constraint: under physical law, no pendulum can complete 86,400 periods without 24 sidereal hours having passed. Representation requires only the constraint, not the source. The distinction generalizes: thermostats, fuel gauges, and even logical clocks in distributed computing track abstract quantities (average kinetic energy, remaining fuel, causal order) via constraint conditions.

8. An Analogical Deep Dive: Logical Clocks in Distributed Systems

Lamport’s logical clocks timestamp events in a network--critical to ensuring causal ordering without a shared physical time. Each process increments a local counter on events, piggybacks the counter in messages, and merges max values received. The counter value is not driven by time at all; it is driven by message traffic. Yet under causal assumptions (messages travel forward in causal order), the counter encodes “happened-before.” This shows that genuine temporal information can be bootstrapped from relational structure alone. Biological timekeeping does something similar: chemical oscillators, coupled by phase-response curves, synchronize to yield a shared metric suitable for coordination.

9. Addressing Two Residual Concerns

9.1. Time Dilation and Relativity  
Special relativity teaches that rates of processes vary with velocity and gravitational potential. Does this undermine the claim that clocks sense time? No, for representation is always relative to a reference frame built into the normal conditions of use. An airplane’s onboard clock “runs slow” compared to Earth’s surface; still, within its design frame it measures proper time along its world-line. Relativistic physics simply shows there are many temporal magnitudes (coordinate time, proper time). A sensor can be tuned to any one of them.

9.2. Illusion of Flow  
Some philosophers argue that the felt flow or passage of time is illusory, so no sense could detect it. My argument targets a humbler notion: sensing duration and temporal order, not metaphysical flow. A visual system need not detect “noumenal extension” to measure distance. Likewise, temporal sensory systems need not resolve the A-series debate to code intervals.

10. Toward a Research Program: Temporal Perception as Structural Inference

Taking the foregoing seriously suggests a broader view: perceptual systems are detectors of invariant structure, not necessarily of substance-like stimuli. Vision recovers 3-D shape by exploiting projective invariances; audition derives pitch from harmonic structure. Time perception recovers duration by exploiting lawful regularities in cyclic or accumulative processes. What unifies sensory modalities, then, is not energy transduction but structural inference under nomic covariance. This framing invites new empirical projects—e.g., designing synthetic bio-oscillators to plug into animal nervous systems and asking whether the animal thereby acquires an additional “sense” of ultradian rhythm.

11. Conclusion

The causal-impotence objection presupposes an outdated transduction model of perception. Once we replace that with an information-theoretic and teleosemantic analysis, the obstacle disappears. A clock—be it a pendulum, an atom, or a gene network—carries information about elapsed time because the evolution of its internal state is lawfully constrained by temporal relations, even though “time itself” exerts no push. Biological organisms exploit these law-bound correlations to guide behavior, satisfying all the marks of a genuine sensory modality. There is, in this perfectly ordinary sense, a sense of time.

How can a mechanism, biological or artifactual, carry information about elapsed time when “time itself” seems unable to do anything—unable, that is, to push, pull, illuminate, or otherwise causally impinge on a sensor in the way that photons impinge on a retina?  The objection turns on a picture of perception in which (i) a sensory organ is activated by the very environmental feature it represents and (ii) representing requires that sort of activation.  I shall argue that both conjuncts are false.  Once we distinguish four ways something can “carry information,” the sense–data picture of perception loses its grip, and it becomes plain how clocks, brains included, can represent temporal properties without depending on “causal influence” from time.  I close by suggesting that the resulting account is not merely defensive: it reveals why the human sense of duration has the curious profile it does (mid-range accuracy, systematic contextual distortions, and susceptibility to entrainment).

I.  Clarifying the Target

Call the objection the Causal Impotence Argument (CIA):

1. A system S can represent environmental feature F only if S is causally influenced by F.
2. Time (or “bare time,” as opposed to events occurring in time) does not causally influence anything.
∴ 3. No system can represent time; there is no sense of time.

The first premise conflates two distinct claims: an etiological claim about how a representational system ever comes to be correlated with F, and a synchronic claim about how it maintains specific correlations on a given occasion.  Both may fail even for paradigmatic senses.  Smell responds to volatile chemicals, but its evolutionary function is to track not “methyl-mercaptan molecules” as such but food, predators, or mates; the proximal cause and the represented property diverge.  Similarly, binocular vision represents depth by exploiting disparity in retinal images; depth itself does not hit the retina.  The antecedent of (1) therefore needs tightening.

II.  Four Grades of Informational Involvement

To see how clocks, neural or brass, get informational purchase on time, keep distinct the following:

A. Causal Imprint: the feature F physically impinges on S in a way that depends continuously on F’s magnitude (light on photoreceptors).

B. Law-Governed Covariation: the state of S is nomically locked to the value of F, even if F does not push S; think of a gyroscope indicating inertial orientation.

C. Calibration Link: S has been tuned (by learning or evolution) in an environment where its states statistically correlate with specific ranges of F.

D. Functional Expectation: downstream systems treat S’s states as indicative of F, whether or not the correlation presently holds (this covers hallucination and misperception).

Clocks exploit B–D.  The hand position of an escapement clock covaries with the temporal parameter t because Newtonian dynamics guarantee a near-constant period for a pendulum of length L in a given gravitational field.  No one imagines that “time pushes the pendulum”; rather, the angle of displacement θ(t) is a solution to the differential equation  d²θ/dt² + (g/L)sin θ = 0.  Once such a law is in place, correlational information is freely available.  The mechanism merely has to be readable.

III.  The Gyroscope Analogy

Orientation with respect to inertial space (call it Ω) is another causally impotent quantity:  facing North does not shove your iPhone’s gyroscope.  Yet micro-electro-mechanical gyroscopes represent Ω by conserving angular momentum in vibrating masses.  Their outputs drive navigation software; we call that “sensing orientation.”  If CIA were sound, we would have to deny that smartphones, desert ants, or pigeons represent heading.  The better lesson is that law-governed covariation (II.B) suffices for representation once a consumer system treats the signal as such (II.D).

IV.  Clocks in Flesh and Silicon

1. Circadian clocks.  The SCN (suprachiasmatic nucleus) in mammals contains coupled feedback loops of gene expression with a free-running period of ~24.2 h.  The state of phosphorylation of PER proteins at any moment is not caused by “time” but by earlier states of the same molecular network plus thermal noise.  Light input does calibrate the oscillator, but after lesion studies we know the loop can run for weeks in isolation culture.  The system embodies a dynamical law; reading any phase variable provides information about elapsed time since the last entraining cue.

2. Interval timing in cortex and basal ganglia.  On the most widely supported models, the brain measures intervals in the hundreds of milliseconds to tens of seconds by detecting the trajectory of population activity in recurrent networks with slowly decaying excitatory or inhibitory currents.  Eigenvalue spectra of such networks give them quasi-linear state-space rotations:  the location of the network’s activity bump after initial stimulation maps onto an elapsed-time estimate.  What drives the change of state?  Endogenous neural dynamics plus baseline noise—not “time as force.”

3. Atomic clocks.  Cesium-133 atoms absorb microwaves of 9 192 631 770 Hz when transitioned between hyperfine ground states.  If the microwave cavity frequency drifts, feedback adjusts it until absorption peaks.  Again, no mysterious temporal “kick” is required; quantum transitions follow the Schrödinger equation with t as a parameter, and that suffices for law-governed covariation.

V.  Answering the Harder Objections

Objection 1:  Covariation without causal influence is too cheap — everything covaries with everything under a contrived function.  

Reply:  Information-carrying covariation must be lawful and exploitable by some consumer mechanism.  The pendulum’s phase is a monotone function of real time over significant ranges, and gear trains translate that phase into an analog of t that can guide action (winding the clock, catching a train, etc.).  Arbitrary correlations lack that double anchor in law and function.

Objection 2:  Law-dependence only relocates the mystery; why should a law with t-parameters count as representing t instead of merely unfolding?  

Reply:  Representation is partially pragmatic: a state represents F when the system that uses it treats it as varying with F.  Our SCN projects to almost every major hypothalamic nucleus; feeding, thermoregulation, and hormone release depend on its phase.  Interfering with the clock’s outputs produces behavioral disarray similar to jet lag.  This robust downstream exploitation is absent for, say, the correlation between nail growth and t, so nail length does not function as a timer even though it covaries lawfully with age.

Objection 3:  Even if mechanisms track local duration, they cannot deliver a perceptual “sense” of time because perception is by definition exteroceptive.

Reply:  Two replies.  (a) Some acknowledged senses (proprioception, nociception, equilibrioception) are introceptive; what matters is not input modality but informational role.  (b) Psychophysically, humans make direct comparative judgments of duration (e.g., interval b is longer than a) with Weber fractions similar to brightness judgments.  The systematic illusions (subjective dilation during oddball or threat stimuli, compression during saccades) parallel biases in standard senses.  The simplest explanatory unification is to class duration-tracking alongside them.

VI.  Why the Human Sense of Time Has Its Character

Our account predicts three empirical features.

1.  Mid-range accuracy.  Because neural oscillators are noisy, Weber fractions for interval timing hover around 10 %.  That is exactly what one expects from integration in a drift-diffusion process with multiplicative noise.

2.  Contextual distortion.  If duration coding piggybacks on population trajectories that are also modulated by attention, arousal, or prediction error, then transient spikes in dopaminergic midbrain activity will distort subjective time.  This matches the observed correlation between dopamine agonists and time-overestimation.

3.  Entrainment.  Because calibration links matter (II.C), periodic exteroceptive cues such as day–night cycles entrain internal clocks.  Missed cues (e.g., cave experiments) reveal the free-running period.

VII.  A Residual Worry:  Time’s Relativity

A final worry:  the mechanisms described assume Newtonian background time, yet in relativity there is no absolute global t.  Does the clock account smuggle in a discredited metaphysics?  No.  Local proper time along a world-line is well-defined in relativity; all the mechanisms we have discussed are parameterized by their own proper times.  Inter-clock comparisons incorporate relativistic shifts (GPS satellites use onboard atomic clocks with relativistic corrections).  Thus our picture of representations that exploit local dynamical laws is in harmony with the best physics available.

VIII.  Conclusions and Consequences

(1)  The Causal Impotence Argument equivocates on “causal influence.”  Sensory representation need not depend on the represented property’s exerting a force.  

(2)  What matters is the presence of lawful covariation plus functional uptake.  Clocks, both biological and artifactual, achieve this through self-sustaining oscillations or integrating processes whose state variables are predictable monotonic functions of elapsed proper time.

(3)  Accepting this account unifies a host of data on human and animal timing, rescues ordinary talk of a “sense of time,” and leaves room for scientifically tractable questions about how those internal clocks are built and calibrated.  

“Time” is indeed causally impotent in the naïve sense—but so is North, temperature in a vacuum, or orientation in inertial space.  Yet we routinely sense or measure all of those by harnessing devices whose internal dynamics stand in the right lawful relations.  A genuine sense of time, like any sense, is an evolved solution to an ecological problem; it exploits the fact that the universe offers stable process laws.  The pendulum, the cesium atom, and the neuronal loop are our allies.  It is in their regular dance—not in any metaphysical shove from Time-with-a-capital-T—that we find the informational bridge.

Is there, or could there be, a genuine “sense of time”?  Many philosophers and cognitive scientists doubt it.  Their core objection turns on the familiar thought that sensory systems acquire information only when an environmental feature causally impinges on them—photons on the retina, air pressure waves on the cochlea, volatile chemicals on olfactory receptors, and so forth.  But (the objection continues) “time” is not the sort of entity that can strike, tug, or push.  It is at best a dimension, a parameter, or a form of succession; at worst, it is abstract and wholly causally inert.  Hence nothing in the environment can convey time to a receptor, and so there can be no bona fide time-sense.  Clocks, on this line, merely “tick” in isolation; they do not detect anything.  

I will argue that this objection misfires.  It rests on a conflation between (i) causal origination and (ii) informational registration.  A system can carry perfectly accurate information about a variable without that variable itself exerting any distinctive causal force on the system.  What is required is lawful, counterfactually robust correlation, not direct causal influx from the variable as such.  Once we recognise this, the path is open for explaining how clock-like mechanisms—both artefactual and biological—can serve as genuine time sensors.  The key idea is that they exploit processes whose own dynamics are stably related to elapsed time; by coupling to, counting, or comparing those processes, the mechanism reliably indicates temporal properties.  Time, of course, still does no causal work.  But neither does “temperature” causally strike a thermometer, nor “velocity” hit a speedometer, nor “probability” bombard a Geiger counter.  In each case, information rides in on causal interactions among concrete goings-on that are lawfully linked to the target magnitude, even though the abstract magnitude itself is not a novel causal agent.  

My thesis, then, is this: the absence of a unique “causal arrow from time” does not undermine the possibility of time perception or time measurement, because information is secured by lawful covariation, not by the causal potency of the measured variable itself.  Clock mechanisms qualify as time-sensors exactly to the extent that (a) they instantiate internal dynamics whose state variables correlate determinately with temporal parameters, and (b) they are embedded in organisms or artefacts that can exploit those correlations for guidance and control.  A careful look at how artificial clocks, circadian oscillators, and interval timers actually operate dissolves the original worry and suggests a more general lesson: sensing is a functional role, not an ontological relationship to a sui generis kind of causal impact.

I proceed in five steps.  (1) I diagnose the source of the “causal impotence” worry.  (2) I introduce an information-theoretic conception of sensing that is neutral on the specific causal origin of correlations.  (3) I illustrate the conception with three varieties of clock: periodic oscillators (pendula and quartz crystals), irreversible accumulators (hourglasses and radioactive decay chains), and relational comparators (phase-locked circadian systems).  (4) I address four objections: the redundancy objection, the calibration objection, the perspectival objection, and the epistemic circularity objection.  (5) I close with a brief reflection on the upshot for the philosophy of perception.

1.  The Source of the Worry: Conflating Causal Impact with Measured Magnitude

The objection rests on a perfectly reasonable picture of canonical sensing.  In paradigmatic exteroception, an environmental magnitude impinges on specialised receptors whose activation directly depends on that magnitude.  Photons with frequency λ cause isomerisation in retinal opsins; acoustic pressure variations cause displacement of hair-cell stereocilia.  In each case the distal property one wants to know about is also a proximal cause.  Generalising from these cases, one might propose the principle:

(Causal Interface Principle) If S senses M, then instances of M exert a characteristic causal influence on S.

Time, on standard views, has no such instances; it is a dimension, not a push or a pressure.  So by the Causal Interface Principle, there can be no sense of time.

Yet this principle is questionable.  Consider a mercury thermometer.  What causes the column to rise is not “temperature” per se, but collisions of faster-moving molecules of air or liquid with the bulb.  Temperature is a statistical property of molecular motion; it is not “in” any one collision.  Nevertheless, the height of the mercury column carries highly reliable information about temperature by virtue of a law-governed correlation.  Similarly, a pitot tube measures airspeed; what pushes on the pressure sensor is air molecules, not “speed” as such.  Indeed, most interesting physical magnitudes are abstract summaries of underlying micro-events.  The causal relation is always mediated by token interactions that correspond to, but do not literally instantiate, the magnitude being sensed.

Once this is granted, the Causal Interface Principle must be reformulated:

(Information Principle) S senses M just in case S’s states systematically and lawfully covary with values of M, in a way that can be reasonably exploited for control or representation.

On this weaker—and I contend more accurate—principle, causal influence is of course required; nothing entirely causally isolated can register anything.  But the influence may come from concrete processes that are nomically tied to M, rather than from M in its abstract guise.  The thermometer is thus a bona fide temperature sensor, even though “temperature” itself never collides with it.  By parity of reasoning, a clock can be a time sensor if its internal states lawfully track temporal parameters, even though “time” never strikes it.

2.  Indicator Semantics: Information Without Direct Causation by the Tracked Variable

An explicit framework helps here.  Fred Dretske’s indicator-semantics and related informational theories of content analyse a state S of system R as expressing proposition p just in case:

(i) There is a lawful correlation: p holds whenever S occurs, within the ambient conditions C.
(ii) R has the function (derived or natural) of permitting some consumer system to act on p when S obtains.

Notice that p could range over times: p = “the interval τ has elapsed since t₀”, or “it is now circadian phase φ”.  The lawful correlation might be grounded in the period of a quartz crystal, in the flow rate of sand through a calibrated aperture, or in the phosphorylation cycle of PER proteins in the suprachiasmatic nucleus.  In none of these cases does “time” causally bombard the sensor.  Rather, physical regularities guarantee that after N oscillations, roughly N×(period) seconds have passed.  The reliability of the correlation—not a mysterious causal impact from time—underwrites the informational link.

Why call this “sensing” rather than “mere computation”?  Because the mechanism is open to the world in precisely the same sense as vision or audition: its accuracy depends on law-governed interaction with environmental processes.  A quartz wristwatch gains or loses time as ambient temperature changes; an hourglass slows in humid air; a circadian oscillator entrains to the light-dark cycle.  Each is vulnerable to perturbations, and each can be recalibrated by causal engagement with external cues.  These are hallmarks of sensory systems.

3.  Three Families of Time Sensors

Concrete cases make the abstract point vivid.

3.1  Periodic Oscillators

The archetypal clock is a pendulum.  A mass on a rod swings with period T ≈ 2π√(L/g).  Nothing about “time” shoves the bob; gravity and inertia do.  Yet after k periods,  kT seconds have elapsed, give or take small corrections.  The law relating L and T is stable across a wide range of conditions, so a gear train counting swings can indicate elapsed seconds.  Quartz crystals operate on the same principle: piezoelectric feedback sustains oscillation at a resonant frequency determined by the lattice structure.  In effect, the clock exploits a stable dynamical invariant of some material; by counting cycles, it tells time.  

Note the elegance: the system is self-generated—no external time-pulse needed.  Correlation with objective time is secured by the lawful regularity of the intrinsic dynamics, which only persist because of energy flow (battery, gravitational drop), not because “time” energises the crystal.

3.2  Irreversible Accumulators

Hourglasses and clepsydrae employ monotonic processes: sand flowing, water draining, wax burning.  The cumulative volume transferred is (within calibration limits) proportional to elapsed time.  Again, causal interaction is mediated by gravity, viscosity, and aperture shape; time per se need not act.  What matters is that the process has a reliably constant rate.  Even radioactive decay chains can serve: a radiocarbon sample “records” how long it has been since last equilibrium because the proportion of C-14 atoms remaining statistically declines with half-life τ½.  Archaeologists read “time since death” off that ratio, notwithstanding that “time” never jostled the carbon.

3.3  Relational Comparators

Living organisms often need to time intervals shorter than a second or longer than a day.  Many species possess circadian oscillators: gene-protein feedback loops whose phase can be reset by light pulses hitting retinal ganglion cells.  The oscillator’s internal state carries information about time of day if it remains phase-locked to the solar cycle.  Mammalian interval timing on the scale of seconds to minutes seems to rely on striatal accumulators or cortical ramping activity calibrated by dopamine signals.  Here the relevant lawlike regularity is more plastic and the calibration constant can drift; but learning mechanisms keep the clock in registry with environmental cues.  Biological clocks thus exemplify the generic sensor model: internal dynamics + external calibration = reliable temporal information.

4.  Four Objections and Replies

4.1  Redundancy: “Clocks Merely Infer Time from Change”

One might object that a pendulum clock does not measure time at all; it merely measures its own oscillations, which we then interpret temporally.  But this threatens to trivialise all measurement.  A thermometer “merely” measures mercury expansion; a barometer “merely” measures column height; a photodiode “merely” measures current flow.  The point of measurement is precisely to exploit a proxy that lawfully covaries with the target magnitude.  Provided the covariance is law-like and appropriately insensitive to confounds, the proxy genuinely measures.  There is no deeper requirement that the magnitude itself be the direct cause.

4.2  Calibration: “Without an External Standard, the Clock Drifts”

True—but again, this parallels ordinary senses.  Vision relies on ocular accommodation and photoreceptor health; both degrade.  Cochlear hair cells wear out.  Yet vision and audition remain senses.  Biological time-keepers combat drift by entraining to Zeitgebers: daylight, temperature cycles, feeding schedules.  Artefactual clocks are synchronised via radio signals or atomic standards.  The need for calibration does not negate sensory status; it shows only that sensing is fallible and, in biological cases, adaptively correctable.

4.3  Perspectival: “Time is Global; Sensors Deliver Local Data”

A sense of time ought to inform one of absolute present, not just elapsed intervals, the critic says.  But all sensory modalities deliver local information: a photoreceptor tells you about light at its location, not the global luminance field.  A local interval timer that informs an organism that “3.2 seconds have passed since the leech bit me” is already behaviourally valuable—e.g., for escape timing or sequence generation.  Absolute dating (today is March 14th) emerges from integrating many interval readings anchored to periodic cues (sunrise, lunar cycles).  The sense of time, so construed, is distributed across a network of specialised mechanisms, each local but collectively global.  

4.4  Epistemic Circularity: “To Build the Clock, One Already Needed the Concept of Time”

Engineers rely on prior clocks to calibrate new ones; biologists evolve clocks under temporal constraints.  Does this make time sensing circular?  No more than one needs prior eyes to evolve new photoreceptors.  Natural selection rewards organisms whose internal processes resonate with environmental regularities.  The fact that the relevant regularity is temporal does not entail an epistemic vicious circle; selection simply tunes mechanisms so that their dynamics mesh with the day-night rhythm or the speed of prey.  In artificial contexts, reference standards bootstrap the enterprise; but epistemic circularity is avoided because the chain terminates in conventions fixed by the best current standard, not in impossible self-validation.

5.  Implications for the Philosophy of Perception

The debate illuminates a larger moral: the taxonomy of the senses should be functionally rather than ontologically grounded.  What unifies vision, audition, and proprioception is not a distinctive kind of causal impact from “lightness”, “loudness”, or “position”, but a functional profile: receptor transduction, neural coding, calibration, and behavioural exploitation.  Time-keeping mechanisms share that profile.  They (a) transduce token events (oscillatory cycles, molecular decays) into neural or mechanical states, (b) encode those states in ways that preserve temporal metric information, (c) calibrate via feedback, and (d) guide action—sleep-wake schedules, speech rhythm, musical performance, predator avoidance.  Hence either we recognise a genuine sense of time, or we must drastically shrink our notion of sensing to exclude many uncontroversial cases.  

The deeper lesson is semantic.  Information is cheap: lawful covariation suffices.  Causal impact is necessary, of course, but the source of impact may be a proxy, not the measured magnitude itself.  Once this is acknowledged, the supposed causal impotence of time ceases to threaten time perception.  Clocks, biological or artefactual, are time sensors because the states they occupy are reliable indicators, within a stable nomic background, of objective temporal properties.  Time does not have to knock; the door is opened by regularity.

Thesis.  The objection rests on a mistaken assumption about what it takes for a physical system to carry information.  A sensory or measuring device does not need to be acted upon by the very property it represents; it is enough that the device’s states stand in a reliable, law‐grounded correlation with that property.  Because many physical processes unfold at a dynamical rate that is lawfully invariant, a biological or artefactual “clock” can exploit such processes to map its own causal evolution onto temporal intervals.  Hence a mechanism can represent time without time itself exerting any causal force.  The sense of time is possible in the same way an odometer senses distance: by harnessing a process whose cumulative changes covary with the target magnitude, not by being pushed on by “distance” or “time.”

Plan.  (1) Disentangle causal influence, covariation, and representation. (2) Rebut the causal‐impotence argument by analogy with other measurement cases. (3) Show how clocks turn self‐moving dynamics into temporal information. (4) Address three objections: calibration, drift, and the “no external stimulus” worry. (5) Extend the reply to biological time perception. (6) Close with a moral about what sensory systems really are.

1. Causal influence vs. informational relevance  

The objection presupposes a simple picture:

P1. A sensory system S represents environmental magnitude M only if M causally affects S.  
P2. Time (as such) does not causally affect anything.  
C. Therefore there is no genuine sensing of time.

Premise P1 is too strong.  Consider four diagnostic counterexamples.

a.  The odometer.  The device tracks kilometres travelled.  What causally turns the gear train is rotation of the axle, not “distance.”  Nevertheless, its counter reliably covaries with distance because, given the constraint that tyre circumference = c, N rotations = N·c metres.  

b.  The fuel gauge.  In many float systems the gauge reads “40 L” when the float’s height is h.  What pushes the float is petrol, not “volume” in the abstract; but the pointer is informative about volume because of known hydrostatic regularities.  

c.  MRI thermometry.  Magnetic resonance phase shift in water molecules is sensitive to temperature.  Temperature does not push protons; magnetic fields do.  Yet phase encodes temperature via a lawful mapping F(phase) → T.  

d.  Natural signs.  Tree rings encode past rainfall; rings are produced by cambial growth and nutrients, not by “the amount of rain” acting directly.  Still, dendroclimatologists legitimately treat ring width as evidence for rainfall because of statistical regularities.

Moral: What matters is not that M directly strikes S, but that there is (i) a stable causal chain from some proximal causal goings‐on to S, and (ii) a law or statistical regularity linking those proximal goings‐on to M.  If those two conditions hold, S’s state carries Shannon information about M and—under standard teleosemantic or indicator‐semantic accounts—represents M.

2. Why time is no special spoil‐sport  

Suppose a quartz crystal oscillates at 32 768 Hz when driven by a fixed voltage.  The driving voltage, by piezoelectric coupling, causes the crystal to deform; the mechanical resonance then produces an electrical square wave.  Time does not push the crystal.  Yet there is a mathematically tight relation:

If the crystal has completed N oscillations, then elapsed time ≈ N / 32 768 seconds.

In information‐theoretic terms, mutual information I(N; t) is maximised (subject to noise) because the deterministic law induces a one‐to‐one mapping between count of cycles and elapsed time.  A microcontroller that counts cycles can, by a simple division, output the current time of day.  It therefore represents time.  Nothing spooky occurs; we simply exploit a lawful regularity between a causal process internal to the device and the abstract parameter t that indexes solutions to the differential equation d²x/dt² + (ω²)x = 0.

Hence P1 in the objection should be replaced by a more nuanced principle:

P1*.  A system S can represent magnitude M if some subset of S’s physically produced states covaries with M under a law L that is usable by the consumer of those states.

Once the quartz mechanism is installed in a watch, the user (or the rest of the circuitry) is the consumer; she knows, implicitly or explicitly, that every 32 768 ticks ≈ 1 s.  Time’s alleged causal impotence is irrelevant; the representation piggybacks on the lawful synchrony between the crystal’s dynamics and temporal metric structure.

3. From self‐moving dynamics to temporal information  

General recipe for a clock:

Step 1.  Start with a self‐sustaining, periodic or monotonically accumulating process P: pendulum swings, radioactive decay chains, caesium hyperfine transitions, or neuronal “ramp” activity caused by calcium influx.

Step 2.  Show that P’s internal state variable x(t) satisfies a differential equation whose solution is either periodic with constant period T or monotone with known rate r (e.g., dx/dt = r).

Step 3.  Design a read‐out R that maps some readily detectable feature of P (zero‐crossings, pulse counts, threshold passage) onto a tally variable k.

Step 4.  Construct a code C such that decoding(k) = f⁻¹(k) returns elapsed time Δt with error ε < δ.

Each step is purely causal—oscillation, detection, counting, computation—but the device as a whole earns the right to say “three minutes have passed” because f is mathematically guaranteed.  Time need not cause anything beyond the causal march of the dynamical law itself.

Consider a sandglass.  What drives the flow is gravity acting on sand grains.  The designer empirically verifies that volume v crosses the neck per second.  Turning the glass at noon thereby establishes a relation:

If height h of the upper column = 0, then t ≈ noon + (V_total/v) s.

Again, gravity, viscosity, and grain geometry do the causal work; time figures only as the parameter in v = dh/dt.  Yet the position of the meniscus legitimately indicates time.

4. Replies to three lingering worries  

Worry 1.  Calibration.  How does the clock acquire the law L linking its internal dynamics to real time?  Short answer: by external calibration—matching noon on the sundial to 12:00 on the quartz watch—or by evolutionary learning in organisms.  The dependence on calibration does not undermine representation; it is a familiar fact about measurement generally (thermometers are calibrated in ice baths).

Worry 2.  Drift.  Every physical oscillator drifts owing to temperature, ageing, or noise.  But representational success does not require infallibility, only sufficient reliability for the organism’s or engineer’s purposes.  Error correction—daily radio‐time pips, circadian entrainment by light—keeps drift within acceptable bounds.

Worry 3.  No external stimulus.  Vision, hearing, touch all involve an ongoing causal input.  Clocks seem “dark,” producing signals spontaneously.  Does that make them bona fide senses?  Here one must distinguish two projects: (i) the metaphysical possibility of time representation (our topic), and (ii) whether time sense should count as a proper modality.  The first is secured by the argument above.  For the second, consider proprioception: muscle spindles give information about limb position largely from endogenous signals; yet proprioception is a recognised sense.  What matters is informative value, not the exogenous/endogenous divide.

5. Biological time perception  

Human and animal brains instantiate many clocklike subsystems:

a.  Circadian oscillators.  The phosphorylation cycle of PER/CRY proteins in suprachiasmatic neurons has a near‐24h period.  Light serves as a zeitgeber to phase‐lock the oscillator, but once entrained the molecular loop free‐runs.  The loop’s phosphorylation state φ(t) is used to modulate body temperature, hormone release, and subjective alertness; downstream circuits decode φ(t) as “time of day.”  

b.  Interval timing in basal ganglia and cerebellum.  Dopaminergic ramping sets a drift rate r for striatal neurons; after a “go” cue, accumulated activity A(t) ≈ r·t.  When A crosses threshold θ, the animal anticipates reward.  Manipulating dopamine alters perceived duration, showing that the internal rate constant, not an external clock pulse, drives timing.

c.  Reentrant cortical loops.  Some models treat recurrent neural activity as a high‐dimensional trajectory; elapsed time is decoded from the current point on the trajectory via population codes.  Again, the causal movers are synaptic currents, not an abstract “time force.”

If one accepts that neuronal firing patterns represent sound frequency or spatial location by lawful correlation, consistency dictates that they can represent duration by the same criterion.

6. What sensory systems really are  

The deeper lesson is methodological.  Philosophers often construe sensing as a two‐place causal relation: environmental magnitude → receptor.  But information theory and cognitive science favour a three‐place relation:

Magnitude M is represented by system S for consumer C when  
(i) states of S are causally produced in ways statistically dependent on M, and  
(ii) C is suitably disposed to use those states as a guide to facts about M.

Causal dependence need not be direct or force‐mediated by M itself; it may be mediated by any reliable bridge law.  Time, being a parameter in every dynamical law, always furnishes such a bridge: if process P obeys dP/dt = F(P), then P’s evolution is law‐entangled with t.  A designer or an evolved organism can therefore turn P into a clock by attaching a consumer attuned to that entanglement.

Conclusion.  The “time is causally impotent” objection conflates causal interaction with informational correlation.  Once we separate the two, we see that a clock mechanism is simply a physical process whose lawful evolution is used by some consumer—human, electronic, or neural—to infer temporal facts.  Time need not push on the mechanism; its role is already built into the dynamical law that governs the mechanism’s own causal unfolding.  Accordingly, there is nothing incoherent in positing a genuine sense of time, and plenty of empirical evidence—quartz watches, circadian oscillators, ramping neurons—to show how it is realised.

Telling time, it is often said, is not like telling color. Photons bombard the retina, pressure waves buffet the cochlea, airborne chemicals bind olfactory receptors; in each case an external, causally efficacious feature of the world does work on a specialized peripheral transducer. By contrast, the objection continues, “time itself” never bombards, buffets, or binds. If sense organs are defined by reception of causal influence from the feature sensed, then there can be no genuine “sense of time,” nor could a clock—biological or mechanical—count as a sensor for a feature that exerts no force.  

I will argue that this objection rests on a conflation between (a) a metaphysically spare conception of time as a universal parameter and (b) concrete temporal regularities instantiated in physical processes. Once we distinguish the two, we see that clocks do gather time-relevant information by being causally coupled to temporally regular processes, even though no sui generis “force of time” impinges on them. In short:

Thesis: A device can encode accurate temporal information not because “time causes it to change,” but because it is itself a causally situated physical process whose state reliably covaries—by lawful necessity—with elapsed duration. Temporal sensing is therefore an instance of relational information gathering rather than transduction of a proprietary causal signal.  

The argument proceeds in four stages. First, I disentangle three senses of “time” and show that only one is relevant to perception. Second, I supply an information-theoretic model that renders causal influence unnecessary for carrying information. Third, I analyze how ordinary clocks—mechanical, atomic, or neural—embody this model. Finally, I answer two lingering objections: the “arbitrariness” challenge (why does a given process track time rather than something else?) and the “rate drift” challenge (does calibration presuppose an external standard and thereby beg the question?). Along the way I draw on examples from biology and technology that, I contend, reframe the entire debate over temporal sensing.

1. Three faces of time  
------------------------------------------------  
Philosophical discussions often slide between three progressively more austere conceptions:

1.1 Metric time.  This is time as a quantitative dimension—seconds, hours, and days—needed to state the laws of dynamics. It is the “t” in Newton’s mechanics and in Schrödinger’s equation.  

1.2 Event time.  Here “time” denotes concrete temporal relations among events: duration, simultaneity, and temporal order. These are not abstract axes but relational properties instantiated by sequences of states.  

1.3 Causal time-force (the straw target).  A folkloric notion according to which time is an invisible “something” that pushes the world along. If “time flows,” perhaps it exerts a kind of pressure.

The objection presupposes 1.3: if time exerts no pressure on a sensor, nothing temporal can be sensed. But once we jettison 1.3, the problem evaporates. Sensory systems need not couple to the *dimension* of time; they need only be embedded within temporally structured processes whose evolution is law-bound. A pendulum’s swing, an oscillating cesium atom, or the decay of radioactive nuclei are examples. Nothing pushes them *because* a minute has passed; rather, the passage of a minute *just is* their undergoing sixty periods of a certain lawful change.  

Importantly, our other senses also pivot on embedding rather than direct impact. Consider proprioception. Muscle spindle afferents are deformed by changes in muscle length, but the property perceived—limb position—is relational (angles among joints). The joint angle does not itself impinge on receptors; mechanical stretch does. Likewise, temporal perception can piggy-back on causal factors—oscillatory neural firings, metabolic cycles—whose lawful unfolding *instantiates* durations.

2. Information without a dedicated temporal force  
------------------------------------------------  
Claude Shannon’s central lesson was that information is, at root, correlation. Variable X carries information about variable Y to the extent that the state of X reduces uncertainty about Y. Causal influence is one, but only one, route to correlation. For example, the rings of a tree carry reliable information about age, yet age does not flow into the trunk as an external cause; it is *reflected* in the physical accretion process. Similarly, glacier ice layers record past snowfall without past times acting on the ice.

Translate this into the sensory case: Let S(t) be the internal state of a clock or neural circuit, and let Δ be elapsed duration. Because both S and Δ are governed by the same dynamical law (often expressible as dS/dt = k), mutual information I(S;Δ) can be high even though Δ never causally “strikes” S. What matters is lawful co-evolution, not a one-way arrow of force.

Philosophers of information sometimes require “indicator causation”: the correlating relation must itself be causal to ground content. Our model satisfies that: the *process* that evolves S is causal through and through, even if the *variable* Δ is not an extra substance in the causal nexus. Put differently, clocks measure time by *being causes*, not by *being caused* by time.

3. Anatomy of a clock: oscillators as temporal sensors  
------------------------------------------------  
Let us now anatomize three paradigms.

3.1 The pendulum clock  
A pendulum of length L has period T = 2π√(L/g). Gravity g and the mechanical constraint of the rod dictate the differential equation d²θ/dt² = -(g/L)sinθ. There is no term “F_time.” A gear train counts swings; the displayed state after n oscillations covaries with elapsed duration nT. The causal story runs solely through forces of tension, gravity, and inertia. Yet anyone reading the dial acquires accurate temporal information.

3.2 The atomic clock  
Cesium-133 atoms have a hyperfine transition frequency of 9,192,631,770 Hz. In the presence of a resonant microwave cavity, the atoms absorb and emit radiation, locking an electronic oscillator to that frequency. Again, no time-force agitates the atoms; quantum electrodynamics plus the weak interaction suffice. Because the transition is a universal constant, the resulting correlation between oscillator phase and duration is breathtakingly stable—hence our current definition of the second.

3.3 Circadian and interval timing in biology  
Mammalian suprachiasmatic nuclei house transcription-translation feedback loops that generate roughly 24-hour rhythms. Though light cues entrain the phase, the intracellular chemical kinetics would tick away even in constant darkness. More striking are sub-second interval timers observed in cerebellar Purkinje cells: cascades of calcium-induced calcium release create stereotyped temporal windows that guide motor learning. No “hormone of time” drips onto these cells; rather, molecular reaction chains close only after set delays, giving neural populations an internal stopwatch.

Across these cases, time is “sensed” as a *ratio* of states: number of swings, phase angle, phosphorylation level. A sensor, broadly speaking, is any subsystem whose state space partitions trackable environmental magnitudes in an evolutionarily useful way. That criterion is met.

4. Answering two hard objections  
------------------------------------------------  
4.1 The arbitrariness challenge  
Why think a pendulum tracks time rather than “number of oscillations”? Similarly, why not treat a neuron’s calcium concentration as a marker for calcium, full stop? The worry is semantic: what authorizes the temporal interpretation over others?

Answer: What grounds content in such systems is functional embedding. The pendulum’s oscillations drive gear trains whose only role is to coordinate actions—opening the clock face, timing factory shifts—where accuracy is evaluated against temporal criteria (celestial cycles, social schedules). In biological settings, natural selection favors organisms that successfully use these internal states to anticipate periodic opportunities (e.g., flower opening). Misinterpret the state as anything other than duration and fitness plummets. Hence Ruth Millikan’s “bio-semantic” teleology: the proper function of the state is to indicate duration.

Notice that the same teleological underpinning is needed for canonical senses. If one treated retinal outputs as indicators of photon energy but used them to guide audition, visual content attribution would collapse. Temporal sense therefore enjoys parity of explanatory footing with vision and touch.

4.2 The rate-drift challenge  
Clock mechanisms can speed up or slow down (temperature affects pendulum length; metabolic rates vary). Doesn’t calibration presuppose an independent time standard, smuggling in what the objection disallows?

Three replies.

First, drift is ubiquitous in sensing. Cones bleach, olfactory receptors saturate. Calibration—via saccades, sniffing, or homeostatic gain control—does not negate the genuineness of vision or smell. It is a design feature of robust sensing.

Second, many biological timers self-correct through multi-oscillator coupling; the SCN averages signals across thousands of neurons, and errors cancel. Engineering analogues include quartz oscillators whose temperature coefficients are deliberately inverted.

Third and crucially, calibration does not presuppose a prior temporal sensor; it piggy-backs on *external periodic events*: day–night transitions, heartbeats in fetal development, even planetary tides. Those events are themselves physical processes, not metaphysical clocks. Hence the supposed vicious regress never starts.

5. From transduction to embodiment: reframing the debate  
------------------------------------------------  
Let us step back. The objection’s grip stems from an outmoded, input-output model of sense organs. On this view a peripheral receptor must be bombarded by a stimulus field, transduce it, and send the result inward for processing. But contemporary cognitive science emphasizes *embodied prediction*. Organisms maintain dynamically updated generative models; perception is the matching of internal dynamics to external regularities. In such a framework, a sensory system is any suite of mechanisms whose evolving state is predictively coupled to structured aspects of the environment. Temporal regularities are precisely such structure. Thus an endogenous oscillator, continually entrained by sunrise, qualifies as sensory in the broader sense of “information-gathering interface.”

The philosophical upshot is a shift from *impact* to *co-variance*: perceiving time is not detecting a stuff but skillfully riding the lawful symphony of change that is the world. The retina does something analogous: it outputs spatio-temporal contrasts rather than raw luminance, betting on correlations with object boundaries. Temporal perception similarly bets on correlations among internal phases, motor efference copies, and external rhythms.

6. Two revealing comparisons  
------------------------------------------------  
6.1 Magnetic direction  
A magnetotactic bacterium or a migratory bird “senses north.” But north is not a causal agent; the magnetic *field* is. Still, “north” is just a relational property of that field—its orientation relative to Earth’s axis. Nobody doubts that magnetic detection is a genuine sense even though “northness” per se exerts no additional force beyond the field. Time stands to clocks as north stands to magnetite crystals: an abstraction read off lawful structure.

6.2 Temperature perception  
Thermo-receptors transduce molecular kinetic energy, but what they report is macro-level temperature. Temperature, like time, is not a fundamental force but a statistical measure of microstates. The transducer does not interact with temperature tout court; it interacts with vibrating molecules. Yet we readily grant a sense of temperature. Why treat time differently?

7. Consequences for philosophy of mind  
------------------------------------------------  
Granting a sense of time illuminates puzzling phenomena:

• Experienced duration dilation under emotional arousal can be reinterpreted as gain modulation in neural pacemakers.  
• The apparent continuity of conscious experience (the specious present) may reflect high-order inferences from overlapping oscillatory hierarchies.  
• Temporal illusions (e.g., “colour–phi”) become analogues of visual illusions: evidence of constructive inference rather than proof that time is not sensed.

Recognizing clocks as sensors also blurs the boundary between perception and memory. Interval timing over seconds to minutes relies on ramping synaptic traces, which double as short-term storage. Thus the traditional tripartition—sense, cognition, memory—looks less like a taxonomy of faculties and more like a spectrum of temporally discriminating mechanisms.

8. Conclusion  
------------------------------------------------  
The initial objection stumbles by mislocating the requisite causal link. Sensory systems need not be struck by the very property they represent; they need only participate in causal processes whose lawful unfolding carries information about that property. Because physical laws specify how systems change *with respect to time*, any system with sufficiently reliable intrinsic dynamics can become a timekeeper. Pendulums, cesium atoms, phosphorylating proteins, and reverberating neural networks are all eligible. Time’s alleged causal impotence is beside the point: sensing duration is not a matter of being pushed by time but of skilfully exploiting the world’s rhythmic constancies.

Once we abandon the myth of a “time force,” the case for a genuine sense of time looks no weaker, and in some respects stronger, than the case for proprioception, magnetoception, or thermoreception. Clock mechanisms, biological and artefactual alike, therefore exemplify how an organism or instrument can carry information about time through lawful co-evolution rather than transduction of a dedicated causal signal. Far from being an embarrassment, temporal sensing reminds us that information lies in structure and relation, not in mysterious fluids flowing from properties into minds.

I. Introduction and Thesis  

The “causal‐impotence” objection to a sense of time runs as follows. (1) Sensory systems provide information only if some environmental feature causally impinges on the receptor surface: light on retina, chemicals on olfactory epithelium, pressure on skin. (2) Time, unlike light or pressure, has no causal powers; it is “that in which” events occur, not a force that pushes on things. (3) Therefore no mechanism—neural or mechanical—can literally sense time. At most, organisms make post-hoc inferences from sequences of other sensations.  

I argue that the objection rests on a mistaken picture of how information can be carried and how measurement works. A mechanism can inform an agent about a magnitude not by being struck by that very magnitude, but by exploiting law-like regularities that set up reliable correlations between its internal state transitions and the temporal relations in its environment.  Clocks—both biological and artifact—are paradigms of this indirect, “structure-exploiting” mode of sensing. Time need not shove the hands of a clock; the lawful dynamics of the clock’s components suffice to embed temporal information in its states. 

I develop the response in five steps:

1. Distinguish two routes by which a system can carry information: impact-driven and dynamic-law-driven.  
2. Show, using an information-theoretic criterion, that the dynamic-law route is sufficient for bona fide sensory representation.  
3. Analyse mechanical clocks as concrete examples; demonstrate how they satisfy the criterion without time’s causal help.  
4. Extend the lesson to biological timing mechanisms—circadian oscillators and interval timers in vertebrate brains—showing that organisms plausibly possess a genuine sense of time.  
5. Address residual worries: Does the view trivialise the notion of sensing? Aren’t clocks merely measuring devices, not senses? What about temporal illusions?  

My conclusion: the causal-impotence objection fails. Sensory systems need only be causally sensitive to *states of affairs that lawfully covary with* the target magnitude; direct causal influence from the magnitude itself is optional. Appreciating this reshapes the debate about temporal perception and, more generally, about the taxonomy of senses.

II. Two Ways of Carrying Information  

Consider Dretske’s (1981) useful definition: a signal S carries information about a variable X if, given suitable background conditions, P(X | S)/P(X) = 1. That is, learning S removes uncertainty about X. On the face of it, retinal activations satisfy the condition because photons (“X = there is light of wavelength λ from direction θ”) impinge directly on photoreceptors, altering their state. Call this impact-driven information.  

But Dretske’s formula is silent on whether *X itself* causes S, or whether some third factor does. What matters is reliable covariance. Suppose a sealed digital thermometer is in thermal equilibrium with its surroundings. The outside air’s temperature and the display reading are nomically linked: given the device’s calibration history, the reading perfectly covaries with the ambient temperature. Yet the number “23 °C” on the display is not caused by temperature *as such* but by the expansion of a liquid, the resistance of a thermistor, or some other intermediate property. Still, it carries information about temperature. The causal chain runs from air molecules to internal changes to the display; “temperature” names a relational property of the molecular distribution, not a force. 

Dynamic-law information extends this idea. Some mechanisms have intrinsic dynamics—oscillations, decay rates, phase lags—that are lawfully related to elapsed time. If the period of an oscillator is stable, then counting cycles yields information about duration even though “time” never strikes the system. An hourglass, for example, provides a state (amount of sand in the lower bulb) whose magnitude covaries with elapsed time via gravity and flux rate. No one thinks gravity “measures sand” or “time pushes sand grains”; yet learning how much sand has fallen lets an observer infer time.  

Thus, covariance can be mediated by (i) causal chains initiated by the target property or (ii) stable internal dynamics correlated with the target. Both are legitimate under Dretske’s information criterion.

III. How Clocks Work Without Time Causation  

A paradigmatic mechanical clock contains three parts: (a) a resonator (pendulum, balance wheel, quartz crystal) with a period T determined by physical parameters; (b) an escapement that converts oscillations into discrete steps; (c) a counter/display.  The resonator’s successive states S1, S2, … Sn occur at intervals ≈ T. The law of simple pendular motion guarantees that, within engineering tolerances, the number n of swings after start moment t0 covaries linearly with elapsed time Δt = nT.  

Critically, time plays no causal role beyond being the dimension in which the causal story unfolds. Gravity and inertia generate the oscillations; friction damps them; the escapement injects periodic energy. The device’s *internal structure* plus background physical laws sets up the covariance. The final display “10:37” carries information because, conditional on correct calibration and normal operation, the mutual information I(Display; Real-time) is high.  

From an interventionist viewpoint (Woodward 2003), the relation is counterfactually robust. If one were to intervene on the length of the pendulum arm, one would systematically change the rate; intervening on real time while holding physics fixed is metaphysically impossible—hence the appearance that time lacks causal powers. But that impossibility doesn’t undermine the counterfactual: had the arm been longer, the same number of swings would correlate with a greater elapsed time. The device’s functional profile embeds the time variable.  

One might object that the device works only because an external agent designed and calibrated it. But design is not essential: the same principle applies to naturally occurring processes. Consider radioactive decay: the fraction of undecayed nuclei at moment t is e^{–λt}. Physicists exploit this by measuring remaining activity to infer sample age—again, no causal influence emanates from “time.” Covariance suffices.

IV. Biological Timing: Toward a Sense of Time  

Organisms exploit dynamical regularities in roughly three regimes: circadian (~24 h), interval (milliseconds–seconds), and millisecond-level sequencing (speech, locomotion). I claim that at least some of these mechanisms deserve to be classified as sensory. Let me focus on vertebrate interval timing, studied in the basal ganglia–cerebellar circuits.

(a) Empirical sketch. Neurons in the striatum exhibit ramping firing profiles whose slopes scale with the to-be-timed interval; dopaminergic modulation adjusts pacemaker rates; lesions disrupt duration-based decisions. Animals can perform temporal bisection, generalisation, and Weber-law scalar timing—all hallmarks of psychophysical sensing.  

(b) Information analysis. Suppose an internal pacemaker emits ticks at mean rate r. An accumulator counts ticks until criterion k is reached, then triggers a behavioural response (e.g., press lever). Under stationary conditions, the expected number of ticks correlates with elapsed time: E[Δt] = k/r. Inflating r via pharmacological manipulation predictably compresses subjective time. The neural state—number of ticks—thus carries Shannon information about Δt.  

(c) Independence from non-temporal cues. Experiments randomise retinal flow, proprioception, and auditory events; animals still time accurately, indicating that duration estimation is not inferred from exteroceptive change but from endogenous dynamics.  

The system therefore parallels the mechanical clock: no causal arrow runs from “time” to neurons; rather, the lawful decay of dopaminergic modulation and oscillatory circuits sets up a correlation exploited for behaviour. If we are willing to call proprioception a sense though it relies on efference-copy and muscle spindle dynamics, parity demands recognising an internal sense of duration.

V. Objections and Replies  

1. “Correlation isn’t causation; without causal impact you don’t have sensing, only computation.”  
Reply: Vision, audition, etc. crucially depend on correlations too. Photons do not carry “redness”; the nervous system must exploit systematic covariation between wavelengths and photoreceptor responses shaped by evolutionary calibration. The only extra condition for sensing is that the correlation be *registered by the organism for guiding action*. Temporal mechanisms satisfy this.

2. “Clocks are not senses; they’re tools. Biological timers are internal controls, not perceptual.”  
Reply: The distinction between interoceptive sensing and control is porous. Baroreceptors sense blood pressure to regulate homeostasis; yet few deny they are sensory neurons. If a system produces contentful estimations usable across behavioural domains (e.g., predicting duration, synchronising movement, acquiring language prosody), that is better classified as a sense than a mere reflex. Time-keeping networks meet this functional/general-purpose criterion.

3. “Your view trivialises sensing: any lawful change becomes ‘time information’.”  
Reply: Not any change, only changes whose parametrisation tracks temporal metrics across contexts and is treated by the organism as such. The length of my fingernails covaries with age, but the body doesn’t consult nail length to decide birthday cake size. Contrast interval neurons: downstream circuits read their output to decide when to start courtship songs. The informational/functional role screens off accidental correlations.

4. Temporal illusions (e.g., intentional binding, chronostasis) show that time perception is highly malleable; this counts against a dedicated sense.  
Reply: All modalities suffer illusions when underlying cues are perturbed (e.g., colour constancy failures). The very possibility of systematic distortion implies a process specialised enough to go wrong in specifiable ways. Indeed, illusions help map the computations—the recalibration at saccades in chronostasis reveals that time-estimating circuits integrate efference copy with pacemaker counts.

VI. Clarifying the Conceptual Lesson  

The causal-impotence objection mistakes a metaphysical point for a functional constraint. Yes, time is not a “cause” alongside electromagnetic or mechanical forces. But a sensory system does not need the target magnitude to be a force; it needs a *law-grounded mapping* from the magnitude to internal states the organism can use. That mapping may be mediated by dynamics intrinsic to the organism. Clocks, hourglasses, radiocarbon decay, circadian oscillators, and basal-ganglia accumulators all instantiate such mappings.  

A helpful distinction emerges:

Direct-impact measurement  
    stimulus: proximal energy specific to magnitude  
    example: photons for vision, pressure waves for hearing

Endogenous-dynamics measurement  
    stimulus: none; the system’s own evolution correlates with magnitude  
    example: pendulum swings for time, radioactive decay for age

Both satisfy Dretske-style information, both can ground representation, and both admit calibration. Thus, “sensing” should be understood functionally (information acquisition for guiding behaviour) rather than mechanistically (being hit by the property sensed).

VII. Wider Implications  

1. Taxonomy of the senses. Recognising endogenous-dynamics sensing supports expanding the list beyond the canonical five. The sense of balance (vestibular) already straddles the border: it relies on inertial forces rather than environmental “substances.” A sense of time extends the trend.  

2. Embodied cognition. Timing mechanisms are distributed—cardiac rhythms, motor resonances, cortical oscillations. Understanding them as sensory emphasises continual feedback between bodily states and cognitive timing.  

3. AI and robotics. Artificial agents require temporal representations. The argument licenses treating internal oscillators and Kalman-filter-based interval estimators in robots as sensory modules, guiding design of adaptive architectures without external chronometers.

VIII. Conclusion  

Clocks teach us that causal impingement by the target magnitude is not the only road to information. When a process’s lawful dynamics embed a stable parameter, later states can stand in for that parameter, enabling genuine measurement. Time is the paradigm of such a parameter. Biological and artefactual clocks, exploiting oscillation, decay, or cumulative integration, therefore constitute legitimate sensory systems for time. The causal impotence of time poses no obstacle; what matters is reliable, exploitable covariance. Recognising this dissolves a venerable objection and enlarges our conception of what sensing—and cognition—can be.

How A Mechanism Can Represent Time Without Being ​Caused​ by Time  
                                     -------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Framing the Objection and the Reply  
A widespread line of thought runs as follows. (i) Sensory systems work only when the sensed feature exerts a causal influence on the apparatus—photons strike the retina, air-pressure waves jostle cochlear hair cells, chemicals bind to olfactory receptors. (ii) Time, unlike light or odorant molecules, is not the sort of thing that can impinge on a receptor; it is “causally impotent.” (iii) Hence there can be no genuine time-sense—what we call “feeling the passage of time” must be an illusion or a cognitive inference, not perception.

I shall argue that the second step rests on a confusion between ​causal source​ and ​information carrier​. A mechanism can carry information about a magnitude even when that magnitude is not itself an independent causal agent, provided that law-like regularities guarantee a reliable correlation between the mechanism’s states and the magnitude’s values. A clock—whether the suprachiasmatic nucleus in a mammal or a cesium fountain in a laboratory—illustrates the point: its moving parts are not pushed around by “time,” but because their dynamics instantiate a temporally invariant pattern, their successive states encode how much time has elapsed. Once this confusion is cleared, the claim that there is no sensory system for time loses its force.

2. Why “Direct” Causation Is Not a Requirement for Representation  
The objection tacitly endorses what we might call the ​Contact Doctrine​: A representational state R can carry information about property P only if P itself affects R through a dedicated causal channel. But many uncontroversial cases violate the doctrine.

Temperature.  A cold receptor is triggered by molecular collisions, not by “degree Celsius.” What makes the receptor sensitive to temperature is a lawful regularity: within the relevant range, mean molecular kinetic energy covaries with collision rate, and collision rate affects the receptor. The semantic link to temperature is mediated, not direct.

Magnetic-field lines.  A compass needle does not register “northness.” It responds to a vector sum of electromagnetic forces. Because that sum is lawfully related to the Earth’s field, we treat the needle as representing direction. Again, representation flows via reliable correlation, not direct action of “northness” on metal.

Temporal order is no different in principle. If there are physical processes whose evolution respects stable temporal invariants—periodic oscillations, exponential decay, constant rates of flow—then those processes can be harnessed as indicators of temporal magnitude even though no separate entity called ​time​ pushes on them.

3. From Correlation to Semantic Content: A Minimal Theory  
Suppose state s of mechanism M occurs iff magnitude T (elapsed time since some zero-point) falls within interval I. Claude Shannon showed that mutual information is indifferent to whether the correlation is mediated by another variable. Fred Dretske (1981) and Karen Neander (2017) added that natural selection (or learning) can exploit the correlation so that s ​functions​ to indicate T ∈ I. When that etiological condition is satisfied, s ​means​ “T is in I.” Note what is ​not​ required:

• An energy packet traveling from an abstract entity called Time to the sensor;  
• A dedicated time-particle;  
• Even a metaphysical substance “flowing.”

What ​is​ required is a stable nomic link, plus a system that uses the link for guidance—exactly what we find in ordinary clocks and in neural timing circuits.

4. How Clocks Work Without Time Pushing on Them  
It helps to distinguish two clock architectures.

4.1 Exogenous-driver clocks: hourglasses, sundials, water clocks  
These devices rely on a process whose rate is fixed by (or tightly correlated with) environmental regularities:

• An hourglass uses the constant acceleration of gravity and the quasi-constant aperture size.  
• A sundial exploits the rotational period of the Earth relative to the Sun.  

In neither case does “time” hit the apparatus. Grains of sand fall and cast shadows move because of gravity and angular momentum conservation. Those physical processes supply an information-bearing ​signal​—the height of the sand pile, the shadow angle—from which elapsed time can be read.

4.2 Endogenous-oscillator clocks: balance wheels, quartz crystals, atomic standards, circadian pacemakers  
These devices isolate a dynamical subsystem whose period is highly stable given the relevant boundary conditions. The balance wheel’s periodicity depends on moment of inertia I and torsional stiffness κ; quartz crystals depend on piezoelectric coupling; atomic clocks depend on hyperfine transition frequencies fixed by constants of nature. If N oscillations have occurred, then elapsed time ≈ N × (period). The causal story involves elastic forces, electromagnetic interactions, and quantum transitions; wherein lies the “time causal influence”? Nowhere. Rather, the oscillation embodies a ​symmetry​: the laws governing the subsystem are (approximately) invariant under time translation, yielding a conserved quantity (energy) that, in turn, supports a stable period. By coupling a counter to the oscillator, engineers convert that lawful invariance into usable temporal information.

5. From Clocks to Biological Time-Sensing  
The brain’s timing capacities fit the same template.

5.1 Millisecond range: interval timing for speech and music  
Cortical-basal-ganglia circuits exhibit ramping neuron populations whose firing rate integrates a constant input (due to the properties of NMDA receptors and recurrent excitation). Because dv/dt ≈ k, the time to reach threshold ~ (θ/k). The causal input is synaptic current; the semantic target is duration.

5.2 Second-to-minute range: striatal beat-frequency model  
Dopaminergic inputs reset a bank of cortical oscillators with slightly different periods. The pattern of phase coincidence evolves deterministically; downstream neurons detect particular coincidence patterns corresponding to elapsed intervals. Oscillations are driven by membrane currents, not by “time,” yet reliably map onto ​how long​ has passed.

5.3 Circadian range  
The molecular clock in the suprachiasmatic nucleus is a transcription-translation feedback loop with a period of ~24 h, entrained by light-induced signaling cascades. The loop’s biochemical causal structure endows each phase state with information about the day-night cycle. Light photons initiate entrainment; “time of day” itself imparts no causal jolt.

6. Anticipating and Answering Objections  
Objection 1: ​Correlation is not enough; the device might continue to oscillate even if time stopped—so it would misrepresent.​  
Reply: “Time stopping” is either incoherent (most physical theories define time via change) or else a wholesale breakdown of the nomic background. In that scenario, ​all​ reference breaks down: thermometers mis-register temperatures when laws change, compasses fail if electromagnetism disappears. Vacuous possibility is no threat to ordinary representational legitimacy.

Objection 2: ​Photoreceptors are acted on by photons; temporal receptors would need an analogous contact with chronons, else they differ in kind.​  
Reply: The analogy fails even for spatial vision. Photoreceptors are not sensitive to ​distance​ yet vision represents distance, shape, and motion by processing patterns across retinal arrays. Likewise, a time-sense may synthesize information distributed across internal changes. Representation outruns proximal stimulation.

Objection 3: ​Endogenous oscillators measure only themselves; without external calibration they drift.​  
Reply: True—and exactly parallel worries hold for any sense organ. The retina yields ambiguous 2-D images; calibration via stereopsis, vergence, and learning corrects them. Circadian clocks synch via morning light; interval clocks re-calibrate via dopaminergic prediction errors. Dependence on calibration does not negate sensing; it just shows that sensing is interactive.

Objection 4: ​The alleged sense of time is reconstructive and thus cognitive, not sensory.​  
Reply: The distinction between “perceptual” and “cognitive” is graded. If the processes are automatic, encapsulated, and feed downstream behavior (e.g., saccadic suppression of chronostasis) without propositional mediation, they meet standard criteria for perceptual systems. Current empirical work (e.g., Eagleman, 2008) shows precisely such low-level temporal illusions.

7. A Revealing Distinction: Carrier vs. Source  
The foregoing cases suggest a conceptual tool not yet standard but useful. Let

• The ​carrier​ of information for magnitude M be the physical variable C whose values covary lawfully with M and interact causally with the sensor.  
• The ​source​ be M itself.

For olfaction, ​carrier​ = volatile molecules; ​source​ = chemical identity. For clocks, ​carrier​ = phase of oscillation (or height of sand, etc.); ​source​ = elapsed time. The Contact Doctrine is driven by conflating carrier with source. Once they are prised apart, we see that many sensory systems detect their targets by being causally affected by carriers that happen to track the target. The sense of time employs internal carriers (neural phases, decay of integrators) whose link to time is backed by environmental or evolutionary calibration. Nothing metaphysically suspicious lurks here.

8. An Information-Theoretic Sketch of a Clock  
To make matters fully explicit, consider a quartz watch.

Let φ(t) be the phase of its quartz oscillator at physical time t. The piezoelectric effect yields a differential equation  
 d²x/dt² + (2πf)²x = 0,  where f ≈ 32,768 Hz.  
Count cycles with an integer-valued variable n(t) updated at each zero crossing; drive the display every 32,768 counts. The causal pathway is  
 Crystal deformation → electrical signal → flip-flop counter → gear train → hand position.  
Mutual information I(n; t) is maximized under the assumption of frequency stability. No term “time” appears on the right-hand side of the causal chain. Nevertheless the Shannon channel (n → t) carries log₂(#counts) bits about elapsed seconds. Under an etiological semantics, the function of n is to indicate t, because the device was designed and selected for that task.

9. Does Time Have Any Causal Role at All?  
One might wonder whether I have conceded too much: perhaps time does, after all, exert causal influence by governing the dynamical laws that yield stable oscillations. If so, the original objection collapses for a different reason—the premise that time is causally impotent is false. On many formulations of mechanics (Hamiltonian, Lagrangian) the time parameter is part of the explanatory machinery. Whether to treat that parameter as a “cause” in the everyday sense is a debated metaphysical question, but the epistemic moral is clear: either clocks represent time because they are pushed by time (the objection fails), or clocks represent time by exploiting lawful correlations without such pushing (the objection fails). The dilemma is fatal to the objector.

10. Why This Counts as a Genuine Sense  
A sensory modality, by most cognitive-scientific standards, (i) supplies organisms with non-inferential information, (ii) is subserved by specialized receptor and processing pathways, and (iii) can be selectively impaired. Interval-timing studies reveal exactly this profile: pharmacological manipulation of striatal dopamine shifts perceived duration; lesions of the cerebellum degrade millisecond timing; genetic knockouts of Per2 disrupt circadian phase perception. Hence the “time-sense” satisfies operational criteria for genuine sensation even though its carriers are endogenously generated.

11. Residual Worries About Illusion  
Humans systematically misperceive long intervals (Vierordt’s Law) and short flashes (subjective slowing under threat). But every modality has characteristic illusions (color constancy errors, auditory streaming). Illusoriness undermines only simplistic ​naïve realism​, not the existence of a sense organ. Indeed, the pattern of illusions itself furnishes evidence for specialized temporal coding.

12. Conclusion: From Confusion to Clarity  
The objection that time cannot be sensed because time is not a causal agent conflates the metaphysical structure of causation with the informational structure of representation. Clocks—mechanical, atomic, or neural—convert lawful, temporally invariant dynamics into signals usable for action. They do so by coupling a ​carrier​ variable that is causally accessible to the device with the ​source​ variable of temporal magnitude.
