Once we separate these roles, we see that direct causal impingement by the represented property is unnecessary. A sense of time is thus no more mysterious than a sense of temperature or direction. The philosophical moral is broader: representation by ​tracking​ does not require “energy flow” from the represented property, only a stable, exploitable correlation secured by the laws of nature and the design (biological or artifactual) of the system.

Clockwork Without a Cosmic Push: How Mechanisms Can Sense Time in the Absence of Temporal Causation
----------------------------------------------------------------

1. Framing the Challenge  

To perceive colour your eyes must be causally struck by certain wavelengths of light; to perceive pitch your ears must be set trembling by pressure waves of the corresponding frequency.  These observations have suggested to many philosophers that *any* genuine sensory system must be driven, at bottom, by causal traffic from the relevant environmental property to the organism.  Time, however, is commonly thought to be causally inert.  Unlike photons or air-pressure fluctuations, “the mere passage of t” does not push, pull, impinge, or in any other way exert force on cortical tissue.  Hence (the objection concludes) there can be no *sense* of time—only higher-level inference or memory that reconstructs durations retrospectively.

I shall argue that this objection mis-locates where causal work has to be done for information to be available.  A sensory system does not require *direct* causal energy from the target property; it requires a *reliable causal correlation* between states of the system and states of the world.  Because physical laws ensure that *every* continuous dynamical system is lawfully parameterised by time, suitably engineered mechanisms can exploit purely internal dynamics to generate just such correlations.  A clock, biological or artefactual, thus carries usable information about elapsed time even though time exerts no force on it.  In short:

Thesis: A device or neural subsystem counts as a time-sense when (i) its internal state space is lawfully indexed to elapsed time by virtue of its own dynamics, (ii) the correlation is stable enough to be exploited for control or prediction, and (iii) the correlation is not accidental but underwrites the teleofunction of the mechanism.  Direct causal influence from time is unnecessary because the physical evolution of any system already *encodes* time within its state transitions.

The argument proceeds in four steps.  First, I expose the tacit “impact requirement” at work in the objection and show why it is overly demanding.  Second, I compare time-sensing to familiar cases in which we already allow perception of causally impotent properties (speed, number, probability).  Third, I analyse clock mechanisms—pendular, quartz, atomic, and biological—in information-theoretic terms, spelling out how they come to *carry* temporal information.  Finally, I address three worries: (a) that the correlation is merely accidental, (b) that without an external time signal the device cannot detect drift, and (c) that genuine sensation requires dedicated receptors rather than self-generated rhythms.  Each worry can be quelled once we shift from an “impact” model of sensation to a “covariance plus function” model.

2. Why the Impact Requirement Over-reaches  

The classical sense modalities do indeed involve energy transfer: photons excite opsins, compressions bend hair cells, volatile chemicals dock with olfactory receptors.  The temptation is to treat this as *definitional* of sensory systems.  Yet even in paradigmatic perception the environmental property we claim to sense is often not the one doing causal work.  Two quick illustrations make the point.

Example 1:  A speedometer “perceives” speed (distance per unit time).  What physically drives the needle is rotational motion of a magnet; but speed as such exerts no unique force.  The needle tracks speed because the rotational frequency of the magnet *covaries* with speed given the mechanical constraints of the vehicle.  What matters is the lawful mapping from speeds to needle positions, not that “speed pushes the gauge.”

Example 2:  Consider perceiving *probability* in a random dot kinetogram.  The retina is hit by individual photons, but what subjects report is the *proportion* of dots moving rightwards.  The property perceived—probability—is abstract and causally impotent; the informational purchase stems from statistical regularities over many causal micro-events.

These examples show a general pattern: sensing a property P requires (i) causal interactions *somewhere* in the chain, (ii) a stable mapping from P to some detectible feature S of those interactions, and (iii) a consumer that uses S *as* information about P.  Direct causal potency of P itself is optional.

The same pattern can hold for time.  All dynamical systems instantiate states S(t) that evolve according to laws dS/dt = F(S).  Because elapsed time monotonically orders state transitions, one can design mechanisms whose *current* state reliably covaries with how much time has passed since a reference event.  Time never “impacts” the device; rather, the device *rides* law-governed change to mark time’s passage.

3. From Covariance to Representation:  The Architecture of Clocks  

Let me put flesh on that abstract schema by walking through three increasingly sophisticated clock types.

3.1 The Pendulum Clock  

The period T of a pendulum of length L is (to first order) 2π√(L/g).  Once set swinging, the bob’s angular displacement θ(t) is periodic with phase φ(t) = ωt + φ₀.  Counting zero-crossings therefore yields a monotonic tally of elapsed seconds.  What causally moves the escapement gear is gravitational torque and inertial momentum—not “time.”  Yet because φ(t) = ωt, the gear’s state carries mutual information H(φ; t) that approaches log₂(N) bits for N swings observed.  The lawlike regularity establishes the covariance; engineering (isochronous anthropic constant length, temperature-compensated rods) improves reliability.

3.2 The Quartz Oscillator  

A slice of β-quartz exhibits piezo-electricity: mechanical strain produces voltage and vice versa.  When cut at the right angle and driven into resonance, it vibrates at 32 768 Hz.  The crystal’s molecular lattice and the circuit’s feedback loop create an attractor whose periodicity is extraordinarily stable across voltage fluctuations.  Again, nothing external needs to bang the crystal once it is driven; the system’s own dynamics maintain the mapping t ↦ phase.  Dividing down the high-frequency square wave by binary counters realises the familiar one-second pulse.  Digital “temporal information” is implemented in registers that increment once per pulse.  The causal pathway runs: lattice forces → mechanical strain → voltage → logic gate; time does not appear as a distinct force term.

3.3 The Circadian Clock in the Suprachiasmatic Nucleus (SCN)  

Biological organisms display free-running oscillations with periods close to 24 h.  In mammals the SCN achieves this via transcription-translation feedback loops: CLOCK and BMAL1 proteins promote transcription of PER and CRY; accumulated PER/CRY dimers ultimately inhibit CLOCK/BMAL1, causing levels to fall and the cycle to restart.  Mutations stretching or shortening degradation rates lengthen or shorten behavioural periods, demonstrating that it is *chemical kinetics* that push the cycle, not time’s mystical tug.  Yet the organism exploits phase information to anticipate dawn, regulate body temperature, and schedule hormone release.  When present, zeitgeber stimuli (light pulses) entrain the oscillator, fixing φ = 0 at sunrise, but in constant darkness the SCN continues to “know” the hour as accurately as any wristwatch left indoors.

Across these cases we see the same structure: intrinsic dynamics create lawful, stable phase-time covariance; the system counts phase cycles; downstream consumers treat the count as information about duration.  Causal energy flows among physical variables other than time, but the mapping is robust enough that treating the device as a *time sensor* is explanatorily indispensable.

4. Meeting the Objections  

Objection A:  “Correlation without causation is mere coincidence.”  
Reply:  What matters is *non-accidental* correlation.  Teleosemantics or etiological functionalism offers a neat criterion: a state S represents property P when S has the function (selected by evolution or design) of indicating P because of a history in which S-P correlations caused beneficial outcomes.  Pendulum lengths were chosen, quartz cuts refined, and SCN loops conserved precisely because they delivered behaviourally useful time information.  Accidental correlations would not persist under selection nor be worth the engineer’s expense.  Thus the covariance here is not lucky; it is the very reason the mechanism exists in its current form.

Objection B:  “Without an external time signal the device cannot detect or correct drift, so it doesn’t really know the time.”  
Reply:  Two distinctions help.  (i) *Interval* vs *calendar* time: a stopwatch need only measure intervals; calibration to an absolute standard is unnecessary.  (ii) *Representation* vs *accuracy*: miscalibrated thermometers still represent temperature, albeit inaccurately.  Likewise, a quartz watch that has lost five seconds is still a time sensor; it is just a noisy one.  In biological cases the sun or social cues can provide periodic recalibration, but recalibration is not constitutive of temporal representation itself.

Objection C:  “Genuine senses have dedicated receptors that transduce external stimuli; clocks are self-contained and so resemble inference, not perception.”  
Reply:  The taxonomy of senses has already expanded beyond classical exteroception.  Proprioception, nociception, and vestibular balance all rely heavily on internal signals (muscle spindle stretch, tissue damage, hair-cell inertia).  The vestibular system, in particular, employs the *endogenous* dynamics of fluid in the semicircular canals to detect angular acceleration; we do not deem it inferential.  The divide, therefore, is not internal vs external but *direct, ongoing informational coupling* vs retrospective reconstruction.  Clocks maintain coupling by continuously evolving, not by episodic reasoning over stored memories.  Experimentally, SCN lesion in rodents abolishes learned anticipation of feeding times even though hippocampal memory remains, confirming that timing and memory dissociate behaviourally.

5. Distinctions that Clarify the Terrain  

Several conceptual distinctions help avoid conflation.

5.1 Parameter vs Force Distinction  
Time is a *parameter* in dynamical laws, not a *force*.  Sensory systems can track parameters provided there is a lawful S(t) mapping.  Temperature also began as a parameter in thermodynamics; mercury provides the S.  Gauge fields need not themselves slam into receptors.

5.2 Relational vs Intrinsic Property  
Colour and pain are intrinsic properties of perceptual states; duration is relational (between two moments).  Tracking a relational property often requires memory or oscillation.  That fact explains why time-sensing mechanisms are always extended in time (pacemaker-accumulator, oscillators, delay lines), not point receptors.  The objection under scrutiny mistakes this *architectural* consequence of relationality for evidence of non-sensation.

5.3 Exteroceptive vs Proprioceptive Timing  
Humans possess multiple timing systems: millisecond-range interval timing in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, circadian timing in the SCN, and prospective timing that utilises cortical beta oscillations.  Some are entrained exteroceptively (light), others run proprioceptively (striatal dopamine pulses).  A unified account need not treat them identically; what unites them is lawful state-time covariance exploited by the organism.

6. Information-Theoretic Formalisation  

Let T be a random variable over elapsed time since reference event t₀, with prior distribution p(t).  Let C be the clock’s current internal state (phase, gear position, gene-expression vector).  Physical law plus initial conditions induce a conditional distribution p(c | t).  The mutual information I(T;C) quantifies how much knowing C reduces uncertainty about T.  A perfect clock achieves I = H(T).  Time’s causal impotency is irrelevant; all that is required is that p(c | t) be sharply peaked for each t.  Engineering (or evolution) tunes system parameters to maximise I under noise and drift constraints.  This formalisation captures why clocks are *better* or *worse* sensors without appealing to metaphysical forces.

7. Repercussions for the Philosophy of Perception  

Recognising clocks as legitimate time-senses has three broader implications.

7.1 Modality Pluralism  
It bolsters the view that sense modalities are individuated by computational role, not receptor anatomy.  Timing fulfils a unique ecological role—coordinating action with periodic events, predicting regularities—sufficient to merit modality status even if its “receptors” are pacemaker neurons.

7.2 Reconciling B-Theoretic Time with Temporal Phenomenology  
If clocks index time without being acted upon by time, the B-theorist (who denies a flowing present) can still explain rich temporal phenomenology.  The seeming “flow” emerges from representational dynamics, not from metaphysical becoming.

7.3 Methodological Lessons  
The case shows the risk of projecting metaphysical assumptions about properties onto epistemic mechanisms.  Thermometers do not require a “temperature force,” nor do compasses need a “direction force” to sense north.  We should expect similar indirect strategies in neural information gathering.

8. Conclusion  

The absence of a causal “push” from time poses no special problem for temporal sensation.  What any sensory system needs is (a) causal interactions within the mechanism that evolve lawfully, (b) a reliable, exploitable correlation between those internal states and the environmental property of interest, and (c) historical or design-based anchoring of that correlation to the system’s function.  Clocks—mechanical, electronic, and biological—satisfy these criteria in abundance.  They track time the way speedometers track speed: by converting dynamics that necessarily unfold in time into state variables consumable by further processes.  Once we replace the Impact Requirement with a Covariance-and-Function framework, the supposed impossibility of a time sense dissolves, and with it a venerable impediment to understanding how organisms so effortlessly live in synchrony with the temporal structure of their worlds.

Time seems like an elusive quarry for the senses. We can be lit by photons, vibrated by pressure waves, or chemically stimulated by odorants, but—so the objection goes—nothing literally “touches” us that deserves the name time. If sensory systems must be driven by causal impingement from the very feature they detect, then, because time itself does not hit, bump, or flow into anything, there is no genuine sense of time. My aim is to show that this objection rests on a misunderstanding of both what it is to carry information and how biological or artefactual clocks work. Once we have the right picture of representation, the causal impotence of time ceases to be a problem. Roughly, clocks—neural or mechanical—encode time not because time exerts a proprietary force on them but because their own ongoing causal dynamics stand in a law-like, reliable covariation with temporal magnitudes. Time leaves its “fingerprints” in the lawful evolution of states, and that is enough for sensory registration.

1. Clarifying the burden of the objection  

       (O) In order for a system S to sense feature F, F must causally influence S.
       (I) Time does not causally influence anything; it is not a force or energy source.
       (C) Therefore, no system can sense time.

Two clarifications are essential. First, (O) is stronger than many causal theories of perception actually require. Most contemporary information-theoretic or teleosemantic accounts speak of reliable covariance under appropriate counterfactual conditions, not of direct causal influence by the very property represented. Second, (I) is ambiguous between two claims:

   (I1) Time exerts no sui generis force.  
   (I2) Nothing about the causal evolution of physical systems can be informative about time.

Only (I1) is plausible. (I2) is demonstrably false: pendulums, radioactive decay chains, and sodium-potassium oscillations in the brain all exhibit temporal regularities from which elapsed time can be read. The puzzle, then, is why (I1) seems to threaten representation when (I2) does not. The answer lies in conflating two quite different modes of information transmission: exogenous impingement and endogenous unfolding.

2. Two ways to carry information  

Exogenous sensing: A variable outside the system directly modulates the system’s states—photons flip retinal opsins, airborne molecules bind olfactory receptors. The sensed magnitude is an external cause of the receptor state.

Endogenous timing: The system is set into motion once (by winding, by initial conditions, by routine metabolism) and thereafter passes through a succession of states in accord with physical laws. Because the mapping from state to elapsed time is highly reliable—indeed nomologically necessary—the system’s later states carry as much information about temporal distance from the start as retinal signals carry about wavelength composition of incident light. Here the sensor does not wait for repeated causal pushes from the magnitude it represents; rather, it “reads itself” as it lawfully evolves.

Notably, thermometers lie somewhere between these poles. The mercury column rises because molecular kinetic energy from the surrounding medium agitates it, so temperature both causes and covaries with expansion. But the expansion is mediated by more fundamental forces (electromagnetic interactions), not by a bespoke “temperature force.” That does not stop the device from measuring temperature. Likewise, pendulums measure time although the restoring force is gravity, not some direct “tempus force.”

3. A simple mechanical case: the balance-spring watch  

Consider a balance wheel attached to a spiral spring. Once energized, the wheel oscillates at a frequency determined (within engineering tolerances) by its moment of inertia I and the spring constant κ. The differential equation θ̈ = −(κ/I) θ entails a period T = 2π √(I/κ). After n oscillations the watch’s gear train has advanced n steps, moving the hands accordingly. Reading the hand positions yields the value nT, that is, the elapsed time.

What caused the wheel gradually to reach orientation θ at moment t? Not time as such, but the local restoring torque κθ and the wheel’s own inertia. Nevertheless the mapping between gear-train state G and elapsed time t is rigid: had the watch been started one second later, G would have lagged by precisely one second. The device’s subsequent states are lawful functions of the initial state and the governing equation. If we adopt Fred Dretske’s indicator semantics, state G indicates duration d exactly because P(d|G) ≈ 1 across normal operating ranges. No extra “time force” is required.

4. Biological analogues: circadian and interval timing  

The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in mammals is a biochemical oscillator. Transcription-translation feedback loops involving the Period and Clock genes generate near-24-hour rhythms in protein concentration. Light exposure each morning entrains the oscillator, but once entrained the system free-runs: the rising and falling concentrations themselves drive cyclical downstream effects (body temperature, hormone release), and these molecular states constitute an internal clock. Again, temporal information is carried by endogenous dynamics. What affects the SCN at noon is not “noonness” but the concentration gradient produced by earlier transcription events.

Interval timing on the scale of seconds to minutes exhibits a similar architecture. Neural models such as the Striatal Beat-Frequency account posit that cortical neurons with slightly different oscillatory frequencies create a transient coincidence pattern at characteristic intervals. The pacemaker neurons are not hit repeatedly by a “ten-second force.” Instead, their phase relations unfold predictably. When the striatum detects a particular phase vector, it can treat that vector as a token of a ten-second interval. Behavioral evidence—peak-interval procedures, temporal bisection tasks—confirms that animals possess such internal chronometers.

5. Objection: covariance without causation is epistemically inert  

A critic might insist that lawful covariance is not enough. If a barometer happens to match stock-market fluctuations, the match is accidental and not a ground for representation. The defender of time-sensing must explain why clock-state/time covariance is non-accidental.

The standard move is to invoke etiology or function. A trait represents what it was selected—or constructed—to indicate. Watches are engineered to couple hand angle with elapsed seconds because that mapping satisfies designers’ purposes. Neural clocks are shaped by evolutionary pressures favoring organisms that anticipate regular environmental cycles. In Ruth Millikan’s teleosemantics, a state’s proper function is what past reliance on that state secured. Because organisms that used SCN phase to regulate feeding and sleep out-reproduced those that did not, the phase comes to function as a representation of time of day. The covariance is not incidental; it is the very reason the system exists.

6. Objection: representation requires causal intake of new information  

Another line of attack: A system that only evolves from its initial conditions cannot respond to unexpected changes. A wound watch removed from its owner continues to tick, but its states no longer tell her what time it is relative to Earth’s rotation; without periodic re-synchronization, drift sets in. So perhaps clocks do not really sense time; they merely simulate it until recalibrated.

But the need for calibration plagues every sensory modality. Retinas bleach, cochlear hairs fatigue, thermoreceptors adapt. Maintenance inputs are routine; they do not undermine the claim that vision, audition, and thermoreception are senses. What matters is that, between calibrations, the system is under the control of the environmental magnitude in question in virtue of a reliable information-channel. For clocks, that control is mediated through physical law plus initial synchronization (sunlight entrainment for circadian clocks, NTP packets for your laptop). Thus, even when no new photons specially marked “time” arrive, the system continues to carry information about time, just as a retina carries information about color during a fixation despite no fresh photons arriving from the peripheral scene.

7. A deeper moral: time as structural cause  

Why are we tempted to demand a dedicated time-force? Because we tacitly privilege “event-to-event contact” causation. Yet much of physics teaches a more structural notion: to explain why a double pendulum traces a Lissajous curve we appeal to constraint equations, not forces from geometry. Time is the parameter in the differential equations governing every dynamical system. When a system’s state at t1 causes its state at t2, time is a structural, not token, cause—what Nancy Cartwright calls a nomological machine. The dependence of later on earlier states is intelligible only by reference to temporal metrics. Clocks exploit that dependence: they are physical implementations whose deterministic or stochastic evolution is monotonic with elapsed time. So if one grants that structural causes supply legitimate information channels, the prima facie causal impotence of time is no bar to temporal representation.

8. Bringing it back to sensing  

Does this show that we literally have a “sense of time”? Two caveats:

A. There is unlikely to be a single dedicated receptor organ; rather, multiple specialized timing subsystems function at different scales (microsecond auditory localization, millisecond motor control, seconds-to-minutes interval timing, circadian and circalunar rhythms). Vision, too, fractures into rods, cones, motion detectors, and parvocellular or magnocellular streams. Unity of modality need not mean unitary receptor.

B. Temporal phenomenology involves integrative processing that combines outputs from many internal clocks with exteroceptive content. Still, the objection under discussion was metaphysical, not phenomenological: could any sensor provide genuinely temporal information? The foregoing shows that biological and artefactual clocks do exactly that.

9. Answering the guiding question explicitly  

How can a clock carry information about time without time itself causally influencing it? Because:

1. The clock’s mechanism instantiates a dynamical law whose independent variable is time.  
2. Given an initial condition (start signal, winding, photon pulse), the system’s later states are law-bound functions of elapsed time.  
3. Therefore, a mapping f: state → duration exists such that, for all normal operating conditions, reading state s yields the true duration t = f(s).  
4. Information-theoretically (in Shannon’s sense), mutual information I(S;T) is high.  
5. Teleologically, the mechanism was built or selected precisely to exploit that mapping, elevating the covariance from brute fact to representational function.

Consequently, temporal information flows through causal intermediaries (oscillations, chemical reactions, decay processes) rather than through a proprietary “time particle.” The objection trades on a caricature of causation and of sensory representation; once those caricatures are set aside, the path is clear for a perfectly naturalized sense of time.

10. Epilogue: lessons for philosophy of perception  

The debate echoes earlier worries about color. Light of 700 nm does not itself “cause red”; it merely excites L-cones. Color is a relational construct built on stable correlations. Temporal sensing extends the same lesson: what matters in perception is not being pushed around by color, temperature, or time itself, but being appropriately embedded in causal-nomological patterns that license reliable inference. The retina that can be fooled by colored filters and the clock that can be fooled by relativistic time dilation are nevertheless genuine sensors by any scientifically respectable standard. To demand more is to fetishize a naïve model of causal contact that the rest of perceptual science has long since outgrown.

How to Sense What Does Not Push Back:
        A Relational–Mechanistic Reply to the “Causal Impotence” Objection

1. Introduction and Thesis  

One of the most persistent intuitions in the philosophy of perception is that sensing is a matter of being *struck* by the world. Photons impinge on the retina; pressure waves buffet the cochlea; odorant molecules latch onto receptors. On this model, a feature must “push” on the sensory organ if that organ is to carry information about it. Time, however, appears to do no pushing. If causal efficacy is a criterion for being sensed, then—so the objection goes—there can be no genuine sense of time, either in animals or in clocks.  

I will argue that the objection trades on an equivocation about what it takes for a physical system to *carry information* about an environmental magnitude. While it is true that nothing like a “time particle” bombards clockwork or neural tissue, systems can nevertheless come to *lawfully covary* with temporal structure. What matters for sensing is nomic (law-governed) dependence, not direct causal impact by a sui generis temporal entity.  

The core of my proposal is a *relational–mechanistic account*.  (1) Relational: time is not an independent causal ingredient but an ordering relation among events; representation of time is therefore grounded in relations that hold *between* internal states, not in an extra influx of time-stuff.  (2) Mechanistic: clocks—biological and artificial—are built around self-propagating processes whose successive states stand in precisely specifiable temporal ratios. Those internal transitions, when suitably calibrated and coupled to acting or believing subsystems, constitute sensing time.  

Hence: a mechanism M can carry information about duration D not because “time causes state S of M,” but because (i) there is a stable, counterfactual-supporting mapping from determinate durations to determinate states of M, and (ii) the mapping exists in virtue of physical laws governing M’s own dynamics plus an initial calibration interface with the world. Once we free ourselves from a push-model of perception, both ordinary clocks and neural timing circuits emerge as paradigms of genuine sensory systems for time.

The remainder of the essay develops this reply. Section 2 diagnoses the mistake in the causal-impotence objection. Section 3 builds an informational framework that does not require time to be a causal agent. Section 4 illustrates the framework with thermometers, pendulums, and quartz oscillators. Section 5 extends the account to biological timing, showing how humans and other animals literally “sense” time. Section 6 answers three residual objections, and Section 7 concludes with broader implications for perception theory.

2. Two Ways to Mis-Describe Time  

A. Treating Time as an Entity.  
The objection presupposes that if time were to be sensed, it would have to stand to the clock as light stands to the eye. But light is a *substance* (photon flux) while time is a *scale of relation*: the systematic pattern in which events succeed one another. Reifying that relational structure into a causal agent is already a category error. Because relations are instantiated *by* the very events they order, they need no additional push.  

B. Conflating ‘Causally Absorbing’ with ‘Informationally Dependent’.  
Even granting the relational nature of time, one might insist that some *cause* must enter the clock from outside if the clock is to be informative. Yet a system can be informative about X provided its states covary with X in a way underwritten by physical law, even if X does not itself impress a dedicated signal upon it. To separate the two notions, consider a hanging calendar. Nothing about Tuesday “hits” the paper, yet tearing off one page per day yields true information about what day it is. Dependence, not impact, does the explanatory work.

3. Information without Impact: A Nomic-Covariance Model  

Let us adopt Fred Dretske’s (1981) information-theoretic slogan: a state S of system M carries the information that P when, given background laws L, the probability of P conditional on S is 1. Crucially, the *channel* identified by L can be constituted by M’s own dynamics plus initial and boundary conditions. No special particle has to travel the channel.  

Formally:

Law-Channel Principle  
M encodes magnitude µ if and only if  
(LC) For each determinate value v of µ there exists a determinate state s of M such that, under the laws L and given normal operating conditions C, µ = v ⇒ M is in s, and  
(ST) The mapping v ↦ s is stable across counterfactual interventions short of breakdown.

When the magnitude µ is a *temporal interval*, the mapping is realized by internal processes whose period or cumulative change is law-fixed. The laws supply the glue; the world need not supply additional causal inputs at each tick.

4. Mechanical Case Studies  

4.1 The Mercury Thermometer  
Temperature, like time, is often said to be dispositional: it is the mean kinetic energy of micro-particles, not a substance. Yet a rise in ambient temperature correlates with expansion of mercury because of the coefficient of thermal expansion and the rigidity of glass. Here the thermometer tracks temperature through *structural coupling*, not because “temperature rays” strike it. Debunking the objection for time is easier once we recognize that we unproblematically treat a thermometer as a sensor.

4.2 The Pendulum Clock  
The period of a simple pendulum is 2π√(l/g). After an initial displacement, gravity and inertia guarantee oscillations of near-constant duration, independent of amplitude to first order. The mechanism is *self-propagating*: no further environmental cause besides sustaining potential energy via the escapement is required. Each beat lawfully marks ≈ 1 s, furnishing a reliable v ↦ s mapping.

4.3 The Quartz Wristwatch  
A quartz crystal driven by an electric field vibrates at 32 768 Hz because quantum-mechanical lattice properties fix its piezoelectric resonance. Electronic dividers count transitions, yielding a one-second pulse. Time is sensed here via the *intrinsic rhythmicity* of matter under stable conditions.

In all three devices, causal input happens mainly at manufacture and sporadic calibration. During ordinary operation, what makes a given state informative about elapsed time is the lawful regularity of internal transitions.

5. Biological Timing: Endogenous Clocks as Sensory Systems  

5.1 Circadian Oscillators  
The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) in mammals sustains a near-24-hour transcription-translation feedback loop. Light serves as a *Zeitgeber* that entrains the phase but does not drive each hourly tick. Once entrained, the SCN’s molecular states nomically covary with solar time, enabling downstream circuits to set sleep–wake cycles. That is structural covariance, not impact by a temporal force.

5.2 Interval Timing in the Seconds Range  
Striatal beat-frequency models posit multiple cortical oscillators with slightly different periods. The striatum detects their coincident phase pattern to estimate elapsed intervals. No external entity labeled “time” impinges on these oscillators; differential cell-intrinsic decay of activation suffices.

5.3 Millisecond Timing in the Cerebellum  
Purkinje cells integrate climbing-fiber input with parallel-fiber burst patterns whose synaptic weights encode experienced delays. Plasticity implements the mapping v ↦ s over millisecond windows critical for motor coordination. Again, the dependence is internal.

The point generalizes: whenever a biological system recruits predictable change—ion flux, gene expression, membrane potential decay—and *reads it as duration*, it literally senses time.

6. Replies to Residual Objections  

Objection 1: “Lawful covariance just pushes the bump down the rug; why does internal change track *objective* time rather than merely its own idiosyncratic metric?”  

Reply: Calibration ties internal processes to wider temporal structure. A quartz watch runs fast in a furnace; accordingly, it *misrepresents* time relative to standard seconds. Error is intelligible precisely because the mapping aims at an external magnitude. The same goes for jet-lagged circadian clocks. Objective time functions as the explanans of misrepresentation, confirming that the mechanism aims at it rather than at self-change per se.

Objection 2: “Relativity teaches that time is frame-dependent; so any putative time sense is hopelessly parochial.”  

Reply: Sensory modalities commonly track magnitudes in restricted regimes: human vision registers only 400–700 nm wavelengths; hearing spans roughly 20 Hz–20 kHz. Likewise, biological and artifact clocks track *proper time* along their world-lines. That local metric is perfectly objective within the relativistic manifold. Clocks disagree across frames, but so do color detectors under different illuminations. This is epistemic relativity, not conceptual defeat.

Objection 3: “Psychological distortions—time flies when you’re having fun—imply we do not really sense time.”  

Reply: Perception is always modulated by attention, arousal, and expectation. Speed-size illusions do not show that we fail to see motion. Distortions merely demonstrate that multiple timing mechanisms (oscillatory, accumulator, state-dependent) compete, and that higher-level priors can re-weight their outputs. That is further evidence for genuine sensory coding: malleability is characteristic of perceptual systems.

7. Conclusion: Diachronic Transduction as Sensing  

A good sensor performs *transduction*: it converts an environmental magnitude into an internal signal usable by the organism or device. In clocks, the conversion is *diachronic*: the mechanism leverages lawful evolution of its own states to mirror temporal intervals. The absence of a pushing “time particle” is no impediment, for transduction can be realized via internal regularity plus calibration.  

In vision, photons carry energy that excites photoreceptors; in audition, pressure waves mechano-depolarize hair cells. In chronoperception, the passage of time is written into patterns of neural activity by molecular and electrical processes whose unfolding constitutes the very relation to be sensed. Time is “felt” not as an external blow but as an internally regimented becoming. That is a difference of mechanism, not of epistemic status.

Therefore, the causal-impotence objection fails. The possibility of a sense of time—and of clocks that keep it—rests on a relational–mechanistic principle: if a system’s lawful self-change can be stably calibrated to durations, then the system *senses* time in everything the term legitimately connotes. Far from being an embarrassment, the absence of temporal impact underscores a philosophically important point: what matters for perception is lawful covariance, not the mode of causal delivery. Recognizing this frees us to study temporal sensing with the same conceptual tools we apply to every other modality and dissolves an old puzzle born of a misdescribed metaphysics of time.
